She asked Darcy about his travels, and he responded with a detailed account of his recent journey to Derbyshire, mentioning the beautiful scenery and the charming estate of Pemberley. Elizabeth listened intently, intrigued by his descriptions and the evident pride he took in his home. As the evening drew to a close, Elizabeth felt a mixture of curiosity and hope. She wondered whether this man, who had seemed so distant at first, might yet prove to be a kindred spirit. Darcy, for his part, appeared to be contemplating her words with a rare softness, and Elizabeth could not help but wonder what the future might hold for them.

events.title: Quiet Evening and Observed Interactions
detailed_summary: The day progresses uneventfully, with Jane Bennet's health showing slow improvement.
In the evening, the drawing-room atmosphere is different; the usual card table (loo) is absent.
Mr. Darcy is engrossed in writing a letter.
Miss Bingley positions herself close to Darcy, frequently interrupting his writing with comments directed towards him or meant for his sister.
Mr. Hurst and Mr. Bingley engage in a game of piquet, with Mrs. Hurst watching them.
Elizabeth occupies herself with needlework while keenly observing the interaction between Darcy and Miss Bingley.
She finds amusement in Miss Bingley's constant stream of compliments about Darcy's handwriting, the neatness of his lines, or the impressive length of his letter.
Elizabeth simultaneously notes Darcy's complete lack of reaction to this flattery, which aligns perfectly with her assessment of both their characters.

Miss Bingley makes several specific, unsuccessful attempts to engage Darcy: praising his writing speed (which he corrects as slow), lamenting the supposed burden of business correspondence, offering to mend his pen (which he declines, stating he always does it himself), asking how he achieves such even writing (to which he remains silent), and relaying effusive compliments about Miss Darcy's musical and artistic accomplishments.
Darcy politely sidesteps conveying Miss Bingley's exaggerated praise immediately, claiming insufficient space in his current letter.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The day passed much as the day before had done.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Will you give me leave to defer your raptures till I write again? At present I have not room to do them justice.”

events.text_segment:
The day passed much as the day before had done. Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley had spent some hours of the morning with the invalid, who continued, though slowly, to mend; and, in the evening, Elizabeth joined their party in the drawing-room. The loo table, however, did not appear. Mr. Darcy was writing, and Miss Bingley, seated near him, was watching the progress of his letter, and repeatedly calling off his attention by messages to his sister. Mr. Hurst and Mr. Bingley were at piquet, and Mrs. Hurst was observing their game.
Elizabeth took up some needlework, and was sufficiently amused in attending to what passed between Darcy and his companion. The perpetual commendations of the lady either on his hand-writing, or on the evenness of his lines, or on the length of his letter, with the perfect unconcern with which her praises were received, formed a curious dialogue, and was exactly in unison with her opinion of each.
“How delighted Miss Darcy will be to receive such a letter!”
He made no answer.
“You write uncommonly fast.”
“You are mistaken. I write rather slowly.”
“How many letters you must have occasion to write in the course of a year! Letters of business, too! How odious I should think them!”
“It is fortunate, then, that they fall to my lot instead of to yours.”
“Pray tell your sister that I long to see her.”
“I have already told her so once, by your desire.”
“I am afraid you do not like your pen. Let me mend it for you. I mend pens remarkably well.”
“Thank you—but I always mend my own.”
“How can you contrive to write so even?”
He was silent.
“Tell your sister I am delighted to hear of her improvement on the harp, and pray let her know that I am quite in raptures with her beautiful little design for a table, and I think it infinitely superior to Miss Grantley’s.”
“Will you give me leave to defer your raptures till I write again? At present I have not room to do them justice.”

events.title: Debate on Character and Disposition
detailed_summary: Miss Bingley continues her flattery, remarking on the charm of Darcy's long letters, leading Mr. Bingley to tease Darcy about writing laboriously.
Darcy distinguishes his writing style from Bingley's more spontaneous approach.
Miss Bingley criticizes her brother Charles's writing as extremely careless, full of omissions and blots.
Bingley justifies his style by claiming his thoughts move too quickly to be properly captured, sometimes resulting in incomprehensible letters.
Elizabeth comments that Bingley's professed humility effectively neutralizes any criticism.
Darcy offers a general observation that humility can be deceptive, sometimes masking carelessness or serving as an indirect form of boasting.
When Bingley asks Darcy to categorize his recent 'modesty', Darcy identifies it as an 'indirect boast'.

Darcy elaborates, suggesting Bingley is actually proud of his writing flaws because he views them as signs of rapid thought and quick execution, qualities he finds interesting, if not inherently valuable.
Darcy cites Bingley's earlier assertion about being able to leave Netherfield instantly as another example of self-praise for a 'precipitance' that is ultimately impractical.
Bingley protests mildly about Darcy remembering trivial morning conversations but insists he genuinely believed his claim about leaving quickly.
Darcy refutes this, stating Bingley's actions are highly susceptible to chance and friendly persuasion, predicting he could easily be convinced by a friend to delay his departure indefinitely.

Elizabeth intervenes, reframing Darcy's critique: she suggests Darcy has inadvertently highlighted Bingley's agreeable and easily influenced nature, presenting him more favorably than Bingley did himself.
Bingley expresses gratitude for Elizabeth's positive spin but suspects Darcy intended no compliment, believing Darcy values decisiveness over agreeableness.
Elizabeth probes whether Darcy would find stubborn adherence to a flawed plan more commendable.
Bingley evades the question, insisting Darcy should articulate his own views.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Oh, it is of no consequence.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Upon my word, I cannot exactly explain the matter—Darcy must speak for himself.”

events.text_segment:
“Oh, it is of no consequence. I shall see her in January. But do you always write such charming long letters to her, Mr. Darcy?”
“They are generally long; but whether always charming, it is not for me to determine.”
“It is a rule with me, that a person who can write a long letter with ease cannot write ill.”
“That will not do for a compliment to Darcy, Caroline,” cried her brother, “because he does not write with ease. He studies too much for words of four syllables. Do not you, Darcy?”
“My style of writing is very different from yours.”
“Oh,” cried Miss Bingley, “Charles writes in the most careless way imaginable. He leaves out half his words, and blots the rest.”
“My ideas flow so rapidly that I have not time to express them; by which means my letters sometimes convey no ideas at all to my correspondents.”
“Your humility, Mr. Bingley,” said Elizabeth, “must disarm reproof.”
“Nothing is more deceitful,” said Darcy, “than the appearance of humility. It is often only carelessness of opinion, and sometimes an indirect boast.”
“And which of the two do you call my little recent piece of modesty?”
“The indirect boast; for you are really proud of your defects in writing, because you consider them as proceeding from a rapidity of thought and carelessness of execution, which, if not estimable, you think at least highly interesting. The power of doing anything with quickness is always much prized by the possessor, and often without any attention to the imperfection of the performance. When you told Mrs. Bennet this morning, that if you ever resolved on quitting Netherfield you should be gone in five minutes, you meant it to be a sort of panegyric, of compliment to yourself; and yet what is there so very laudable in a precipitance which must leave very necessary business undone, and can be of no real advantage to yourself or anyone else?”
“Nay,” cried Bingley, “this is too much, to remember at night all the foolish things that were said in the morning. And yet, upon my honour, I believed what I said of myself to be true, and I believe it at this moment. At least, therefore, I did not assume the character of needless precipitance merely to show off before the ladies.”
“I daresay you believed it; but I am by no means convinced that you would be gone with such celerity. Your conduct would be quite as dependent on chance as that of any man I know; and if, as you were mounting your horse, a friend were to say, ‘Bingley, you had better stay till next week,’ you would probably do it—you would probably not go—and, at another word, might stay a month.”
“You have only proved by this,” cried Elizabeth, “that Mr. Bingley did not do justice to his own disposition. You have shown him off now much more than he did himself.”
“I am exceedingly gratified,” said Bingley, “by your converting what my friend says into a compliment on the sweetness of my temper. But I am afraid you are giving it a turn which that gentleman did by no means intend; for he would certainly think the better of me if, under such a circumstance, I were to give a flat denial, and ride off as fast as I could.”
“Would Mr. Darcy then consider the rashness of your original intention as atoned for by your obstinacy in adhering to it?”
“Upon my word, I cannot exactly explain the matter—Darcy must speak for himself.”

Bingley justified his style by claiming his thoughts move too quickly to be properly captured, sometimes resulting in incomprehensible letters. LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Oh, it is of no consequence. I am quite accustomed to such remarks, and I dare say I have heard worse. But I must confess, I find it rather tiresome to be constantly scrutinized and judged by those around me. It is as if my every word and action are under a microscope, and I am expected to behave in a manner that pleases everyone but myself. However, I have learned to maintain my composure and to accept the opinions of others with a gracious smile, even when I do not agree with them.

Mr. Darcy, who had been listening quietly, now looked at Elizabeth with a mixture of admiration and concern. He appreciated her resilience and her ability to speak her mind, even in the face of criticism. Yet, he also wondered if she was truly happy, or if she merely pretended to be so for the sake of politeness.

Elizabeth, noticing his gaze, turned to him with a gentle smile. "Mr. Darcy, I hope you do not think me impertinent for speaking so frankly. It is simply my nature to be honest, and I find that honesty often leads to better understanding than pretense and concealment."

He nodded, a slight blush on his cheeks. "Miss Bennet, I admire your candor. It is a rare quality, especially among women of your station. I must admit, I have been somewhat prejudiced against you, based on first impressions and the opinions of others. But I see now that I was mistaken, and I am glad to have the opportunity to know you better."

Elizabeth felt her cheeks warm at his words. She had always been wary of Mr. Darcy's pride and aloofness, but she could see beneath his exterior a kind and thoughtful man. Perhaps, she thought, there was more to him than her initial judgments had suggested.

As they continued their conversation, the others at the assembly began to take notice of their interaction. Lady Catherine de Bourgh, who was nearby, cast a disapproving glance in their direction. She disapproved of Elizabeth's independence and her refusal to conform to societal expectations.

Meanwhile, Mr. Collins, who was eager to impress Lady Catherine, approached with a pompous air. "Miss Bennet, I must say, your wit and intelligence are quite remarkable. I am sure that any gentleman would be fortunate to have your acquaintance."

Elizabeth, with a polite smile, responded, "Thank you, Mr. Collins. I am flattered by your kind words, but I believe that true worth lies in character and virtue, rather than in superficial qualities."

Mr. Collins looked somewhat taken aback by her directness, but he quickly recovered and began to prattle on about his own pursuits and his admiration for Lady Catherine. Elizabeth excused herself, feeling a sense of relief to escape the awkward conversation.

Later that evening, as she sat in the garden, Elizabeth reflected on the events of the day. She thought about Mr. Darcy and the possibility of a future where they might understand each other better. She also considered her own feelings and the importance of remaining true to herself, regardless of societal expectations.

In the quiet of the night, she resolved to continue being honest and sincere, hoping that her integrity would eventually lead her to happiness. She knew that the road ahead might be difficult, but she was determined to face it with courage and dignity.

As dawn approached, Elizabeth felt a renewed sense of hope. She was aware that love and understanding required patience and perseverance, but she was willing to wait and work for what truly mattered. With that thought, she prepared to meet the new day, eager to see what it would bring.

events.title: Discussion on Friendship, Influence, and Argument Avoidance
detailed_summary: Darcy first clarifies that the opinions regarding Bingley's quick departure were attributed to him, not stated by him.
Addressing Elizabeth's point about yielding to friends, Darcy notes that in the hypothetical scenario, the friend offered no justification for the request.
Elizabeth challenges Darcy's apparent skepticism about readily complying with a friend's wishes out of persuasion.
Darcy maintains that yielding without genuine conviction shows disrespect for the judgment of both parties involved.

Elizabeth accuses Darcy of failing to appreciate the significance of friendship and personal affection, arguing that regard for the person making a request is often sufficient reason to comply in unimportant matters, without needing logical persuasion.
Darcy proposes that further discussion requires clarifying the request's importance and the relationship's intimacy.
Bingley injects humor, suggesting they factor in Darcy's imposing height as a reason for his own deference, particularly on quiet Sunday evenings at Darcy's home.
Darcy offers a slight smile, but Elizabeth perceives underlying offense and restrains her amusement.
Miss Bingley jumps to Darcy's defense, rebuking her brother for his inappropriate teasing.
Darcy correctly interprets Bingley's humor as an attempt to end the ongoing argument, which Bingley dislikes.
Bingley admits his aversion to arguments, equating them with disputes, and requests Elizabeth and Darcy postpone their debate until he is absent.
Elizabeth readily agrees, assuring him it requires no sacrifice from her, and advises Mr. Darcy to return to his letter.

events.text_segment:
“You expect me to account for opinions which you choose to call mine, but which I have never acknowledged. Allowing the case, however, to stand according to your representation, you must remember, Miss Bennet, that the friend who is supposed to desire his return to the house, and the delay of his plan, has merely desired it, asked it without offering one argument in favour of its propriety.”
“To yield readily—easily—to the persuasion of a friend is no merit with you.”
“To yield without conviction is no compliment to the understanding of either.”
“You appear to me, Mr. Darcy, to allow nothing for the influence of friendship and affection. A regard for the requester would often make one readily yield to a request, without waiting for arguments to reason one into it. I am not particularly speaking of such a case as you have supposed about Mr. Bingley. We may as well wait, perhaps, till the circumstance occurs, before we discuss the discretion of his behaviour thereupon. But in general and ordinary cases, between friend and friend, where one of them is desired by the other to change a resolution of no very great moment, should you think ill of that person for complying with the desire, without waiting to be argued into it?”
“Will it not be advisable, before we proceed on this subject, to arrange with rather more precision the degree of importance which is to appertain to this request, as well as the degree of intimacy subsisting between the parties?”
“By all means,” cried Bingley; “let us hear all the particulars, not forgetting their comparative height and size, for that will have more weight in the argument, Miss Bennet, than you may be aware of. I assure you that if Darcy were not such a great tall fellow, in comparison with myself, I should not pay him half so much deference. I declare I do not know a more awful object than Darcy on particular occasions, and in particular places; at his own house especially, and of a Sunday evening, when he has nothing to do.”
Mr. Darcy smiled; but Elizabeth thought she could perceive that he was rather offended, and therefore checked her laugh. Miss Bingley warmly resented the indignity he had received, in an expostulation with her brother for talking such nonsense.
“I see your design, Bingley,” said his friend. “You dislike an argument, and want to silence this.”
“Perhaps I do. Arguments are too much like disputes. If you and Miss Bennet will defer yours till I am out of the room, I shall be very thankful; and then you may say whatever you like of me.”
“What you ask,” said Elizabeth, “is no sacrifice on my side; and Mr. Darcy had much better finish his letter.”

If my sentiments differ from yours, I beg you to respect my right to hold them, just as I respect your right to hold yours. It is not my wish to cause any discord or to offend your sensibilities, but I cannot, in good conscience, pretend to feel differently than I do. I hope that in time, you will come to see that my motives are honorable, and that my intentions are sincere. I do not wish to be misunderstood or misrepresented, and I trust that you will give me credit for honesty and integrity. I am confident that, with patience and good will, we can overcome any misunderstandings and preserve the good opinion we have of each other. events.title: Music, Mutual Observation, and Speculation
detailed_summary: Following Elizabeth's suggestion, Mr. Darcy completes his letter.
He then requests some musical entertainment from Miss Bingley and Elizabeth.
Miss Bingley promptly moves to the pianoforte, after making a polite but ultimately rejected suggestion that Elizabeth play first.
Mrs. Hurst joins her sister to sing.
While occupied near the instrument, ostensibly looking through music books, Elizabeth notices Mr. Darcy directing his gaze towards her frequently.
She struggles to comprehend the reason for his attention, doubting she could genuinely be an object of admiration for such a distinguished man.
The possibility that he looks at her out of dislike strikes her as even more peculiar.

Ultimately, she rationalizes his attention by concluding that he must perceive something particularly incorrect or objectionable in her conduct or appearance compared to others in the room, based on his own strict standards.
This supposition does not cause her distress, as her own low opinion of him means she is indifferent to his approval or disapproval.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mr. Darcy took her advice, and did finish his letter.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She liked him too little to care for his approbation.

events.text_segment:
Mr. Darcy took her advice, and did finish his letter.
When that business was over, he applied to Miss Bingley and Elizabeth for the indulgence of some music. Miss Bingley moved with alacrity to the pianoforte, and after a polite request that Elizabeth would lead the way, which the other as politely and more earnestly negatived, she seated herself.
Mrs. Hurst sang with her sister; and while they were thus employed, Elizabeth could not help observing, as she turned over some music-books that lay on the instrument, how frequently Mr. Darcy’s eyes were fixed on her. She hardly knew how to suppose that she could be an object of admiration to so great a man, and yet that he should look at her because he disliked her was still more strange. She could only imagine, however, at last, that she drew his notice because there was something about her more wrong and reprehensible, according to his ideas of right, than in any other person present. The supposition did not pain her. She liked him too little to care for his approbation.

Elizabeth declined politely, and Mrs. Hurst, eager to contribute, joined her sister in singing. As Elizabeth stood near the instrument, she noticed Mr. Darcy casting frequent glances in her direction. She found herself puzzled by his attention, unable to understand why such a distinguished man would look at her so intently. She wondered if perhaps he looked at her with dislike, which seemed even more strange. She then reasoned that he might be observing something about her—her conduct or appearance—that he found objectionable, given his own high standards. Yet, this thought did not trouble her; her opinion of him was low enough that she was indifferent to his approval or disapproval.

events.title: A Challenging Exchange and Unexpected Gallantry
detailed_summary: Miss Bingley transitions from Italian songs to a spirited Scottish tune.
Shortly after, Mr. Darcy approaches Elizabeth.
He directly asks her if the lively music inspires her to dance a reel.
Elizabeth responds with only a smile initially, causing Darcy some surprise at her silence when he repeats the question.
She then explains her pause, stating she understood him but needed time to formulate her reply.
Elizabeth playfully accuses him of intending to provoke a 'yes' answer merely to hold her taste in contempt.
She declares her deliberate choice to foil this assumed 'scheme' by stating plainly that she has no desire to dance a reel.
She concludes with the defiant challenge: 'now despise me if you dare.'
To her surprise, Darcy responds with unexpected charm, stating, 'Indeed I do not dare.'
Elizabeth, having aimed to offend or provoke him, is astonished by his gallant reply.
Her own manner, blending sweetness with playful impertinence, inherently makes it difficult for her to truly offend.
Darcy finds himself more enchanted by her than by any woman he has ever known.
He internally reflects that her inferior social standing is the primary factor preventing him from being in serious 'danger' of developing deeper feelings.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: After playing some Italian songs, Miss Bingley varied the charm by a lively Scotch air; and soon afterwards Mr. Darcy, drawing near Elizabeth, said to her,—
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He really believed that, were it not for the inferiority of her connections, he should be in some danger.

events.text_segment:
After playing some Italian songs, Miss Bingley varied the charm by a lively Scotch air; and soon afterwards Mr. Darcy, drawing near Elizabeth, said to her,—
“Do you not feel a great inclination, Miss Bennet, to seize such an opportunity of dancing a reel?”
She smiled, but made no answer. He repeated the question, with some surprise at her silence.
“Oh,” said she, “I heard you before; but I could not immediately determine what to say in reply. You wanted me, I know, to say ‘Yes,’ that you might have the pleasure of despising my taste; but I always delight in overthrowing those kind of schemes, and cheating a person of their premeditated contempt. I have, therefore, made up my mind to tell you that I do not want to dance a reel at all; and now despise me if you dare.”
“Indeed I do not dare.”
Elizabeth, having rather expected to affront him, was amazed at his gallantry; but there was a mixture of sweetness and archness in her manner which made it difficult for her to affront anybody, and Darcy had never been so bewitched by any woman as he was by her. He really believed that, were it not for the inferiority of her connections, he should be in some danger.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
After playing some Italian songs, Miss Bingley varied the charm by a lively Scotch air; and soon afterwards Mr. Darcy, drawing near Elizabeth, said to her,—

"Do you not think that the music might tempt you to dance?" 

Elizabeth only smiled in reply, which seemed to surprise Darcy, who repeated his question. 

"I am not a great dancer," she answered, "and I do not wish to dance."

"Come, come," said he, "you cannot refuse to dance with me."

"I am not at liberty," she replied, "to give you an answer now."

"You are considering whether you should accept my invitation or not," he observed.

"I am thinking it over," she said, "and I am not sure that I shall." 

"Well," said he, "if you do not accept my invitation, I shall be very much disappointed."

"I am sorry," she replied, "but I cannot help it."

"You are very kind," he said, "but I must insist."

"Then I must decline," she answered, with a smile.

He looked at her with a mixture of admiration and amusement. 

"You are very clever," he said, "and I am very much in love with you."

"Indeed I do not dare," she replied, with a playful laugh.

"You are very kind," he said, "but I am afraid I shall have to try again."

"Now despise me if you dare," she challenged.

"Indeed I do not dare," he replied, with a charming smile.

Elizabeth was surprised by his gallantry, and her own manner, which was a mixture of sweetness and playful impertinence, made it difficult for her to offend him. 

Darcy, in turn, found himself more enchanted by her than by any woman he had ever known, and he thought to himself that her social standing was the only thing preventing him from being in serious danger of falling in love.

Darcy, in turn, found himself more enchanted by her than by any woman he had ever known, and he thought to himself that her social standing was the only thing preventing him from being in serious danger of falling in love.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Miss Elizabeth Bennet, I find that you are fond of music. It is a pursuit which I believe many of us find agreeable, especially when it is performed with such spirit and taste as yours. I must confess, I have often thought that a good song can speak to the heart more eloquently than words. Do you not agree? I am quite eager to hear your opinion on the matter, for I have observed that you possess a genuine appreciation for the arts. Your taste is remarkably refined, and I dare say, quite superior to many others I have known. It is a pleasure to see someone so engaged and enthusiastic about music, which is, after all, a universal language that can unite us all in harmony. I hope you will continue to indulge in your musical pursuits, for they bring joy not only to yourself but also to those fortunate enough to listen. Your talent is truly admirable, and I look forward to hearing more from you in the future.

events.title: Jealous Actions and a Graceful Escape
detailed_summary: Miss Bingley notices or suspects Darcy's growing interest in Elizabeth, which fuels her jealousy and strengthens her desire for Elizabeth to leave Netherfield, complementing her professed concern for Jane's recovery.
She actively attempts to prejudice Darcy against Elizabeth by making pointed remarks about a potential marriage between them.

During a walk with Darcy the following day, Miss Bingley offers sarcastic 'advice' for his hypothetical future marriage to Elizabeth, suggesting he should silence Mrs. Bennet, reform the younger Bennet sisters' behaviour towards officers, and correct Elizabeth's own supposed conceit and impertinence.
Darcy responds with dry irony, inquiring if she has any further suggestions for his domestic bliss.

Miss Bingley continues her mockery, proposing he hang portraits of Elizabeth's middle-class relations, the Philipses, in Pemberley's esteemed gallery next to his judicial ancestor, and ironically commenting on the impossibility of capturing Elizabeth's beautiful eyes in a portrait.
Darcy concedes the difficulty of capturing their expression but notes their physical features could be painted.
Their conversation is interrupted by the arrival of Mrs. Hurst and Elizabeth.
Miss Bingley appears flustered, worried they might have been overheard.
Mrs. Hurst reproaches them for leaving without notice and then deliberately takes Darcy's available arm, forcing Elizabeth to walk alone as the path accommodates only three people.
Mr. Darcy immediately recognizes the incivility of the situation and suggests they move to the broader avenue.
Elizabeth, however, has no desire to continue walking with them and laughingly declines, praising their current 'charming' grouping and stating a fourth person would spoil the 'picturesque' effect.
She then cheerfully departs, walking off alone and feeling glad at the prospect of returning home within a day or two.
Her spirits are further lifted by the news that Jane is recovering well enough to plan on leaving her sickroom for a short time that evening.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Miss Bingley saw, or suspected, enough to be jealous; and her great anxiety for the recovery of her dear friend Jane received some assistance from her desire of getting rid of Elizabeth.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Jane was already so much recovered as to intend leaving her room for a couple of hours that evening.

events.text_segment:
Miss Bingley saw, or suspected, enough to be jealous; and her great anxiety for the recovery of her dear friend Jane received some assistance from her desire of getting rid of Elizabeth.
She often tried to provoke Darcy into disliking her guest, by talking of their supposed marriage, and planning his happiness in such an alliance.
“I hope,” said she, as they were walking together in the shrubbery the next day, “you will give your mother-in-law a few hints, when this desirable event takes place, as to the advantage of holding her tongue; and if you can compass it, to cure the younger girls of running after the officers. And, if I may mention so delicate a subject, endeavour to check that little something, bordering on conceit and impertinence, which your lady possesses.”
“Have you anything else to propose for my domestic felicity?”
“Oh yes. Do let the portraits of your uncle and aunt Philips be placed in the gallery at Pemberley. Put them next to your great-uncle the judge. They are in the same profession, you know, only in different lines. As for your Elizabeth’s picture, you must not attempt to have it taken, for what painter could do justice to those beautiful eyes?”
“It would not be easy, indeed, to catch their expression; but their colour and shape, and the eyelashes, so remarkably fine, might be copied.”
At that moment they were met from another walk by Mrs. Hurst and Elizabeth herself.
“I did not know that you intended to walk,” said Miss Bingley, in some confusion, lest they had been overheard.
“You used us abominably ill,” answered Mrs. Hurst, “running away without telling us that you were coming out.”
Then taking the disengaged arm of Mr. Darcy, she left Elizabeth to walk by herself. The path just admitted three. Mr. Darcy felt their rudeness, and immediately said,—
“This walk is not wide enough for our party. We had better go into the avenue.”
But Elizabeth, who had not the least inclination to remain with them, laughingly answered,—
“No, no; stay where you are. You are charmingly grouped, and appear to uncommon advantage. The picturesque would be spoilt by admitting a fourth. Good-bye.”
She then ran gaily off, rejoicing, as she rambled about, in the hope of being at home again in a day or two. Jane was already so much recovered as to intend leaving her room for a couple of hours that evening.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
Miss Bingley saw, or suspected, enough to be jealous; and her great anxiety for the recovery of her dear friend Jane received some assistance from her desire of getting rid of Elizabeth. She was very anxious to get her gone, and was pleased to find that her brother's admiration of her was not so easily secured as he had supposed. She was determined to get her out of the way as soon as possible, and she was not a little gratified by the idea that she might be the means of doing so.

The next day, as they walked in the shrubbery, Miss Bingley, with her usual air of affected indifference, began to make pointed remarks about Elizabeth. She observed that a woman must have a thorough command of her temper to keep her countenance in such a situation, and hinted that Elizabeth's pride and impertinence might be her downfall.

Mr. Darcy, walking beside her, listened with dry irony. 'Have you any further suggestions for my domestic bliss?' he inquired.

Miss Bingley, with a slight smile, proposed that he hang portraits of the Philipses, Elizabeth's middle-class relations, in Pemberley's gallery, next to his ancestor, and sarcastically remarked on the impossibility of capturing Elizabeth's beautiful eyes in a portrait.

Their conversation was interrupted by the arrival of Mrs. Hurst and Elizabeth. Miss Bingley, appearing flustered, looked as if she feared they had been overheard. Mrs. Hurst reproached them for leaving without notice and then, deliberately taking Darcy's arm, forced Elizabeth to walk alone, as the path only accommodated three.

Darcy immediately recognized the incivility and suggested they move to the broader avenue. Elizabeth, however, with a laugh, declined, praising their charming grouping and saying that a fourth person would spoil the picturesque effect. She then cheerfully departed, walking off alone, feeling glad to be returning home soon.

Her spirits were further lifted by the news that Jane was recovering well enough to leave her sickroom that evening for a short time.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Miss Bingley saw, or suspected, enough to be jealous; and her great anxiety for the recovery of her dear friend Jane received some assistance from her desire of getting rid of Elizabeth. She was determined to keep her away from Mr. Bingley, and to prevent any intimacy that might lead to a closer attachment. Her schemes, however, were not always successful, for Elizabeth's lively and intelligent nature made her a favorite among the other guests, and her conversations often drew attention and admiration.

Elizabeth, meanwhile, was unaware of Miss Bingley's feelings and was more concerned with her own impressions of the people around her. She found Mr. Darcy's manners somewhat distant, but his conversation was engaging and intelligent. She was also struck by his pride and his apparent disdain for those he considered beneath him, which she found both disagreeable and intriguing.

As the days went by, Elizabeth's interactions with Mr. Darcy became more frequent, and she began to see a different side of him—one that was capable of kindness and wit. Despite her initial prejudice, she started to appreciate his qualities and to question her own judgments. Her lively spirit and honest opinions often clashed with his reserved demeanor, leading to spirited exchanges that both amused and challenged them.

Meanwhile, Jane continued to be the object of Mr. Bingley's affection, and her gentle nature and sincere sweetness made her a favorite among the family and friends. Elizabeth observed their growing attachment with quiet happiness, hoping that their union would bring happiness to both.

The social gatherings at Netherfield and the Meryton ball provided ample opportunity for interactions and misunderstandings. Elizabeth's quick wit and lively conversation often contrasted with the more formal and reserved manners of the others, highlighting her independent spirit.

Throughout these events, Miss Bingley's envy and her attempts to undermine Elizabeth's reputation became more apparent, but Elizabeth remained unaffected, confident in her own worth and integrity. Her keen observations and spirited independence set her apart from the conventional expectations of society.

In the end, the misunderstandings and prejudices began to give way to mutual respect and affection, as characters learned to see beyond their initial impressions and to value each other's true qualities. Elizabeth's journey from prejudice to understanding was a central theme of the novel, illustrating the importance of self-awareness and the dangers of hasty judgments.

events.title: Post-Dinner Pleasantries and Shifting Focus
detailed_summary: Elizabeth ensures Jane is comfortable before they join the Bingley sisters and Mrs. Hurst in the drawing-room.
The ladies engage in pleasant conversation for an hour, displaying their conversational skills through descriptions, anecdotes, and witty remarks about acquaintances.
Upon the arrival of Mr. Bingley, Mr. Darcy, and Mr. Hurst, the group's dynamics shift.
Miss Bingley immediately directs her attention towards Mr. Darcy.
Mr. Darcy offers Miss Bennet polite congratulations on her recovery, while Mr. Hurst gives a brief acknowledgement.
Mr. Bingley, however, expresses great joy and showers Jane with attention, ensuring her comfort by adjusting the fire and seating arrangement.
Bingley proceeds to sit beside Jane, conversing almost exclusively with her.
Elizabeth observes this focused attention on her sister with considerable satisfaction from across the room.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When the ladies removed after dinner Elizabeth ran up to her sister, and seeing her well guarded from cold, attended her into the drawing-room, where she was welcomed by her two friends with many professions of pleasure; and Elizabeth had never seen them so agreeable as they were during the hour which passed before the gentlemen appeared.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Elizabeth, at work in the opposite corner, saw it all with great delight.

events.text_segment:
When the ladies removed after dinner Elizabeth ran up to her sister, and seeing her well guarded from cold, attended her into the drawing-room, where she was welcomed by her two friends with many professions of pleasure; and Elizabeth had never seen them so agreeable as they were during the hour which passed before the gentlemen appeared. Their powers of conversation were considerable. They could describe an entertainment with accuracy, relate an anecdote with humour, and laugh at their acquaintance with spirit.
But when the gentlemen entered, Jane was no longer the first object; Miss Bingley’s eyes were instantly turned towards Darcy, and she had something to say to him before he had advanced many steps. He addressed himself directly to Miss Bennet with a polite congratulation; Mr. Hurst also made her a slight bow, and said he was “very glad;” but diffuseness and warmth remained for Bingley’s salutation. He was full of joy and attention. The first half hour was spent in piling up the fire, lest she should suffer from the change of room; and she removed, at his desire, to the other side of the fireplace, that she might be farther from the door. He then sat down by her, and talked scarcely to anyone else. Elizabeth, at work in the opposite corner, saw it all with great delight.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
When the ladies removed after dinner Elizabeth ran up to her sister, and seeing her well guarded from cold, attended her into the drawing-room, where she was welcomed by her two friends with many professions of pleasure; and Elizabeth had never seen them so agreeable as they were during the hour which passed before the gentlemen appeared.

The ladies then took their seats, and the conversation flowed on with great liveliness and variety. They described their acquaintances, shared amusing anecdotes, and exchanged witty remarks, each trying to outdo the other in cleverness. Elizabeth listened with pleasure, observing how well her friends could entertain and engage.

At length, the door opened, and Mr. Bingley, Mr. Darcy, and Mr. Hurst entered. Miss Bingley immediately turned her attention towards Mr. Darcy, attempting to catch his eye. Mr. Darcy, in turn, approached Elizabeth and offered her polite congratulations on her recovery, which she received with modest gratitude. Mr. Hurst acknowledged her with a brief nod.

Bingley, however, was visibly delighted to see Jane looking well. He expressed his joy openly and, after adjusting the fire and seating, sat down beside her, engaging her in conversation almost exclusively. Jane responded with gentle pleasure, and Bingley’s attentions were evident.

Elizabeth, from her position across the room, watched this display of Bingley’s affection towards her sister with a sense of satisfaction, pleased to see her sister so well cared for and happy.

events.title: Evening Activities Diverge: Cards Rejected, Reading Preferred
detailed_summary: After tea, Mr. Hurst suggests playing cards, but Miss Bingley declines the idea.
She has privately learned that Mr. Darcy does not wish to play cards, leading her to reject Mr. Hurst's explicit request as well.
Miss Bingley asserts that no one desires to play, and the lack of dissent from the others seems to confirm her statement.
Left without his preferred activity, Mr. Hurst settles onto a sofa and falls asleep.
Mr. Darcy selects a book and begins to read.
Miss Bingley picks up a book as well, while Mrs. Hurst occupies herself with her jewelry, occasionally joining Mr. Bingley's conversation with Jane Bennet.

events.text_segment: When tea was over Mr. Hurst reminded his sister-in-law of the card-table—but in vain. She had obtained private intelligence that Mr. Darcy did not wish for cards, and Mr. Hurst soon found even his open petition rejected. She assured him that no one intended to play, and the silence of the whole party on the subject seemed to justify her. Mr. Hurst had, therefore, nothing to do but to stretch himself on one of the sofas and go to sleep. Darcy took up a book. Miss Bingley did the same; and Mrs. Hurst, principally occupied in playing with her bracelets and rings, joined now and then in her brother’s conversation with Miss Bennet.

events.title: Miss Bingley's Failed Attentions and Ball Controversy
detailed_summary: Miss Bingley pretends to read but spends more effort observing Mr. Darcy and attempting to engage him in conversation about his book or reading in general.
She makes frequent inquiries or glances at his page, but he responds minimally and continues reading.

Frustrated with her own book (chosen only because it was the companion volume to Darcy's), she yawns loudly and proclaims the superiority of reading as an evening pastime, perhaps hoping to elicit a response.
When her statement receives no reply, she yawns again, sets aside her book, and looks for another diversion.
Overhearing her brother discussing a potential ball at Netherfield with Miss Bennet, Miss Bingley interjects.
She questions his seriousness and advises him to consider if all guests, implying Darcy, would find a ball pleasurable.
Mr. Bingley affirms the ball is happening regardless of Darcy's preferences and mentions sending out invitations soon.
Miss Bingley expresses her dislike for the typical ball format, suggesting conversation would be a more rational focus.
Bingley concedes her point about rationality but counters that it wouldn't resemble a ball.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Miss Bingley’s attention was quite as much engaged in watching Mr. Darcy’s progress through his book, as in reading her own; and she was perpetually either making some inquiry, or looking at his page.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Much more rational, my dear Caroline, I dare say; but it would not be near so much like a ball.”

events.text_segment:
Miss Bingley’s attention was quite as much engaged in watching Mr. Darcy’s progress through his book, as in reading her own; and she was perpetually either making some inquiry, or looking at his page. She could not win him, however, to any conversation; he merely answered her question and read on. At length, quite exhausted by the attempt to be amused with her own book, which she had only chosen because it was the second volume of his, she gave a great yawn and said, “How pleasant it is to spend an evening in this way! I declare, after all, there is no enjoyment like reading! How much sooner one tires of anything than of a book! When I have a house of my own, I shall be miserable if I have not an excellent library.”
No one made any reply. She then yawned again, threw aside her book, and cast her eyes round the room in quest of some amusement; when, hearing her brother mentioning a ball to Miss Bennet, she turned suddenly towards him and said,—
“By the bye Charles, are you really serious in meditating a dance at Netherfield? I would advise you, before you determine on it, to consult the wishes of the present party; I am much mistaken if there are not some among us to whom a ball would be rather a punishment than a pleasure.”
“If you mean Darcy,” cried her brother, “he may go to bed, if he chooses, before it begins; but as for the ball, it is quite a settled thing, and as soon as Nicholls has made white soup enough I shall send round my cards.”
“I should like balls infinitely better,” she replied, “if they were carried on in a different manner; but there is something insufferably tedious in the usual process of such a meeting. It would surely be much more rational if conversation instead of dancing made the order of the day.”
“Much more rational, my dear Caroline, I dare say; but it would not be near so much like a ball.”

events.title: A Strategic Walk and Darcy's Intriguing Refusal
detailed_summary: Receiving no reply from her brother, Miss Bingley rises and walks about the room, showcasing her elegant figure, clearly intending to capture Darcy's notice.
Despite her efforts, Darcy remains engrossed in his book.
In a final attempt to gain his attention, Miss Bingley turns to Elizabeth and invites her to take a walk around the room, suggesting it's refreshing.

events.text_segment:
Miss Bingley made no answer, and soon afterwards got up and walked about the room. Her figure was elegant, and she walked well; but Darcy, at whom it was all aimed, was still inflexibly studious. In the desperation of her feelings, she resolved on one effort more; and, turning to Elizabeth, said,—
“Miss Eliza Bennet, let me persuade you to follow my example, and take a turn about the room. I assure you it is very refreshing after sitting so long in one attitude.”
Elizabeth was surprised, but agreed to it immediately. Miss Bingley succeeded no less in the real object of her civility: Mr. Darcy looked up. He was as much awake to the novelty of attention in that quarter as Elizabeth herself could be, and unconsciously closed his book. He was directly invited to join their party, but he declined it, observing that he could imagine but two motives for their choosing to walk up and down the room together, with either of which motives his joining them would interfere. What could he mean? She was dying to know what could be his meaning—and asked Elizabeth whether she could at all understand him.
“Not at all,” was her answer; “but, depend upon it, he means to be severe on us, and our surest way of disappointing him will be to ask nothing about it.”

events.text_segment:
Miss Bingley, however, was incapable of disappointing Mr. Darcy in anything, and persevered, therefore, in requiring an explanation of his two motives.
“I have not the smallest objection to explaining them,” said he, as soon as she allowed him to speak. “You either choose this method of passing the evening because you are in each other’s confidence, and have secret affairs to discuss, or because you are conscious that your figures appear to the greatest advantage in walking: if the first, I should be completely in your way; and if the second, I can admire you much better as I sit by the fire.”
“Oh, shocking!” cried Miss Bingley. “I never heard anything so abominable. How shall we punish him for such a speech?”
“Nothing so easy, if you have but the inclination,” said Elizabeth. “We can all plague and punish one another. Tease him—laugh at him. Intimate as you are, you must know how it is to be done.”
“But upon my honour I do not. I do assure you that my intimacy has not yet taught me that. Tease calmness of temper and presence of mind! No, no; I feel he may defy us there. And as to laughter, we will not expose ourselves, if you please, by attempting to laugh without a subject. Mr. Darcy may hug himself.”
“Mr. Darcy is not to be laughed at!” cried Elizabeth. “That is an uncommon advantage, and uncommon I hope it will continue, for it would be a great loss to me to have many such acquaintance. I dearly love a laugh.”
“Miss Bingley,” said he, “has given me credit for more than can be. The wisest and best of men,—nay, the wisest and best of their actions,—may be rendered ridiculous by a person whose first object in life is a joke.”
“Certainly,” replied Elizabeth, “there are such people, but I hope I am not one of them. I hope I never ridicule what is wise or good. Follies and nonsense, whims and inconsistencies, do divert me, I own, and I laugh at them whenever I can. But these, I suppose, are precisely what you are without.”
“Perhaps that is not possible for anyone. But it has been the study of my life to avoid those weaknesses which often expose a strong understanding to ridicule.”
“Such as vanity and pride.”
“Yes, vanity is a weakness indeed. But pride—where there is a real superiority of mind—pride will be always under good regulation.”
Elizabeth turned away to hide a smile.
“Your examination of Mr. Darcy is over, I presume,” said Miss Bingley; “and pray what is the result?”
“I am perfectly convinced by it that Mr. Darcy has no defect. He owns it himself without disguise.”
“No,” said Darcy, “I have made no such pretension. I have faults enough, but they are not, I hope, of understanding. My temper I dare not vouch for. It is, I believe, too little yielding; certainly too little for the convenience of the world. I cannot forget the follies and vices of others so soon as I ought, nor their offences against myself. My feelings are not puffed about with every attempt to move them. My temper would perhaps be called resentful. My good opinion once lost is lost for ever.”
“That is a failing, indeed!” cried Elizabeth. “Implacable resentment is a shade in a character. But you have chosen your fault well. I really cannot laugh at it. You are safe from me.”
“There is, I believe, in every disposition a tendency to some particular evil, a natural defect, which not even the best education can overcome.”
“And your defect is a propensity to hate everybody.”
“And yours,” he replied, with a smile, “is wilfully to misunderstand them.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Miss Bingley, however, was incapable of disappointing Mr. Darcy in anything, and persevered, therefore, in requiring an explanation of his two motives. She was determined to understand the true reason behind his recent conduct, which had been somewhat reserved and distant. Her curiosity was piqued, and she was eager to uncover the secret that seemed to weigh heavily on his mind.

Mr. Darcy, feeling the pressure of her persistent inquiries, hesitated for a moment before responding. He was aware of her intentions and knew that her questions were driven by a mixture of genuine concern and a desire to impress him with her perceptiveness. Nevertheless, he resolved to be honest, at least in part, to satisfy her curiosity.

"Miss Bingley," he began, with a tone that was both calm and measured, "my motives are not as complex as you might imagine. The first is a matter of personal pride and the second pertains to my regard for Miss Elizabeth Bennet."

Miss Bingley looked at him with a mixture of anticipation and skepticism. "Pray, continue, Mr. Darcy," she said, her voice slightly more subdued.

"Regarding my pride," he explained, "it is not merely a matter of social standing or superficial pride, but a reflection of my own principles and the standards I set for myself. I have always believed in acting with integrity and sincerity, and I find myself compelled to be cautious in my dealings, especially when it concerns matters of the heart."

He paused briefly, collecting his thoughts before proceeding. "As for my regard for Miss Bennet," he added, "it is genuine and sincere. I have come to admire her qualities—her intelligence, her wit, and her moral strength. Yet, I am painfully aware of the obstacles that stand between us, not least of which is her family's lower social standing and her own initial prejudice against me."

Miss Bingley listened intently, her eyes fixed on his face, trying to decipher the true meaning behind his words. She was aware that Mr. Darcy's feelings were complex, and that his pride often conflicted with his affections.

"But," she pressed, "why did you not speak openly of your feelings? Why did you hesitate and seem so reserved?"

He sighed, a hint of regret in his expression. "It is not easy to confess one's feelings, especially when one fears rejection or misunderstanding. I was cautious, perhaps too cautious, because I valued her opinion and did not wish to offend her or her family. Moreover, I was uncertain whether my feelings would be reciprocated, and I did not wish to risk losing her entirely."

Miss Bingley nodded slowly, understanding more of his internal struggle. "And now?" she asked softly. "Have your feelings changed?"

"My feelings have only grown stronger," he replied sincerely. "But I am also aware of the importance of patience and respect. I do not wish to rush her or impose my will upon her. I hope that, in time, she will see me for who I truly am and understand the depth of my regard."

She was silent for a moment, contemplating his words. "It is admirable that you are so considerate," she said finally. "But I fear that Miss Bennet's own feelings may not align with yours."

"That is a risk I am willing to take," he responded quietly. "For I believe that true affection must be based on mutual understanding and respect."

Miss Bingley, sensing that her questions had been answered, nodded politely. "Thank you for your candor, Mr. Darcy. I am glad to have understood your motives better."

He inclined his head slightly, a faint smile touching his lips. "It is always a pleasure to converse with you, Miss Bingley."

As she withdrew, Mr. Darcy reflected on the conversation. He felt a mixture of relief and apprehension, knowing that his feelings for Elizabeth Bennet were genuine and deep, yet aware of the obstacles that still lay ahead. His pride and his regard for her would continue to influence his actions, but he was resolved to be patient and true to his heart.

After a moment's reflection, Darcy finds himself not displeased by the interruption.
He inwardly acknowledges the growing risk of directing too much of his attention towards Elizabeth Bennet.

events.title: Elizabeth Seeks to Leave Netherfield Despite Mother's Objections
detailed_summary: Following an agreement between herself and Jane, Elizabeth writes to Mrs. Bennet requesting the carriage for their return home.
Mrs. Bennet, wishing Jane to stay at Netherfield for a full week until Tuesday, denies the request in her response.
Mrs. Bennet adds a postscript suggesting they could stay even longer if the Bingleys insisted.
Elizabeth, determined not to impose and eager to get home, resolves against staying longer.
She convinces Jane that they should ask Mr. Bingley if they can borrow his carriage to leave that same morning.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: In consequence of an agreement between the sisters, Elizabeth wrote the next morning to her mother, to beg that the carriage might be sent for them in the course of the day.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Against staying longer, however, Elizabeth was positively resolved—nor did she much expect it would be asked; and fearful, on the contrary, of being considered as intruding themselves needlessly long, she urged Jane to borrow Mr. Bingley’s carriage immediately, and at length it was settled that their original design of leaving Netherfield that morning should be mentioned, and the request made.

events.text_segment: In consequence of an agreement between the sisters, Elizabeth wrote the next morning to her mother, to beg that the carriage might be sent for them in the course of the day. But Mrs. Bennet, who had calculated on her daughters remaining at Netherfield till the following Tuesday, which would exactly finish Jane’s week, could not bring herself to receive them with pleasure before. Her answer, therefore, was not propitious, at least not to Elizabeth’s wishes, for she was impatient to get home. Mrs. Bennet sent them word that they could not possibly have the carriage before Tuesday; and in her postscript it was added, that if Mr. Bingley and his sister pressed them to stay longer, she could spare them very well. Against staying longer, however, Elizabeth was positively resolved—nor did she much expect it would be asked; and fearful, on the contrary, of being considered as intruding themselves needlessly long, she urged Jane to borrow Mr. Bingley’s carriage immediately, and at length it was settled that their original design of leaving Netherfield that morning should be mentioned, and the request made.

events.title: Darcy Welcomes Departure, Resolves to Conceal Admiration
detailed_summary: Mr. Darcy receives the news of the Bennets' impending departure with relief, feeling Elizabeth has stayed long enough.
He internally admits that she attracts him more than he prefers.
He also observes Miss Bingley's discourtesy towards Elizabeth and increased teasing directed at himself.
He strategically decides to be particularly careful not to betray any sign of his admiration for Elizabeth going forward.
Darcy intends to avoid giving Elizabeth any hope that she might impact his happiness, aware that his behavior on this last day could either encourage or extinguish such a notion.
He commits to this plan, speaking very little to her throughout Saturday.

events.text_segment: To Mr. Darcy it was welcome intelligence: Elizabeth had been at Netherfield long enough. She attracted him more than he liked; and Miss Bingley was uncivil to her and more teasing than usual to himself. He wisely resolved to be particularly careful that no sign of admiration should now escape him—nothing that could elevate her with the hope of influencing his felicity; sensible that, if such an idea had been suggested, his behaviour during the last day must have material weight in confirming or crushing it. Steady to his purpose, he scarcely spoke ten words to her through the whole of Saturday: and though they were at one time left by themselves for half an hour, he adhered most conscientiously to his book, and would not even look at her.

events.title: Homecoming at Longbourn and Family Updates
detailed_summary: Jane and Elizabeth's return home is met with a cool reception from Mrs. Bennet.
Mrs. Bennet expresses surprise and disapproval, feeling they caused trouble and worrying Jane might get sick again.
Their father, Mr. Bennet, though reserved in his words, is genuinely pleased to see them.
Mr. Bennet notes that their absence had negatively impacted the liveliness and substance of the family's evening conversations.
They find Mary occupied with her usual studies of music and philosophy, eager to share new moral insights.
Catherine and Lydia offer news related to the militia regiment's activities since Wednesday.
This news includes officers dining with their uncle (Mr. Phillips), a soldier receiving punishment, and a rumour about Colonel Forster's potential marriage.

events.text_segment:
They were not welcomed home very cordially by their mother. Mrs. Bennet wondered at their coming, and thought them very wrong to give so much trouble, and was sure Jane would have caught cold again. But their father, though very laconic in his expressions of pleasure, was really glad to see them; he had felt their importance in the family circle. The evening conversation, when they were all assembled, had lost much of its animation, and almost all its sense, by the absence of Jane and Elizabeth.
They found Mary, as usual, deep in the study of thorough bass and human nature; and had some new extracts to admire and some new observations of threadbare morality to listen to. Catherine and Lydia had information for them of a different sort. Much had been done, and much had been said in the regiment since the preceding Wednesday; several of the officers had dined lately with their uncle; a private had been flogged; and it had actually been hinted that Colonel Forster was going to be married.

events.title: Mr. Bennet Teases His Family About an Unexpected Guest
detailed_summary: Over breakfast, Mr. Bennet informs his wife they will have a guest for dinner.
Mrs. Bennet immediately speculates it might be Charlotte Lucas, then excitedly assumes it must be Mr. Bingley, chiding Jane for not telling her.
She expresses delight at seeing Bingley but laments the lack of fish for dinner, instructing Lydia to call the servant.
Mr. Bennet corrects her, stating the guest is a gentleman unknown to him personally.
This revelation causes surprise among Mrs. Bennet and all five daughters, who eagerly press him for more information.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I hope, my dear,” said Mr. Bennet to his wife, as they were at breakfast the next morning, “that you have ordered a good dinner to-day, because I have reason to expect an addition to our family party.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: This roused a general astonishment; and he had the pleasure of being eagerly questioned by his wife and five daughters at once.

events.text_segment:
I hope, my dear,” said Mr. Bennet to his wife, as they were at breakfast the next morning, “that you have ordered a good dinner to-day, because I have reason to expect an addition to our family party.”
“Who do you mean, my dear? I know of nobody that is coming, I am sure, unless Charlotte Lucas should happen to call in; and I hope my dinners are good enough for her. I do not believe she often sees such at home.”
“The person of whom I speak is a gentleman and a stranger.”
Mrs. Bennet’s eyes sparkled. “A gentleman and a stranger! It is Mr. Bingley, I am sure. Why, Jane—you never dropped a word of this—you sly thing! Well, I am sure I shall be extremely glad to see Mr. Bingley. But—good Lord! how unlucky! there is not a bit of fish to be got to-day. Lydia, my love, ring the bell. I must speak to Hill this moment.”
“It is not Mr. Bingley,” said her husband; “it is a person whom I never saw in the whole course of my life.”
This roused a general astonishment; and he had the pleasure of being eagerly questioned by his wife and five daughters at once.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
I hope, my dear," said Mr. Bennet to his wife, as they were at breakfast the next morning, "that you have ordered a good dinner to-day, because I have reason to expect an addition to our family party."

"A visitor?" she cried. "Who do you think it is? Charlotte Lucas?"

"No, my dear, I don't know who it is. But I dare say it is a gentleman, and a very agreeable one, too."

"Oh!" she cried, "I am so glad! I hope it is Mr. Bingley."

"I do not know who it is," said Mr. Bennet, "but I have an idea that it is a gentleman whom I have not had the pleasure of knowing yet."

Mrs. Bennet looked at him with a mixture of curiosity and expectation.

"Well," she said, "I am sure I shall be very glad to see him."

"And I," said Jane, "shall be very glad to see him, too."

"And I," said Lydia, "shall be very glad to see him, as well."

"And I," added Elizabeth, "shall be very glad to see him, too."

"And I," said Mary, "shall be very glad to see him, as well."

"And I," said Catherine, "shall be very glad to see him, too."

Mrs. Bennet, in her excitement, immediately began to speculate about the guest, wondering if it might be Charlotte Lucas, or perhaps Mr. Bingley himself. She expressed her delight at the prospect of seeing Mr. Bingley, but also lamented the lack of fish for dinner, instructing Lydia to call the servant to prepare some.

events.title: Revelation of Mr. Collins and His Letter of Introduction
detailed_summary: Mr. Bennet, enjoying their suspense, explains he received and answered a letter some weeks prior.
He reveals the letter is from his cousin, Mr. Collins, who stands to inherit Longbourn upon Mr. Bennet's death.
Mrs. Bennet reacts with distress, calling Mr. Collins odious and lamenting the entail that disadvantages her daughters.
Jane and Elizabeth try, unsuccessfully as often before, to explain the legal nature of the entail to their mother, who remains unreasonable on the topic.
Mrs. Bennet continues her complaints about the injustice of the situation.
Mr. Bennet acknowledges the unfairness but suggests Mr. Collins's letter might soften her opinion.
Mrs. Bennet dismisses this, calling the letter impertinent and hypocritical, preferring Collins maintain the family quarrel.
Mr. Bennet introduces the letter, noting Collins seems to have felt some duty to reconcile.
He reads the letter aloud, dated October 15th from Hunsford.
In the letter, Mr. Collins expresses past unease about the family disagreement and his wish to mend relations after his father's death.
He mentions his ordination and patronage by Lady Catherine de Bourgh, detailing his position and intention to behave respectfully towards her.
He frames his reconciliation attempt as a clerical duty to promote peace.
Collins acknowledges the awkwardness of the entail and apologizes for potentially injuring the daughters, promising amends.
He proposes a visit, arriving Monday, November 18th, and staying until the following Saturday week, assuring them Lady Catherine permits his absence.
The letter concludes with formal respects to Mrs. Bennet and the daughters.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: After amusing himself some time with their curiosity, he thus explained:—“About a month ago I received this letter, and about a fortnight ago I answered it; for I thought it a case of some delicacy, and requiring early attention.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “William Collins.”

events.text_segment:
After amusing himself some time with their curiosity, he thus explained:—“About a month ago I received this letter, and about a fortnight ago I answered it; for I thought it a case of some delicacy, and requiring early attention. It is from my cousin, Mr. Collins, who, when I am dead, may turn you all out of this house as soon as he pleases.”
“Oh, my dear,” cried his wife, “I cannot bear to hear that mentioned. Pray do not talk of that odious man. I do think it is the hardest thing in the world, that your estate should be entailed away from your own children; and I am sure, if I had been you, I should have tried long ago to do something or other about it.”
Jane and Elizabeth attempted to explain to her the nature of an entail. They had often attempted it before: but it was a subject on which Mrs. Bennet was beyond the reach of reason; and she continued to rail bitterly against the cruelty of settling an estate away from a family of five daughters, in favour of a man whom nobody cared anything about.
“It certainly is a most iniquitous affair,” said Mr. Bennet; “and nothing can clear Mr. Collins from the guilt of inheriting Longbourn. But if you will listen to his letter, you may, perhaps, be a little softened by his manner of expressing himself.”
“No, that I am sure I shall not: and I think it was very impertinent of him to write to you at all, and very hypocritical. I hate such false friends. Why could not he keep on quarrelling with you, as his father did before him?”
“Why, indeed, he does seem to have had some filial scruples on that head, as you will hear.”
“Hunsford, near Westerham, Kent, 15th October.
“Dear Sir,
“The disagreement subsisting between yourself and my late honoured father always gave me much uneasiness; and, since I have had the misfortune to lose him, I have frequently wished to heal the breach: but, for some time, I was kept back by my own doubts, fearing lest it might seem disrespectful to his memory for me to be on good terms with anyone with whom it had always pleased him to be at variance.”—‘There, Mrs. Bennet.’—“My mind, however, is now made up on the subject; for, having received ordination at Easter, I have been so fortunate as to be distinguished by the patronage of the Right Honourable Lady Catherine de Bourgh, widow of Sir Lewis de Bourgh, whose bounty and beneficence has preferred me to the valuable rectory of this parish, where it shall be my earnest endeavour to demean myself with grateful respect towards her Ladyship, and be ever ready to perform those rites and ceremonies which are instituted by the Church of England. As a clergyman, moreover, I feel it my duty to promote and establish the blessing of peace in all families within the reach of my influence; and on these grounds I flatter myself that my present overtures of good-will are highly commendable, and that the circumstance of my being next in the entail of Longbourn estate will be kindly overlooked on your side, and not lead you to reject the offered olive branch. I cannot be otherwise than concerned at being the means of injuring your amiable daughters, and beg leave to apologize for it, as well as to assure you of my readiness to make them every possible amends; but of this hereafter. If you should have no objection to receive me into your house, I propose myself the satisfaction of waiting on you and your family, Monday, November 18th, by four o’clock, and shall probably trespass on your hospitality till the Saturday se’nnight following, which I can do without any inconvenience, as Lady Catherine is far from objecting to my occasional absence on a Sunday, provided that some other clergyman is engaged to do the duty of the day. I remain, dear sir, with respectful compliments to your lady and daughters, your well-wisher and friend,
“William Collins.”

events.title: Family Reacts to Mr. Collins and His Letter
detailed_summary: Mr. Bennet confirms the arrival time and sarcastically praises Collins's conscientiousness and politeness, anticipating a valuable connection, especially through Lady Catherine.
Mrs. Bennet concedes Collins's mention of making amends is sensible and indicates she wouldn't oppose it.
Jane acknowledges the difficulty in guessing the nature of his intended amends but finds the sentiment commendable.
Elizabeth notes his excessive deference to Lady Catherine and his formal intentions regarding parish duties (christenings, marriages, burials).
Elizabeth judges him to be an odd, pompous character and questions his sense, particularly regarding his apology for the entail.
Mr. Bennet agrees, expressing hope that Collins will prove foolish and amusing due to the mix of subservience and self-importance in his writing.
Mary comments on the letter's composition, finding the olive branch metaphor adequately expressed, though not original.
Catherine and Lydia show no interest in Collins or his letter, preoccupied with the lack of military men.
Mrs. Bennet's negative feelings towards Collins have significantly lessened after reading his letter, and she prepares for his arrival with unexpected calmness, surprising her family.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “At four o’clock, therefore, we may expect this peace-making gentleman,” said Mr. Bennet, as he folded up the letter.

events.text_segment:
“At four o’clock, therefore, we may expect this peace-making gentleman,” said Mr. Bennet, as he folded up the letter. “He seems to be a most conscientious and polite young man, upon my word; and, I doubt not, will prove a valuable acquaintance, especially if Lady Catherine should be so indulgent as to let him come to us again.”
“There is some sense in what he says about the girls, however; and, if he is disposed to make them any amends, I shall not be the person to discourage him.”
“Though it is difficult,” said Jane, “to guess in what way he can mean to make us the atonement he thinks our due, the wish is certainly to his credit.”
Elizabeth was chiefly struck with his extraordinary deference for Lady Catherine, and his kind intention of christening, marrying, and burying his parishioners whenever it were required.
“He must be an oddity, I think,” said she. “I cannot make him out. There is something very pompous in his style. And what can he mean by apologizing for being next in the entail? We cannot suppose he would help it, if he could. Can he be a sensible man, sir?”
“No, my dear; I think not. I have great hopes of finding him quite the reverse. There is a mixture of servility and self-importance in his letter which promises well. I am impatient to see him.”
“In point of composition,” said Mary, “his letter does not seem defective. The idea of the olive branch perhaps is not wholly new, yet I think it is well expressed.”
To Catherine and Lydia neither the letter nor its writer were in any degree interesting. It was next to impossible that their cousin should come in a scarlet coat, and it was now some weeks since they had received pleasure from the society of a man in any other colour. As for their mother, Mr. Collins’s letter had done away much of her ill-will, and she was preparing to see him with a degree of composure which astonished her husband and daughters.

Catherine and Lydia, meanwhile, showed no interest in Collins or his letter, being preoccupied with the lack of military men.

events.text_segment:
Mr. Collins was punctual to his time, and was received with great politeness by the whole family. Mr. Bennet indeed said little; but the ladies were ready enough to talk, and Mr. Collins seemed neither in need of encouragement, nor inclined to be silent himself. He was a tall, heavy-looking young man of five-and-twenty. His air was grave and stately, and his manners were very formal. He had not been long seated before he complimented Mrs. Bennet on having so fine a family of daughters, said he had heard much of their beauty, but that, in this instance, fame had fallen short of the truth; and added, that he did not doubt her seeing them all in due time well disposed of in marriage. This gallantry was not much to the taste of some of his hearers; but Mrs. Bennet, who quarrelled with no compliments, answered most readily,—
“You are very kind, sir, I am sure; and I wish with all my heart it may prove so; for else they will be destitute enough. Things are settled so oddly.”

events.text_segment:
“You allude, perhaps, to the entail of this estate.”
“Ah, sir, I do indeed. It is a grievous affair to my poor girls, you must confess. Not that I mean to find fault with you, for such things, I know, are all chance in this world. There is no knowing how estates will go when once they come to be entailed.”
“I am very sensible, madam, of the hardship to my fair cousins, and could say much on the subject, but that I am cautious of appearing forward and precipitate. But I can assure the young ladies that I come prepared to admire them. At present I will not say more, but, perhaps, when we are better acquainted——”
He was interrupted by a summons to dinner; and the girls smiled on each other. They were not the only objects of Mr. Collins’s admiration. The hall, the dining-room, and all its furniture, were examined and praised; and his commendation of everything would have touched Mrs. Bennet’s heart, but for the mortifying supposition of his viewing it all as his own future property. The dinner, too, in its turn, was highly admired; and he begged to know to which of his fair cousins the excellence of its cookery was owing. But here he was set right by Mrs. Bennet, who assured him, with some asperity, that they were very well able to keep a good cook, and that her daughters had nothing to do in the kitchen. He begged pardon for having displeased her. In a softened tone she declared herself not at all offended; but he continued to apologize for about a quarter of an hour.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
"You allude, perhaps, to the entail of this estate." Mr. Collins observed, addressing Mrs. Bennet with a respectful tone. She responded with a sigh, "Yes, it is a grievous affair for my daughters, but I do not blame you, sir; it is all chance." Mr. Collins nodded sympathetically, adding, "I am aware of the hardship this entails for my cousins, and I hope to say more on the subject later, though I wish to avoid appearing too forward."

He then turned to the young ladies, bowing politely. "I have come prepared to admire you all, and I dare say as I get to know you better, I shall find more to commend."

Just then, dinner was announced, and the sisters exchanged amused glances. Mr. Collins, shifting his attention, began to praise the house itself, extolling the hall, the dining room, and the furniture. "What a splendid property!" he exclaimed. "I must say, the dining room is particularly well-appointed."

Mrs. Bennet, overhearing this, looked annoyed. She suspected that Mr. Collins was mentally claiming the estate as his own future inheritance. She responded sharply, "The house is well enough, but we have a good cook, and my daughters are not involved in the kitchen."

Mr. Collins quickly apologized, "Pardon me, madam; I meant no offense."

Mrs. Bennet assured him she was not offended, but he continued to apologize profusely, for about fifteen minutes, much to the amusement of her daughters.
