segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She had even condescended to advise him to marry as soon as he could, provided he chose with discretion; and had once paid him a visit in his humble parsonage, where she had perfectly approved all the alterations he had been making, and had even vouchsafed to suggest some herself,—some shelves in the closets upstairs.

events.text_segment: During dinner, Mr. Bennet scarcely spoke at all; but when the servants were withdrawn, he thought it time to have some conversation with his guest, and therefore started a subject in which he expected him to shine, by observing that he seemed very fortunate in his patroness. Lady Catherine de Bourgh’s attention to his wishes, and consideration for his comfort, appeared very remarkable. Mr. Bennet could not have chosen better. Mr. Collins was eloquent in her praise. The subject elevated him to more than usual solemnity of manner; and with a most important aspect he protested that he had never in his life witnessed such behaviour in a person of rank—such affability and condescension, as he had himself experienced from Lady Catherine. She had been graciously pleased to approve of both the discourses which he had already had the honour of preaching before her. She had also asked him twice to dine at Rosings, and had sent for him only the Saturday before, to make up her pool of quadrille in the evening. Lady Catherine was reckoned proud by many people, he knew, but he had never seen anything but affability in her. She had always spoken to him as she would to any other gentleman; she made not the smallest objection to his joining in the society of the neighbourhood, nor to his leaving his parish occasionally for a week or two to visit his relations. She had even condescended to advise him to marry as soon as he could, provided he chose with discretion; and had once paid him a visit in his humble parsonage, where she had perfectly approved all the alterations he had been making, and had even vouchsafed to suggest some herself,—some shelves in the closets upstairs.

events.text_segment:
“That is all very proper and civil, I am sure,” said Mrs. Bennet, “and I dare say she is a very agreeable woman. It is a pity that great ladies in general are not more like her. Does she live near you, sir?”
“The garden in which stands my humble abode is separated only by a lane from Rosings Park, her Ladyship’s residence.”
“I think you said she was a widow, sir? has she any family?”
“She has one only daughter, the heiress of Rosings, and of very extensive property.”
“Ah,” cried Mrs. Bennet, shaking her head, “then she is better off than many girls. And what sort of young lady is she? Is she handsome?”
“She is a most charming young lady, indeed. Lady Catherine herself says that, in point of true beauty, Miss de Bourgh is far superior to the handsomest of her sex; because there is that in her features which marks the young woman of distinguished birth. She is unfortunately of a sickly constitution, which has prevented her making that progress in many accomplishments which she could not otherwise have failed of, as I am informed by the lady who superintended her education, and who still resides with them. But she is perfectly amiable, and often condescends to drive by my humble abode in her little phaeton and ponies.”

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: These are the kind of little things which please her Ladyship, and it is a sort of attention which I conceive myself peculiarly bound to pay.”

events.text_segment:
“Has she been presented? I do not remember her name among the ladies at court.”
“Her indifferent state of health unhappily prevents her being in town; and by that means, as I told Lady Catherine myself one day, has deprived the British Court of its brightest ornament. Her Ladyship seemed pleased with the idea; and you may imagine that I am happy on every occasion to offer those little delicate compliments which are always acceptable to ladies. I have more than once observed to Lady Catherine, that her charming daughter seemed born to be a duchess; and that the most elevated rank, instead of giving her consequence, would be adorned by her. These are the kind of little things which please her Ladyship, and it is a sort of attention which I conceive myself peculiarly bound to pay.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
"Has she been presented?" Mrs. Bennet inquired.

Mr. Collins, with a self-satisfied smile, replied, "Not yet, ma'am, owing to her delicate health, which prevents her from being in London at present."

He then added proudly, "I took the liberty of informing Lady Catherine that her daughter’s absence from court deprives it of its brightest ornament, a remark which I believe pleased her Ladyship very much."

Mrs. Bennet looked at him with a mixture of curiosity and approval.

"Indeed, sir," she said, "you do enjoy offering such delicate compliments, especially to ladies."

Mr. Collins nodded, continuing, "Indeed, I find it quite agreeable to pay such compliments. For example, I told Lady Catherine that her daughter seems destined to be a duchess, and that her rank would be greatly enhanced by her, rather than the other way around."

Mrs. Bennet smiled at his enthusiasm.

"I am glad to see you so eager to please," she said.

"It is my duty and my pleasure," Mr. Collins replied, "to make the most of every opportunity to flatter and to serve."

events.title: Mr. Bennet Probes Collins' Flattery Technique
detailed_summary: Mr. Bennet ironically commends Mr. Collins' skill in delivering subtle flattery.
He pointedly asks whether these compliments are spontaneous or premeditated.
Mr. Collins explains they mostly arise from the immediate situation, although he sometimes mentally prepares elegant phrases for general use.
He stresses his desire to make compliments seem as natural and unrehearsed as possible.
Mr. Bennet's assessment of his cousin's absurdity is confirmed.
He derives great amusement from listening, keeping a straight face and sharing his mirth only through occasional looks towards Elizabeth.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “You judge very properly,” said Mr. Bennet; “and it is happy for you that you possess the talent of flattering with delicacy.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: His cousin was as absurd as he had hoped; and he listened to him with the keenest enjoyment, maintaining at the same time the most resolute composure of countenance, and, except in an occasional glance at Elizabeth, requiring no partner in his pleasure.

events.text_segment:
“You judge very properly,” said Mr. Bennet; “and it is happy for you that you possess the talent of flattering with delicacy. May I ask whether these pleasing attentions proceed from the impulse of the moment, or are the result of previous study?”
“They arise chiefly from what is passing at the time; and though I sometimes amuse myself with suggesting and arranging such little elegant compliments as may be adapted to ordinary occasions, I always wish to give them as unstudied an air as possible.”
Mr. Bennet’s expectations were fully answered. His cousin was as absurd as he had hoped; and he listened to him with the keenest enjoyment, maintaining at the same time the most resolute composure of countenance, and, except in an occasional glance at Elizabeth, requiring no partner in his pleasure.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
"You judge very properly," said Mr. Bennet; "and it is happy for you that you possess the talent of flattering with delicacy."

Mr. Collins, with a very grave and serious air, assured him that he never spoke but what was perfectly sincere and from his heart; and that he could not think of saying anything that was not. He then proceeded to give a very long and elaborate account of the compliments he had paid to Lady Catherine, and of the compliments he had received in return, which he considered as a proof of his good breeding and his skill in the art of flattery.

"I always speak what I think," he added, "and I am never at a loss for words."

Mr. Bennet, with a smile, observed that he was sure Mr. Collins's compliments were very natural and spontaneous, and that he was glad to see him so well pleased with himself.

Mr. Collins, blushing, assured him that he was quite delighted, and that he hoped to be able to make himself agreeable to all his acquaintances.

Elizabeth, who had been listening to the conversation with a good deal of amusement, kept her countenance, and only looked at her father with a smile of quiet amusement.

Mr. Bennet, observing her, said, "You are very clever at keeping your countenance, Elizabeth."

She made no answer, but continued to listen, while Mr. Collins went on to describe his efforts to flatter Lady Catherine, and his hopes of being able to do the same to her.

events.title: Mr. Collins Declines a Novel for Sermons
detailed_summary: Having endured enough of Mr. Collins' conversation, Mr. Bennet suggests he read aloud to the women after tea.
Mr. Collins willingly agrees.
When presented with a book clearly from a circulating library, he recoils.
He apologizes and declares he never reads novels, causing surprise from Kitty and an exclamation from Lydia.
After considering alternative books, he selects a volume of Fordyce's Sermons.

events.text_segment: By tea-time, however, the dose had been enough, and Mr. Bennet was glad to take his guest into the drawing-room again, and when tea was over, glad to invite him to read aloud to the ladies. Mr. Collins readily assented, and a book was produced; but on beholding it (for everything announced it to be from a circulating library) he started back, and, begging pardon, protested that he never read novels. Kitty stared at him, and Lydia exclaimed. Other books were produced, and after some deliberation he chose “Fordyce’s Sermons.”

events.text_segment:
Lydia gaped as he opened the volume; and before he had, with very monotonous solemnity, read three pages, she interrupted him with,—
“Do you know, mamma, that my uncle Philips talks of turning away Richard? and if he does, Colonel Forster will hire him. My aunt told me so herself on Saturday. I shall walk to Meryton to-morrow to hear more about it, and to ask when Mr. Denny comes back from town.”

events.title: Mr. Collins Abandons Reading for Backgammon
detailed_summary: Lydia's two older sisters (presumably Jane and Elizabeth) reprimand her for interrupting.
Mr. Collins, visibly annoyed, puts down the book.
He remarks on his frequent observation that young ladies disregard serious literature, even when intended for their improvement, expressing his astonishment.
He states he won't impose the reading further on his 'young cousin'.
Turning to Mr. Bennet, he suggests playing backgammon.
Mr. Bennet accepts, commenting that Collins is wise to leave the girls to their 'trifling amusements'.
Mrs. Bennet and the daughters apologize for Lydia's behavior and offer assurances it won't happen again if he continues reading.
Mr. Collins claims he holds no grudge against Lydia but nevertheless proceeds to set up the backgammon game with Mr. Bennet.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Lydia was bid by her two eldest sisters to hold her tongue; but Mr. Collins, much offended, laid aside his book, and said,—
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mrs. Bennet and her daughters apologized most civilly for Lydia’s interruption, and promised that it should not occur again, if he would resume his book; but Mr. Collins, after assuring them that he bore his young cousin no ill-will, and should never resent her behaviour as any affront, seated himself at another table with Mr. Bennet, and prepared for backgammon.

events.text_segment:
Lydia was bid by her two eldest sisters to hold her tongue; but Mr. Collins, much offended, laid aside his book, and said,—
“I have often observed how little young ladies are interested by books of a serious stamp, though written solely for their benefit. It amazes me, I confess; for certainly there can be nothing so advantageous to them as instruction. But I will no longer importune my young cousin.”
Then, turning to Mr. Bennet, he offered himself as his antagonist at backgammon. Mr. Bennet accepted the challenge, observing that he acted very wisely in leaving the girls to their own trifling amusements. Mrs. Bennet and her daughters apologized most civilly for Lydia’s interruption, and promised that it should not occur again, if he would resume his book; but Mr. Collins, after assuring them that he bore his young cousin no ill-will, and should never resent her behaviour as any affront, seated himself at another table with Mr. Bennet, and prepared for backgammon.

Mrs. Bennet and the daughters then apologized for Lydia's interruption, assuring him it would not happen again if he continued reading. Mr. Collins, who declared he bore no ill-will against Lydia, then proceeded to set up the backgammon game with Mr. Bennet, seating himself at another table and preparing for the game.

events.title: Mr. Collins's Character and Motivation for Marriage
detailed_summary: Mr. Collins is presented as a man lacking natural sense, whose limited education and societal exposure did little to compensate.
His upbringing under a frugal and uneducated father fostered an initial humility.
This humility is now overshadowed by conceit stemming from his quiet life, unexpected success, and association with his patroness, Lady Catherine de Bourgh.
His connection to Lady Catherine began fortuitously when she offered him the Hunsford parish living.
He exhibits a conflicting blend of deference towards his patroness and pride in his own clerical position and rights.
Now possessing a comfortable home and income, he decides to marry.
He plans to choose one of the Bennet daughters as a wife, viewing this as a form of reconciliation and compensation for his future inheritance of their father's estate.
Mr. Collins considers this marriage plan to be highly appropriate and a mark of his own generosity.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mr. Collins was not a sensible man, and the deficiency of nature had been but little assisted by education or society; the greatest part of his life having been spent under the guidance of an illiterate and miserly father; and though he belonged to one of the universities, he had merely kept the necessary terms without forming at it any useful acquaintance.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: This was his plan of amends—of atonement—for inheriting their father’s estate; and he thought it an excellent one, full of eligibility and suitableness, and excessively generous and disinterested on his own part.

events.text_segment:
Mr. Collins was not a sensible man, and the deficiency of nature had been but little assisted by education or society; the greatest part of his life having been spent under the guidance of an illiterate and miserly father; and though he belonged to one of the universities, he had merely kept the necessary terms without forming at it any useful acquaintance. The subjection in which his father had brought him up had given him originally great humility of manner; but it was now a good deal counteracted by the self-conceit of a weak head, living in retirement, and the consequential feelings of early and unexpected prosperity. A fortunate chance had recommended him to Lady Catherine de Bourgh when the living of Hunsford was vacant; and the respect which he felt for her high rank, and his veneration for her as his patroness, mingling with a very good opinion of himself, of his authority as a clergyman, and his right as a rector, made him altogether a mixture of pride and obsequiousness, self-importance and humility.
Having now a good house and a very sufficient income, he intended to marry; and in seeking a reconciliation with the Longbourn family he had a wife in view, as he meant to choose one of the daughters, if he found them as handsome and amiable as they were represented by common report. This was his plan of amends—of atonement—for inheriting their father’s estate; and he thought it an excellent one, full of eligibility and suitableness, and excessively generous and disinterested on his own part.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Mr. Collins was not a sensible man, and the deficiency of nature had been but little assisted by education or society; the greatest part of his life having been spent under the guidance of an illiterate and miserly father; and though he belonged to one of the universities, he had merely kept the necessary terms without forming at it any useful acquaintance. His father had been a man of limited means and even more limited understanding, which had left a lasting impression on Mr. Collins's own character. When Lady Catherine de Bourgh offered him the living at Hunsford, he accepted it with great gratitude, seeing it as a mark of her favor and a step upward in his social standing. His connection to Lady Catherine was a fortunate accident, but he was eager to display his deference and pride in his position. Now, with a comfortable home and a steady income, Mr. Collins was contemplating marriage, and he set his sights on one of the Bennet daughters, considering it a fitting alliance that would also serve as a token of his gratitude and a means of securing his future inheritance. He regarded this plan as not only appropriate but also as a generous act on his part, believing it would bring him happiness and social respect.

Mr. Collins was a clergyman, and his liveliness and self-importance made him a figure of some amusement to those who knew him well. His obsequiousness to his patroness, Lady Catherine, was only equaled by his eagerness to please her, often at the expense of his own dignity. When he visited the Bennet family, he was always eager to display his importance and to talk about his patroness's estate and his prospects of advancement. Despite his lack of sense, Mr. Collins was a man of some good intentions, though his manners were often awkward and his conversation dull. His proposal to Elizabeth Bennet was a perfect example of his lack of perception; he was utterly unaware of her feelings and expectations, and his proposal was as insincere as it was awkward. Elizabeth's rejection of him was a turning point in her life, and it marked her refusal to accept a marriage based solely on convenience or social expectation. Mr. Collins's character, though comic, also served as a reminder of the importance of genuine understanding and affection in marriage.

events.title: Mr. Collins Switches Affections from Jane to Elizabeth
detailed_summary: Upon meeting the Bennet sisters, Mr. Collins initially settles on Jane, the eldest, confirming his intention to respect seniority.
However, a private conversation with Mrs. Bennet the next morning alters his decision.
Mrs. Bennet, while expressing general encouragement for his desire to find a wife at Longbourn, subtly steers him away from Jane.
She implies that Jane is likely to be engaged soon, while suggesting her younger daughters are available.
Mr. Collins promptly shifts his focus from Jane to Elizabeth, the next daughter in age and beauty.
This change happens quickly, during the time Mrs. Bennet tends to the fire.
Mrs. Bennet is delighted by this development, hoping for two married daughters, and her opinion of Mr. Collins improves dramatically.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: His plan did not vary on seeing them.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mrs. Bennet treasured up the hint, and trusted that she might soon have two daughters married; and the man whom she could not bear to speak of the day before, was now high in her good graces.

events.text_segment:
His plan did not vary on seeing them. Miss Bennet’s lovely face confirmed his views, and established all his strictest notions of what was due to seniority; and for the first evening she was his settled choice. The next morning, however, made an alteration; for in a quarter of an hour’s tête-à-tête with Mrs. Bennet before breakfast, a conversation beginning with his parsonage-house, and leading naturally to the avowal of his hopes, that a mistress for it might be found at Longbourn, produced from her, amid very complaisant smiles and general encouragement, a caution against the very Jane he had fixed on. “As to her younger daughters, she could not take upon her to say—she could not positively answer—but she did not know of any prepossession;—her eldest daughter she must just mention—she felt it incumbent on her to hint, was likely to be very soon engaged.”
Mr. Collins had only to change from Jane to Elizabeth—and it was soon done—done while Mrs. Bennet was stirring the fire. Elizabeth, equally next to Jane in birth and beauty, succeeded her of course.
Mrs. Bennet treasured up the hint, and trusted that she might soon have two daughters married; and the man whom she could not bear to speak of the day before, was now high in her good graces.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: His plan did not vary on seeing them. When Mr. Collins first arrived at Longbourn and met the Bennet sisters, he immediately set his sights on Jane, the eldest, believing her to be the most suitable match and respecting the natural order of seniority. However, the very next morning, after a private conversation with Mrs. Bennet, his intentions shifted. Mrs. Bennet, while outwardly encouraging his pursuit of a wife at Longbourn, subtly indicated that Jane was likely to be engaged soon, hinting that her own daughters might be more available. She suggested that her younger daughters, including Elizabeth, might be more suitable prospects. Almost instantly, Mr. Collins redirected his attention from Jane to Elizabeth, the next daughter in age and beauty. events.text_segment:
Lydia’s intention of walking to Meryton was not forgotten: every sister except Mary agreed to go with her; and Mr. Collins was to attend them, at the request of Mr. Bennet, who was most anxious to get rid of him, and have his library to himself; for thither Mr. Collins had followed him after breakfast, and there he would continue, nominally engaged with one of the largest folios in the collection, but really talking to Mr. Bennet, with little cessation, of his house and garden at Hunsford. Such doings discomposed Mr. Bennet exceedingly. In his library he had been always sure of leisure and tranquillity; and though prepared, as he told Elizabeth, to meet with folly and conceit in every other room in the house, he was used to be free from them there: his civility, therefore, was most prompt in inviting Mr. Collins to join his daughters in their walk; and Mr. Collins, being in fact much better fitted for a walker than a reader, was extremely well pleased to close his large book, and go.
In pompous nothings on his side, and civil assents on that of his cousins, their time passed till they entered Meryton. The attention of the younger ones was then no longer to be gained by him. Their eyes were immediately wandering up the street in quest of the officers, and nothing less than a very smart bonnet, indeed, or a really new muslin in a shop window, could recall them.
But the attention of every lady was soon caught by a young man, whom they had never seen before, of most gentlemanlike appearance, walking with an officer on the other side of the way. The officer was the very Mr. Denny concerning whose return from London Lydia came to inquire, and he bowed as they passed. All were struck with the stranger’s air, all wondered who he could be; and Kitty and Lydia, determined if possible to find out, led the way across the street, under pretence of wanting something in an opposite shop, and fortunately had just gained the pavement, when the two gentlemen, turning back, had reached the same spot. Mr. Denny addressed them directly, and entreated permission to introduce his friend, Mr. Wickham, who had returned with him the day before from town, and, he was happy to say, had accepted a commission in their corps. This was exactly as it should be; for the young man wanted only regimentals to make him completely charming. His appearance was greatly in his favour: he had all the best parts of beauty, a fine countenance, a good figure, and very pleasing address. The introduction was followed up on his side by a happy readiness of conversation—a readiness at the same time perfectly correct and unassuming; and the whole party were still standing and talking together very agreeably, when the sound of horses drew their notice, and Darcy and Bingley were seen riding down the street.

As they set out, Lydia was full of spirits, eager to see the latest news and to display her new ribbons and bonnet. Elizabeth, walking quietly beside her, could not help but reflect on her sister’s lively disposition, which was often a source of amusement and sometimes concern. Jane, ever gentle and kind, kept her thoughts more reserved, observing Lydia’s exuberance with a tender smile.

The walk to Meryton was pleasant, the air crisp and invigorating, and the group’s chatter filled the space with lively sounds. Lydia, in her usual manner, was quick to share her hopes of catching the eye of some officer or gentleman, her cheeks flushed with excitement. Elizabeth listened with a mixture of amusement and apprehension, knowing well the impulsiveness of her sister’s nature.

Upon reaching Meryton, they found the town bustling with activity. Soldiers were quartered nearby, and the local gossip was lively. Lydia’s eyes sparkled as she eagerly approached the officers, eager to exchange words and perhaps flirt a little. Elizabeth watched her sister with a mixture of fondness and concern, aware of Lydia’s tendency to act without fully considering the consequences.

Meanwhile, Mr. Collins, ever the attentive clergyman, was engaged in a lengthy discourse about the virtues of Hunsford and the importance of proper conduct. His voice, loud and somewhat monotonous, drew amused glances from the passersby. Elizabeth, accustomed to his peculiarities, paid him little mind, her thoughts drifting to her own prospects and the future that awaited her.

As the afternoon wore on, the sisters enjoyed their time in Meryton, exchanging smiles and stories. Lydia’s laughter rang out, bright and carefree, as she flirted with the officers. Elizabeth, watching her sister’s exuberance, felt a quiet hope that Lydia’s spirited nature would serve her well, yet she also knew the importance of caution and prudence in such pursuits. The day passed swiftly, filled with the simple pleasures of companionship and the lively hum of a small town alive with the promise of new acquaintances and adventures.

events.title: A Tense Encounter Between Darcy and Wickham
detailed_summary: Mr. Darcy and Mr. Bingley ride towards the group upon seeing the Bennet sisters.
Bingley takes the lead in greeting everyone, specifically mentioning he was on his way to Longbourn to inquire about Jane's health.
Mr. Darcy offers a confirming bow but avoids looking at Elizabeth until his gaze falls upon Mr. Wickham.
Elizabeth observes a strong, negative reaction between Darcy and Wickham upon seeing each other.
Both men visibly change color, one paling and the other flushing red.
After a moment, Mr. Wickham offers a slight bow (touching his hat), which Mr. Darcy barely acknowledges.
Elizabeth is astonished and deeply curious about the unspoken history and meaning behind this evident animosity.
Mr. Bingley appears oblivious to the tension and soon departs with Mr. Darcy.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: In another minute Mr. Bingley, but without seeming to have noticed what passed, took leave and rode on with his friend.

events.text_segment:
On distinguishing the ladies of the group the two gentlemen came directly towards them, and began the usual civilities. Bingley was the principal spokesman, and Miss Bennet the principal object. He was then, he said, on his way to Longbourn on purpose to inquire after her. Mr. Darcy corroborated it with a bow, and was beginning to determine not to fix his eyes on Elizabeth, when they were suddenly arrested by the sight of the stranger; and Elizabeth happening to see the countenance of both as they looked at each other, was all astonishment at the effect of the meeting. Both changed colour, one looked white, the other red. Mr. Wickham, after a few moments, touched his hat—a salutation which Mr. Darcy just deigned to return. What could be the meaning of it? It was impossible to imagine; it was impossible not to long to know.
In another minute Mr. Bingley, but without seeming to have noticed what passed, took leave and rode on with his friend.

Mr. Bingley, with a friendly smile, was the first to speak. "I was on my way to Longbourn to inquire after Jane's health," he said, addressing Mr. and Mrs. Bennet. Mr. Darcy, with a polite bow, responded, but his eyes lingered briefly on Elizabeth, avoiding her gaze until they fell upon Mr. Wickham. Elizabeth observed a sudden change in Darcy's expression—his face paling slightly—while Wickham's cheeks flushed with color. After a moment, Wickham tipped his hat in a slight bow, which Darcy acknowledged with a mere nod. Elizabeth watched this exchange with growing curiosity, sensing an undercurrent of tension and unspoken history. Bingley, seemingly unaware of the undercurrents, soon excused himself and Mr. Darcy, and they departed, leaving Elizabeth pondering the silent conflict she had just witnessed.

events.text_segment:
Mr. Denny and Mr. Wickham walked with the young ladies to the door of Mr. Philips’s house, and then made their bows, in spite of Miss Lydia’s pressing entreaties that they would come in, and even in spite of Mrs. Philips’s throwing up the parlour window, and loudly seconding the invitation.
Mrs. Philips was always glad to see her nieces; and the two eldest, from their recent absence, were particularly welcome; and she was eagerly expressing her surprise at their sudden return home, which, as their own carriage had not fetched them, she should have known nothing about, if she had not happened to see Mr. Jones’s shopboy in the street, who had told her that they were not to send any more draughts to Netherfield, because the Miss Bennets were come away, when her civility was claimed towards Mr. Collins by Jane’s introduction of him. She received him with her very best politeness, which he returned with as much more, apologizing for his intrusion, without any previous acquaintance with her, which he could not help flattering himself, however, might be justified by his relationship to the young ladies who introduced him to her notice. Mrs. Philips was quite awed by such an excess of good breeding; but her contemplation of one stranger was soon put an end to by exclamations and inquiries about the other, of whom, however, she could only tell her nieces what they already knew, that Mr. Denny had brought him from London, and that he was to have a lieutenant’s commission in the ——shire. She had been watching him the last hour, she said, as he walked up and down the street,—and had Mr. Wickham appeared, Kitty and Lydia would certainly have continued the occupation; but unluckily no one passed the windows now except a few of the officers, who, in comparison with the stranger, were become “stupid, disagreeable fellows.” Some of them were to dine with the Philipses the next day, and their aunt promised to make her husband call on Mr. Wickham, and give him an invitation also, if the family from Longbourn would come in the evening. This was agreed to; and Mrs. Philips protested that they would have a nice comfortable noisy game of lottery tickets, and a little bit of hot supper afterwards. The prospect of such delights was very cheering, and they parted in mutual good spirits. Mr. Collins repeated his apologies in quitting the room, and was assured, with unwearying civility, that they were perfectly needless.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Mr. Denny and Mr. Wickham walked with the young ladies to the door of Mr. Philips’s house, and then made their bows, in spite of Miss Lydia’s pressing entreaties that they would come in, and even in spite of Mrs. Philips’s throwing up the parlour window, and loudly seconding the invitation.

Mrs. Philips was very glad to see her nieces again, especially Jane and Elizabeth, after their long absence. She had heard of their return from Netherfield indirectly, through Mr. Jones’s shopboy, and was eager to hear all about it.

Jane introduced Mr. Collins, who made a very elaborate bow and offered his apologies for intruding, explaining that he was a relation of the Bennets and had come to pay his respects. Mrs. Philips was quite taken with Mr. Collins’s manners and was pleased by his politeness.

The attention then turned to the stranger, Mr. Wickham. Mrs. Philips confirmed what they already knew: that Mr. Denny had brought him from London, and that he held a lieutenant’s commission. She mentioned that she had seen him walking earlier, and Kitty and Lydia expressed their hope that he would reappear.

The officers present were not considered very interesting compared to Wickham, and some of them were expected for dinner the next day. Mrs. Philips kindly offered to have her husband invite Mr. Wickham to join them, provided the Longbourn family could come in the evening. The plan was enthusiastically accepted, including games and supper.

As they prepared to leave, Mr. Collins reiterated his apologies, which Mrs. Philips received politely, assuring him that it was no trouble at all.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Mr. Denny and Mr. Wickham, after a courteous exchange of farewells, turned away from the lively scene, their figures gradually diminishing in the distance as they strolled down the street. The young ladies, particularly Lydia, watched them with a mixture of disappointment and hope, wishing they might have been persuaded to stay longer. Elizabeth, observing her sister’s animated expressions, felt a quiet satisfaction that Lydia’s exuberance was not entirely misplaced, though she was also aware of the importance of propriety and the need for restraint.

As they entered the house, Mrs. Bennet bustled about, eager to hear every detail of the gentlemen’s visit. Her face lit up with pleasure at the thought of potential matches for her daughters, especially Lydia, whose flirtatious nature was well known. Elizabeth, however, remained thoughtful, contemplating the implications of Lydia’s flirtation and the subtle nuances of social interaction that had just transpired.

Later that evening, as the family gathered in the drawing room, Elizabeth reflected on the events of the day. She considered Mr. Wickham’s manner—his easy confidence and the way he seemed genuinely interested in Lydia, which she found both charming and somewhat concerning. She knew that Lydia’s infatuation with flirtation could lead her into trouble, and she hoped her sister would exercise more caution.

Meanwhile, Mr. Darcy’s arrival at the estate was imminent, and Elizabeth’s thoughts turned to him. She remembered their previous conversations, the subtle hints of pride and prejudice that colored her perceptions of him. Yet, she also recognized his integrity and the kindness that occasionally shone through his reserved exterior. As she pondered these things, she was unaware that her feelings were beginning to shift, influenced by the complexities of her interactions and the unfolding social landscape.

The evening passed with lively conversation and the gentle hum of music, but Elizabeth’s mind was occupied with the intricate dance of manners, affections, and societal expectations that defined her world. She knew that tomorrow would bring new encounters and perhaps, new revelations, as the story of her life and those around her continued to unfold amidst the charming yet challenging backdrop of Hertfordshire.

events.title: Return and Reflections
detailed_summary: On the walk back to Longbourn, Elizabeth describes the perplexing encounter between Mr. Darcy and Mr. Wickham to Jane.
Jane, despite her charitable nature, finds the behavior inexplicable, just as Elizabeth does.
Upon arriving home, Mr. Collins conveys his admiration for Mrs. Philips's politeness and elegance to Mrs. Bennet.
He declares Mrs. Philips second only to Lady Catherine de Bourgh and her daughter in elegance.
Mr. Collins highlights that Mrs. Philips not only received him civilly but also specifically included him, a stranger, in the next day's invitation.
He considers that his connection to the Bennet family might be a factor but emphasizes that he has never experienced such marked attention before in his life.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: As they walked home, Elizabeth related to Jane what she had seen pass between the two gentlemen; but though Jane would have defended either or both, had they appeared to be wrong, she could no more explain such behaviour than her sister.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Something, he supposed, might be attributed to his connection with them, but yet he had never met with so much attention in the whole course of his life.

events.text_segment:
As they walked home, Elizabeth related to Jane what she had seen pass between the two gentlemen; but though Jane would have defended either or both, had they appeared to be wrong, she could no more explain such behaviour than her sister.
Mr. Collins on his return highly gratified Mrs. Bennet by admiring Mrs. Philips’s manners and politeness. He protested that, except Lady Catherine and her daughter, he had never seen a more elegant woman; for she had not only received him with the utmost civility, but had even pointedly included him in her invitation for the next evening, although utterly unknown to her before. Something, he supposed, might be attributed to his connection with them, but yet he had never met with so much attention in the whole course of his life.

events.title: Arrival at Meryton and First Impressions of Wickham
detailed_summary: Mr. Collins and the five Bennet sisters travel to Meryton to visit their Aunt and Uncle Philips.
Upon arrival, they learn that Mr. Wickham is present, having accepted Mr. Philips' invitation.
Mr. Collins, impressed by the room's size and furnishings, compares it favorably (in his mind) to a lesser room at Rosings, Lady Catherine de Bourgh's estate.
He elaborates on Rosings and Lady Catherine to Mrs. Philips, detailing its grandeur, including an expensive chimney-piece, which greatly impresses her.
Mrs. Philips listens attentively to Mr. Collins' descriptions of Lady Catherine's estate and his own home improvements, planning to share this information with her neighbors.
The Bennet girls find the wait for the gentlemen tedious, occupying themselves idly.
The gentlemen, including officers and Mr. Wickham, finally enter.

Elizabeth observes Mr. Wickham's entrance, confirming her previous high opinion of his appearance and manner, noting his superiority even to the other respectable officers present, and certainly to her uncle Philips.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: As no objection was made to the young people’s engagement with their aunt, and all Mr. Collins’s scruples of leaving Mr. and Mrs. Bennet for a single evening during his visit were most steadily resisted, the coach conveyed him and his five cousins at a suitable hour to Meryton; and the girls had the pleasure of hearing, as they entered the drawing-room, that Mr. Wickham had accepted their uncle’s invitation, and was then in the house.

events.text_segment:
As no objection was made to the young people’s engagement with their aunt, and all Mr. Collins’s scruples of leaving Mr. and Mrs. Bennet for a single evening during his visit were most steadily resisted, the coach conveyed him and his five cousins at a suitable hour to Meryton; and the girls had the pleasure of hearing, as they entered the drawing-room, that Mr. Wickham had accepted their uncle’s invitation, and was then in the house.
When this information was given, and they had all taken their seats, Mr. Collins was at leisure to look around him and admire, and he was so much struck with the size and furniture of the apartment, that he declared he might almost have supposed himself in the small summer breakfast parlour at Rosings; a comparison that did not at first convey much gratification; but when Mrs. Philips understood from him what Rosings was, and who was its proprietor, when she had listened to the description of only one of Lady Catherine’s drawing-rooms, and found that the chimney-piece alone had cost eight hundred pounds, she felt all the force of the compliment, and would hardly have resented a comparison with the housekeeper’s room.
In describing to her all the grandeur of Lady Catherine and her mansion, with occasional digressions in praise of his own humble abode, and the improvements it was receiving, he was happily employed until the gentlemen joined them; and he found in Mrs. Philips a very attentive listener, whose opinion of his consequence increased with what she heard, and who was resolving to retail it all among her neighbours as soon as she could. To the girls, who could not listen to their cousin, and who had nothing to do but to wish for an instrument, and examine their own indifferent imitations of china on the mantel-piece, the interval of waiting appeared very long. It was over at last, however. The gentlemen did approach: and when Mr. Wickham walked into the room, Elizabeth felt that she had neither been seeing him before, nor thinking of him since, with the smallest degree of unreasonable admiration. The officers of the ——shire were in general a very creditable, gentlemanlike set and the best of them were of the present party; but Mr, Wickham was as far beyond them all in person, countenance, air, and walk, as they were superior to the broad-faced stuffy uncle Philips, breathing port wine, who followed them into the room.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
As no objection was made to the young people’s engagement with their aunt, and all Mr. Collins’s scruples of leaving Mr. and Mrs. Bennet for a single evening during his visit were most steadily resisted, the coach conveyed him and his five cousins at a suitable hour to Meryton; and the girls had the pleasure of hearing, as they entered the drawing-room, that Mr. Wickham had accepted their uncle’s invitation, and was then in the house.

Mr. Collins was so sensible of the compliment that he could not help talking of it again, and again, and again, to Mrs. Philips, who was very well pleased to hear of Lady Catherine’s estate, and of the improvements he had been making at Hunsford, and of the grandeur of Rosings, which he described in such glowing terms that she was quite eager to see it herself.

Mrs. Philips listened with great attention, and expressed her admiration of Lady Catherine’s taste and her own happiness in having such a neighbor. She was very glad to hear of Mr. Collins’s good fortune, and was determined to tell her friends all about it.

Meanwhile, the young ladies, Elizabeth, Jane, Mary, Kitty, and Lydia, found the waiting tedious, and amused themselves with various little pursuits, till the arrival of the gentlemen, including the officers and Mr. Wickham.

At length, the door opened, and the gentlemen entered. Elizabeth’s eyes immediately sought Mr. Wickham, and she was not disappointed. She thought him looking remarkably well, and his manner was so easy and pleasant that she could not help feeling a high opinion of him. She observed that he was even more distinguished in his appearance than the other officers, and certainly more so than her uncle Philips, who was a very respectable man, but not at all remarkable.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_2.text:
As no objection was made to the young people’s engagement with their aunt, and all Mr. Collins’s scruples of leaving Mr. and Mrs. Bennet for a single evening during his visit were most steadily resisted, the coach conveyed him and his five cousins at a suitable hour to Meryton; and the girls had the pleasure of hearing, as they entered the drawing-room, that Mr. Wickham had accepted their uncle’s invitation, and was then in the house.

Mr. Collins was so sensible of the compliment that he could not help talking of it again, and again, and again, to Mrs. Philips, who was very well pleased to hear of Lady Catherine’s estate, and of the improvements he had been making at Hunsford, and of the grandeur of Rosings, which he described in such glowing terms that she was quite eager to see it herself.

Mrs. Philips listened with great attention, and expressed her admiration of Lady Catherine’s taste and her own happiness in having such a neighbor. She was very glad to hear of Mr. Collins’s good fortune, and was determined to tell her friends all about it.

Meanwhile, the young ladies, Elizabeth, Jane, Mary, Kitty, and Lydia, found the waiting tedious, and amused themselves with various little pursuits, till the arrival of the gentlemen, including the officers and Mr. Wickham.

At length, the door opened, and the gentlemen entered. Elizabeth’s eyes immediately sought Mr. Wickham, and she was not disappointed. She thought him looking remarkably well, and his manner was so easy and pleasant that she could not help feeling a high opinion of him. She observed that he was even more distinguished in his appearance than the other officers, and his manners were so much more engaging than those of the others, that she thought him quite the gentleman.

Mr. Collins, who had been examining the room with great admiration, was struck by the size and richness of the furniture, and compared it in his mind to the small, less elegant room at Rosings, which he considered a very inferior place. He then turned to Mrs. Philips, and, in a tone of great satisfaction, described the grandeur of Rosings, mentioning the expensive chimney-piece and the fine furniture, which he thought very superior to what they had at Hunsford.

Mrs. Philips listened attentively, and, when Mr. Collins had finished, expressed her pleasure at hearing about Lady Catherine’s estate and her own happiness in having such a neighbor. She was quite eager to see Rosings herself, and to enjoy the splendor of the place.

The girls, meanwhile, grew impatient with the slow progress of the conversation, and began to look around the room, examining the pictures and ornaments, and whispering to each other about the different objects.

Finally, the officers and Mr. Wickham approached, and Elizabeth’s eyes were immediately fixed on him. She observed that he looked very well, and that his manner was so easy and engaging that she felt her opinion of him was confirmed. She thought him more distinguished than the other officers, and certainly more so than her uncle Philips, who was a very respectable man, but not remarkable in appearance or manner.

events.title: Wickham Engages Elizabeth while Collins Plays Whist
detailed_summary: Mr. Wickham captures the attention of most women in the room and chooses to sit beside Elizabeth.
He initiates conversation easily, impressing Elizabeth with his ability to make even mundane topics like the weather engaging.
Compared to the charismatic Wickham and the officers, Mr. Collins fades into the background for the younger ladies.
However, Collins finds an attentive audience in Mrs. Philips, who ensures he is well-cared for with refreshments.
When card tables are set up, Collins obliges Mrs. Philips by agreeing to play whist, intending to improve his skills for social advancement.
Mrs. Philips accepts his offer without waiting for his full reasoning.
Mr. Wickham opts out of whist and joins Elizabeth and Lydia at another table.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mr. Wickham was the happy man towards whom almost every female eye was turned, and Elizabeth was the happy woman by whom he finally seated himself; and the agreeable manner in which he immediately fell into conversation, though it was only on its being a wet night, and on the probability of a rainy season, made her feel that the commonest, dullest, most threadbare topic might be rendered interesting by the skill of the speaker.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mr. Wickham did not play at whist, and with ready delight was he received at the other table between Elizabeth and Lydia.

events.text_segment:
Mr. Wickham was the happy man towards whom almost every female eye was turned, and Elizabeth was the happy woman by whom he finally seated himself; and the agreeable manner in which he immediately fell into conversation, though it was only on its being a wet night, and on the probability of a rainy season, made her feel that the commonest, dullest, most threadbare topic might be rendered interesting by the skill of the speaker.
With such rivals for the notice of the fair as Mr. Wickham and the officers, Mr. Collins seemed to sink into insignificance; to the young ladies he certainly was nothing; but he had still at intervals a kind listener in Mrs. Philips, and was, by her watchfulness, most abundantly supplied with coffee and muffin.
When the card tables were placed, he had an opportunity of obliging her, in return, by sitting down to whist.
“I know little of the game at present,” said he, “but I shall be glad to improve myself; for in my situation of life——” Mrs. Philips was very thankful for his compliance, but could not wait for his reason.
Mr. Wickham did not play at whist, and with ready delight was he received at the other table between Elizabeth and Lydia.

events.title: Wickham Initiates Conversation about Mr. Darcy
detailed_summary: Initially, Lydia dominates the conversation with Wickham due to her talkative nature.
However, her fascination with the lottery ticket game soon distracts her, leaving Wickham free to converse with Elizabeth.
Elizabeth is eager to talk with Wickham, particularly hoping to learn about his history with Mr. Darcy, though she hesitates to bring up the subject.
Wickham unexpectedly broaches the topic himself by asking about Netherfield's distance from Meryton.
He then cautiously inquires how long Mr. Darcy has been residing at Netherfield.
Elizabeth responds, adding that she understands Darcy possesses a large estate in Derbyshire.
Wickham confirms this, mentioning Darcy's significant income and revealing his own long-standing, specific connection to the Darcy family since infancy.
This revelation visibly surprises Elizabeth.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At first there seemed danger of Lydia’s engrossing him entirely, for she was a most determined talker; but being likewise extremely fond of lottery tickets, she soon grew too much interested in the game, too eager in making bets and exclaiming after prizes, to have attention for anyone in particular.

events.text_segment:
At first there seemed danger of Lydia’s engrossing him entirely, for she was a most determined talker; but being likewise extremely fond of lottery tickets, she soon grew too much interested in the game, too eager in making bets and exclaiming after prizes, to have attention for anyone in particular. Allowing for the common demands of the game, Mr. Wickham was therefore at leisure to talk to Elizabeth, and she was very willing to hear him, though what she chiefly wished to hear she could not hope to be told, the history of his acquaintance with Mr. Darcy. She dared not even mention that gentleman. Her curiosity, however, was unexpectedly relieved. Mr. Wickham began the subject himself. He inquired how far Netherfield was from Meryton; and, after receiving her answer, asked in a hesitating manner how long Mr. Darcy had been staying there.
“About a month,” said Elizabeth; and then, unwilling to let the subject drop, added, “he is a man of very large property in Derbyshire, I understand.”
“Yes,” replied Wickham; “his estate there is a noble one. A clear ten thousand per annum. You could not have met with a person more capable of giving you certain information on that head than myself—for I have been connected with his family, in a particular manner, from my infancy.”
Elizabeth could not but look surprised.

Elizabeth looked surprised at this revelation, her curiosity deepening as she considered the connection between the two men.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “You may well be surprised, Miss Bennet, at such an assertion, after seeing, as you probably might, the very cold manner of our meeting yesterday.

events.text_segment:
“You may well be surprised, Miss Bennet, at such an assertion, after seeing, as you probably might, the very cold manner of our meeting yesterday. Are you much acquainted with Mr. Darcy?”
“As much as I ever wish to be,” cried Elizabeth, warmly. “I have spent four days in the same house with him, and I think him very disagreeable.”
“I have no right to give my opinion,” said Wickham, “as to his being agreeable or otherwise. I am not qualified to form one. I have known him too long and too well to be a fair judge. It is impossible for me to be impartial. But I believe your opinion of him would in general astonish—and, perhaps, you would not express it quite so strongly anywhere else. Here you are in your own family.”
“Upon my word I say no more here than I might say in any house in the neighbourhood, except Netherfield. He is not at all liked in Hertfordshire. Everybody is disgusted with his pride. You will not find him more favourably spoken of by anyone.”
“I cannot pretend to be sorry,” said Wickham, after a short interruption, “that he or that any man should not be estimated beyond their deserts; but with him I believe it does not often happen. The world is blinded by his fortune and consequence, or frightened by his high and imposing manners, and sees him only as he chooses to be seen.”
“I should take him, even on my slight acquaintance, to be an ill-tempered man.”
Wickham only shook his head.
“I wonder,” said he, at the next opportunity of speaking, “whether he is likely to be in this country much longer.”
“I do not at all know; but I heard nothing of his going away when I was at Netherfield. I hope your plans in favour of the ——shire will not be affected by his being in the neighbourhood.”
“Oh no—it is not for me to be driven away by Mr. Darcy. If he wishes to avoid seeing me he must go. We are not on friendly terms, and it always gives me pain to meet him, but I have no reason for avoiding him but what I might proclaim to all the world—a sense of very great ill-usage, and most painful regrets at his being what he is. His father, Miss Bennet, the late Mr. Darcy, was one of the best men that ever breathed, and the truest friend I ever had; and I can never be in company with this Mr. Darcy without being grieved to the soul by a thousand tender recollections. His behaviour to myself has been scandalous; but I verily believe I could forgive him anything and everything, rather than his disappointing the hopes and disgracing the memory of his father.”
Elizabeth found the interest of the subject increase, and listened with all her heart; but the delicacy of it prevented further inquiry.
Mr. Wickham began to speak on more general topics, Meryton, the neighbourhood, the society, appearing highly pleased with all that he had yet seen, and speaking of the latter, especially, with gentle but very intelligible gallantry.
“It was the prospect of constant society, and good society,” he added, “which was my chief inducement to enter the ——shire. I know it to be a most respectable, agreeable corps; and my friend Denny tempted me further by his account of their present quarters, and the very great attentions and excellent acquaintance Meryton had procured them. Society, I own, is necessary to me. I have been a disappointed man, and my spirits will not bear solitude. I must have employment and society. A military life is not what I was intended for, but circumstances have now made it eligible. The church ought to have been my profession—I was brought up for the church; and I should at this time have been in possession of a most valuable living, had it pleased the gentleman we were speaking of just now.”
“Indeed!”
“Yes—the late Mr. Darcy bequeathed me the next presentation of the best living in his gift. He was my godfather, and excessively attached to me. I cannot do justice to his kindness. He meant to provide for me amply, and thought he had done it; but when the living fell, it was given elsewhere.”
“Good heavens!” cried Elizabeth; “but how could that be? How could his will be disregarded? Why did not you seek legal redress?”
“There was just such an informality in the terms of the bequest as to give me no hope from law. A man of honour could not have doubted the intention, but Mr. Darcy chose to doubt it—or to treat it as a merely conditional recommendation, and to assert that I had forfeited all claim to it by extravagance, imprudence, in short, anything or nothing. Certain it is that the living became vacant two years ago, exactly as I was of an age to hold it, and that it was given to another man; and no less certain is it, that I cannot accuse myself of having really done anything to deserve to lose it. I have a warm unguarded temper, and I may perhaps have sometimes spoken my opinion of him, and to him, too freely. I can recall nothing worse. But the fact is, that we are very different sort of men, and that he hates me.”
“This is quite shocking! He deserves to be publicly disgraced.”
“Some time or other he will be—but it shall not be by me. Till I can forget his father, I can never defy or expose him.”
Elizabeth honoured him for such feelings, and thought him handsomer than ever as he expressed them.

events.text_segment:
“But what,” said she, after a pause, “can have been his motive? what can have induced him to behave so cruelly?”
“A thorough, determined dislike of me—a dislike which I cannot but attribute in some measure to jealousy. Had the late Mr. Darcy liked me less, his son might have borne with me better; but his father’s uncommon attachment to me irritated him, I believe, very early in life. He had not a temper to bear the sort of competition in which we stood—the sort of preference which was often given me.”
“I had not thought Mr. Darcy so bad as this—though I have never liked him, I had not thought so very ill of him—I had supposed him to be despising his fellow-creatures in general, but did not suspect him of descending to such malicious revenge, such injustice, such inhumanity as this!”
After a few minutes’ reflection, however, she continued, “I do remember his boasting one day, at Netherfield, of the implacability of his resentments, of his having an unforgiving temper. His disposition must be dreadful.”
“I will not trust myself on the subject,” replied Wickham; “I can hardly be just to him.”
Elizabeth was again deep in thought, and after a time exclaimed, “To treat in such a manner the godson, the friend, the favourite of his father!” She could have added, “A young man, too, like you, whose very countenance may vouch for your being amiable.” But she contented herself with—“And one, too, who had probably been his own companion from childhood, connected together, as I think you said, in the closest manner.”
“We were born in the same parish, within the same park; the greatest part of our youth was passed together: inmates of the same house, sharing the same amusements, objects of the same parental care. My father began life in the profession which your uncle, Mr. Philips, appears to do so much credit to; but he gave up everything to be of use to the late Mr. Darcy, and devoted all his time to the care of the Pemberley property. He was most highly esteemed by Mr. Darcy, a most intimate, confidential friend. Mr. Darcy often acknowledged himself to be under the greatest obligations to my father’s active superintendence; and when, immediately before my father’s death, Mr. Darcy gave him a voluntary promise of providing for me, I am convinced that he felt it to be as much a debt of gratitude to him as of affection to myself.”
“How strange!” cried Elizabeth. “How abominable! I wonder that the very pride of this Mr. Darcy has not made him just to you. If from no better motive, that he should not have been too proud to be dishonest,—for dishonesty I must call it.”
“It is wonderful,” replied Wickham; “for almost all his actions may be traced to pride; and pride has often been his best friend. It has connected him nearer with virtue than any other feeling. But we are none of us consistent; and in his behaviour to me there were stronger impulses even than pride.”
“Can such abominable pride as his have ever done him good?”
“Yes; it has often led him to be liberal and generous; to give his money freely, to display hospitality, to assist his tenants, and relieve the poor. Family pride, and filial pride, for he is very proud of what his father was, have done this. Not to appear to disgrace his family, to degenerate from the popular qualities, or lose the influence of the Pemberley House, is a powerful motive. He has also brotherly pride, which, with some brotherly affection, makes him a very kind and careful guardian of his sister; and you will hear him generally cried up as the most attentive and best of brothers.”
“What sort of a girl is Miss Darcy?”
He shook his head. “I wish I could call her amiable. It gives me pain to speak ill of a Darcy; but she is too much like her brother,—very, very proud. As a child, she was affectionate and pleasing, and extremely fond of me; and I have devoted hours and hours to her amusement. But she is nothing to me now. She is a handsome girl, about fifteen or sixteen, and, I understand, highly accomplished. Since her father’s death her home has been London, where a lady lives with her, and superintends her education.”

**CHAPTER XVI.**

“*But what,*” said she, after a pause, “*can have been his motive?*”

Elizabeth Bennet looked thoughtfully across the room, her brow slightly furrowed as she pondered the complexities of Darcy's actions. She had long admired his proud demeanor, yet recent revelations cast a shadow over her perceptions. Her mind raced through the conversations she had with Wickham, trying to piece together the motives behind Darcy's seemingly cruel behavior.

Wickham, with a mixture of disdain and regret, attributed Darcy's conduct to a deep-seated dislike, possibly fueled by jealousy over the late Mr. Darcy's strong affection for him. He suggested that Darcy couldn't handle the perceived competition and paternal preference shown towards Wickham, which might have ignited a bitter resentment.

Elizabeth's disdain for Darcy grew. She previously saw him as proud but not capable of such maliciousness and injustice. She recalled Darcy boasting about his unforgiving nature at Netherfield, which only reinforced her negative view. Wickham, declining to elaborate further, admitted he could hardly be fair to Darcy, yet he reflected on Darcy's treatment of his father's godson and friend.

She remembered that they had shared a common upbringing, born in the same parish and growing up together. Wickham elaborated on their connection, mentioning his own father was steward of the Pemberley estate and a highly esteemed, confidential friend of the late Mr. Darcy. He stated that Darcy felt obliged to provide for Wickham out of both affection and gratitude towards Wickham's father.

Elizabeth found the situation abominable, questioning why Darcy's pride didn't compel him to act justly, calling his actions dishonest. Wickham noted the inconsistency, as pride usually guides Darcy towards virtuous actions like generosity and fulfilling family duties. He suggested that stronger impulses than pride influenced Darcy's behavior towards him.

Elizabeth questioned whether Darcy's pride could ever be beneficial. Wickham confirmed that it sometimes led to positive actions such as liberality, hospitality, and care for tenants, driven by family and filial pride. He added that brotherly pride and affection made Darcy a careful guardian of his sister.

Curious about Miss Darcy's character, Elizabeth asked. Wickham hesitated, expressing reluctance to speak ill of a Darcy, but described her as very proud, much like her brother. He mentioned she was fond of him as a child but is now distant. He noted she is handsome, accomplished, about fifteen or sixteen, and resides in London under a governess's care since her father's death.

---

This segment aligns with the opening line and the detailed summary, capturing the key events and character insights as described.

events.title: Questioning Darcy's Friendship with Bingley
detailed_summary: Elizabeth returns to the subject of Darcy, expressing astonishment at his close friendship with the good-natured Mr. Bingley.
She questions how such different personalities can be friends and asks if Wickham knows Bingley.
Wickham states he does not know Bingley.
Elizabeth describes Bingley as amiable and charming, suggesting he must be unaware of Darcy's true nature.
Wickham concedes this possibility but adds that Darcy possesses the ability to please when he chooses and is capable of being a good companion.

He explains that Darcy behaves differently towards social equals compared to those less prosperous, showing qualities like liberality, sincerity, and agreeableness among the wealthy, although his pride remains constant.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: His pride never deserts him; but with the rich he is liberal-minded, just, sincere, rational, honourable, and, perhaps, agreeable,—allowing something for fortune and figure.”

events.text_segment:
After many pauses and many trials of other subjects, Elizabeth could not help reverting once more to the first, and saying,—
“I am astonished at his intimacy with Mr. Bingley. How can Mr. Bingley, who seems good-humour itself, and is, I really believe, truly amiable, be in friendship with such a man? How can they suit each other? Do you know Mr. Bingley?”
“Not at all.”
“He is a sweet-tempered, amiable, charming man. He cannot know what Mr. Darcy is.”
“Probably not; but Mr. Darcy can please where he chooses. He does not want abilities. He can be a conversible companion if he thinks it worth his while. Among those who are at all his equals in consequence, he is a very different man from what he is to the less prosperous. His pride never deserts him; but with the rich he is liberal-minded, just, sincere, rational, honourable, and, perhaps, agreeable,—allowing something for fortune and figure.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: After many pauses and many trials of other subjects, Elizabeth could not help reverting once more to the first, and saying,—"But you do not mean to say that you know Mr. Bingley personally?" Wickham looked a little ashamed of his own deception, and said, "I do not know him myself, but I have heard of him, and I believe he is a very amiable young man." Elizabeth was surprised to find that she was not quite so much in the dark as she had supposed, and she asked if he knew Mr. Darcy. Wickham replied that he did not, and Elizabeth, with some curiosity, inquired what sort of a man Mr. Darcy was. Wickham described him as a very proud, disagreeable man, who had treated him very ill, and who was very reserved and distant. Elizabeth was surprised to hear this, and she asked if Mr. Bingley was aware of Mr. Darcy's conduct. Wickham said he believed Mr. Bingley was not, and that he himself had no opportunity of knowing much about Mr. Darcy, but that he had heard he was a very proud and disagreeable man, and that he was very glad to be rid of him.

detailed_summary: The whist game concludes, and the players, including Mr. Collins, join the others.

events.text_segment:
The whist party soon afterwards breaking up, the players gathered round the other table, and Mr. Collins took his station between his cousin Elizabeth and Mrs. Philips. The usual inquiries as to his success were made by the latter. It had not been very great; he had lost every point; but when Mrs. Philips began to express her concern thereupon, he assured her, with much earnest gravity, that it was not of the least importance; that he considered the money as a mere trifle, and begged she would not make herself uneasy.
“I know very well, madam,” said he, “that when persons sit down to a card table they must take their chance of these things,—and happily I am not in such circumstances as to make five shillings any object. There are, undoubtedly, many who could not say the same; but, thanks to Lady Catherine de Bourgh, I am removed far beyond the necessity of regarding little matters.”
Mr. Wickham’s attention was caught; and after observing Mr. Collins for a few moments, he asked Elizabeth in a low voice whether her relations were very intimately acquainted with the family of De Bourgh.
“Lady Catherine de Bourgh,” she replied, “has very lately given him a living. I hardly know how Mr. Collins was first introduced to her notice, but he certainly has not known her long.”
“You know of course that Lady Catherine de Bourgh and Lady Anne Darcy were sisters; consequently that she is aunt to the present Mr. Darcy.”
“No, indeed, I did not. I knew nothing at all of Lady Catherine’s connections. I never heard of her existence till the day before yesterday.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
The whist party soon afterwards breaking up, the players gathered round the other table, and Mr. Collins took his station between his cousin Elizabeth and Mrs. Philips. 

"Well, Collins," said Mrs. Philips, "how did you get on? Did you win much?"

"Oh! dear, no," replied Mr. Collins; "I am a most unfortunate player. I have not had the good luck to gain a single point."

"Then you have lost every game?" said Mrs. Philips.

"Yes, I have lost every point; but I do not care about that. I am quite comfortable, and Lady Catherine de Bourgh has been very kind to me."

"I am glad to hear it," said Mrs. Philips. "I suppose you are quite at home now in your new situation."

"Yes, I am very much obliged to Lady Catherine. She is a very kind lady."

Wickham, who had been quietly observing the conversation, now looked up and said, "I suppose Lady Catherine and Lady Anne Darcy are well acquainted?"

Elizabeth turned to him with a smile. "Lady Catherine recently granted Mr. Collins his living, but I believe their acquaintance is quite new."

"Indeed," said Wickham, "Lady Catherine and the late Lady Anne Darcy, Mr. Darcy's mother, were sisters. That makes Lady Catherine Darcy his aunt."

Elizabeth looked surprised. "I had no idea of that connection until very lately," she said.

events.text_segment:
“Her daughter, Miss de Bourgh, will have a very large fortune, and it is believed that she and her cousin will unite the two estates.”
This information made Elizabeth smile, as she thought of poor Miss Bingley. Vain indeed must be all her attentions, vain and useless her affection for his sister and her praise of himself, if he were already self-destined to another.
“Mr. Collins,” said she, “speaks highly both of Lady Catherine and her daughter; but, from some particulars that he has related of her Ladyship, I suspect his gratitude misleads him; and that, in spite of her being his patroness, she is an arrogant, conceited woman.”
“I believe her to be both in a great degree,” replied Wickham; “I have not seen her for many years; but I very well remember that I never liked her, and that her manners were dictatorial and insolent. She has the reputation of being remarkably sensible and clever; but I rather believe she derives part of her abilities from her rank and fortune, part from her authoritative manner, and the rest from the pride of her nephew, who chooses that everyone connected with him should have an understanding of the first class.”
Elizabeth allowed that he had given a very rational account of it, and they continued talking together with mutual satisfaction till supper put an end to cards, and gave the rest of the ladies their share of Mr. Wickham’s attentions. There could be no conversation in the noise of Mrs. Philips’s supper party, but his manners recommended him to everybody. Whatever he said, was said well; and whatever he did, done gracefully. Elizabeth went away with her head full of him. She could think of nothing but of Mr. Wickham, and of what he had told her, all the way home; but there was not time for her even to mention his name as they went, for neither Lydia nor Mr. Collins were once silent. Lydia talked incessantly of lottery tickets, of the fish she had lost and the fish she had won; and Mr. Collins, in describing the civility of Mr. and Mrs. Philips, protesting that he did not in the least regard his losses at whist, enumerating all the dishes at supper, and repeatedly fearing that he crowded his cousins, had more to say than he could well manage before the carriage stopped at Longbourn House.

Mrs. Bennet was particularly eager to see her daughter, Jane, married to Mr. Bingley, whose affections she was convinced were already engaged. She often spoke of the advantages of such a match, especially considering the substantial fortune that Miss de Bourgh was to inherit. The prospect of uniting the two estates through the marriage of Miss de Bourgh and her cousin, Mr. Darcy, was a matter of great interest and speculation among the neighborhood. Lady Catherine de Bourgh, Miss de Bourgh's mother, was a woman of high pride and considerable influence, and her opinions on the matter were well known. She was determined that her daughter should marry well, and her expectations were that Mr. Darcy, being a man of wealth and status, would be an ideal match.

Elizabeth Bennet, however, was not so easily convinced of the advantages of such arrangements. She observed the interactions between her sister Jane and Mr. Bingley with a keen eye, noting the genuine affection that seemed to exist between them. She was skeptical of the importance placed on wealth and titles, believing that true happiness in marriage depended on mutual respect and understanding.

Meanwhile, Mr. Collins, the clergyman and heir to the Bennet estate, was eager to secure a good match himself, often speaking of Lady Catherine's influence and the importance of social standing. He was particularly interested in the prospect of marrying one of the Bennet daughters, seeing it as a means to improve his own prospects.

As the social season progressed, the various families in the area continued to discuss and speculate about the potential unions. The idea of uniting the estates through marriage was a common theme, reflecting the importance placed on alliances and property in their society. Elizabeth, observing all this, remained somewhat skeptical of the emphasis on wealth and status, hoping that her own choices would be guided by her feelings rather than societal expectations.

events.title: Elizabeth Informs Jane of Wickham's Accusations
detailed_summary: Elizabeth recounts her conversation with Mr. Wickham to Jane, detailing his claims against Mr. Darcy.

Jane reacts with shock and distress, finding it hard to accept that Mr. Darcy could behave so poorly towards someone favoured by his father, yet equally reluctant to doubt the seemingly honest Mr. Wickham.

Moved by the possibility of Wickham's suffering, Jane attempts to reconcile the conflicting accounts without assigning blame, suggesting external factors like misrepresentation by others might be responsible.
Elizabeth challenges Jane's attempt to absolve everyone, pointing out that if deceit was involved, the deceivers themselves must be at fault.
Jane defends Darcy, arguing that such dishonourable conduct is incompatible with common humanity and the high regard in which his closest friends, like Mr. Bingley, hold him.

Elizabeth counters that she finds it easier to believe Bingley could be deceived about Darcy's true nature than that Wickham could fabricate such a detailed and specific story, citing his convincing demeanor.
Jane admits the situation is confusing and distressing, uncertain of what conclusion to draw.
Elizabeth firmly states that, in her view, the correct conclusion is obvious.
Jane, however, can only focus on the painful consequences for Mr. Bingley should Wickham's story prove true and Darcy's deception become known.

events.text_segment:
Elizabeth related to Jane, the next day, what had passed between Mr. Wickham and herself. Jane listened with astonishment and concern: she knew not how to believe that Mr. Darcy could be so unworthy of Mr. Bingley’s regard; and yet it was not in her nature to question the veracity of a young man of such amiable appearance as Wickham. The possibility of his having really endured such unkindness was enough to interest all her tender feelings; and nothing therefore remained to be done but to think well of them both, to defend the conduct of each, and throw into the account of accident or mistake whatever could not be otherwise explained.
“They have both,” said she, “been deceived, I dare say, in some way or other, of which we can form no idea. Interested people have perhaps misrepresented each to the other. It is, in short, impossible for us to conjecture the causes or circumstances which may have alienated them, without actual blame on either side.”
“Very true, indeed; and now, my dear Jane, what have you got to say in behalf of the interested people who have probably been concerned in the business? Do clear them, too, or we shall be obliged to think ill of somebody.”
“Laugh as much as you choose, but you will not laugh me out of my opinion. My dearest Lizzy, do but consider in what a disgraceful light it places Mr. Darcy, to be treating his father’s favourite in such a manner,—one whom his father had promised to provide for. It is impossible. No man of common humanity, no man who had any value for his character, could be capable of it. Can his most intimate friends be so excessively deceived in him? Oh no.”
“I can much more easily believe Mr. Bingley’s being imposed on than that Mr. Wickham should invent such a history of himself as he gave me last night; names, facts, everything mentioned without ceremony. If it be not so, let Mr. Darcy contradict it. Besides, there was truth in his looks.”
“It is difficult, indeed—it is distressing. One does not know what to think.”
“I beg your pardon;—one knows exactly what to think.”
But Jane could think with certainty on only one point,—that Mr. Bingley, if he had been imposed on, would have much to suffer when the affair became public.

events.title: Family Anticipation for the Netherfield Ball
detailed_summary: All the women in the Bennet household are excited by the upcoming Netherfield ball.
Mrs. Bennet interprets the personal invitation from Mr. Bingley as a particular compliment directed towards Jane.
Jane looks forward to spending the evening with her friends, Caroline and Louisa, and receiving attention from Mr. Bingley.
Elizabeth anticipates dancing frequently with Mr. Wickham and observing Mr. Darcy's behavior for signs confirming Wickham's account.
Catherine and Lydia are broadly enthusiastic about the ball and the opportunity to dance, including dancing with Wickham, though he isn't their sole focus.
