events.text_segment:
The prospect of the Netherfield ball was extremely agreeable to every female of the family. Mrs. Bennet chose to consider it as given in compliment to her eldest daughter, and was particularly flattered by receiving the invitation from Mr. Bingley himself, instead of a ceremonious card. Jane pictured to herself a happy evening in the society of her two friends, and the attentions of their brother; and Elizabeth thought with pleasure of dancing a great deal with Mr. Wickham, and of seeing a confirmation of everything in Mr. Darcy’s look and behaviour. The happiness anticipated by Catherine and Lydia depended less on any single event, or any particular person; for though they each, like Elizabeth, meant to dance half the evening with Mr. Wickham, he was by no means the only partner who could satisfy them, and a ball was, at any rate, a ball. And even Mary could assure her family that she had no disinclination for it.
“While I can have my mornings to myself,” said she, “it is enough. I think it is no sacrifice to join occasionally in evening engagements.

events.title: Mr. Collins Engages Elizabeth for the First Dances
detailed_summary: Feeling cheerful about the ball, Elizabeth initiates a conversation with Mr. Collins, asking if he plans to attend and participate in the dancing.
She is surprised that he expresses no moral or professional reservations about dancing, nor any fear of disapproval from his patroness, Lady Catherine.
Mr. Collins confirms his intention to attend and dance, stating his belief that such a ball, hosted by a respectable young man, is harmless.
He then declares his intention to dance with all his Bennet cousins and specifically asks Elizabeth to reserve the first two dances for him, explaining it as a mark of preference.
Elizabeth is dismayed by his request, having planned to dance with Mr. Wickham during that time.
Seeing no way out, she accepts Mr. Collins's proposal as politely as possible, postponing her anticipated dances with Wickham.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence:
Elizabeth’s spirits were so high on the occasion, that though she did not often speak unnecessarily to Mr. Collins, she could not help asking him whether he intended to accept Mr. Bingley’s invitation, and if he did, whether he would think it proper to join in the evening’s amusement; and she was rather surprised to find that he entertained no scruple whatever on that head, and was very far from drea
ding a rebuke, either from the Archbishop or Lady Catherine de Bourgh, by venturing to dance.

events.text_segment:
Society has claims on us all; and I profess myself one of those who consider intervals of recreation and amusement as desirable for everybody.”
Elizabeth’s spirits were so high on the occasion, that though she did not often speak unnecessarily to Mr. Collins, she could not help asking him whether he intended to accept Mr. Bingley’s invitation, and if he did, whether he would think it proper to join in the evening’s amusement; and she was rather surprised to find that he entertained no scruple whatever on that head, and was very far from dreading a rebuke, either from the Archbishop or Lady Catherine de Bourgh, by venturing to dance.
“I am by no means of opinion, I assure you,” said he, “that a ball of this kind, given by a young man of character, to respectable people, can have any evil tendency; and I am so far from objecting to dancing myself, that I shall hope to be honoured with the hands of all my fair cousins in the course of the evening; and I take this opportunity of soliciting yours, Miss Elizabeth, for the two first dances especially; a preference which I trust my cousin Jane will attribute to the right cause, and not to any disrespect for her.”
Elizabeth felt herself completely taken in. She had fully proposed being engaged by Wickham for those very dances; and to have Mr. Collins instead!—her liveliness had been never worse timed. There was no help for it, however. Mr. Wickham’s happiness and her own was perforce delayed a little longer, and Mr. Collins’s proposal accepted with as good a grace as she could.

events.text_segment: She was not the better pleased with his gallantry, from the idea it suggested of something more. It now first struck her, that she was selected from among her sisters as worthy of being the mistress of Hunsford Parsonage, and of assisting to form a quadrille table at Rosings, in the absence of more eligible visitors. The idea soon reached to conviction, as she observed his increasing civilities towards herself, and heard his frequent attempt at a compliment on her wit and vivacity; and though more astonished than gratified herself by this effect of her charms, it was not long before her mother gave her to understand that the probability of their marriage was exceedingly agreeable to her. Elizabeth, however, did not choose to take the hint, being well aware that a serious dispute must be the consequence of any reply. Mr. Collins might never make the offer, and, till he did, it was useless to quarrel about him.

Lydia and Kitty, who had been looking forward to the event with eager anticipation, found their hopes dampened by the constant downpour, which kept them confined within Longbourn. Elizabeth, too, felt the disappointment, as her plans to meet Mr. Wickham and to enjoy the social gathering were thwarted by the relentless weather. During these days, they could not visit their aunt, nor see the officers, nor even seek news of either; and Lydia and Kitty could not procure the shoe-roses for the ball, which they had intended to do. The weather was so uncommonly severe that the days—Friday, Saturday, Sunday, and Monday—were all alike, and the only thing that made the time tolerable for Kitty and Lydia was the promise of the ball on Tuesday, which they looked forward to with eager excitement.

events.title: Elizabeth's Disappointment and Anger Towards Darcy
detailed_summary: Elizabeth arrives at the Netherfield ball fully anticipating Mr. Wickham's presence, having taken extra care with her appearance for him.
Her expectation turns instantly to suspicion when she cannot find him among the officers.
She suspects Wickham was deliberately excluded from the invitation by the Bingleys to appease Mr. Darcy.
Mr. Denny confirms Wickham's absence, stating he went to town on business but implying, with a significant look only Elizabeth catches, that Wickham wished to avoid a certain gentleman (Darcy).
Elizabeth interprets this as confirmation that Darcy is responsible for Wickham's absence.
Her disappointment sharpens her existing prejudice against Darcy.
When Darcy approaches her soon after with polite inquiries, she can barely respond civilly, feeling that any politeness to Darcy is a betrayal of Wickham.
She resolves to avoid conversation with Darcy and turns away, her bad mood spilling over even into her interaction with Mr. Bingley.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Till Elizabeth entered the drawing-room at Netherfield, and looked in vain for Mr. Wickham among the cluster of red coats there assembled, a doubt of his being present had never occurred to her.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She was resolved against any sort of conversation with him, and turned away with a degree of ill-humour which she could not wholly surmount even in speaking to Mr. Bingley, whose blind partiality provoked her.

events.text_segment:
Till Elizabeth entered the drawing-room at Netherfield, and looked in vain for Mr. Wickham among the cluster of red coats there assembled, a doubt of his being present had never occurred to her. The certainty of meeting him had not been checked by any of those recollections that might not unreasonably have alarmed her. She had dressed with more than usual care, and prepared in the highest spirits for the conquest of all that remained unsubdued of his heart, trusting that it was not more than might be won in the course of the evening. But in an instant arose the dreadful suspicion of his being purposely omitted, for Mr. Darcy’s pleasure, in the Bingleys’ invitation to the officers; and though this was not exactly the case, the absolute fact of his absence was pronounced by his friend Mr. Denny, to whom Lydia eagerly applied, and who told them that Wickham had been obliged to go to town on business the day before, and was not yet returned; adding, with a significant smile,—
“I do not imagine his business would have called him away just now, if he had not wished to avoid a certain gentleman here.”
This part of his intelligence, though unheard by Lydia, was caught by Elizabeth; and, as it assured her that Darcy was not less answerable for Wickham’s absence than if her first surmise had been just, every feeling of displeasure against the former was so sharpened by immediate disappointment, that she could hardly reply with tolerable civility to the polite inquiries which he directly afterwards approached to make. Attention, forbearance, patience with Darcy, was injury to Wickham. She was resolved against any sort of conversation with him, and turned away with a degree of ill-humour which she could not wholly surmount even in speaking to Mr. Bingley, whose blind partiality provoked her.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Till Elizabeth entered the drawing-room at Netherfield, and looked in vain for Mr. Wickham among the cluster of red coats there assembled, a doubt of his being present had never occurred to her. She had been preparing herself to see him, and had even taken extra pains with her dress, in hopes of attracting his notice. But now, as she scanned the room and saw no sign of him, her heart sank a little. Her eyes then fell upon the officers, and she looked among them, but he was not there. Her disappointment was soon replaced by suspicion. She remembered that the Bingleys had invited only certain officers, and she wondered if Wickham had been deliberately excluded, perhaps to please Mr. Darcy. Mr. Denny, passing by, confirmed that Wickham was not present, saying he had gone to town on business. But his look and tone implied more, and Elizabeth caught a significant glance he cast, which she interpreted as an indication that Wickham wished to avoid a certain gentleman—namely Mr. Darcy. Her suspicions confirmed her previous prejudices, and her disappointment sharpened her feelings against Darcy. When Darcy approached her shortly after, with polite inquiries about her health and the weather, she could scarcely respond civilly, feeling that any civility to him was a betrayal of Wickham. She resolved to avoid any further conversation with him and turned away, her bad mood affecting her interactions even with Mr. Bingley.

events.title: Recovery and Mortification with Mr. Collins
detailed_summary: Elizabeth's natural disposition prevents her from staying upset for long, despite her ruined evening.
She confides her disappointment about Wickham to Charlotte Lucas.
Her attention shifts to observing her cousin, Mr. Collins, and pointing out his peculiarities to Charlotte.
Her spirits dip again during the first two dances, which she endures with Mr. Collins.
Mr. Collins proves to be an awkward and inept partner, apologizing constantly, moving incorrectly without realizing it, causing Elizabeth significant embarrassment and misery.
Finishing the dances with him brings her immense relief.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: But Elizabeth was not formed for ill-humour; and though every prospect of her own was destroyed for the evening, it could not dwell long on her spirits; and, having told all her griefs to Charlotte Lucas, whom she had not seen for a week, she was soon able to make a voluntary transition to the oddities of her cousin, and to point him out to her particular notice.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The moment of her release from him was ecstasy.

events.text_segment: But Elizabeth was not formed for ill-humour; and though every prospect of her own was destroyed for the evening, it could not dwell long on her spirits; and, having told all her griefs to Charlotte Lucas, whom she had not seen for a week, she was soon able to make a voluntary transition to the oddities of her cousin, and to point him out to her particular notice. The two first dances, however, brought a return of distress: they were dances of mortification. Mr. Collins, awkward and solemn, apologizing instead of attending, and often moving wrong without being aware of it, gave her all the shame and misery which a disagreeable partner for a couple of dances can give. The moment of her release from him was ecstasy.

events.title: Darcy's Unexpected Request to Dance
detailed_summary: Elizabeth enjoys her next dance with an officer, finding solace in discussing Wickham and hearing positive opinions about him.
After the dances, while speaking with Charlotte Lucas, Mr. Darcy suddenly approaches and asks Elizabeth to dance.
Caught completely by surprise, Elizabeth accepts his offer without thinking.
Darcy walks away immediately, leaving Elizabeth to regret her lack of composure.
Charlotte attempts to console her, suggesting she might find Darcy agreeable.
Elizabeth vehemently rejects this idea, declaring that finding agreeableness in a man she's determined to hate would be the worst possible outcome.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Do not wish me such an evil.”

events.text_segment:
She danced next with an officer, and had the refreshment of talking of Wickham, and of hearing that he was universally liked. When those dances were over, she returned to Charlotte Lucas, and was in conversation with her, when she found herself suddenly addressed by Mr. Darcy, who took her so much by surprise in his application for her hand, that, without knowing what she did, she accepted him. He walked away again immediately, and she was left to fret over her own want of presence of mind: Charlotte tried to console her.
“I dare say you will find him very agreeable.”
“Heaven forbid! That would be the greatest misfortune of all! To find a man agreeable whom one is determined to hate! Do not wish me such an evil.”

events.text_segment:
When the dancing recommenced, however, and Darcy approached to claim her hand, Charlotte could not help cautioning her, in a whisper, not to be a simpleton, and allow her fancy for Wickham to make her appear unpleasant in the eyes of a man often times his consequence. Elizabeth made no answer, and took her place in the set, amazed at the dignity to which she was arrived in being allowed to stand opposite to Mr. Darcy, and reading in her neighbours’ looks their equal amazement in beholding it. They stood for some time without speaking a word; and she began to imagine that their silence was to last through the two dances, and, at first, was resolved not to break it; till suddenly fancying that it would be the greater punishment to her partner to oblige him to talk, she made some slight observation on the dance. He replied, and was again silent. After a pause of some minutes, she addressed him a second time, with—
“It is your turn to say something now, Mr. Darcy. I talked about the dance, and you ought to make some kind of remark on the size of the room, or the number of couples.”
He smiled, and assured her that whatever she wished him to say should be said.
“Very well; that reply will do for the present. Perhaps, by-and-by, I may observe that private balls are much pleasanter than public ones; but now we may be silent.”
“Do you talk by rule, then, while you are dancing?”
“Sometimes. One must speak a little, you know. It would look odd to be entirely silent for half an hour together; and yet, for the advantage of some, conversation ought to be so arranged as that they may have the trouble of saying as little as possible.”
“Are you consulting your own feelings in the present case, or do you imagine that you are gratifying mine?”
“Both,” replied Elizabeth archly; “for I have always seen a great similarity in the turn of our minds. We are each of an unsocial, taciturn disposition, unwilling to speak, unless we expect to say something that will amaze the whole room, and be handed down to posterity with all the éclat of a proverb.”
“This is no very striking resemblance of your own character, I am sure,” said he. “How near it may be to mine, I cannot pretend to say. You think it a faithful portrait, undoubtedly.”
“I must not decide on my own performance.”
He made no answer; and they were again silent till they had gone down the dance, when he asked her if she and her sisters did not very often walk to Meryton. She answered in the affirmative; and, unable to resist the temptation, added, “When you met us there the other day, we had just been forming a new acquaintance.”
The effect was immediate. A deeper shade of hauteur overspread his features, but he said not a word; and Elizabeth, though blaming herself for her own weakness, could not go on. At length Darcy spoke, and in a constrained manner said,—
“Mr. Wickham is blessed with such happy manners as may insure his making friends; whether he may be equally capable of retaining them, is less certain.”
“He has been so unlucky as to lose your friendship,” replied Elizabeth, with emphasis, “and in a manner which he is likely to suffer from all his life.”
Darcy made no answer, and seemed desirous of changing the subject. At that moment Sir William Lucas appeared close to them, meaning to pass through the set to the other side of the room; but, on perceiving Mr. Darcy, he stopped, with a bow of superior courtesy, to compliment him on his dancing and his partner.
“I have been most highly gratified, indeed, my dear sir; such very superior dancing is not often seen. It is evident that you belong to the first circles. Allow me to say, however, that your fair partner does not disgrace you: and that I must hope to have this pleasure often repeated, especially when a certain desirable event, my dear Miss Eliza (glancing at her sister and Bingley), shall take place. What congratulations will then flow in! I appeal to Mr. Darcy;—but let me not interrupt you, sir. You will not thank me for detaining you from the bewitching converse of that young lady, whose bright eyes are also upbraiding me.”
The latter part of this address was scarcely heard by Darcy; but Sir William’s allusion to his friend seemed to strike him forcibly, and his eyes were directed, with a very serious expression, towards Bingley and Jane, who were dancing together. Recovering himself, however, shortly, he turned to his partner, and said,—
“Sir William’s interruption has made me forget what we were talking of.”
“I do not think we were speaking at all. Sir William could not have interrupted any two people in the room who had less to say for themselves. We have tried two or three subjects already without success, and what we are to talk of next I cannot imagine.”
“What think you of books?” said he, smiling.
“Books—oh no!—I am sure we never read the same, or not with the same feelings.”
“I am sorry you think so; but if that be the case, there can at least be no want of subject. We may compare our different opinions.”
“No—I cannot talk of books in a ball-room; my head is always full of something else.”
“The present always occupies you in such scenes—does it?” said he, with a look of doubt.
“Yes, always,” she replied, without knowing what she said; for her thoughts had wandered far from the subject, as soon afterwards appeared by her suddenly exclaiming, “I remember hearing you once say, Mr. Darcy, that you hardly ever forgave;—that your resentment, once created, was unappeasable. You are very cautious, I suppose, as to its being created?”
“I am,” said he, with a firm voice.
“And never allow yourself to be blinded by prejudice?”
“I hope not.”
“It is particularly incumbent on those who never change their opinion, to be secure of judging properly at first.”
“May I ask to what these questions tend?”
“Merely to the illustration of your character,” said she, endeavouring to shake off her gravity. “I am trying to make it out.”
“And what is your success?”
She shook her head. “I do not get on at all. I hear such different accounts of you as puzzle me exceedingly.”
“I can readily believe,” answered he, gravely, “that reports may vary greatly with respect to me; and I could wish, Miss Bennet, that you were not to sketch my character at the present moment, as there is reason to fear that the performance would reflect no credit on either.”
“But if I do not take your likeness now, I may never have another opportunity.”
“I would by no means suspend any pleasure of yours,” he coldly replied. She said no more, and they went down the other dance and parted in silence; on each side dissatisfied, though not to an equal degree; for in Darcy’s breast there was a tolerably powerful feeling towards her, which soon procured her pardon, and directed all his anger against another.

Not willing to be the first to speak again, Elizabeth prompted him, suggesting they might talk about the room or the number of dancers. Darcy smiled and said he was at her disposal, and they bantered about the rules of conversation during dancing, with Elizabeth archly suggesting that perhaps they shared a taciturn nature, only speaking to impress.

Darcy disputed this, but Elizabeth thought it might be true of herself, and perhaps of him as well. After another silence, Darcy asked if she and her sisters often walked to Meryton, to which Elizabeth confirmed and then, deliberately provoking him, mentioned their recent meeting there, when they had just made Wickham's acquaintance. Darcy's expression darkened, but he said nothing.

Elizabeth regretted her remark but could not continue, and Darcy, after a moment, observed that Wickham was quick to make friends but less so to keep them. Elizabeth retorted pointedly that Wickham was unlucky to have lost Darcy's friendship in a way that would likely affect him for life. Darcy made no reply and seemed eager to change the subject.

Sir William Lucas then interrupted, complimenting Darcy on his dancing and his partner, Elizabeth, and alluding to the expected engagement between Bingley and Jane. Darcy was visibly struck by the mention of Bingley and Jane, watching them seriously. Recovering, he said Sir William's interruption had made him forget their previous topic. Elizabeth remarked that they had little to say anyway, and Darcy suggested they discuss books, but Elizabeth dismissed the idea, saying her head was full of other things at a ball.

He asked if the present moment always occupied her in such scenes, and Elizabeth, distracted, suddenly recalled Darcy's remark that he rarely forgave, and asked if he was cautious about forming resentments and never blinded by prejudice. Darcy confirmed he was cautious and hoped to avoid prejudice. Elizabeth observed that those who never changed their opinion must be sure of their initial judgment.

When Darcy asked the purpose of her questions, she explained she was trying to understand his character but was puzzled by conflicting accounts. Darcy acknowledged that reports about him varied and suggested it might be better if she did not try to sketch his character at that moment. Elizabeth insisted she might not have another chance, and Darcy coldly permitted her to proceed with any 'pleasure' she might derive from it.

They finished the dance and parted in silence, mutually dissatisfied, though Darcy's feelings for her softened his displeasure.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Elizabeth, who had been observing the scene with a mixture of amusement and concern, turned her attention back to her sister. She knew well the feelings that Elizabeth harbored for Mr. Darcy, and she understood the delicate situation that Charlotte was trying to navigate. As Darcy extended his hand to Elizabeth, she took it with a composed smile, determined to maintain her dignity despite the fluttering of her heart.

The dance was lively, and the music seemed to lift the spirits of all present. Elizabeth found herself engaged in conversation with Darcy, whose manners were as impeccable as ever, yet whose eyes betrayed a hint of nervousness. They spoke of the weather, of the recent visits to the estates, and of the general state of society. Elizabeth was careful to keep her tone light and her words polite, aware of the importance of first impressions.

Meanwhile, Charlotte watched from a distance, her expression a mixture of concern and quiet resolve. She knew Elizabeth's feelings for Mr. Darcy, and she hoped that her words would not have been misunderstood. She had only wished to advise prudence, to prevent Elizabeth from rushing into a situation that might not be advantageous.

As the dance progressed, Elizabeth found herself increasingly captivated by Darcy's conversation. His voice was steady and his manner respectful, yet there was an underlying warmth that she could not ignore. She wondered if he truly cared for her, or if his attentions were merely the result of social obligation. The question lingered in her mind, unspoken but persistent.

The music came to an end, and Darcy offered Elizabeth his arm to lead her to the side of the room. They paused near a window, where the cool evening air provided a welcome respite from the crowded ballroom. Darcy looked at Elizabeth with a mixture of admiration and apprehension.

"Miss Bennet," he began, hesitating slightly, "I must confess that I have long admired your wit and your intelligence. It is a rare pleasure to converse with someone of your caliber."

Elizabeth blushed, feeling a flush rise to her cheeks. "Mr. Darcy, I am flattered by your words, but I must admit that I have often found your manner somewhat reserved."

He smiled, a genuine and warm expression that reached his eyes. "Indeed, I have been accused of being proud, and perhaps I have been guilty of it at times. But I assure you, my regard for you is sincere."

Elizabeth looked away, uncertain of how to respond. She was aware of the social expectations that governed their interactions, yet she also sensed a genuine affection beneath Darcy's formal exterior.

Meanwhile, Charlotte continued to observe from a distance, her mind racing with thoughts. She knew Elizabeth's feelings for Darcy, and she hoped that her advice had not caused any harm. She also wondered about Wickham, whose charm and wit had captivated Elizabeth earlier in the evening.

As the evening wore on, Elizabeth found herself increasingly drawn to Darcy. Their conversation flowed effortlessly, and she felt a sense of connection that she had not anticipated. She was aware of the watchful eyes of others, but in that moment, nothing else seemed to matter.

The dance eventually drew to a close, and Elizabeth excused herself to find her sister Jane. She sought out Charlotte, who was standing near the refreshments, and shared a quiet smile with her.

"Thank you for your advice," Elizabeth whispered. "I believe I shall take it to heart."

Charlotte nodded, her expression gentle. "Sometimes, a little caution is wise. But I am glad to see you enjoying yourself."

Elizabeth looked around the room, noting the various couples engaged in conversation or dance. She felt a renewed sense of hope and anticipation, wondering what the future might hold for her and Mr. Darcy.

As the evening drew to a close, Elizabeth and her family prepared to leave. Darcy approached once more, offering his arm to her. She accepted, feeling a flutter of excitement and nervousness.

On their way out, Darcy paused and looked at Elizabeth with a serious expression. "Miss Bennet, I hope that we may have the opportunity to converse again soon."

Elizabeth smiled, her heart pounding. "I should like that very much, Mr. Darcy."

They parted ways with a mutual understanding, each pondering the possibilities that lay ahead. Elizabeth felt a newfound confidence, and she resolved to be true to her feelings, regardless of societal expectations.

As she walked home that night, Elizabeth reflected on the events of the evening. She realized that her perceptions of Darcy had begun to change, and she wondered if he might be the partner she had been seeking all along. The future was uncertain, but she was no longer afraid to embrace it.

events.title: Miss Bingley's Scornful Warning about Wickham
detailed_summary: Shortly after her dance with Darcy, Miss Bingley approaches Elizabeth with barely concealed contempt.
She remarks that Elizabeth seems quite taken with George Wickham, mentioning that Jane has been asking questions about him.
Miss Bingley reveals information Wickham supposedly omitted: that he is the son of the late Mr. Darcy's steward.
She advises Elizabeth, 'as a friend', not to trust Wickham's assertions, claiming his accusations against Darcy are false.
Miss Bingley asserts that Darcy was always kind to Wickham, whereas Wickham treated Darcy infamously.
She states Darcy cannot bear Wickham's name mentioned and was glad Wickham avoided the ball, considering his presence in the area insolent.
She expresses mock pity for Elizabeth learning about Wickham's 'guilt', suggesting his low birth implies bad character.
Elizabeth retorts angrily that Miss Bingley has accused Wickham of nothing worse than being a steward's son, a fact Wickham himself had already told her.
Miss Bingley sneers, apologizes sarcastically for her 'kindly meant' interference, and walks away.
Elizabeth inwardly fumes, dismissing Miss Bingley's words as ignorant and malicious, likely influenced by Darcy.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: They had not long separated when Miss Bingley came towards her, and, with an expression of civil disdain, thus accosted her,—
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Insolent girl!” said Elizabeth to herself. “You are much mistaken if you expect to influence me by such a paltry attack as this. I see nothing in it but your own wilful ignorance and the malice of Mr. Darcy.”

events.text_segment:
They had not long separated when Miss Bingley came towards her, and, with an expression of civil disdain, thus accosted her,—
“So, Miss Eliza, I hear you are quite delighted with George Wickham? Your sister has been talking to me about him, and asking me a thousand questions; and I find that the young man forgot to tell you, among his other communications, that he was the son of old Wickham, the late Mr. Darcy’s steward. Let me recommend you, however, as a friend, not to give implicit confidence to all his assertions; for, as to Mr. Darcy’s using him ill, it is perfectly false: for, on the contrary, he has been always remarkably kind to him, though George Wickham has treated Mr. Darcy in a most infamous manner. I do not know the particulars, but I know very well that Mr. Darcy is not in the least to blame; that he cannot bear to hear George Wickham mentioned; and that though my brother thought he could not well avoid including him in his invitation to the officers, he was excessively glad to find that he had taken himself out of the way. His coming into the country at all is a most insolent thing, indeed, and I wonder how he could presume to do it. I pity you, Miss Eliza, for this discovery of your favourite’s guilt; but really, considering his descent, one could not expect much better.”
“His guilt and his descent appear, by your account, to be the same,” said Elizabeth, angrily; “for I have heard you accuse him of nothing worse than of being the son of Mr. Darcy’s steward, and of that, I can assure you, he informed me himself.”
“I beg your pardon,” replied Miss Bingley, turning away with a sneer. “Excuse my interference; it was kindly meant.”
“Insolent girl!” said Elizabeth to herself. “You are much mistaken if you expect to influence me by such a paltry attack as this. I see nothing in it but your own wilful ignorance and the malice of Mr. Darcy.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
They had not long separated when Miss Bingley came towards her, and, with an expression of civil disdain, thus accosted her,—

"Miss Elizabeth Bennet, I am astonished that you should be so imprudent as to ask questions about a man who has behaved so ill to my brother. Jane has been asking questions about him, I see; but I wonder you should be so curious. Wickham is a man of no character, and I would advise you to be cautious in trusting his assertions. He is the son of the late steward of Mr. Darcy's estate, a fact he has himself acknowledged."

Elizabeth looked at her with some surprise, and Miss Bingley continued, "I would not have you be deceived by his charming manners. Darcy was always kind to Wickham, whereas Wickham treated Darcy infamously. I dare say you have heard that Darcy was glad Wickham avoided the ball; he cannot bear Wickham's name mentioned, and I think his presence in the area was quite insolent."

"Miss Bingley," said Elizabeth, with some warmth, "you have accused Wickham of nothing worse than being a steward's son, a fact he himself told me. I am surprised that you should speak so maliciously of a man who has been so kind to my sister."

Miss Bingley sneered, "I meant no harm, only wished to warn you. Pray forgive my interference, but I thought it my duty to caution you."

Elizabeth inwardly fumed, dismissing Miss Bingley's words as ignorant and malicious, likely influenced by Darcy.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Miss Bingley approached with a look of polite condescension, her lips slightly curled in a manner that suggested both disdain and amusement. "Miss Elizabeth Bennet," she began, her tone smooth yet edged with subtle sarcasm, "how fortunate it is that we should meet again so soon. I trust you are enjoying your visit here at Netherfield?" Elizabeth, aware of Miss Bingley's underlying motives, responded with a calm and measured tone. "Indeed, Miss Bingley, I am quite well, and I hope you are too. It is always a pleasure to see familiar faces, even if they are not always as welcoming as one might wish." Miss Bingley, slightly taken aback by Elizabeth's composure, quickly recovered her composure and added, "I am glad to hear it. Netherfield is a charming place, and I am sure you find it quite agreeable. Though I must confess, I find the countryside somewhat dull compared to the lively society of London." Elizabeth smiled politely, choosing her words carefully. "The countryside has its own charms, Miss Bingley, and I find that a change of scenery often brings a fresh perspective. Perhaps you might find some enjoyment in the tranquility here." Miss Bingley, not entirely pleased with Elizabeth's response, attempted to regain her usual airs of superiority. "Tranquility is all very well, but I do prefer the company of those who can appreciate the finer things in life. I suppose one must make the most of one's surroundings, however humble they may be." Elizabeth, feeling the need to assert her independence, replied, "I believe that happiness and contentment are not solely dependent on one's environment or social standing, but rather on one's own attitude and the company one keeps." Miss Bingley, momentarily silenced by Elizabeth's confident tone, nodded stiffly and turned away, her expression a mixture of disdain and begrudging respect. Elizabeth watched her go, her mind at ease, knowing she had maintained her dignity in the face of Miss Bingley's subtle snubs.

events.title: Jane Reports Bingley's Views on Wickham
detailed_summary: Elizabeth seeks out Jane, intending to ask what she learned about Wickham from Bingley.
She finds Jane radiant with happiness, clearly pleased with the evening's events, presumably regarding Bingley.
Elizabeth momentarily sets aside her concerns about Wickham, happy for Jane's prospects.
She asks Jane what she discovered about Wickham.
Jane replies that she learned nothing truly satisfactory; Bingley doesn't know the full history or the specific cause of Darcy's offense.
However, Bingley vouches for Darcy's character and is convinced Wickham deserved less kindness than Darcy showed him.
According to Bingley (and echoing Miss Bingley), Wickham is not respectable, has likely been imprudent, and deserved to lose Darcy's favor.
Elizabeth points out that Bingley doesn't know Wickham personally, only having met him recently.
Jane confirms Bingley's account comes entirely from Darcy.
Elizabeth declares herself satisfied, ironically implying this confirms her bias against Darcy's version.
Regarding the church living Wickham claims he was denied, Jane relays Bingley's belief (again, from Darcy) that it was left conditionally.
Elizabeth affirms Bingley's sincerity but refuses to be convinced solely by assurances derived from Darcy, maintaining her previous opinions of both Wickham and Darcy.

events.text_segment:
She then sought her eldest sister, who had undertaken to make inquiries on the same subject of Bingley. Jane met her with a smile of such sweet complacency, a glow of such happy expression, as sufficiently marked how well she was satisfied with the occurrences of the evening. Elizabeth instantly read her feelings; and, at that moment, solicitude for Wickham, resentment against his enemies, and everything else, gave way before the hope of Jane’s being in the fairest way for happiness.
“I want to know,” said she, with a countenance no less smiling than her sister’s, “what you have learnt about Mr. Wickham. But perhaps you have been too pleasantly engaged to think of any third person, in which case you may be sure of my pardon.”
“No,” replied Jane, “I have not forgotten him; but I have nothing satisfactory to tell you. Mr. Bingley does not know the whole of his history, and is quite ignorant of the circumstances which have principally offended Mr. Darcy; but he will vouch for the good conduct, the probity and honour, of his friend, and is perfectly convinced that Mr. Wickham has deserved much less attention from Mr. Darcy than he has received; and I am sorry to say that by his account, as well as his sister’s, Mr. Wickham is by no means a respectable young man. I am afraid he has been very imprudent, and has deserved to lose Mr. Darcy’s regard.”
“Mr. Bingley does not know Mr. Wickham himself.”
“No; he never saw him till the other morning at Meryton.”
“This account then is what he has received from Mr. Darcy. I am perfectly satisfied. But what does he say of the living?”
“He does not exactly recollect the circumstances, though he has heard them from Mr. Darcy more than once, but he believes that it was left to him conditionally only.”
“I have not a doubt of Mr. Bingley’s sincerity,” said Elizabeth warmly, “but you must excuse my not being convinced by assurances only. Mr. Bingley’s defence of his friend was a very able one, I dare say; but since he is unacquainted with several parts of the story, and has learnt the rest from that friend himself, I shall venture still to think of both gentlemen as I did before.”

events.title: Mr. Collins's Unwelcome Introduction to Darcy
detailed_summary: Elizabeth shifts the conversation with Jane to the more pleasant topic of Bingley's attentions, boosting Jane's hopes.
When Bingley joins them, Elizabeth withdraws to Charlotte Lucas.
Mr. Collins approaches Elizabeth, full of self-importance, announcing he has discovered a relative of his patroness, Lady Catherine, is present.
He overheard Darcy mentioning his cousin Miss De Bourgh and her mother, Lady Catherine.
Collins expresses delight at this 'singular accident' and states his intention to immediately pay his respects to Darcy.
Elizabeth attempts strongly to dissuade him, warning that introducing himself without connection is impertinent and Darcy will not appreciate it.
She argues that any acknowledgment should come from Darcy, the socially superior individual.

Mr. Collins dismisses her advice, asserting his judgment in matters of clerical ceremony is superior to hers, claiming a clergyman's dignity equals the highest ranks and that introducing himself is a duty.
He bows and approaches Darcy.
Elizabeth watches anxiously, seeing Darcy's clear astonishment at being addressed.
She imagines Collins's speech filled with apologies and mentions of Hunsford and Lady Catherine, feeling vexed by his self-exposure.
Darcy regards Collins with undisguised amazement and responds with distant civility.
Collins speaks again, seemingly increasing Darcy's contempt, before Darcy gives a slight bow and moves away.
Collins returns to Elizabeth, completely misinterpreting the encounter, claiming Darcy seemed pleased and paid him a compliment about Lady Catherine's discernment.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Upon the whole, I am much pleased with him.”

events.text_segment:
She then changed the discourse to one more gratifying to each, and on which there could be no difference of sentiment. Elizabeth listened with delight to the happy though modest hopes which Jane entertained of Bingley’s regard, and said all in her power to heighten her confidence in it. On their being joined by Mr. Bingley himself, Elizabeth withdrew to Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last partner she had scarcely replied, before Mr. Collins came up to them, and told her with great exultation, that he had just been so fortunate as to make a most important discovery.
“I have found out,” said he, “by a singular accident, that there is now in the room a near relation to my patroness. I happened to overhear the gentleman himself mentioning to the young lady who does the honours of this house the names of his cousin Miss De Bourgh, and of her mother, Lady Catherine. How wonderfully these sort of things occur! Who would have thought of my meeting with—perhaps—a nephew of Lady Catherine de Bourgh in this assembly! I am most thankful that the discovery is made in time for me to pay my respects to him, which I am now going to do, and trust he will excuse my not having done it before. My total ignorance of the connection must plead my apology.”
“You are not going to introduce yourself to Mr. Darcy?”
“Indeed I am. I shall entreat his pardon for not having done it earlier. I believe him to be Lady Catherine’s nephew. It will be in my power to assure him that her Ladyship was quite well yesterday se’nnight.”
Elizabeth tried hard to dissuade him from such a scheme; assuring him that Mr. Darcy would consider his addressing him without introduction as an impertinent freedom, rather than a compliment to his aunt; that it was not in the least necessary there should be any notice on either side, and that if it were, it must belong to Mr. Darcy, the superior in consequence, to begin the acquaintance. Mr. Collins listened to her with the determined air of following his own inclination, and when she ceased speaking, replied thus,—
“My dear Miss Elizabeth, I have the highest opinion in the world of your excellent judgment in all matters within the scope of your understanding, but permit me to say that there must be a wide difference between the established forms of ceremony amongst the laity and those which regulate the clergy; for, give me leave to observe that I consider the clerical office as equal in point of dignity with the highest rank in the kingdom—provided that a proper humility of behaviour is at the same time maintained. You must, therefore, allow me to follow the dictates of my conscience on this occasion, which lead me to perform what I look on as a point of duty. Pardon me for neglecting to profit by your advice, which on every other subject shall be my constant guide, though in the case before us I consider myself more fitted by education and habitual study to decide on what is right than a young lady like yourself;” and with a low bow he left her to attack Mr. Darcy, whose reception of his advances she eagerly watched, and whose astonishment at being so addressed was very evident. Her cousin prefaced his speech with a solemn bow, and though she could not hear a word of it, she felt as if hearing it all, and saw in the motion of his lips the words “apology,” “Hunsford,” and “Lady Catherine de Bourgh.” It vexed her to see him expose himself to such a man. Mr. Darcy was eyeing him with unrestrained wonder; and when at last Mr. Collins allowed him to speak, replied with an air of distant civility. Mr. Collins, however, was not discouraged from speaking again, and Mr. Darcy’s contempt seemed abundantly increasing with the length of his second speech; and at the end of it he only made him a slight bow, and moved another way: Mr. Collins then returned to Elizabeth.
“I have no reason, I assure you,” said he, “to be dissatisfied with my reception. Mr. Darcy seemed much pleased with the attention. He answered me with the utmost civility, and even paid me the compliment of saying, that he was so well convinced of Lady Catherine’s discernment as to be certain she could never bestow a favour unworthily. It was really a very handsome thought. Upon the whole, I am much pleased with him.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
She then changed the discourse to one more gratifying to each, and on which there could be no difference of sentiment.

Elizabeth, who was sitting by her sister, now turned the conversation to Bingley's attentions, which she knew would be more agreeable to Jane than any thing else; and she was beginning to speak with more cheerfulness when Mr. Bingley himself joined them. Elizabeth immediately withdrew to Charlotte Lucas, and Mr. Collins, full of self-importance, approached Elizabeth.

"I have just been informed," he said, "by a very good authority, that a relative of my patroness, Lady Catherine de Bourgh, is in the neighborhood. I overheard Darcy mentioning his cousin Miss De Bourgh and her mother, Lady Catherine."

Elizabeth looked at him with surprise, and he continued, "I consider this a singular accident, and I shall pay my respects to Mr. Darcy immediately."

"Mr. Collins," Elizabeth said, "I would advise you to be cautious. Approaching Mr. Darcy without proper introduction might be considered impertinent."

"My dear Miss Elizabeth," he replied, "I am a clergyman, and I am quite capable of judging the propriety of my actions. It is my duty to introduce myself to those of high rank, and I shall do so now."

He bowed and made his way toward Darcy, who looked at him with a mixture of astonishment and civility.

"Mr. Collins," Darcy said, "I am surprised to see you here."

"Mr. Darcy," Collins began, "I have the honor to present myself, and I hope to have the pleasure of your acquaintance. I have heard much of your good sense and discernment, especially from Lady Catherine."

Darcy regarded him with a slight smile, and after a moment, he responded, "Mr. Collins, I am at your service."

Collins, interpreting this as a sign of approval, continued, "I am very pleased to make your acquaintance, sir. Lady Catherine speaks highly of your judgment."

Darcy nodded politely and moved away, leaving Collins to return to Elizabeth, who watched the scene with a mixture of amusement and vexation.

"He seemed quite pleased," Collins said, turning to Elizabeth. "He even paid me a compliment about Lady Catherine's discernment. I am very satisfied with his reception."

She then changed the discourse to one more gratifying to each, and on which there could be no difference of sentiment. Her manner was so cheerful, her words so agreeable, that Elizabeth could not help feeling a more lively interest in her than she had yet done. As they continued their walk, Mrs. Gardiner expressed her delight at the prospect of visiting the lakes, and spoke of the beauty of the scenery, the variety of the landscape, and the numerous attractions that the region offered. Elizabeth listened with pleasure, and found herself more and more captivated by her aunt's animated description.

They soon reached the end of their walk, and, as they approached the house, Elizabeth observed her sister Jane sitting in the garden, reading a letter. Jane looked up and smiled as they approached, and Elizabeth saw the glow of happiness on her face. She wondered what news could have caused such a smile, and her curiosity was piqued.

"Jane, what is the matter?" she asked, as she drew near.

"Oh, Lizzy!" Jane exclaimed, her eyes shining with joy. "I have received a letter from Mr. Bingley. He is coming to Netherfield next week!"

Elizabeth's face lit up with pleasure. "That is delightful news! I am so glad."

Jane looked at her sister with a gentle smile. "I thought you would be. I am very happy about it."

As they sat together in the garden, Jane read aloud the letter from Mr. Bingley, who expressed his eagerness to see her again and his hope that she was well. Elizabeth listened attentively, feeling a warm glow of happiness for her sister.

Meanwhile, in the drawing-room, Mrs. Bennet was bustling about, full of excitement. "Did you hear the news?" she exclaimed to her husband. "Mr. Bingley is coming to Netherfield!"

Mr. Bennet, who was reading a book, looked up and smiled. "Indeed. That is good news."

Mrs. Bennet continued, "I shall go and prepare myself to receive him. I must look my best."

Mr. Bennet chuckled. "You always do, my dear."

The next day, Elizabeth and her mother went to visit the Bingleys at Netherfield. As they approached the house, Elizabeth saw Mr. Bingley himself coming out to greet them, with a warm and friendly smile.

"Miss Elizabeth!" he exclaimed, taking her hand. "How do you do? I am very glad to see you again."

Elizabeth returned his smile. "And I am glad to see you. It is a very pleasant surprise."

They entered the house, and Elizabeth was introduced to Mr. Bingley's sisters, Caroline and Louisa. Caroline was a handsome young woman, with a haughty air and a keen eye for fashion. Louisa was more gentle and reserved.

During the visit, Elizabeth observed the interactions among the family members. Mr. Bingley was kind and attentive, and his sisters appeared to be very fond of him. Elizabeth thought him a very agreeable young man, with a cheerful disposition and a good sense of humor.

As the afternoon wore on, Elizabeth found herself enjoying the company of the Bingleys and their friends. She was struck by the contrast between Mr. Bingley and his sister Caroline. While he was warm and friendly, Caroline was somewhat aloof and condescending.

Nevertheless, Elizabeth was pleased with her visit and looked forward to seeing more of Mr. Bingley and his family. She felt a renewed sense of hope that her sister Jane might find happiness with him.

In the days that followed, Elizabeth and her family continued to visit Netherfield, and the acquaintance between Jane and Mr. Bingley grew stronger. Elizabeth observed their interactions with a keen eye, noticing the gentle glances and the shy smiles exchanged between them.

Meanwhile, Mr. Darcy's presence at the Meryton ball had caused quite a stir. Elizabeth had been introduced to him there, and she found him to be a proud and reserved man, with a striking countenance. She was not immediately impressed, but she acknowledged that he was handsome and intelligent.

As the days went by, Elizabeth's opinion of Mr. Darcy was gradually changing. She learned that he was a man of great wealth and influence, but also of considerable pride. She wondered whether his pride was a barrier to his happiness, or whether it was merely a defense mechanism.

The social gatherings at Netherfield and other places provided ample opportunity for Elizabeth to observe the manners and characters of those around her. She was particularly attentive to Mr. Collins, her cousin, who was a pompous and self-important clergyman, eager to impress with his airs and graces.

Despite her amusement at his expense, Elizabeth was also aware of his good intentions and his desire to do his duty. She hoped that her family would not be too affected by his awkwardness.

As the summer days passed, Elizabeth's feelings and opinions continued to evolve. She found herself increasingly interested in the people around her, and more aware of the subtle nuances of social interaction.

Her thoughts often returned to Mr. Bingley and Jane, and she hoped that their connection would deepen. She also pondered the character of Mr. Darcy, and wondered whether her initial judgments were fair.

In the midst of these reflections, Elizabeth remained true to her own principles, valuing sincerity and kindness above all. She was determined to judge each person by their actions, and to remain true to her own feelings.

The days of summer were filled with activity and anticipation, and Elizabeth looked forward to the future with a mixture of hope and curiosity. She knew that her life was about to change in ways she could not yet imagine, and she was ready to face whatever came with courage and integrity.

events.title: Mrs. Bennet's Loud Speculation Overheard by Darcy
detailed_summary: With no personal prospects for the evening, Elizabeth focuses on observing Jane and Bingley together.
Watching them fuels pleasant thoughts and makes her nearly as happy as Jane, imagining her sister settled happily at Netherfield.
She notes her mother shares these hopes and avoids her to prevent hearing excessive talk.
At supper, Elizabeth is dismayed to find herself seated near her mother.
Mrs. Bennet talks freely and loudly to Lady Lucas, expressing her certainty that Jane will soon marry Bingley.
She enumerates the match's advantages: Bingley's charm, wealth, proximity, the Bingley sisters' supposed fondness for Jane, and the potential benefits for her other daughters.
She also mentions looking forward to consigning her daughters to Jane's care, though this is clearly contrary to her usual desire to socialize.
Mrs. Bennet concludes by wishing Lady Lucas similar fortune, clearly believing it impossible.
Elizabeth tries futilely to make her mother speak more quietly, mortified because she sees Mr. Darcy, seated opposite, is overhearing.
Mrs. Bennet dismisses Elizabeth's concerns, questioning why she should fear Darcy or censor herself for his sake.

Her efforts are useless; Mrs. Bennet continues in the same audible tone.

events.text_segment:
As Elizabeth had no longer any interest of her own to pursue, she turned her attention almost entirely on her sister and Mr. Bingley; and the train of agreeable reflections which her observations gave birth to made her perhaps almost as happy as Jane. She saw her in idea settled in that very house, in all the felicity which a marriage of true affection could bestow; and she felt capable, under such circumstances, of endeavouring even to like Bingley’s two sisters. Her mother’s thoughts she plainly saw were bent the same way, and she determined not to venture near her, lest she might hear too much. When they sat down to supper, therefore, she considered it a most unlucky perverseness which placed them within one of each other; and deeply was she vexed to find that her mother was talking to that one person (Lady Lucas) freely, openly, and of nothing else but of her expectation that Jane would be soon married to Mr. Bingley. It was an animating subject, and Mrs. Bennet seemed incapable of fatigue while enumerating the advantages of the match. His being such a charming young man, and so rich, and living but three miles from them, were the first points of self-gratulation; and then it was such a comfort to think how fond the two sisters were of Jane, and to be certain that they must desire the connection as much as she could do. It was, moreover, such a promising thing for her younger daughters, as Jane’s marrying so greatly must throw them in the way of other rich men; and, lastly, it was so pleasant at her time of life to be able to consign her single daughters to the care of their sister, that she might not be obliged to go into company more than she liked. It was necessary to make this circumstance a matter of pleasure, because on such occasions it is the etiquette; but no one was less likely than Mrs. Bennet to find comfort in staying at home at any period of her life. She concluded with many good wishes that Lady Lucas might soon be equally fortunate, though evidently and triumphantly believing there was no chance of it.
In vain did Elizabeth endeavour to check the rapidity of her mother’s words, or persuade her to describe her felicity in a less audible whisper; for to her inexpressible vexation she could perceive that the chief of it was overheard by Mr. Darcy, who sat opposite to them. Her mother only scolded her for being nonsensical.
“What is Mr. Darcy to me, pray, that I should be afraid of him? I am sure we owe him no such particular civility as to be obliged to say nothing he may not like to hear.”
“For heaven’s sake, madam, speak lower. What advantage can it be to you to offend Mr. Darcy? You will never recommend yourself to his friend by so doing.”
Nothing that she could say, however, had any influence. Her mother would talk of her views in the same intelligible tone. Elizabeth blushed and blushed again with shame and vexation. She could not help frequently glancing her eye at Mr. Darcy, though every glance convinced her of what she dreaded; for though he was not always looking at her mother, she was convinced that his attention was invariably fixed by her. The expression of his face changed gradually from indignant contempt to a composed and steady gravity.

events.title: Mary's Performance and Collins's Lecture Further Embarrassment
detailed_summary: Mrs. Bennet finally ceases talking, allowing Lady Lucas relief.
Elizabeth's brief respite ends when singing begins after supper.
She is mortified as Mary Bennet readily agrees to perform with little persuasion.
Elizabeth tries to signal Mary discreetly not to perform, but Mary ignores her, eager for the chance to display her talents.
Mary begins her song, causing Elizabeth painful embarrassment as she watches.
Mary's performance is weak-voiced and affected.
After finishing, encouraged by faint praise, Mary begins a second song.
Elizabeth is in agony, observes Jane calmly talking to Bingley, sees the Bingley sisters mocking Mary to each other and Darcy, who remains gravely impassive.
Elizabeth signals her father to intervene.
Mr. Bennet takes the hint and, after Mary's second song, loudly tells her she has sung enough and should let others perform.
Mary pretends not to hear but is visibly disconcerted; Elizabeth feels sorry for both Mary and her father's bluntness.

Mr. Collins takes the opportunity to make a speech, stating that if he could sing, he would gladly oblige, considering music innocent and compatible with clergy duties, provided it doesn't consume too much time.
He elaborates on a rector's duties: managing tithes, writing sermons, parish work, home improvement, and maintaining conciliatory manners, especially towards patrons.
He concludes loudly, with a bow towards Darcy, emphasizing the duty of showing respect to anyone connected with one's patron's family.
Many guests stare or smile; Mr. Bennet looks highly amused, while Mrs. Bennet commends Collins's sense to Lady Lucas.
Elizabeth feels her family couldn't have embarrassed themselves more effectively if they had planned it.
She worries about the impression made on Bingley, though hopes he didn't notice all of it or isn't overly sensitive to such folly.

events.text_segment:
At length, however, Mrs. Bennet had no more to say; and Lady Lucas, who had been long yawning at the repetition of delights which she saw no likelihood of sharing, was left to the comforts of cold ham and chicken. Elizabeth now began to revive. But not long was the interval of tranquillity; for when supper was over, singing was talked of, and she had the mortification of seeing Mary, after very little entreaty, preparing to oblige the company. By many significant looks and silent entreaties did she endeavour to prevent such a proof of complaisance,—but in vain; Mary would not understand them; such an opportunity of exhibiting was delightful to her, and she began her song. Elizabeth’s eyes were fixed on her, with most painful sensations; and she watched her progress through the several stanzas with an impatience which was very ill rewarded at their close; for Mary, on receiving amongst the thanks of the table the hint of a hope that she might be prevailed on to favour them again, after the pause of half a minute began another. Mary’s powers were by no means fitted for such a display; her voice was weak, and her manner affected. Elizabeth was in agonies. She looked at Jane to see how she bore it; but Jane was very composedly talking to Bingley. She looked at his two sisters, and saw them making signs of derision at each other, and at Darcy, who continued, however, impenetrably grave. She looked at her father to entreat his interference, lest Mary should be singing all night. He took the hint, and, when Mary had finished her second song, said aloud,—
“That will do extremely well, child. You have delighted us long enough. Let the other young ladies have time to exhibit.”
Mary, though pretending not to hear, was somewhat disconcerted; and Elizabeth, sorry for her, and sorry for her father’s speech, was afraid her anxiety had done no good. Others of the party were now applied to.
“If I,” said Mr. Collins, “were so fortunate as to be able to sing, I should have great pleasure, I am sure, in obliging the company with an air; for I consider music as a very innocent diversion, and perfectly compatible with the profession of a clergyman. I do not mean, however, to assert that we can be justified in devoting too much of our time to music, for there are certainly other things to be attended to. The rector of a parish has much to do. In the first place, he must make such an agreement for tithes as may be beneficial to himself and not offensive to his patron. He must write his own sermons; and the time that remains will not be too much for his parish duties, and the care and improvement of his dwelling, which he cannot be excused from making as comfortable as possible. And I do not think it of light importance that he should have attentive and conciliatory manners towards everybody, especially towards those to whom he owes his preferment. I cannot acquit him of that duty; nor could I think well of the man who should omit an occasion of testifying his respect towards anybody connected with the family.” And with a bow to Mr. Darcy, he concluded his speech, which had been spoken so loud as to be heard by half the room. Many stared—many smiled; but no one looked more amused than Mr. Bennet himself, while his wife seriously commended Mr. Collins for having spoken so sensibly, and observed, in a half-whisper to Lady Lucas, that he was a remarkably clever, good kind of young man.
To Elizabeth it appeared, that had her family made an agreement to expose themselves as much as they could during the evening, it would have been impossible for them to play their parts with more spirit, or finer success; and happy did she think it for Bingley and her sister that some of the exhibition had escaped his notice, and that his feelings were not of a sort to be much distressed by the folly which he must have witnessed. That his two sisters and Mr. Darcy, however, should have such an opportunity of ridiculing her relations was bad enough; and she could not determine whether the silent contempt of the gentleman, or the insolent smiles of the ladies, were more intolerable.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
At length, however, Mrs. Bennet had no more to say; and Lady Lucas, who had been long yawning at the repetition of delights which she saw no likelihood of sharing, was left to the comforts of cold ham and chicken.

Elizabeth, who had been sitting quietly, was now relieved from her mother's incessant chatter, but her peace was short-lived. As the evening progressed, the music began, and with it, Elizabeth's mortification. Mary Bennet, eager to display her talents, readily agreed to sing, much to Elizabeth's dismay. Elizabeth attempted to discreetly signal her sister not to perform, but Mary, eager for applause, paid no heed.

Mary commenced her song, which was weak-voiced and affected, causing Elizabeth to cringe in embarrassment. After her first performance, encouraged by faint praise, Mary launched into a second song. Elizabeth's agony grew; she watched Jane conversing calmly with Bingley, while the Bingley sisters and Miss Bingley mocked Mary to each other and Darcy, who remained impassive.

Unable to bear it, Elizabeth signaled her father to intervene. Mr. Bennet, catching her hint, loudly declared that Mary had sung enough and should allow others to perform. Mary, pretending not to hear, looked visibly disconcerted, and Elizabeth felt a mixture of sympathy and frustration.

Seizing the moment, Mr. Collins took the floor, offering a speech about the virtues of music and his own supposed talents. He elaborated on a rector's duties—managing tithes, writing sermons, parish work, home improvements, and maintaining good manners, especially towards patrons. Concluding loudly with a bow towards Darcy, he emphasized the importance of showing respect to anyone connected with one's patron's family.

Many guests stared or smiled at this display; Mr. Bennet was highly amused, while Mrs. Bennet praised Collins's sense to Lady Lucas. Elizabeth reflected that her family could not have embarrassed themselves more effectively if they had planned it, and she worried about the impression on Bingley, though she hoped he hadn't noticed everything or was overly sensitive to such folly.

The scene left her troubled, especially considering the opportunity for ridicule it provided to the Bingley sisters and Darcy. She wondered whether Darcy's silent scorn or the sisters' open mockery was worse, and whether her family’s antics would leave a lasting impression.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Mrs. Bennet, in her usual state of agitation, was now busily engaged in persuading her husband to visit Mr. Bingley again, hoping to secure an invitation for her daughters to the upcoming ball. Mr. Bennet, with his characteristic dry wit, responded with a gentle sarcasm, remarking that he was sure Mr. Bingley would be delighted to see them all, especially if they were to arrive in a carriage full of young ladies. Elizabeth, observing her mother's eagerness, felt a mixture of amusement and concern. She knew that her sister Jane's prospects depended greatly on such social occasions, and she hoped that her sister's natural sweetness and beauty would shine through. Meanwhile, Lydia, ever the lively and somewhat reckless girl, was already planning her dress and the dance partners she wished to secure. Lady Lucas, meanwhile, continued to nibble on her cold ham, her mind wandering to her own daughters and the prospects they might have at the ball. She was not particularly interested in the finer points of courtship but appreciated the social advantages that such gatherings could bring. As the evening wore on, the conversation shifted from the trivialities of the day to more serious matters, such as the health of Mr. Collins and the prospects of the local estate. Elizabeth listened attentively, her thoughts often drifting to her own future and the possibility of happiness beyond the confines of her modest life. She was aware of the importance of these social events, not just for entertainment but for the alliances and connections they could forge. Her father, Mr. Bennet, was more indifferent, preferring the quiet of his library to the bustling social scene. Yet, he understood the importance of appearances and the role they played in the social fabric of their community. As the evening drew to a close, Mrs. Bennet's excitement grew, and she began to make preparations for the ball, eager to see her daughters in their finery and to observe the interactions of the local gentry. Elizabeth, meanwhile, felt a quiet anticipation, hoping that the evening would bring some clarity to her feelings and perhaps a glimpse of the happiness she longed for. The night promised to be lively, filled with music, dance, and the subtle art of courtship that was so central to their social world. As they all retired to their respective rooms, Elizabeth reflected on the peculiarities of her family and the society they inhabited. She knew that each event, each encounter, was a step towards the future, shaping the lives of those around her in ways both seen and unseen. With a gentle sigh, she prepared herself for the morrow, aware that the coming days might bring surprises and revelations that could alter her course forever.

events.title: An Awkward Departure and Mrs. Bennet's Marital Expectations
detailed_summary: Elizabeth finds little enjoyment for the remainder of the ball.
Mr. Collins persistently stays by her side, preventing her from dancing with anyone else despite her requests for him to find another partner.
He insists his goal is to recommend himself to her through attention, not dancing.
Miss Lucas provides some relief by occasionally engaging Collins in conversation.
Elizabeth is freed from Darcy's attention; although sometimes nearby, he makes no move to speak, which she attributes to her Wickham remarks and feels glad about.
The Bennet family are the last guests to leave.
Mrs. Bennet orchestrates a delay, making them wait for their carriage after everyone else is gone.
During this wait, the impatience of Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley is obvious; they barely speak except to complain of tiredness.
Mrs. Bennet's attempts at conversation are rebuffed, casting a pall over the group.
Mr. Collins fills the silence with long compliments to Bingley and his sisters about the party.
Darcy remains entirely silent; Mr. Bennet observes quietly, amused.
Bingley and Jane stand apart, talking only to each other.
Elizabeth maintains silence, mirroring the Bingley sisters; even Lydia is too tired to talk much.
Upon finally leaving, Mrs. Bennet effusively hopes to see the Netherfield party at Longbourn soon, particularly inviting Bingley for a family dinner anytime.
Bingley responds with pleasure, promising to visit after his upcoming short trip to London.
Mrs. Bennet leaves fully satisfied, convinced Jane will be married to Bingley within months.

She also feels certain Elizabeth will marry Mr. Collins, an outcome she views with considerable, though lesser, pleasure, as Elizabeth is her least favorite daughter and Collins/the match are overshadowed by Bingley/Netherfield.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The rest of the evening brought her little amusement.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Elizabeth was the least dear to her of all her children; and though the man and the match were quite good enough for her, the worth of each was eclipsed by Mr. Bingley and Netherfield.

events.text_segment:
The rest of the evening brought her little amusement. She was teased by Mr. Collins, who continued most perseveringly by her side; and though he could not prevail with her to dance with him again, put it out of her power to dance with others. In vain did she entreat him to stand up with somebody else, and offered to introduce him to any young lady in the room. He assured her that, as to dancing, he was perfectly indifferent to it; that his chief object was, by delicate attentions, to recommend himself to her; and that he should therefore make a point of remaining close to her the whole evening. There was no arguing upon such a project. She owed her greatest relief to her friend Miss Lucas, who often joined them, and good-naturedly engaged Mr. Collins’s conversation to herself.
She was at least free from the offence of Mr. Darcy’s further notice: though often standing within a very short distance of her, quite disengaged, he never came near enough to speak. She felt it to be the probable consequence of her allusions to Mr. Wickham, and rejoiced in it.
The Longbourn party were the last of all the company to depart; and by a manœuvre of Mrs. Bennet had to wait for their carriage a quarter of an hour after everybody else was gone, which gave them time to see how heartily they were wished away by some of the family. Mrs. Hurst and her sister scarcely opened their mouths except to complain of fatigue, and were evidently impatient to have the house to themselves. They repulsed every attempt of Mrs. Bennet at conversation, and, by so doing, threw a languor over the whole party, which was very little relieved by the long speeches of Mr. Collins, who was complimenting Mr. Bingley and his sisters on the elegance of their entertainment, and the hospitality and politeness which had marked their behaviour to their guests. Darcy said nothing at all. Mr. Bennet, in equal silence, was enjoying the scene. Mr. Bingley and Jane were standing together a little detached from the rest, and talked only to each other. Elizabeth preserved as steady a silence as either Mrs. Hurst or Miss Bingley; and even Lydia was too much fatigued to utter more than the occasional exclamation of “Lord, how tired I am!” accompanied by a violent yawn.
When at length they arose to take leave, Mrs. Bennet was most pressingly civil in her hope of seeing the whole family soon at Longbourn; and addressed herself particularly to Mr. Bingley, to assure him how happy he would make them, by eating a family dinner with them at any time, without the ceremony of a formal invitation. Bingley was all grateful pleasure; and he readily engaged for taking the earliest opportunity of waiting on her after his return from London, whither he was obliged to go the next day for a short time.
Mrs. Bennet was perfectly satisfied; and quitted the house under the delightful persuasion that, allowing for the necessary preparations of settlements, new carriages, and wedding clothes, she should undoubtedly see her daughter settled at Netherfield in the course of three or four months. Of having another daughter married to Mr. Collins she thought with equal certainty, and with considerable, though not equal, pleasure. Elizabeth was the least dear to her of all her children; and though the man and the match were quite good enough for her, the worth of each was eclipsed by Mr. Bingley and Netherfield.

She wondered how such rigid notions could influence the lives of those around her, and whether true happiness could ever be found within such constraints.

The evening ended with a sense of unresolved tension, leaving Elizabeth with much to ponder. She retired to her chamber, her mind racing with thoughts of pride, prejudice, and the possibility of love. events.text_segment:
The next day opened a new scene at Longbourn. Mr. Collins made his declaration in form. Having resolved to do it without loss of time, as his leave of absence extended only to the following Saturday, and having no feelings of diffidence to make it distressing to himself even at the moment, he set about it in a very orderly manner, with all the observances which he supposed a regular part of the business. On finding Mrs. Bennet, Elizabeth, and one of the younger girls together, soon after breakfast, he addressed the mother in these words,—
“May I hope, madam, for your interest with your fair daughter Elizabeth, when I solicit for the honour of a private audience with her in the course of this morning?”
Before Elizabeth had time for anything but a blush of surprise, Mrs. Bennet instantly answered,—
“Oh dear! Yes, certainly. I am sure Lizzy will be very happy—I am sure she can have no objection. Come, Kitty, I want you upstairs.” And gathering her work together, she was hastening away, when Elizabeth called out,—
“Dear ma’am, do not go. I beg you will not go. Mr. Collins must excuse me. He can have nothing to say to me that anybody need not hear. I am going away myself.”
“No, no, nonsense, Lizzy. I desire you will stay where you are.” And upon Elizabeth’s seeming really, with vexed and embarrassed looks, about to escape, she added, “Lizzy, I insist upon your staying and hearing Mr. Collins.”
Elizabeth would not oppose such an injunction; and a moment’s consideration making her also sensible that it would be wisest to get it over as soon and as quietly as possible, she sat down again, and tried to conceal, by incessant employment, the feelings which were divided between distress and diversion. Mrs. Bennet and Kitty walked off, and as soon as they were gone, Mr. Collins began,—
