detailed_summary: Mrs. Gardiner prompts Elizabeth for an update concerning Mr. Wickham, recalling her earlier promise.

events.text_segment:
Mrs. Gardiner about this time reminded Elizabeth of her promise concerning that gentleman, and required information; and Elizabeth had such to send as might rather give contentment to her aunt than to herself. His apparent partiality had subsided, his attentions were over, he was the admirer of some one else. Elizabeth was watchful enough to see it all, but she could see it and write of it without material pain. Her heart had been but slightly touched, and her vanity was satisfied with believing that she would have been his only choice, had fortune permitted it. The sudden acquisition of ten thousand pounds was the most remarkable charm of the young lady to whom he was now rendering himself agreeable; but Elizabeth, less clear-sighted perhaps in this case than in Charlotte’s, did not quarrel with him for his wish of independence. Nothing, on the contrary, could be more natural; and, while able to suppose that it cost him a few struggles to relinquish her, she was ready to allow it a wise and desirable measure for both, and could very sincerely wish him happy.
All this was acknowledged to Mrs. Gardiner; and, after relating the circumstances, she thus went on:—“I am now convinced, my dear aunt, that I have never been much in love; for had I really experienced that pure and elevating passion, I should at present detest his very name, and wish him all manner of evil. But my feelings are not only cordial towards him, they are even impartial towards Miss King. I cannot find out that I hate her at all, or that I am in the least unwilling to think her a very good sort of girl. There can be no love in all this. My watchfulness has been effectual; and though I should certainly be a more interesting object to all my acquaintance, were I distractedly in love with him, I cannot say that I regret my comparative insignificance. Importance may sometimes be purchased too dearly. Kitty and Lydia take his defection much more to heart than I do. They are young in the ways of the world, and not yet open to the mortifying conviction that handsome young men must have something to live on as well as the plain.”

events.title: Anticipation and Preparation for the Hunsford Journey
detailed_summary: The winter months of January and February passed quietly at Longbourn.
In March, Elizabeth was scheduled to visit Charlotte Collins in Hunsford.
Initially uncertain, Elizabeth grew more committed to the visit upon realizing Charlotte expected her.
Her desire to see Charlotte increased with time apart, and her aversion to Mr. Collins lessened.
The novelty of the trip appealed to Elizabeth, offering a welcome change from her home environment with its difficult mother and less engaging younger sisters.
The journey also presented an opportunity to see Jane in London.
As the departure date approached, Elizabeth looked forward to it eagerly.
Travel arrangements solidified according to Charlotte's initial suggestion: Elizabeth would travel with Sir William Lucas and his daughter Maria.
A plan to spend one night in London was added, enhancing the trip.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: With no greater events than these in the Longbourn family, and otherwise diversified by little beyond the walks to Meryton, sometimes dirty and sometimes cold, did January and February pass away.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The improvement of spending a night in London was added in time, and the plan became as perfect as plan could be.

events.text_segment: With no greater events than these in the Longbourn family, and otherwise diversified by little beyond the walks to Meryton, sometimes dirty and sometimes cold, did January and February pass away. March was to take Elizabeth to Hunsford. She had not at first thought very seriously of going thither; but Charlotte, she soon found, was depending on the plan, and she gradually learned to consider it herself with greater pleasure as well as greater certainty. Absence had increased her desire of seeing Charlotte again, and weakened her disgust of Mr. Collins. There was novelty in the scheme; and as, with such a mother and such uncompanionable sisters, home could not be faultless, a little change was not unwelcome for its own sake. The journey would, moreover, give her a peep at Jane; and, in short, as the time drew near, she would have been very sorry for any delay. Everything, however, went on smoothly, and was finally settled according to Charlotte’s first sketch. She was to accompany Sir William and his second daughter. The improvement of spending a night in London was added in time, and the plan became as perfect as plan could be.

events.title: Parting Words and Lingering Sentiments
detailed_summary: Elizabeth's main regret about leaving was parting with her father, who disliked her going and asked her to write, suggesting he might reply.
Her farewell with Mr. Wickham was amicable, particularly on his side.
Despite his current focus on another woman, Wickham seemed to remember Elizabeth's initial interest, compassion, and admiration for him.
His goodbye included well wishes, a reminder about Lady Catherine de Bourgh, and a hope their judgments of people would remain aligned.
Elizabeth perceived a genuine concern in his farewell that reinforced her sincere regard for him.
She left feeling that, regardless of his marital status, Wickham exemplified charm and pleasantness.

events.text_segment:
The only pain was in leaving her father, who would certainly miss her, and who, when it came to the point, so little liked her going, that he told her to write to him, and almost promised to answer her letter.
The farewell between herself and Mr. Wickham was perfectly friendly; on his side even more. His present pursuit could not make him forget that Elizabeth had been the first to excite and to deserve his attention, the first to listen and to pity, the first to be admired; and in his manner of bidding her adieu, wishing her every enjoyment, reminding her of what she was to expect in Lady Catherine de Bourgh, and trusting their opinion of her—their opinion of everybody—would always coincide, there was a solicitude, an interest, which she felt must ever attach her to him with a most sincere regard; and she parted from him convinced, that, whether married or single, he must always be her model of the amiable and pleasing.

events.title: Journey to London and Arrival at the Gardiners'
detailed_summary: Elizabeth found her travel companions, Sir William Lucas and his daughter Maria, dull compared to Wickham.
Maria was good-natured but unintelligent, much like her father.
Their conversation was uninteresting, likened to the noise of the carriage.
Elizabeth usually enjoyed absurdity but was overly familiar with Sir William's repetitive stories about his knighthood and his tired formalities.
The twenty-four-mile journey began early, reaching Gracechurch Street by noon.
Jane was waiting at the window as they arrived at the Gardiners' home.
Jane greeted them warmly in the entrance hall.
Elizabeth observed Jane closely and was happy to see her looking healthy and beautiful.
The Gardiner children eagerly awaited their cousin on the stairs, shyly remaining there.
The atmosphere was filled with joy and affection.
The day was spent agreeably with morning activities and shopping, followed by an evening at the theatre.

events.text_segment:
Her fellow-travellers the next day were not of a kind to make her think him less agreeable. Sir William Lucas, and his daughter Maria, a good-humoured girl, but as empty-headed as himself, had nothing to say that could be worth hearing, and were listened to with about as much delight as the rattle of the chaise. Elizabeth loved absurdities, but she had known Sir William’s too long. He could tell her nothing new of the wonders of his presentation and knighthood; and his civilities were worn out, like his information.
It was a journey of only twenty-four miles, and they began it so early as to be in Gracechurch Street by noon. As they drove to Mr. Gardiner’s door, Jane was at a drawing-room window watching their arrival: when they entered the passage, she was there to welcome them, and Elizabeth, looking earnestly in her face, was pleased to see it healthful and lovely as ever. On the stairs were a troop of little boys and girls, whose eagerness for their cousin’s appearance would not allow them to wait in the drawing-room, and whose shyness, as they had not seen her for a twelvemonth, prevented their coming lower. All was joy and kindness. The day passed most pleasantly away; the morning in bustle and shopping, and the evening at one of the theatres.

events.title: Elizabeth Discusses Jane and Wickham with Mrs. Gardiner
detailed_summary: At the theatre, Elizabeth managed to sit next to Mrs. Gardiner.
They first discussed Jane; Elizabeth learned, with more sadness than surprise, that Jane still experienced periods of sadness despite trying to keep her spirits up.
There was hope, however, that Jane's dejection wouldn't last.
Mrs. Gardiner recounted details of Miss Bingley's visit to Gracechurch Street and shared conversations with Jane, confirming Jane had genuinely relinquished the acquaintance.
Mrs. Gardiner then playfully teased Elizabeth about Wickham's shift in attention to Miss King, praising Elizabeth's composure.
Mrs. Gardiner inquired about Miss King's character, expressing concern that Wickham might be acting out of mercenary motives.

Elizabeth countered, questioning the fine line between prudence and mercenary behaviour in marriage, reminding her aunt of her previous concerns about Wickham marrying Elizabeth due to lack of fortune.
Mrs. Gardiner pressed for information about Miss King to form her own judgment.
Elizabeth described Miss King as a decent young woman.
Mrs. Gardiner pointed out Wickham only showed interest after Miss King inherited her fortune.
Elizabeth defended Wickham, arguing if he couldn't pursue Elizabeth due to her lack of money, why should he pursue another poor girl he didn't care for?
Mrs. Gardiner found the timing of Wickham's attentions indelicate.
Elizabeth argued a man in difficult financial straits cannot always observe social niceties, and if Miss King didn't mind, others shouldn't judge.
Mrs. Gardiner retorted that Miss King's acceptance didn't excuse Wickham but rather suggested a lack of sense or feeling on Miss King's part.
Elizabeth yielded, sarcastically agreeing Wickham should be deemed mercenary and Miss King foolish.
Mrs. Gardiner clarified she didn't wish to think ill of Wickham, especially given his Derbyshire connections.
Elizabeth expressed exasperation with men from Derbyshire and Hertfordshire, declaring she looked forward to meeting the disagreeable Mr. Collins in Hunsford, stating stupid men were preferable.
Mrs. Gardiner cautioned that Elizabeth's words sounded like disappointment.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Elizabeth then contrived to sit by her aunt.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Take care, Lizzy; that speech savours strongly of disappointment.”

events.text_segment:
Elizabeth then contrived to sit by her aunt. Their first subject was her sister; and she was more grieved than astonished to hear, in reply to her minute inquiries, that though Jane always struggled to support her spirits, there were periods of dejection. It was reasonable, however, to hope that they would not continue long. Mrs. Gardiner gave her the particulars also of Miss Bingley’s visit in Gracechurch Street, and repeated conversations occurring at different times between Jane and herself, which proved that the former had, from her heart, given up the acquaintance.
Mrs. Gardiner then rallied her niece on Wickham’s desertion, and complimented her on bearing it so well.
“But, my dear Elizabeth,” she added, “what sort of girl is Miss King? I should be sorry to think our friend mercenary.”
“Pray, my dear aunt, what is the difference in matrimonial affairs, between the mercenary and the prudent motive? Where does discretion end, and avarice begin? Last Christmas you were afraid of his marrying me, because it would be imprudent; and now, because he is trying to get a girl with only ten thousand pounds, you want to find out that he is mercenary.”
“If you will only tell me what sort of girl Miss King is, I shall know what to think.”
“She is a very good kind of girl, I believe. I know no harm of her.”
“But he paid her not the smallest attention till her grandfather’s death made her mistress of this fortune?”
“No—why should he? If it were not allowable for him to gain my affections, because I had no money, what occasion could there be for making love to a girl whom he did not care about, and who was equally poor?”
“But there seems indelicacy in directing his attentions towards her so soon after this event.”
“A man in distressed circumstances has not time for all those elegant decorums which other people may observe. If she does not object to it, why should we?”
“Her not objecting does not justify him. It only shows her being deficient in something herself—sense or feeling.”
“Well,” cried Elizabeth, “have it as you choose. He shall be mercenary, and she shall be foolish.”
“No, Lizzy, that is what I do not choose. I should be sorry, you know, to think ill of a young man who has lived so long in Derbyshire.”
“Oh, if that is all, I have a very poor opinion of young men who live in Derbyshire; and their intimate friends who live in Hertfordshire are not much better. I am sick of them all. Thank heaven! I am going to-morrow where I shall find a man who has not one agreeable quality, who has neither manners nor sense to recommend him. Stupid men are the only ones worth knowing, after all.”
“Take care, Lizzy; that speech savours strongly of disappointment.”

The discussion then shifted to Wickham, with Mrs. Gardiner playfully teasing Elizabeth about his shift in attention to Miss King, praising Elizabeth's composure.

Mrs. Gardiner expressed concern that Wickham might be acting out of mercenary motives, prompting Elizabeth to question the fine line between prudence and mercenary behavior in marriage. She reminded her aunt of her previous worries about Wickham marrying Elizabeth due to her lack of fortune. Mrs. Gardiner pressed for more details about Miss King to form her own judgment.

Elizabeth described Miss King as a decent young woman, noting that Wickham only showed interest after Miss King inherited her fortune. She defended Wickham, arguing that if he couldn't pursue Elizabeth because of her lack of money, why should he pursue another poor girl he didn't care for? Mrs. Gardiner found the timing of Wickham's attentions indelicate.

Elizabeth countered that a man in difficult financial straits cannot always observe social niceties, and if Miss King didn't mind, others shouldn't judge. Mrs. Gardiner retorted that Miss King's acceptance didn't excuse Wickham but rather suggested a lack of sense or feeling on Miss King's part. Elizabeth yielded, sarcastically agreeing Wickham should be deemed mercenary and Miss King foolish.

Mrs. Gardiner clarified she didn't wish to think ill of Wickham, especially given his Derbyshire connections. Elizabeth expressed exasperation with men from Derbyshire and Hertfordshire, declaring she looked forward to meeting the disagreeable Mr. Collins in Hunsford, stating stupid men were preferable. Mrs. Gardiner cautioned that Elizabeth's words sounded like disappointment.

---

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Elizabeth then contrived to sit by her aunt, Lady Lucas, with whom she felt a particular inclination to converse. As they settled into their seats, Elizabeth observed the lively chatter of the surrounding company, noting the ease with which some engaged in flirtations and the awkwardness of others. Her aunt, ever eager to discuss her own children and their prospects, turned to Elizabeth with a smile.

"I do think, Elizabeth," she began, "that Mr. Bingley is very agreeable, and I dare say he will be quite a catch for one of our young ladies."

Elizabeth nodded, her thoughts momentarily drifting to Mr. Bingley himself, whose friendly demeanor and genuine kindness had already made a favorable impression on her. She replied, "He is indeed very pleasant, and I believe he is sincerely interested in Miss Bennet."

Lady Lucas leaned in slightly, lowering her voice. "I have heard from Mrs. Long that he is quite taken with her, and I dare say Miss Bennet is a charming girl."

Elizabeth smiled at the compliment, feeling a warmth of pride for her sister. She then turned the conversation to her own family, asking about the health and happiness of her relatives. Lady Lucas, always attentive, responded with affectionate detail, her words tinged with a hint of pride.

As the evening progressed, Elizabeth observed the interactions around her—the flirtations, the polite exchanges, and the subtle glances exchanged between young men and women. She noticed Mr. Darcy standing apart from the crowd, his expression reserved yet observant. Her eyes met his for a fleeting moment, and she quickly looked away, feeling a mixture of curiosity and apprehension.

The music began, and couples started to pair off for dancing. Elizabeth was soon approached by Mr. Collins, who, with his usual pompous manner, invited her to dance. She politely declined, citing her preference to remain seated and engaged in conversation. Mr. Collins, ever eager to display his importance, nodded sagely and moved on.

Meanwhile, Elizabeth's thoughts wandered to her own feelings and the social expectations that pressed upon her. She was aware of the importance of marriage and the advantages it could bring, yet she also valued her independence and the freedom to think and speak as she pleased.

The evening wore on, and Elizabeth found herself more and more engrossed in the subtle nuances of the gathering—the unspoken messages behind polite smiles, the significance of a well-timed glance, and the delicate dance of social interaction. She felt a growing sense of awareness about her own position and the potential futures that lay ahead.

As the night drew to a close, Elizabeth felt a mixture of satisfaction and anticipation. She had enjoyed the company and the conversation, and she looked forward to the days to come, eager to see how her relationships and her understanding of the world around her would develop.

events.text_segment:
Before they were separated by the conclusion of the play, she had the unexpected happiness of an invitation to accompany her uncle and aunt in a tour of pleasure which they proposed taking in the summer.
“We have not quite determined how far it shall carry us,” said Mrs. Gardiner; “but perhaps, to the Lakes.”
No scheme could have been more agreeable to Elizabeth, and her acceptance of the invitation was most ready and grateful. “My dear, dear aunt,” she rapturously cried, “what delight! what felicity! You give me fresh life and vigour. Adieu to disappointment and spleen. What are men to rocks and mountains? Oh, what hours of transport we shall spend! And when we do return, it shall not be like other travellers, without being able to give one accurate idea of anything. We will know where we have gone—we will recollect what we have seen. Lakes, mountains, and rivers, shall not be jumbled together in our imaginations; nor, when we attempt to describe any particular scene, will we begin quarrelling about its relative situation. Let our first effusions be less insupportable than those of the generality of travellers.”

events.text_segment:
Every object in the next day’s journey was new and interesting to Elizabeth; and her spirits were in a state of enjoyment; for she had seen her sister looking so well as to banish all fear for her health, and the prospect of her northern tour was a constant source of delight.
When they left the high road for the lane to Hunsford, every eye was in search of the Parsonage, and every turning expected to bring it in view. The paling of Rosings park was their boundary on one side. Elizabeth smiled at the recollection of all that she had heard of its inhabitants.
At length the Parsonage was discernible. The garden sloping to the road, the house standing in it, the green pales and the laurel hedge, everything declared they were arriving. Mr. Collins and Charlotte appeared at the door, and the carriage stopped at the small gate, which led by a short gravel walk to the house, amidst the nods and smiles of the whole party. In a moment they were all out of the chaise, rejoicing at the sight of each other. Mrs. Collins welcomed her friend with the liveliest pleasure, and Elizabeth was more and more satisfied with coming, when she found herself so affectionately received. She saw instantly that her cousin’s manners were not altered by his marriage: his formal civility was just what it had been; and he detained her some minutes at the gate to hear and satisfy his inquiries after all her family. They were then, with no other delay than his pointing out the neatness of the entrance, taken into the house; and as soon as they were in the parlour, he welcomed them a second time, with ostentatious formality, to his humble abode, and punctually repeated all his wife’s offers of refreshment.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Every object in the next day’s journey was new and interesting to Elizabeth; and her spirits were in a state of enjoyment; for she had seen her sister looking so well as to banish all fear for her health, and the prospect of her northern tour was a constant source of delight.

As they drew near to Hunsford, the excitement grew. Elizabeth’s mind was busy with thoughts of her visit, and she looked eagerly for the familiar sights. When the carriage finally turned into the lane that led to the Parsonage, she caught sight of the neat, comfortable house, nestled beside the grander estate of Rosings Park.

The moment the carriage stopped, Mr. Collins and Charlotte were at the door to greet them. The door swung open, and everyone stepped out, exchanging warm smiles and greetings. Charlotte welcomed Elizabeth with genuine affection, and Elizabeth felt a renewed sense of satisfaction at her decision to visit.

Elizabeth observed that Mr. Collins’s manner was still formal and somewhat pompous, even after his marriage. He lingered at the gate, asking her numerous questions about her family, his tone polite but somewhat self-important.

After Mr. Collins pointed out the tidy appearance of the entrance, they were led inside. In the parlour, Mr. Collins formally welcomed them once more to his humble abode, and Charlotte, ever attentive, offered refreshments, which they accepted with gratitude.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
Every object in the next day’s journey was new and interesting to Elizabeth; and her spirits were in a state of enjoyment; for she had seen her sister looking so well as to banish all fear for her health, and the prospect of her northern tour was a constant source of delight.

As they approached Hunsford, the party looked out eagerly for the Parsonage, which was situated at the end of a lane, bordering Rosings Park, and was separated from it by a paling of green, with a laurel hedge behind. The house was not large, but very neat, and the garden was well kept. The lane was lined with trees, and the whole scene was very pleasing.

At length, the Parsonage came in view, and the carriage drew up at the door. Mr. Collins and Charlotte were at the door to receive them. The carriage stopped, and everyone got out. They exchanged greetings, and Charlotte welcomed Elizabeth with warmth and pleasure.

Elizabeth observed that Mr. Collins’s manners were still formal and slightly pompous, as usual. He detained her at the gate with a long inquiry about her family, and then, after pointing out the neatness of the entrance, they were led inside.

In the parlour, Mr. Collins formally welcomed them again to his humble abode, and his wife, Mrs. Collins, was very lively in her pleasure at seeing Elizabeth. She offered refreshments, which Mr. Collins echoed, repeating his wife’s offers with a formal air.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Elizabeth was prepared to see him in his glory; and she could not help fancying that in displaying the good proportion of the room, its aspect, and its furniture, he addressed himself particularly to her, as if wishing to make her feel what she had lost in refusing him.

events.text_segment: Elizabeth was prepared to see him in his glory; and she could not help fancying that in displaying the good proportion of the room, its aspect, and its furniture, he addressed himself particularly to her, as if wishing to make her feel what she had lost in refusing him. But though everything seemed neat and comfortable, she was not able to gratify him by any sigh of repentance; and rather looked with wonder at her friend, that she could have so cheerful an air with such a companion. When Mr. Collins said anything of which his wife might reasonably be ashamed, which certainly was not seldom, she involuntarily turned her eye on Charlotte. Once or twice she could discern a faint blush; but in general Charlotte wisely did not hear. After sitting long enough to admire every article of furniture in the room, from the sideboard to the fender, to give an account of their journey, and of all that had happened in London, Mr. Collins invited them to take a stroll in the garden, which was large and well laid out, and to the cultivation of which he attended himself. To work in his garden was one of his most respectable pleasures; and Elizabeth admired the command of countenance with which Charlotte talked of the healthfulness of the exercise, and owned she encouraged it as much as possible. Here, leading the way through every walk and cross walk, and scarcely allowing them an interval to utter the praises he asked for, every view was pointed out with a minuteness which left beauty entirely behind. He could number the fields in every direction, and could tell how many trees there were in the most distant clump. But of all the views which his garden, or which the country or the kingdom could boast, none were to be compared with the prospect of Rosings, afforded by an opening in the trees that bordered the park nearly opposite the front of his house. It was a handsome modern building, well situated on rising ground.

But her thoughts were soon diverted from this vain fancy by the entrance of Mr. Darcy himself. He appeared, as usual, proud and reserved, yet there was a softness in his eyes that Elizabeth had not observed before. She observed him with a mixture of curiosity and disdain, recalling their previous encounters and the feelings they had stirred in her. As he approached, she could not help but notice the slight hesitation in his step, perhaps a sign of his own internal conflict.

"Miss Bennet," he began, with a tone that was more gentle than usual, "I hope you will do me the honor of dancing with me this evening." Elizabeth, surprised by his politeness, hesitated for a moment before replying, "With pleasure, Mr. Darcy." The dance commenced, and as they moved across the floor, their conversation was marked by a newfound civility. Darcy, in a rare moment of openness, expressed his admiration for her wit and vivacity, qualities he had previously overlooked.

Elizabeth, in turn, acknowledged his improvements and the changes she had observed in him. Their dance was a silent dialogue, a step towards mutual understanding. As the evening progressed, Elizabeth found herself contemplating the complexities of her feelings and the possibility that her prejudices might have been unfounded. Darcy's manner was no longer the aloofness of pride, but a reflection of genuine respect and affection.

By the end of the evening, Elizabeth felt a cautious hope blossoming within her. Perhaps, she thought, there was more to Mr. Darcy than his proud exterior, and perhaps, their story was not yet concluded.

events.text_segment:
She had already learnt that Lady Catherine was still in the country. It was spoken of again while they were at dinner, when Mr. Collins joining in, observed,—
“Yes, Miss Elizabeth, you will have the honour of seeing Lady Catherine de Bourgh on the ensuing Sunday at church, and I need not say you will be delighted with her. She is all affability and condescension, and I doubt not but you will be honoured with some portion of her notice when service is over. I have scarcely any hesitation in saying that she will include you and my sister Maria in every invitation with which she honours us during your stay here. Her behaviour to my dear Charlotte is charming. We dine at Rosings twice every week, and are never allowed to walk home. Her Ladyship’s carriage is regularly ordered for us. I should say, one of her Ladyship’s carriages, for she has several.”
“Lady Catherine is a very respectable, sensible woman, indeed,” added Charlotte, “and a most attentive neighbour.”
“Very true, my dear, that is exactly what I say. She is the sort of woman whom one cannot regard with too much deference.”

events.title: Sudden Commotion and Mysterious Sight
detailed_summary: Around midday the following day, while Elizabeth is in her room preparing for a walk, a sudden noise suggests chaos downstairs.
She hears someone running upstairs urgently and calling her name loudly.
Opening her door, Elizabeth finds Maria on the landing, agitated and out of breath.
Maria urges Elizabeth to hurry down to the dining room to witness an extraordinary sight, refusing to divulge what it is.
Despite Elizabeth's questions, Maria reveals nothing more.
They both rush down to the dining room, which overlooks the lane, to discover the source of the excitement: two women stopping in a small carriage (a low phaeton) at the garden gate.

events.text_segment:
About the middle of the next day, as she was in her room getting ready for a walk, a sudden noise below seemed to speak the whole house in confusion; and, after listening a moment, she heard somebody running upstairs in a violent hurry, and calling loudly after her. She opened the door, and met Maria in the landing-place, who, breathless with agitation, cried out,—
“Oh, my dear Eliza! pray make haste and come into the dining-room, for there is such a sight to be seen! I will not tell you what it is. Make haste, and come down this moment.”
Elizabeth asked questions in vain; Maria would tell her nothing more; and down they ran into the dining-room which fronted the lane, in quest of this wonder; it was two ladies, stopping in a low phaeton at the garden gate.

detailed_summary: Elizabeth expresses disappointment, having expected something more dramatic than just visitors.
Maria corrects Elizabeth, clarifying the ladies are Mrs. Jenkinson and Miss De Bourgh, not Lady Catherine.
Maria points out Miss De Bourgh's unexpectedly small and thin appearance.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “And is this all?” cried Elizabeth.

events.text_segment:
“And is this all?” cried Elizabeth. “I expected at least that the pigs were got into the garden, and here is nothing but Lady Catherine and her daughter!”
“La! my dear,” said Maria, quite shocked at the mistake, “it is not Lady Catherine. The old lady is Mrs. Jenkinson, who lives with them. The other is Miss De Bourgh. Only look at her. She is quite a little creature. Who would have thought she could be so thin and small!”
“She is abominably rude to keep Charlotte out of doors in all this wind. Why does she not come in?”
“Oh, Charlotte says she hardly ever does. It is the greatest of favours when Miss De Bourgh comes in.”
“I like her appearance,” said Elizabeth, struck with other ideas. “She looks sickly and cross. Yes, she will do for him very well. She will make him a very proper wife.”
Mr. Collins and Charlotte were both standing at the gate in conversation with the ladies; and Sir William, to Elizabeth’s high diversion, was stationed in the doorway, in earnest contemplation of the greatness before him, and constantly bowing whenever Miss De Bourgh looked that way.
At length there was nothing more to be said; the ladies drove on, and the others returned into the house. Mr. Collins no sooner saw the two girls than he began to congratulate them on their good fortune, which Charlotte explained by letting them know that the whole party was asked to dine at Rosings the next day.

**CHAPTERXXVIII.**

“And is this all?” cried Elizabeth, her voice tinged with disappointment. She had anticipated something more dramatic, perhaps a grander arrival or an unexpected visitor, but instead, only a few ladies and a gentleman had come to the gate.

Maria, standing beside her, quickly corrected, “Those are Mrs. Jenkinson and Miss De Bourgh, not Lady Catherine herself.” She pointed subtly toward the figures at the gate. Elizabeth’s eyes fixed on Miss De Bourgh, who appeared surprisingly small and thin, her demeanor somewhat cross and sickly, which struck Elizabeth as odd for someone of her station.

Elizabeth couldn’t help but criticize, “And Miss De Bourgh’s rudeness in keeping Charlotte standing outside in the wind is quite uncalled for.” Maria explained that Miss De Bourgh rarely entered the Parsonage, and her presence at the gate was a rare favor, making even her brief appearance noteworthy.

Elizabeth observed Miss De Bourgh more closely, noting her appearance and muttering, “She would make a very suitable wife for Mr. Darcy—if only her temper matched her looks.” Meanwhile, Mr. Collins and Charlotte were engaged in conversation with the visitors, their voices muffled but evidently cordial.

Sir William stood in the doorway, his manner quite humorous—bowing repeatedly toward Miss De Bourgh whenever she glanced his way, much to Elizabeth’s amusement. The scene was lively, yet brief; soon, the ladies in the phaeton drove away, and the Hunsford party returned inside.

Mr. Collins, ever eager, immediately congratulated Elizabeth and Maria on their good fortune. Charlotte, with her usual calm, clarified that the entire party had been invited to dine at Rosings the following day, a prospect that filled Elizabeth with a mixture of curiosity and anticipation.

---

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: “And is this all?” cried Elizabeth, with a look of surprise and some disdain. “I expected to find more than this, more than a mere collection of superficial acquaintances and empty compliments. Surely, there must be something more substantial, more genuine, in the society we are meant to be part of.” She paused, her eyes scanning the room filled with genteel but somewhat insipid faces. “I had hoped for conversations of consequence, for connections that might truly matter, but all I see are polite nods and rehearsed smiles. It seems that beneath the veneer of civility, there is little real warmth or sincerity.” Her sister Jane, standing quietly beside her, looked on with gentle concern. Elizabeth’s words reflected her growing impatience with the superficiality that pervaded their social circle. She longed for genuine engagement, for meaningful discourse that could elevate their spirits and minds. As she spoke, her father approached, a bemused smile on his face. “My dear Elizabeth,” he said, “you are too quick to judge. Society has its charms, and not all are as shallow as they seem. Sometimes, beneath the surface, there are treasures worth discovering.” Elizabeth sighed, her gaze turning away from the crowd. She knew her father’s words were true, yet her heart yearned for something more authentic. She resolved to seek out those who valued sincerity and depth, rather than being content with the empty pleasantries that now surrounded her. In her mind, she vowed to find true happiness and connection, beyond the superficialities of her current environment.

events.title: Mr. Collins Revels in the Invitation and Instructs His Guests
detailed_summary: Mr. Collins expresses immense satisfaction regarding the dinner invitation from Lady Catherine, viewing it as a perfect chance to showcase his patroness's magnificence and her civility towards him and Charlotte to his guests.
He professes surprise at the immediacy and inclusivity of the invitation, though admitting he somewhat anticipated a less grand invitation like tea, given his perception of her Ladyship's affability.
Sir William Lucas validates the invitation's significance by relating it to the refined manners he has observed among the elite during his time associated with the court.
The impending visit becomes the primary topic of conversation for the following day and morning.
Mr. Collins meticulously prepares his guests for the grandeur of Rosings—the rooms, servants, and dinner—to prevent them from feeling utterly overwhelmed.

He specifically reassures Elizabeth about her attire, advising her to wear her best dress but stressing that Lady Catherine values the preservation of rank distinctions over elegant clothing from guests.
During the dressing process, Mr. Collins repeatedly interrupts the ladies to hurry them along, emphasizing Lady Catherine's strong aversion to being kept waiting for dinner.

These descriptions of Lady Catherine's personality and lifestyle significantly frighten Maria Lucas, who is inexperienced with grand social situations and anticipates the introduction with great anxiety, comparable to her father's feelings about his court presentation.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mr. Collins's triumph, in consequence of this invitation, was complete.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Such formidable accounts of her Ladyship, and her manner of living, quite frightened Maria Lucas, who had been little used to company; and she looked forward to her introduction at Rosings with as much apprehension as her father had done to his presentation at St. James’s.

events.text_segment:
Mr. Collins's triumph, in consequence of this invitation, was complete. The power of displaying the grandeur of his patroness to his wondering visitors, and of letting them see her civility towards himself and his wife, was exactly what he had wished for; and that an opportunity of doing it should be given so soon was such an instance of Lady Catherine’s condescension as he knew not how to admire enough.
“I confess,” said he, “that I should not have been at all surprised by her Ladyship’s asking us on Sunday to drink tea and spend the evening at Rosings. I rather expected, from my knowledge of her affability, that it would happen. But who could have foreseen such an attention as this? Who could have imagined that we should receive an invitation to dine there (an invitation, moreover, including the whole party) so immediately after your arrival?”
“I am the less surprised at what has happened,” replied Sir William, “from that knowledge of what the manners of the great really are, which my situation in life has allowed me to acquire. About the court, such instances of elegant breeding are not uncommon.”
Scarcely anything was talked of the whole day or next morning but their visit to Rosings. Mr. Collins was carefully instructing them in what they were to expect, that the sight of such rooms, so many servants, and so splendid a dinner, might not wholly overpower them.
When the ladies were separating for the toilette, he said to Elizabeth,—
“Do not make yourself uneasy, my dear cousin, about your apparel. Lady Catherine is far from requiring that elegance of dress in us which becomes herself and daughter. I would advise you merely to put on whatever of your clothes is superior to the rest—there is no occasion for anything more. Lady Catherine will not think the worse of you for being simply dressed. She likes to have the distinction of rank preserved.”
While they were dressing, he came two or three times to their different doors, to recommend their being quick, as Lady Catherine very much objected to be kept waiting for her dinner. Such formidable accounts of her Ladyship, and her manner of living, quite frightened Maria Lucas, who had been little used to company; and she looked forward to her introduction at Rosings with as much apprehension as her father had done to his presentation at St. James’s.

He felt a sense of satisfaction and self-importance that he had not experienced before. His proposal to Charlotte Lucas had been accepted, and he was now to be married to her, a woman of good sense and modesty, who would make him a comfortable and agreeable wife. Mr. Collins, being a clergyman, was pleased with the prospect of settling into a good parish and gaining the respect of his neighbors.

As he prepared for the wedding, he could not help but reflect on his own good fortune. His patroness, Lady Catherine de Bourgh, had always spoken highly of him, and now he was to be married into a family of some standing. He was confident that his future prospects would be secure, and he looked forward to the social advantages that his marriage would bring.

Meanwhile, Elizabeth Bennet watched his triumph with a mixture of amusement and disdain. She thought him a foolish man, overly eager to please those of higher rank, and she was glad that Charlotte had accepted him, even if she did not share his sentiments.

As the day of the wedding approached, Elizabeth could not help but wonder what the future held for her and her family. Mr. Collins's triumph was a reminder of the social expectations and pressures that governed their lives. Yet, beneath the surface, there was a sense that true happiness depended on more than just social standing and material comfort. events.title: Arrival at Rosings and Introduction to Lady Catherine
detailed_summary: Taking advantage of the fine weather, the party walks about half a mile through the park to Rosings.

Elizabeth finds pleasure in the park's scenery but does not share the rapturous admiration Mr. Collins expects, remaining unaffected by his recitation of the house's front window count and the original cost of the glazing.
As they approach the house and ascend the steps, Maria Lucas's fear intensifies, and even Sir William appears visibly unsettled.

Elizabeth, however, maintains her composure, reasoning that she has heard nothing about Lady Catherine suggesting extraordinary talent or virtue, and believes she can face the mere grandeur of wealth and status without fear.
Inside the entrance hall, Mr. Collins gestures with delight towards the room's proportions and decorations.
Servants guide them through an antechamber into the room where Lady Catherine, her daughter Miss de Bourgh, and Mrs. Jenkinson are seated.
Lady Catherine rises to greet them with notable condescension.
Mrs. Collins performs the introductions effectively, having pre-arranged this with her husband to prevent his likely inclusion of excessive apologies and expressions of gratitude.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Her Ladyship, with great condescension, arose to receive them; and as Mrs. Collins had settled it with her husband that the office of introduction should be hers, it was performed in a proper manner, without any of those apologies and thanks which he would have thought necessary.

events.text_segment:
As the weather was fine, they had a pleasant walk of about half a mile across the park. Every park has its beauty and its prospects; and Elizabeth saw much to be pleased with, though she could not be in such raptures as Mr. Collins expected the scene to inspire, and was but slightly affected by his enumeration of the windows in front of the house, and his relation of what the glazing altogether had originally cost Sir Lewis de Bourgh.
When they ascended the steps to the hall, Maria’s alarm was every moment increasing, and even Sir William did not look perfectly calm. Elizabeth’s courage did not fail her. She had heard nothing of Lady Catherine that spoke her awful from any extraordinary talents or miraculous virtue, and the mere stateliness of money and rank she thought she could witness without trepidation.
From the entrance hall, of which Mr. Collins pointed out, with a rapturous air, the fine proportion and finished ornaments, they followed the servants through an antechamber to the room where Lady Catherine, her daughter, and Mrs. Jenkinson were sitting. Her Ladyship, with great condescension, arose to receive them; and as Mrs. Collins had settled it with her husband that the office of introduction should be hers, it was performed in a proper manner, without any of those apologies and thanks which he would have thought necessary.

events.title: Observations of the Hosts and the Sycophantic Dinner
detailed_summary: Despite his court experience, Sir William is thoroughly intimidated by the surrounding splendor, managing only a silent, deep bow before taking a seat.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: In spite of having been at St. James’s, Sir William was so completely awed by the grandeur surrounding him, that he had but just courage enough to make a very low bow, and take his seat without saying a word; and his daughter, frightened almost out of her senses, sat on the edge of her chair, not knowing which way to look.

events.text_segment:
In spite of having been at St. James’s, Sir William was so completely awed by the grandeur surrounding him, that he had but just courage enough to make a very low bow, and take his seat without saying a word; and his daughter, frightened almost out of her senses, sat on the edge of her chair, not knowing which way to look. Elizabeth found herself quite equal to the scene, and could observe the three ladies before her composedly. Lady Catherine was a tall, large woman, with strongly-marked features, which might once have been handsome. Her air was not conciliating, nor was her manner of receiving them such as to make her visitors forget their inferior rank. She was not rendered formidable by silence: but whatever she said was spoken in so authoritative a tone as marked her self-importance, and brought Mr. Wickham immediately to Elizabeth’s mind; and, from the observation of the day altogether, she believed Lady Catherine to be exactly what he had represented.
When, after examining the mother, in whose countenance and deportment she soon found some resemblance of Mr. Darcy, she turned her eyes on the daughter, she could almost have joined in Maria’s astonishment at her being so thin and so small. There was neither in figure nor face any likeness between the ladies. Miss de Bourgh was pale and sickly: her features, though not plain, were insignificant; and she spoke very little, except in a low voice, to Mrs. Jenkinson, in whose appearance there was nothing remarkable, and who was entirely engaged in listening to what she said, and placing a screen in the proper direction before her eyes.
After sitting a few minutes, they were all sent to one of the windows to admire the view, Mr. Collins attending them to point out its beauties, and Lady Catherine kindly informing them that it was much better worth looking at in the summer.
The dinner was exceedingly handsome, and there were all the servants, and all the articles of plate which Mr. Collins had promised; and, as he had likewise foretold, he took his seat at the bottom of the table, by her Ladyship’s desire, and looked as if he felt that life could furnish nothing greater. He carved and ate and praised with delighted alacrity; and every dish was commended first by him, and then by Sir William, who was now enough recovered to echo whatever his son-in-law said, in a manner which Elizabeth wondered Lady Catherine could bear. But Lady Catherine seemed gratified by their excessive admiration, and gave most gracious smiles, especially when any dish on the table proved a novelty to them. The party did not supply much conversation. Elizabeth was ready to speak whenever there was an opening, but she was seated between Charlotte and Miss de Bourgh—the former of whom was engaged in listening to Lady Catherine, and the latter said not a word to her all the dinnertime. Mrs. Jenkinson was chiefly employed in watching how little Miss de Bourgh ate, pressing her to try some other dish and fearing she was indisposed. Maria thought speaking out of the question, and the gentlemen did nothing but eat and admire.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
As the company assembled in the drawing-room, Lady Catherine de Bourgh's commanding presence filled the space with an air of authority and importance. Elizabeth Bennet, observing her with a mixture of curiosity and disdain, could not help but notice the subtle superiority with which Lady Catherine carried herself. The room was decorated with fine paintings and elegant furniture, a testament to the wealth and taste of its owner.

Mr. Darcy, standing slightly apart, was engaged in a quiet conversation with Mr. Bingley, though his eyes occasionally flicked towards Elizabeth, who was trying to compose herself amidst the overwhelming grandeur. Elizabeth felt a flutter of nervousness, aware of the scrutiny she was under, yet she maintained her composure as best as she could.

Mrs. Bennet, ever eager to make a good impression, fluttered around the room, chatting animatedly with the other ladies, her voice rising above the gentle hum of conversation. Her daughter Jane, with her usual gentle grace, was engaged in a pleasant discussion with Miss Bingley, both young women exchanging smiles and polite remarks.

The atmosphere was thick with anticipation and social expectation, each guest conscious of their place and the importance of making a favorable impression. Sir William, still overwhelmed, managed to murmur a few polite words, his voice barely above a whisper, as he attempted to navigate the unfamiliar social terrain.

As the evening progressed, the conversation turned to topics of mutual interest, with Lady Catherine dominating the discourse, her opinions often delivered with a commanding tone. Elizabeth listened attentively, noting the differences in manners and attitudes that distinguished her from the more modest and reserved company.

Despite her initial trepidation, Elizabeth found herself gradually relaxing, engaging in light-hearted exchanges and observing the interactions around her. She was particularly struck by Mr. Darcy's reserved yet attentive demeanor, which contrasted sharply with the more exuberant personalities present.

The evening drew on, and as the guests prepared to depart, Sir William expressed his gratitude for the hospitality extended to him and his daughter. Elizabeth, feeling a newfound confidence, exchanged a few words with Mr. Darcy, who responded with a slight, acknowledging smile.

As they left the grand estate, Elizabeth reflected on the evening's events, contemplating the complexities of social hierarchy and the importance of genuine character over superficial appearances. The grandeur of St. James’s had left an indelible impression on her, but it was the subtle nuances of human interaction that truly captivated her attention.

events.title: Lady Catherine Dominates the Conversation and Interrogates Elizabeth
detailed_summary: Following dinner, the ladies withdraw to the drawing-room, where Lady Catherine holds court, speaking continuously until coffee is served.
She delivers her opinions on every topic with absolute certainty, demonstrating her intolerance for disagreement.
She probes into Charlotte's domestic arrangements with intrusive familiarity, offering extensive advice on managing her household, servants, cows, and poultry.
Elizabeth notes that Lady Catherine considers no detail beneath her notice if it provides an opportunity to impose her views on others.
In between lecturing Charlotte, Lady Catherine directs questions towards Maria and especially Elizabeth, about whose background she is least informed.
She asks Elizabeth about the number and ages of her sisters, their marital prospects, their looks, their education, her father's carriage, and her mother's maiden name.
Elizabeth perceives the rudeness of these questions but answers them calmly.

Lady Catherine then brings up the entailment of Longbourn on Mr. Collins, expressing satisfaction for Charlotte's benefit but general disapproval of entails that disadvantage female heirs, citing her own family's practice.
She concludes this round of questioning by asking Elizabeth if she plays the piano and sings.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Do you play and sing, Miss Bennet?”

events.text_segment:
When the ladies returned to the drawing-room, there was little to be done but to hear Lady Catherine talk, which she did without any intermission till coffee came in, delivering her opinion on every subject in so decisive a manner as proved that she was not used to have her judgment controverted. She inquired into Charlotte’s domestic concerns familiarly and minutely, and gave her a great deal of advice as to the management of them all; told her how everything ought to be regulated in so small a family as hers, and instructed her as to the care of her cows and her poultry. Elizabeth found that nothing was beneath this great lady’s attention which could furnish her with an occasion for dictating to others. In the intervals of her discourse with Mrs. Collins, she addressed a variety of questions to Maria and Elizabeth, but especially to the latter, of whose connections she knew the least, and who, she observed to Mrs. Collins, was a very genteel, pretty kind of girl. She asked her at different times how many sisters she had, whether they were older or younger than herself, whether any of them were likely to be married, whether they were handsome, where they had been educated, what carriage her father kept, and what had been her mother’s maiden name? Elizabeth felt all the impertinence of her questions, but answered them very composedly. Lady Catherine then observed,—
“Your father’s estate is entailed on Mr. Collins, I think? For your sake,” turning to Charlotte, “I am glad of it; but otherwise I see no occasion for entailing estates from the female line. It was not thought necessary in Sir Lewis de Bourgh’s family. Do you play and sing, Miss Bennet?”

events.title: Elizabeth Responds to Lady Catherine with Poise and Wit
detailed_summary: Elizabeth replies modestly that she plays and sings 'a little'.
Lady Catherine expresses an intention to hear her perform on Rosings' 'capital' instrument someday and proceeds to ask if Elizabeth's sisters also possess these accomplishments.

Upon learning only one sister does, Lady Catherine criticizes their upbringing, insisting all should have learned, citing the Miss Webbs as an example despite their father's smaller income, and asks if Elizabeth or her sisters can draw.
Elizabeth states that none of them draw.
Lady Catherine finds this 'very strange,' attributing it to a lack of opportunity and suggesting their mother should have taken them to London annually for instruction.
Elizabeth corrects her, stating her mother would agree, but her father dislikes London.

Lady Catherine then inquires about their governess, expressing shock and disbelief when told they never had one, deeming it impossible to raise five daughters properly without one and assuming their mother must have been entirely devoted ('a slave') to their education.
Elizabeth suppresses a smile while assuring Lady Catherine this was not the case.
Lady Catherine presses further, asking who taught them and attended to them, implying neglect without a governess.

Elizabeth concedes they might seem neglected compared to some families, but clarifies that those sisters wanting to learn always had the necessary resources, encouragement to read, and access to masters, while those preferring idleness were free to do so.

Lady Catherine retorts that a governess prevents idleness and boasts of her success in placing governesses, mentioning Mrs. Jenkinson's nieces and a recent recommendation to Lady Metcalfe, who reportedly called Miss Pope 'a treasure'.
She shifts topic, asking if any of Elizabeth's younger sisters are 'out' in society.
Elizabeth confirms that all five sisters are out.
Lady Catherine reacts with astonishment, finding it 'very odd' that all five are out at once, especially the younger ones before the elder sisters are married.

Elizabeth defends her family's practice, arguing against penalizing younger sisters by denying them social opportunities due to the marital status of older siblings, asserting the youngest has an equal right to enjoy youth and that such restrictions would harm sisterly affection.
Impressed or perhaps provoked by Elizabeth's forthrightness, Lady Catherine comments on her opinionated nature for her age and directly demands to know her age.
Elizabeth skillfully sidesteps the intrusive question with a smile, suggesting that with three younger sisters already grown, Lady Catherine couldn't reasonably expect her to reveal it.
This response leaves Lady Catherine quite surprised, and Elizabeth suspects she might be the first person ever to treat her Ladyship's 'dignified impertinence' with such lighthearted defiance.
Lady Catherine attempts to guess, stating Elizabeth cannot be older than twenty.
Elizabeth simply confirms, 'I am not one-and-twenty.'

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “A little.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “I am not one-and-twenty.”

events.text_segment:
“A little.”
“Oh then—some time or other we shall be happy to hear you. Our instrument is a capital one, probably superior to —— you shall try it some day. Do your sisters play and sing?”
“One of them does.”
“Why did not you all learn? You ought all to have learned. The Miss Webbs all play, and their father has not so good an income as yours. Do you draw?”
“No, not at all.”
“What, none of you?”
“Not one.”
“That is very strange. But I suppose you had no opportunity. Your mother should have taken you to town every spring for the benefit of masters.”
“My mother would have no objection, but my father hates London.”
“Has your governess left you?”
“We never had any governess.”
“No governess! How was that possible? Five daughters brought up at home without a governess! I never heard of such a thing. Your mother must have been quite a slave to your education.”
Elizabeth could hardly help smiling, as she assured her that had not been the case.
“Then who taught you? who attended to you? Without a governess, you must have been neglected.”
“Compared with some families, I believe we were; but such of us as wished to learn never wanted the means. We were always encouraged to read, and had all the masters that were necessary. Those who chose to be idle certainly might.”
“Ay, no doubt: but that is what a governess will prevent; and if I had known your mother, I should have advised her most strenuously to engage one. I always say that nothing is to be done in education without steady and regular instruction, and nobody but a governess can give it. It is wonderful how many families I have been the means of supplying in that way. I am always glad to get a young person well placed out. Four nieces of Mrs. Jenkinson are most delightfully situated through my means; and it was but the other day that I recommended another young person, who was merely accidentally mentioned to me, and the family are quite delighted with her. Mrs. Collins, did I tell you of Lady Metcalfe’s calling yesterday to thank me? She finds Miss Pope a treasure. ‘Lady Catherine,’ said she, ‘you have given me a treasure.’ Are any of your younger sisters out, Miss Bennet?”
“Yes, ma’am, all.”
“All! What, all five out at once? Very odd! And you only the second. The younger ones out before the elder are married! Your younger sisters must be very young?”
“Yes, my youngest is not sixteen. Perhaps she is full young to be much in company. But really, ma’am, I think it would be very hard upon younger sisters that they should not have their share of society and amusement, because the elder may not have the means or inclination to marry early. The last born has as good a right to the pleasures of youth as the first. And to be kept back on such a motive! I think it would not be very likely to promote sisterly affection or delicacy of mind.”
“Upon my word,” said her Ladyship, “you give your opinion very decidedly for so young a person. Pray, what is your age?”
“With three younger sisters grown up,” replied Elizabeth, smiling, “your Ladyship can hardly expect me to own it.”
Lady Catherine seemed quite astonished at not receiving a direct answer; and Elizabeth suspected herself to be the first creature who had ever dared to trifle with so much dignified impertinence.
“You cannot be more than twenty, I am sure,—therefore you need not conceal your age.”
“I am not one-and-twenty.”

Lady Catherine found this very strange, attributing it to a lack of opportunity, and suggested their mother should have taken them to London annually for instruction. Elizabeth corrected her, saying that her mother would have agreed, but her father disliked London.

Lady Catherine then inquired about their governess, expressing shock when told they had never had one. She declared it impossible to raise five daughters properly without a governess and assumed their mother must have been entirely devoted to their education. Elizabeth suppressed a smile and assured her that was not the case.

Lady Catherine pressed further, asking who had attended to their education. Elizabeth admitted that they might seem neglected compared to some families, but clarified that those sisters who wished to learn always had the means, encouragement to read, and access to masters, while those who preferred idleness were free to do so.

Lady Catherine retorted that a governess would prevent idleness and boasted of her success in placing governesses, mentioning Mrs. Jenkinson’s nieces and a recent recommendation to Lady Metcalfe, who called Miss Pope “a treasure.”

She then shifted the topic, asking if any of Elizabeth’s younger sisters were “out” in society. Elizabeth confirmed that all five sisters were out.

Lady Catherine was astonished. “All five at once? That is very odd,” she said. “Especially the younger ones before the elder sisters are married.”

Elizabeth defended her family’s practice, arguing that it would be unjust to deny the younger sisters the opportunity to enjoy society because the older ones were unmarried. She insisted that the youngest had an equal right to youth and that such restrictions would harm sisterly affection.

Impressed or perhaps provoked by Elizabeth’s forthrightness, Lady Catherine remarked on her opinionated nature for her age and demanded to know her age. Elizabeth, with a smile, sidestepped the question, saying that with three younger sisters already grown, Lady Catherine could not reasonably expect her to reveal her age.

This response surprised Lady Catherine, and Elizabeth suspected she might be the first person ever to treat her Ladyship’s “dignified impertinence” with such lighthearted defiance. Lady Catherine guessed she could not be older than twenty.

Elizabeth simply replied, “I am not one-and-twenty.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Elizabeth Bennet looked at Mr. Darcy with a mixture of curiosity and skepticism. "A little," she repeated, raising an eyebrow. "And what, pray, is the extent of your acquaintance with the world outside your own estate?" Mr. Darcy, slightly taken aback by her directness, adjusted his cravat and replied, "I have seen enough to know that there is much to learn, and much to admire in the society of others. But I confess, I am still a novice in many respects." Elizabeth smiled, her eyes twinkling with mischief. "Well, Mr. Darcy, I dare say that a little knowledge is a dangerous thing, but a little experience can be quite enlightening." He looked at her, a hint of a smile playing on his lips. "Perhaps you are right, Miss Bennet. I am eager to learn, and I hope to do so under your guidance." Elizabeth felt her cheeks flush at his words, but she maintained her composure. "Very well," she said, turning away slightly. "Let us proceed, then, and see what the world has in store for us." As they continued their walk, Elizabeth reflected on the conversation. She wondered if Mr. Darcy's words were sincere, or if they merely masked his usual reserve. She also thought about her own perceptions of him—how they had changed from the first time they met, when she had judged him as proud and aloof. Now, she saw a different side of him, one that was perhaps more vulnerable and earnest. The afternoon sun cast a warm glow over the landscape, and the gentle rustling of the leaves added a soothing backdrop to their dialogue. Elizabeth decided to test his sincerity further. "Tell me, Mr. Darcy," she inquired, "what do you value most in a person?" He paused, considering her question carefully. "Honesty and integrity," he replied. "Without those qualities, I believe, one cannot truly be oneself." Elizabeth nodded thoughtfully. "And do you think you possess these qualities?" she asked with a teasing smile. Mr. Darcy looked at her, a hint of a smile breaking through his usual seriousness. "I hope so," he said softly. "But I am aware of my shortcomings, and I am constantly striving to improve." Elizabeth was pleased to hear this. It showed humility and a desire for growth—traits she admired. As they approached the end of their walk, Elizabeth felt a newfound respect for Mr. Darcy. She realized that beneath his initial reserve lay a man of depth and principle. She wondered if he felt the same about her, or if he still saw her as merely a spirited young woman with little regard for propriety. When they reached the house, Mr. Darcy turned to her and said, "Miss Bennet, I am grateful for this walk. It has been most enlightening for me." Elizabeth smiled warmly. "And I, for one, have enjoyed your company more than I expected." They parted ways with a mutual understanding, each contemplating the other's words and actions. Elizabeth thought about how her perceptions had shifted, and she wondered what the future held for them. She knew that love and understanding often grew from the most unlikely beginnings, and she was willing to see where this new path might lead.

events.title: Card Games and Departure from Rosings
detailed_summary: The gentlemen return, tea is served, and then card tables are arranged for evening entertainment.
One table consists of Lady Catherine, Sir William, Mr. Collins, and Mrs. Collins playing quadrille.
Miss de Bourgh chooses to play cassino, forming a second table with Elizabeth, Maria, and Mrs. Jenkinson.

The cassino game proves exceptionally dull; conversation revolves solely around the game rules, punctuated only by Mrs. Jenkinson's anxious inquiries about Miss de Bourgh's physical comfort (temperature, lighting).
Activity at the quadrille table is much livelier, dominated by Lady Catherine's pronouncements, corrections of her partners' play, and personal anecdotes.
Mr. Collins remains deferential, agreeing with everything Lady Catherine says, thanking her for each point won, and apologizing if he perceives he is winning too frequently.
Sir William contributes little conversationally, focusing instead on committing anecdotes and aristocratic names to memory.
The card games conclude when Lady Catherine and her daughter decide they have played sufficiently.
The Collins's carriage is offered to transport the visitors home, an offer which is accepted with gratitude and the carriage is promptly ordered.
While waiting, the entire party gathers around the fireplace to hear Lady Catherine pronounce her forecast for the following day's weather.
The arrival of the coach interrupts these 'instructions,' signaling time for departure.
Mr. Collins delivers numerous thankful speeches, Sir William executes many bows, and the visitors finally leave Rosings.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: From these instructions they were summoned by the arrival of the coach; and with many speeches of thankfulness on Mr. Collins’s side, and as many bows on Sir William’s, they departed.

events.text_segment:
When the gentlemen had joined them, and tea was over, the card tables were placed. Lady Catherine, Sir William, and Mr. and Mrs. Collins sat down to quadrille; and as Miss De Bourgh chose to play at cassino, the two girls had the honour of assisting Mrs. Jenkinson to make up her party. Their table was superlatively stupid. Scarcely a syllable was uttered that did not relate to the game, except when Mrs. Jenkinson expressed her fears of Miss De Bourgh’s being too hot or too cold, or having too much or too little light. A great deal more passed at the other table. Lady Catherine was generally speaking—stating the mistakes of the three others, or relating some anecdote of herself. Mr. Collins was employed in agreeing to everything her Ladyship said, thanking her for every fish he won, and apologizing if he thought he won too many. Sir William did not say much. He was storing his memory with anecdotes and noble names.
When Lady Catherine and her daughter had played as long as they chose, the tables were broken up, the carriage was offered to Mrs. Collins, gratefully accepted, and immediately ordered. The party then gathered round the fire to hear Lady Catherine determine what weather they were to have on the morrow. From these instructions they were summoned by the arrival of the coach; and with many speeches of thankfulness on Mr. Collins’s side, and as many bows on Sir William’s, they departed.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: When the gentlemen had joined them, and tea was over, the card tables were placed. One was occupied by Lady Catherine, Sir William Lucas, Mr. Collins, and Mrs. Collins, who engaged in a game of quadrille. Miss de Bourgh, choosing to play cassino, formed a second table with Elizabeth Bennet, Maria Lucas, and Mrs. Jenkinson. The cassino game was exceedingly dull; the conversation was confined to the rules of the game, with Mrs. Jenkinson frequently inquiring about Miss de Bourgh's comfort—her temperature, her lighting, and so forth. Meanwhile, the activity at the quadrille table was much livelier, with Lady Catherine giving her opinions, correcting her partners' play, and sharing personal anecdotes. Mr. Collins remained deferential, agreeing with Lady Catherine, thanking her for each point he gained, and apologizing if he thought he was winning too often. Sir William contributed little to the conversation, focusing instead on memorizing anecdotes and aristocratic names. After some time, Lady Catherine and her daughter decided they had played enough, and the card tables were cleared. The Collinses' carriage was then offered to take the visitors home, an offer they gratefully accepted, and the carriage was quickly ordered. While waiting, everyone gathered around the fireplace to listen to Lady Catherine's weather forecast for the next day. Their conversation was interrupted by the arrival of the coach, signaling it was time to depart. Mr. Collins delivered many thankful speeches, Sir William made numerous bows, and the visitors finally took their leave of Rosings.

events.title: Sir William's Departure and the Collinses' Domestic Routine
detailed_summary: Sir William Lucas concludes his week-long visit, satisfied with his daughter Charlotte's comfortable marriage and situation.
After his departure, the household routine resumes.
Mr. Collins spends his mornings occupied with driving Sir William, but afterward returns to his own pursuits: gardening, reading, writing, and observing the road from his front-facing book room.
The women occupy a room at the back of the house.
Elizabeth initially questioned Charlotte's choice of sitting room, as the dining parlour seemed more pleasant.
She soon understood Charlotte's motive: the less desirable room ensured Mr. Collins remained occupied in his own separate space, a strategy Elizabeth credits Charlotte for.

Mr. Collins diligently reports these occurrences, even though they are frequent.
Miss De Bourgh sometimes stops for brief conversations with Charlotte at the Parsonage but rarely alights from her carriage.

events.text_segment:
Sir William stayed only a week at Hunsford; but his visit was long enough to convince him of his daughter’s being most comfortably settled, and of her possessing such a husband and such a neighbour as were not often met with. While Sir William was with them, Mr. Collins devoted his mornings to driving him out in his gig, and showing him the country: but when he went away, the whole family returned to their usual employments, and Elizabeth was thankful to find that they did not see more of her cousin by the alteration; for the chief of the time between breakfast and dinner was now passed by him either at work in the garden, or in reading and writing, and looking out of window in his own book room, which fronted the road. The room in which the ladies sat was backwards. Elizabeth at first had rather wondered that Charlotte should not prefer the dining parlour for common use; it was a better sized room, and had a pleasanter aspect: but she soon saw that her friend had an excellent reason for what she did, for Mr. Collins would undoubtedly have been much less in his own apartment had they sat in one equally lively; and she gave Charlotte credit for the arrangement.
From the drawing-room they could distinguish nothing in the lane, and were indebted to Mr. Collins for the knowledge of what carriages went along, and how often especially Miss De Bourgh drove by in her phaeton, which he never failed coming to inform them of, though it happened almost every day. She not unfrequently stopped at the Parsonage, and had a few minutes’ conversation with Charlotte, but was scarcely ever prevailed on to get out.

events.title: Lady Catherine's Patronage and Parish Oversight
detailed_summary: Mr. Collins frequently visits Rosings, often accompanied by Charlotte.
Elizabeth realizes these visits are likely motivated by the hope of securing future church livings from Lady Catherine.
Lady Catherine occasionally visits the Parsonage.
During her visits, Lady Catherine meticulously inspects the household, observing their activities, critiquing their needlework, finding fault with furniture placement, and detecting staff negligence.
If she accepts refreshments, it seems primarily an opportunity to criticize Mrs. Collins's housekeeping, such as the size of meat joints.
Elizabeth observes that Lady Catherine acts like an active local magistrate, despite not holding an official position.
Mr. Collins reports all minor parish matters to her.
Lady Catherine personally intervenes in villagers' affairs, settling disputes, quelling discontent, and admonishing them towards better behavior and prosperity.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Very few days passed in which Mr. Collins did not walk to Rosings, and not many in which his wife did not think it necessary to go likewise; and till Elizabeth recollected that there might be other family livings to be disposed of, she could not understand the sacrifice of so many hours.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Elizabeth soon perceived, that though this great lady was not in the commission of the peace for the county, she was a most active magistrate in her own parish, the minutest concerns of which were carried to her by Mr. Collins; and whenever any of the cottagers were disposed to be quarrelsome, discontented, or too poor, she sallied forth into the village to settle their differences, silence their complaints, and scold them into harmony and plenty.

events.text_segment:
Very few days passed in which Mr. Collins did not walk to Rosings, and not many in which his wife did not think it necessary to go likewise; and till Elizabeth recollected that there might be other family livings to be disposed of, she could not understand the sacrifice of so many hours. Now and then they were honoured with a call from her Ladyship, and nothing escaped her observation that was passing in the room during these visits. She examined into their employments, looked at their work, and advised them to do it differently; found fault with the arrangement of the furniture, or detected the housemaid in negligence; and if she accepted any refreshment, seemed to do it only for the sake of finding out that Mrs. Collins’s joints of meat were too large for her family.
Elizabeth soon perceived, that though this great lady was not in the commission of the peace for the county, she was a most active magistrate in her own parish, the minutest concerns of which were carried to her by Mr. Collins; and whenever any of the cottagers were disposed to be quarrelsome, discontented, or too poor, she sallied forth into the village to settle their differences, silence their complaints, and scold them into harmony and plenty.

events.title: Elizabeth's Quiet Life and Solitary Pleasures at Hunsford
detailed_summary: The routine includes dining at Rosings about twice a week, events which are largely identical to their first experience, minus Sir William.
Evening entertainment typically involves only one card table.
The Collinses have limited other social engagements due to their financial constraints relative to the neighbourhood's lifestyle.
Elizabeth does not mind the lack of social activity.

The fine weather allows her frequent enjoyment outdoors.
She establishes a favorite walk in a sheltered grove bordering the Rosings park, a path seemingly unused by others.

events.text_segment: The entertainment of dining at Rosings was repeated about twice a week; and, allowing for the loss of Sir William, and there being only one card-table in the evening, every such entertainment was the counterpart of the first. Their other engagements were few, as the style of living of the neighbourhood in general was beyond the Collinses’ reach. This, however, was no evil to Elizabeth, and upon the whole she spent her time comfortably enough: there were half hours of pleasant conversation with Charlotte, and the weather was so fine for the time of year, that she had often great enjoyment out of doors. Her favourite walk, and where she frequently went while the others were calling on Lady Catherine, was along the open grove which edged that side of the park, where there was a nice sheltered path, which no one seemed to value but herself, and where she felt beyond the reach of Lady Catherine’s curiosity.

She had a particular fondness for a quiet, secluded path that seemed seldom used, which she often chose for her solitary strolls when the Collinses were at Lady Catherine's, providing her with a welcome retreat from Lady Catherine's inquisitive nature. Her conversations with Charlotte Lucas Collins remained pleasant, and she appreciated the simplicity of their social engagements, which contrasted with the more elaborate entertainments of the neighborhood.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: The entertainment of dining at Rosings was repeated about twice a week; and, allowing for the loss of Sir William, and there being only one card-table in the evening, every such entertainment was the counterpart of the first. The Collinses had little other social engagement, as their circumstances did not permit them to keep up the style of the neighborhood; and Elizabeth, though she did not mind the want of variety, found her time generally pass very pleasantly, chiefly in conversations with Charlotte. The fine weather was often an inducement to enjoy the open air, and she had a favorite walk in a sheltered grove bordering the park, a path which seemed seldom used, and which she particularly valued when the Collinses were visiting Lady Catherine, as it gave her a retreat from her prying and domineering ladyship.
