events.title: Darcy's Unexpected Visit and Abrupt Proposal
detailed_summary: Elizabeth is startled by the doorbell, momentarily hoping it might be Colonel Fitzwilliam making a late call.
Her hopes are dashed, and she is utterly astonished when Mr. Darcy enters the room instead.
Darcy awkwardly and quickly inquires about her health, suggesting this is the reason for his unexpected visit.
Elizabeth responds with polite coldness.
After a brief moment sitting, Darcy stands and paces the room restlessly.
Elizabeth remains silent, though surprised by his behaviour.
Following several minutes of tense silence, Darcy approaches her in an agitated state.
He declares that he has struggled against his feelings unsuccessfully and professes his ardent admiration and love for her.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: While settling this point, she was suddenly roused by the sound of the door-bell; and her spirits were a little fluttered by the idea of its being Colonel Fitzwilliam himself, who had once before called late in the evening, and might now come to inquire particularly after her.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “In vain have I struggled. It will not do. My feelings will not be repressed. You must allow me to tell you how ardently I admire and love you.”

events.text_segment:
While settling this point, she was suddenly roused by the sound of the door-bell; and her spirits were a little fluttered by the idea of its being Colonel Fitzwilliam himself, who had once before called late in the evening, and might now come to inquire particularly after her. But this idea was soon banished, and her spirits were very differently affected, when, to her utter amazement, she saw Mr. Darcy walk into the room. In a hurried manner he immediately began an inquiry after her health, imputing his visit to a wish of hearing that she were better. She answered him with cold civility. He sat down for a few moments, and then getting up walked about the room. Elizabeth was surprised, but said not a word. After a silence of several minutes, he came towards her in an agitated manner, and thus began:—
“In vain have I struggled. It will not do. My feelings will not be repressed. You must allow me to tell you how ardently I admire and love you.”

Her expectations were soon disappointed; for instead of Colonel Fitzwilliam, Mr. Darcy entered the room. He looked at her with a mixture of embarrassment and agitation, and, after a moment's pause, inquired, very hurriedly, after her health. Elizabeth responded with a polite but cool acknowledgment. They sat for a short time in silence, during which Darcy rose and began to walk about the room with restless steps. Elizabeth remained silent, surprised at his unusual behaviour. After a few moments, Darcy approached her, his face flushed with emotion. 'In vain I have struggled,' he said, 'I have struggled against my feelings, but I can no longer conceal the truth. I love you, Elizabeth. I have loved you from the first moment I saw you, and I cannot help myself.'

events.title: Darcy Elaborates on His Conflicted Feelings and Pride
detailed_summary: Elizabeth is rendered speechless by his declaration, experiencing a mixture of shock, confusion, and doubt.
Darcy misinterprets her silence as encouragement and proceeds to explain the depth and duration of his feelings.
His explanation, while eloquent regarding affection, gives equal weight to his conflicting feelings.
He emphasizes his awareness of her social inferiority, the perceived degradation of the connection, and the family-related objections that his judgment raised against his inclination.
He speaks of these obstacles with a fervor that seems focused on the magnitude of the social sacrifice he is making, which Elizabeth finds deeply insulting and counterproductive to his suit.
Despite her strong dislike, Elizabeth initially feels a flicker of acknowledgment for the compliment of his affection and anticipates the pain her refusal will cause him.
However, his subsequent dwelling on her perceived inferiority fuels her resentment, erasing any compassion she might have felt.
She resolves to maintain her composure and answer him patiently once he finishes speaking.
Darcy concludes by reiterating the strength of his attachment, which he claims he could not suppress despite his efforts, and expresses his confident expectation that she will accept his proposal.
His confident demeanor, despite mentioning apprehension, further irritates Elizabeth.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Elizabeth’s astonishment was beyond expression.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Such a circumstance could only exasperate farther; and when he ceased the colour rose into her cheeks and she said,—

events.text_segment:
Elizabeth’s astonishment was beyond expression. She stared, coloured, doubted, and was silent. This he considered sufficient encouragement, and the avowal of all that he felt and had long felt for her immediately followed. He spoke well; but there were feelings besides those of the heart to be detailed, and he was not more eloquent on the subject of tenderness than of pride. His sense of her inferiority, of its being a degradation, of the family obstacles which judgment had always opposed to inclination, were dwelt on with a warmth which seemed due to the consequence he was wounding, but was very unlikely to recommend his suit.
In spite of her deeply-rooted dislike, she could not be insensible to the compliment of such a man’s affection, and though her intentions did not vary for an instant, she was at first sorry for the pain he was to receive; till roused to resentment by his subsequent language, she lost all compassion in anger. She tried, however, to compose herself to answer him with patience, when he should have done. He concluded with representing to her the strength of that attachment which in spite of all his endeavours he had found impossible to conquer; and with expressing his hope that it would now be rewarded by her acceptance of his hand. As he said this she could easily see that he had no doubt of a favourable answer. He spoke of apprehension and anxiety, but his countenance expressed real security. Such a circumstance could only exasperate farther; and when he ceased the colour rose into her cheeks and she said,—

He spoke of his feelings—how long he had loved her, how impossible it had seemed to conceal his affection, and how his regard had only grown stronger with time. Yet, he also admitted the conflicts within him—the social disparity, the objections of his family, and the perceived degradation that such a union would entail. His tone was fervent, almost pleading, as he emphasized the sacrifices he was prepared to make, and the obstacles he believed stood in their way. Elizabeth, though initially touched by the compliment of his affection and the pain her refusal would cause him, grew increasingly indignant as he dwelled on her supposed inferiority. His confident manner, tinged with a hint of apprehension, only heightened her irritation, and she prepared to speak her mind.

events.title: Elizabeth Rejects Darcy's Proposal Coldly
detailed_summary: Elizabeth begins her response by acknowledging the customary practice of expressing gratitude for a proposal, even if the feelings are not reciprocated.
She states plainly that while obligation might be expected, she feels no gratitude towards him.
She asserts that she never sought his good opinion and notes that he has clearly offered it very reluctantly.
Expressing formal regret for causing him pain, she insists it was unintentional and hopes his feelings, which he admitted were long suppressed, will easily recover following her rejection.
Darcy, leaning against the mantelpiece and watching her intently, reacts with visible resentment and surprise.
His face pales with anger, and his inner turmoil is evident.
He struggles to maintain composure, pausing before speaking, a silence Elizabeth finds agonizing.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “In such cases as this, it is, I believe, the established mode to express a sense of obligation for the sentiments avowed, however unequally they may be returned.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The pause was to Elizabeth’s feelings dreadful.

events.text_segment:
“In such cases as this, it is, I believe, the established mode to express a sense of obligation for the sentiments avowed, however unequally they may be returned. It is natural that obligation should be felt, and if I could feel gratitude, I would now thank you. But I cannot—I have never desired your good opinion, and you have certainly bestowed it most unwillingly. I am sorry to have occasioned pain to anyone. It has been most unconsciously done, however, and I hope will be of short duration. The feelings which you tell me have long prevented the acknowledgment of your regard can have little difficulty in overcoming it after this explanation.”
Mr. Darcy, who was leaning against the mantel-piece with his eyes fixed on her face, seemed to catch her words with no less resentment than surprise. His complexion became pale with anger, and the disturbance of his mind was visible in every feature. He was struggling for the appearance of composure, and would not open his lips till he believed himself to have attained it. The pause was to Elizabeth’s feelings dreadful.

events.title: Elizabeth Accuses Darcy Regarding Jane and Wickham
detailed_summary: Darcy, regaining some composure, questions the lack of civility in her rejection.

Elizabeth counters sharply, asking why he chose to propose in such an offensive manner, highlighting his admitted reluctance and struggle against reason and character as justification for any perceived incivility on her part.
She declares she has other, stronger reasons for her dislike, independent of his insulting proposal.
She directly accuses him of being the primary cause of the ruin of her sister Jane's happiness by separating her from Bingley.
Darcy's expression changes momentarily, but he listens without interruption as Elizabeth continues.
She elaborates on the injustice, stating he exposed Jane to criticism for perceived inconsistency and Bingley to ridicule for his disappointment, causing acute misery for both.
She observes with indignation that Darcy seems unmoved and shows no remorse, even smiling with disbelief.

When challenged to deny his actions, Darcy calmly admits he did everything possible to separate his friend (Bingley) from Jane and that he is pleased with his success, claiming he acted more kindly towards Bingley than towards himself.
Elizabeth ignores the implied slight in his last remark but understands its meaning, which only reinforces her negative feelings.
She states that her negative opinion was formed long before the issue with Jane, based on Mr. Wickham's account of Darcy's character months prior.
She challenges Darcy to defend his actions regarding Wickham.
Darcy reacts with heightened color and a less calm tone, noting her keen interest in Wickham's affairs.
Elizabeth defends her interest based on Wickham's reported misfortunes.
Darcy repeats the word 'misfortunes' with clear contempt.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At length, in a voice of forced calmness, he said,—
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “His misfortunes!” repeated Darcy, contemptuously,—“yes, his misfortunes have been great indeed.”

events.text_segment:
At length, in a voice of forced calmness, he said,—
“And this is all the reply which I am to have the honour of expecting! I might, perhaps, wish to be informed why, with so little endeavour at civility, I am thus rejected. But it is of small importance.”
“I might as well inquire,” replied she, “why, with so evident a design of offending and insulting me, you chose to tell me that you liked me against your will, against your reason, and even against your character? Was not this some excuse for incivility, if I was uncivil? But I have other provocations. You know I have. Had not my own feelings decided against you, had they been indifferent, or had they even been favourable, do you think that any consideration would tempt me to accept the man who has been the means of ruining, perhaps for ever, the happiness of a most beloved sister?”
As she pronounced these words, Mr. Darcy changed colour; but the emotion was short, and he listened without attempting to interrupt her while she continued,—
“I have every reason in the world to think ill of you. No motive can excuse the unjust and ungenerous part you acted there. You dare not, you cannot deny that you have been the principal, if not the only means of dividing them from each other, of exposing one to the censure of the world for caprice and instability, the other to its derision for disappointed hopes, and involving them both in misery of the acutest kind.”
She paused, and saw with no slight indignation that he was listening with an air which proved him wholly unmoved by any feeling of remorse. He even looked at her with a smile of affected incredulity.
“Can you deny that you have done it?” she repeated.
With assumed tranquillity he then replied, “I have no wish of denying that I did everything in my power to separate my friend from your sister, or that I rejoice in my success. Towards him I have been kinder than towards myself.”
Elizabeth disdained the appearance of noticing this civil reflection, but its meaning did not escape, nor was it likely to conciliate her.
“But it is not merely this affair,” she continued, “on which my dislike is founded. Long before it had taken place, my opinion of you was decided. Your character was unfolded in the recital which I received many months ago from Mr. Wickham. On this subject, what can you have to say? In what imaginary act of friendship can you here defend yourself? or under what misrepresentation can you here impose upon others?”
“You take an eager interest in that gentleman’s concerns,” said Darcy, in a less tranquil tone, and with a heightened colour.
“Who that knows what his misfortunes have been can help feeling an interest in him?”
“His misfortunes!” repeated Darcy, contemptuously,—“yes, his misfortunes have been great indeed.”

events.title: Elizabeth Condemns Darcy's Character and Actions
detailed_summary: Elizabeth passionately accuses Darcy of causing Wickham's misfortunes, specifically his poverty and lack of independence, which she believes was rightfully his.
Darcy, pacing agitatedly, retorts that this is her final judgment of him and thanks her for the full explanation.
He suggests that his perceived faults might have been forgiven if her pride hadn't been injured by his honest admission of social scruples.
He argues that if he had been less honest and more flattering about his motives, hiding his internal struggles, she might not have made such bitter accusations.

He declares his abhorrence for disguise and defends the feelings he expressed about her connections as natural and just, questioning if she truly expected him to disregard her family's lower social standing.
Elizabeth feels her anger increasing but maintains composure.
She tells Darcy he is mistaken if he thinks the *manner* of his proposal influenced her decision in any way, except to spare her the regret she might have felt refusing a more gentlemanly offer.
Darcy visibly reacts to this, but says nothing.
Elizabeth states unequivocally that no possible manner of proposal from him could ever have tempted her to accept.
Darcy shows clear astonishment, disbelief, and mortification.

She delivers her final condemnation, stating that from their very first acquaintance, his arrogant, conceited, and disdainful manners established a foundational disapproval, which subsequent events solidified into an immovable dislike.
She concludes by declaring that within a month of knowing him, she felt he was the absolute last man she would ever consider marrying.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “And of your infliction,” cried Elizabeth, with energy; “You have reduced him to his present state of poverty—comparative poverty.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “From the very beginning, from the first moment, I may almost say, of my acquaintance with you, your manners impressing me with the fullest belief of your arrogance, your conceit, and your selfish disdain of the feelings of others, were such as to form that groundwork of disapprobation, on which succeeding events have built so immovable a dislike; and I had not known you a month before I felt that you were the last man in the world whom I could ever be prevailed on to marry.”

events.text_segment:
“And of your infliction,” cried Elizabeth, with energy; “You have reduced him to his present state of poverty—comparative poverty. You have withheld the advantages which you must know to have been designed for him. You have deprived the best years of his life of that independence which was no less his due than his desert. You have done all this! and yet you can treat the mention of his misfortunes with contempt and ridicule.”
“And this,” cried Darcy, as he walked with quick steps across the room, “is your opinion of me! This is the estimation in which you hold me! I thank you for explaining it so fully. My faults, according to this calculation, are heavy indeed! But, perhaps,” added he, stopping in his walk, and turning towards her, “these offences might have been overlooked, had not your pride been hurt by my honest confession of the scruples that had long prevented my forming any serious design. These bitter accusations might have been suppressed, had I, with greater policy, concealed my struggles, and flattered you into the belief of my being impelled by unqualified, unalloyed inclination; by reason, by reflection, by everything. But disguise of every sort is my abhorrence. Nor am I ashamed of the feelings I related. They were natural and just. Could you expect me to rejoice in the inferiority of your connections?—to congratulate myself on the hope of relations whose condition in life is so decidedly beneath my own?”
Elizabeth felt herself growing more angry every moment; yet she tried to the utmost to speak with composure when she said,—
“You are mistaken, Mr. Darcy, if you suppose that the mode of your declaration affected me in any other way than as it spared me the concern which I might have felt in refusing you, had you behaved in a more gentlemanlike manner.”
She saw him start at this; but he said nothing, and she continued,—
“You could not have made me the offer of your hand in any possible way that would have tempted me to accept it.”
Again his astonishment was obvious; and he looked at her with an expression of mingled incredulity and mortification. She went on,—
“From the very beginning, from the first moment, I may almost say, of my acquaintance with you, your manners impressing me with the fullest belief of your arrogance, your conceit, and your selfish disdain of the feelings of others, were such as to form that groundwork of disapprobation, on which succeeding events have built so immovable a dislike; and I had not known you a month before I felt that you were the last man in the world whom I could ever be prevailed on to marry.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: You have deprived him of all his prospects of happiness, and have left him nothing to live on but the hope of bettering his circumstances by his own industry. And what is all this, but a proof of your own selfishness and your want of proper consideration for others? Do you think that your conduct will not be known? Do you imagine that the world will excuse you for such unfeeling conduct? I tell you, sir, that your conduct is inexcusable, and that you will have to answer for it one day. But I am not the person to be silenced by your threats or your insults. I will speak the truth, and I will not be afraid to do so. I will tell you, that your pride and your prejudice have blinded you to the real worth of others, and that you have judged Mr. Darcy unfairly. I have seen his true character, and I know that he is a man of honor and integrity. And I am convinced that he is the only person who can make me truly happy. So I will not be swayed by your opinions or your prejudices. I will follow my own heart, and I will marry the man I love, regardless of what you or anyone else may say.

events.title: Darcy's Departure and Elizabeth's Emotional Aftermath
detailed_summary: Darcy curtly acknowledges her statement, indicating he fully understands her feelings.
He expresses shame for his own past feelings towards her.
He formally apologizes for taking her time and offers standard wishes for her health and happiness.
With these words, he leaves the room quickly, and Elizabeth hears him exit the house.
Left alone, Elizabeth is overcome by painful emotional turmoil.
Feeling physically weak, she sits down and cries for half an hour.
Reflecting on the encounter increases her astonishment: Darcy being in love with her for months, enough to propose despite the very objections he used against Bingley marrying Jane.
She acknowledges a fleeting sense of gratification at having inspired such strong affection unknowingly.

However, her anger quickly resurfaces as she recalls his overwhelming pride, his shameless confession about manipulating Jane's relationship, his unapologetic cruelty towards Wickham, and his unfeeling manner.
These thoughts extinguish any pity his affection might have momentarily inspired.
Her agitated thoughts are interrupted by the sound of Lady Catherine's carriage arriving.
Feeling completely unprepared to face Charlotte's scrutiny after the intense encounter, Elizabeth quickly retreats to her own room.

events.text_segment:
“You have said quite enough, madam. I perfectly comprehend your feelings, and have now only to be ashamed of what my own have been. Forgive me for having taken up so much of your time, and accept my best wishes for your health and happiness.”
And with these words he hastily left the room, and Elizabeth heard him the next moment open the front door and quit the house. The tumult of her mind was now painfully great. She knew not how to support herself, and, from actual weakness, sat down and cried for half an hour. Her astonishment, as she reflected on what had passed, was increased by every review of it. That she should receive an offer of marriage from Mr. Darcy! that he should have been in love with her for so many months! so much in love as to wish to marry her in spite of all the objections which had made him prevent his friend’s marrying her sister, and which must appear at least with equal force in his own case, was almost incredible! it was gratifying to have inspired unconsciously so strong an affection. But his pride, his abominable pride, his shameless avowal of what he had done with respect to Jane, his unpardonable assurance in acknowledging, though he could not justify it, and the unfeeling manner which he had mentioned Mr. Wickham, his cruelty towards whom he had not attempted to deny, soon overcame the pity which the consideration of his attachment had for a moment excited.
She continued in very agitating reflections till the sound of Lady Catherine’s carriage made her feel how unequal she was to encounter Charlotte’s observation, and hurried her away to her room.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
You have said quite enough, madam.

Elizabeth Bennet sat alone in her chamber, overwhelmed by the tumult of her thoughts and feelings. Darcy's words, so curt yet so full of meaning, echoed in her mind. He had acknowledged her feelings with a cold formality that left her both hurt and bewildered. His shame for his past sentiments and his apology for taking up her time seemed to her a strange mixture of humility and pride.

As she listened, she heard the sound of his departure, the hurried footsteps down the hall, and then silence. Alone, she felt her strength ebbing away, and she sank into a chair, tears flowing freely for half an hour. Her mind raced with reflections: Darcy, in love with her for months, had dared to propose despite the objections he had previously voiced—objections rooted in his own pride and prejudice.

A fleeting thrill of gratification warmed her at the thought that she might have inspired such affection, yet it was quickly overshadowed by her anger. She recalled his haughty manner, his shameless confession of manipulating Jane and Bingley's relationship, his unfeeling cruelty towards Wickham, and his overall arrogance. These memories extinguished any pity she might have felt.

Her agitation was interrupted by the arrival of Lady Catherine's carriage, its wheels clattering on the gravel. Elizabeth, feeling unprepared to face Charlotte's scrutiny after such an emotional upheaval, hastily retreated to her own chamber, seeking refuge from the world and her own tumultuous feelings.

events.title: Elizabeth's Restless Morning Walk
detailed_summary: Elizabeth woke up still consumed by the thoughts of the previous night's events, particularly Mr. Darcy's proposal.
Unable to settle into any activity, she decided to go for a walk after breakfast.
She started towards her preferred walking route but changed her mind, remembering Mr. Darcy sometimes frequented that area.
Choosing an alternative path, she walked up a lane that led away from the main road, with the park fence still bordering one side.
She eventually passed through one of the gates into the park grounds.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She soon passed one of the gates into the ground.

events.text_segment: Elizabeth awoke the next morning to the same thoughts and meditations which had at length closed her eyes. She could not yet recover from the surprise of what had happened: it was impossible to think of anything else; and, totally indisposed for employment, she resolved soon after breakfast to indulge herself in air and exercise. She was proceeding directly to her favourite walk, when the recollection of Mr. Darcy’s sometimes coming there stopped her, and instead of entering the park, she turned up the lane which led her farther from the turnpike road. The park paling was still the boundary on one side, and she soon passed one of the gates into the ground.

events.title: An Unexpected Encounter and a Letter
detailed_summary: After pacing the lane a few times, Elizabeth paused at the park gates, appreciating the pleasant morning and the improved spring scenery.
As she was about to resume her walk, she noticed a gentleman inside the park grove walking towards her.
Fearing it was Mr. Darcy, she immediately started to retreat.
However, the man, now closer, recognized her and eagerly called her name.
Although she had turned away, upon hearing her name spoken by Mr. Darcy, she turned back towards the gate.
He met her there, presented a letter which she accepted automatically, and expressed his hope that she would read it, mentioning he had been waiting for her.
With a brief bow, he turned and disappeared back into the trees.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: After walking two or three times along that part of the lane, she was tempted, by the pleasantness of the morning, to stop at the gates and look into the park.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Will you do me the honour of reading that letter?” and then, with a slight bow, turned again into the plantation, and was soon out of sight.

events.text_segment: After walking two or three times along that part of the lane, she was tempted, by the pleasantness of the morning, to stop at the gates and look into the park. The five weeks which she had now passed in Kent had made a great difference in the country, and every day was adding to the verdure of the early trees. She was on the point of continuing her walk, when she caught a glimpse of a gentleman within the sort of grove which edged the park: he was moving that way; and fearful of its being Mr. Darcy, she was directly retreating. But the person who advanced was now near enough to see her, and stepping forward with eagerness, pronounced her name. She had turned away; but on hearing herself called, though in a voice which proved it to be Mr. Darcy, she moved again towards the gate. He had by that time reached it also; and, holding out a letter, which she instinctively took, said, with a look of haughty composure, “I have been walking in the grove some time, in the hope of meeting you. Will you do me the honour of reading that letter?” and then, with a slight bow, turned again into the plantation, and was soon out of sight.

events.title: Opening Darcy's Letter: Curiosity and Justification
detailed_summary: Driven by intense curiosity rather than hope for enjoyment, Elizabeth opened the letter.
She was surprised to find it was quite long, consisting of two densely written sheets, with even the envelope filled.
Continuing her walk along the lane, she began reading.
The letter was dated from Rosings, early that morning.
Darcy begins by reassuring her that the letter is not intended to repeat the sentiments or offers she found offensive the previous night.
He states his purpose is not to cause her pain or humiliate himself by revisiting his wishes, which should be forgotten for both their sakes.
He explains that writing and reading the letter is a necessary burden, undertaken because his reputation requires clarification.
He asks her to forgive his demanding her attention, acknowledging she will grant it unwillingly but appealing to her sense of fairness.

events.text_segment:
With no expectation of pleasure, but with the strongest curiosity, Elizabeth opened the letter, and to her still increasing wonder, perceived an envelope containing two sheets of letter paper, written quite through, in a very close hand. The envelope itself was likewise full. Pursuing her way along the lane, she then began it. It was dated from Rosings, at eight o’clock in the morning, and was as follows:—
“Be not alarmed, madam, on receiving this letter, by the apprehension of its containing any repetition of those sentiments, or renewal of those offers, which were last night so disgusting to you. I write without any intention of paining you, or humbling myself, by dwelling on wishes, which, for the happiness of both, cannot be too soon forgotten; and the effort which the formation and the perusal of this letter must occasion, should have been spared, had not my character required it to be written and read. You must, therefore, pardon the freedom with which I demand your attention; your feelings, I know, will bestow it unwillingly, but I demand it of your justice.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
With no expectation of pleasure, but with the strongest curiosity, Elizabeth opened the letter, and to her still increasing wonder, perceived an envelope containing two sheets of letter paper, written quite through, in a very close hand. Continuing her walk along the lane, she began reading. The letter was dated from Rosings, early that morning.

"Elizabeth,

I thank you for your kind and generous feelings towards me, which I have deeply appreciated. I am aware that my conduct has been subject to much misinterpretation, and I feel it necessary to clarify my intentions.

"I am not now attempting to repeat the sentiments or offers which you found offensive the previous night. My purpose is not to cause you pain or to humiliate myself by revisiting my wishes, which I trust you will forget for both our sakes.

"Writing and reading this letter is a burden I undertake because my reputation requires clarification. I ask you to forgive my demanding your attention, knowing you will grant it unwillingly, but I appeal to your sense of fairness.

"Please believe me, Elizabeth, that my feelings have been sincere, and I hope that, in time, you will come to see the truth of my intentions."

He then concludes with a respectful request for her understanding and a hope for her forgiveness.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: If I have wounded your sister’s feelings, it was unknowingly done; and though the motives which governed me may to you very naturally appear insufficient, I have not yet learnt to condemn them.

events.text_segment: “Two offences of a very different nature, and by no means of equal magnitude, you last night laid to my charge. The first mentioned was, that, regardless of the sentiments of either, I had detached Mr. Bingley from your sister,—and the other, that I had, in defiance of various claims, in defiance of honour and humanity, ruined the immediate prosperity and blasted the prospects of Mr. Wickham. Wilfully and wantonly to have thrown off the companion of my youth, the acknowledged favourite of my father, a young man who had scarcely any other dependence than on our patronage, and who had been brought up to expect its exertion, would be a depravity, to which the separation of two young persons whose affection could be the growth of only a few weeks, could bear no comparison. But from the severity of that blame which was last night so liberally bestowed, respecting each circumstance, I shall hope to be in future secured, when the following account of my actions and their motives has been read. If, in the explanation of them which is due to myself, I am under the necessity of relating feelings which may be offensive to yours, I can only say that I am sorry. The necessity must be obeyed, and further apology would be absurd. I had not been long in Hertfordshire before I saw, in common with others, that Bingley preferred your elder sister to any other young woman in the country. But it was not till the evening of the dance at Netherfield that I had any apprehension of his feeling a serious attachment. I had often seen him in love before. At that ball, while I had the honour of dancing with you, I was first made acquainted, by Sir William Lucas’s accidental information, that Bingley’s attentions to your sister had given rise to a general expectation of their marriage. He spoke of it as a certain event, of which the time alone could be undecided. From that moment I observed my friend’s behaviour attentively; and I could then perceive that his partiality for Miss Bennet was beyond what I had ever witnessed in him. Your sister I also watched. Her look and manners were open, cheerful, and engaging as ever, but without any symptom of peculiar regard; and I remained convinced, from the evening’s scrutiny, that though she received his attentions with pleasure, she did not invite them by any participation of sentiment. If you have not been mistaken here, I must have been in an error. Your superior knowledge of your sister must make the latter probable. If it be so, if I have been misled by such error to inflict pain on her, your resentment has not been unreasonable. But I shall not scruple to assert, that the serenity of your sister’s countenance and air was such as might have given the most acute observer a conviction that, however amiable her temper, her heart was not likely to be easily touched. That I was desirous of believing her indifferent is certain; but I will venture to say that my investigations and decisions are not usually influenced by my hopes or fears. I did not believe her to be indifferent because I wished it; I believed it on impartial conviction, as truly as I wished it in reason. My objections to the marriage were not merely those which I last night acknowledged to have required the utmost force of passion to put aside in my own case; the want of connection could not be so great an evil to my friend as to me. But there were other causes of repugnance; causes which, though still existing, and existing to an equal degree in both instances, I had myself endeavoured to forget, because they were not immediately before me. These causes must be stated, though briefly. The situation of your mother’s family, though objectionable, was nothing in comparison of that total want of propriety so frequently, so almost uniformly betrayed by herself, by your three younger sisters, and occasionally even by your father:—pardon me,—it pains me to offend you. But amidst your concern for the defects of your nearest relations, and your displeasure at this representation of them, let it give you consolation to consider that to have conducted yourselves so as to avoid any share of the like censure is praise no less generally bestowed on you and your eldest sister than it is honourable to the sense and disposition of both. I will only say, farther, that from what passed that evening my opinion of all parties was confirmed, and every inducement heightened, which could have led me before to preserve my friend from what I esteemed a most unhappy connection. He left Netherfield for London on the day following, as you, I am certain, remember, with the design of soon returning. The part which I acted is now to be explained. His sisters’ uneasiness had been equally excited with my own: our coincidence of feeling was soon discovered; and, alike sensible that no time was to be lost in detaching their brother, we shortly resolved on joining him directly in London. We accordingly went—and there I readily engaged in the office of pointing out to my friend the certain evils of such a choice. I described and enforced them earnestly. But however this remonstrance might have staggered or delayed his determination, I do not suppose that it would ultimately have prevented the marriage, had it not been seconded by the assurance, which I hesitated not in giving, of your sister’s indifference. He had before believed her to return his affection with sincere, if not with equal, regard. But Bingley has great natural modesty, with a stronger dependence on my judgment than on his own. To convince him, therefore, that he had deceived himself was no very difficult point. To persuade him against returning into Hertfordshire, when that conviction had been given, was scarcely the work of a moment. I cannot blame myself for having done thus much. There is but one part of my conduct, in the whole affair, on which I do not reflect with satisfaction; it is that I condescended to adopt the measures of art so far as to conceal from him your sister’s being in town. I knew it myself, as it was known to Miss Bingley; but her brother is even yet ignorant of it. That they might have met without ill consequence is, perhaps, probable; but his regard did not appear to me enough extinguished for him to see her without some danger. Perhaps this concealment, this disguise, was beneath me. It is done, however, and it was done for the best. On this subject I have nothing more to say, no other apology to offer. If I have wounded your sister’s feelings, it was unknowingly done; and though the motives which governed me may to you very naturally appear insufficient, I have not yet learnt to condemn them.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Two offences of a very different nature, and by no means of equal magnitude, you last night laid to my charge.

I am perfectly convinced that I did not act with any design to offend or injure you; and I am very sorry if I have caused you pain. But I must be permitted to say that I think you have been mistaken in your judgment of me, and that I have not deserved the harshest censure you have passed.

You accuse me of having, in some way or other, interfered with your happiness, and of having, in particular, prevented Bingley from returning to you. I do not deny that I was concerned in the matter; but I do deny that I did anything which I ought to be ashamed of, or that I did anything which I could not justify.

I observed Bingley’s partiality for Jane Bennet very early in my visit to Hertfordshire, but I did not then believe it to be serious. It was only at the Netherfield ball that I saw how deeply he was attached to her, and I then thought it my duty to warn him against a match which I considered unsuitable.

I learned from Sir William Lucas that a marriage was generally expected between Bingley and Miss Darcy, and I was inclined to think that Bingley’s regard for Jane was not very serious. But when I saw how Bingley looked at her, and how he was constantly talking of her, I could not help feeling that he was very much in love.

I also observed Jane Bennet at the ball, and I thought her cheerful manner and her easy temper showed no particular regard for Bingley. I believed her to be indifferent to him, and I was glad to think so, because I thought it would be better for him to marry someone who was not so much in love with him.

I admit that I wished to believe Jane Bennet indifferent, but I did not let that wish influence my judgment. I observed her conduct carefully, and I formed my opinion accordingly.

There were other objections to the match besides social connections. Mrs. Bennet, the younger sisters, and sometimes even Mr. Bennet, showed a lack of propriety and decorum which I could not overlook. I do not mean to speak disrespectfully of them, but I must be honest.

I am aware that this may seem harsh, but I think you will agree that I have spoken the truth. I have no wish to offend you, but I must be faithful to my own judgment.

These observations led me to resolve to prevent what I considered an unsuitable marriage for Bingley. I, along with Bingley’s sisters, who shared my concerns, went to London to persuade him not to return to Hertfordshire.

I did not merely tell him that the match was improper; I explained to him the supposed evils of the union, and I used all the arguments I thought would be effective.

I believe that my arguments alone might not have been enough, but I was able to convince Bingley that he had misjudged Jane’s feelings, and that she was not as indifferent as he had supposed.

I took advantage of his self-doubt and his trust in my judgment, and I persuaded him that he had been mistaken.

It was then an easy matter to persuade him not to return to Hertfordshire.

I am satisfied with what I did, except for one thing: I concealed Jane Bennet’s presence in London from Bingley. I admit that this was perhaps beneath my dignity, but I did it for his own good.

I do not regret my actions, though I am aware that you may think differently. I only hope that you will understand that I had no malicious intent, and that any harm done to Jane Bennet was unintentional.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: —With respect to that other, more weighty accusation, of having injured Mr. Wickham, I can only refute it by laying before you the whole of his connection with my family.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mr. Wickham’s chief object was unquestionably my sister’s fortune, which is thirty thousand pounds; but I cannot help supposing that the hope of revenging himself on me was a strong inducement.

events.text_segment: —With respect to that other, more weighty accusation, of having injured Mr. Wickham, I can only refute it by laying before you the whole of his connection with my family. Of what he has particularly accused me I am ignorant; but of the truth of what I shall relate I can summon more than one witness of undoubted veracity. Mr. Wickham is the son of a very respectable man, who had for many years the management of all the Pemberley estates, and whose good conduct in the discharge of his trust naturally inclined my father to be of service to him; and on George Wickham, who was his godson, his kindness was therefore liberally bestowed. My father supported him at school, and afterwards at Cambridge; most important assistance, as his own father, always poor from the extravagance of his wife, would have been unable to give him a gentleman’s education. My father was not only fond of this young man’s society, whose manners were always engaging, he had also the highest opinion of him, and hoping the church would be his profession, intended to provide for him in it. As for myself, it is many, many years since I first began to think of him in a very different manner. The vicious propensities, the want of principle, which he was careful to guard from the knowledge of his best friend, could not escape the observation of a young man of nearly the same age with himself, and who had opportunities of seeing him in unguarded moments, which Mr. Darcy could not have. Here again I shall give you pain—to what degree you only can tell. But whatever may be the sentiments which Mr. Wickham has created, a suspicion of their nature shall not prevent me from unfolding his real character. It adds even another motive. My excellent father died about five years ago; and his attachment to Mr. Wickham was to the last so steady, that in his will he particularly recommended it to me to promote his advancement in the best manner that his profession might allow, and if he took orders, desired that a valuable family living might be his as soon as it became vacant. There was also a legacy of one thousand pounds. His own father did not long survive mine; and within half a year from these events Mr. Wickham wrote to inform me that, having finally resolved against taking orders, he hoped I should not think it unreasonable for him to expect some more immediate pecuniary advantage, in lieu of the preferment, by which he could not be benefited. He had some intention, he added, of studying the law, and I must be aware that the interest of one thousand pounds would be a very insufficient support therein. I rather wished than believed him to be sincere; but, at any rate, was perfectly ready to accede to his proposal. I knew that Mr. Wickham ought not to be a clergyman. The business was therefore soon settled. He resigned all claim to assistance in the church, were it possible that he could ever be in a situation to receive it, and accepted in return three thousand pounds. All connection between us seemed now dissolved. I thought too ill of him to invite him to Pemberley, or admit his society in town. In town, I believe, he chiefly lived, but his studying the law was a mere pretence; and being now free from all restraint, his life was a life of idleness and dissipation. For about three years I heard little of him; but on the decease of the incumbent of the living which had been designed for him, he applied to me again by letter for the presentation. His circumstances, he assured me, and I had no difficulty in believing it, were exceedingly bad. He had found the law a most unprofitable study, and was now absolutely resolved on being ordained, if I would present him to the living in question—of which he trusted there could be little doubt, as he was well assured that I had no other person to provide for, and I could not have forgotten my revered father’s intentions. You will hardly blame me for refusing to comply with this entreaty, or for resisting every repetition of it. His resentment was in proportion to the distress of his circumstances—and he was doubtless as violent in his abuse of me to others as in his reproaches to myself. After this period, every appearance of acquaintance was dropped. How he lived, I know not. But last summer he was again most painfully obtruded on my notice. I must now mention a circumstance which I would wish to forget myself, and which no obligation less than the present should induce me to unfold to any human being. Having said thus much, I feel no doubt of your secrecy. My sister, who is more than ten years my junior, was left to the guardianship of my mother’s nephew, Colonel Fitzwilliam, and myself. About a year ago, she was taken from school, and an establishment formed for her in London; and last summer she went with the lady who presided over it to Ramsgate; and thither also went Mr. Wickham, undoubtedly by design; for there proved to have been a prior acquaintance between him and Mrs. Younge, in whose character we were most unhappily deceived; and by her connivance and aid he so far recommended himself to Georgiana, whose affectionate heart retained a strong impression of his kindness to her as a child, that she was persuaded to believe herself in love and to consent to an elopement. She was then but fifteen, which must be her excuse; and after stating her imprudence, I am happy to add, that I owed the knowledge of it to herself. I joined them unexpectedly a day or two before the intended elopement; and then Georgiana, unable to support the idea of grieving and offending a brother whom she almost looked up to as a father, acknowledged the whole to me. You may imagine what I felt and how I acted. Regard for my sister’s credit and feelings prevented any public exposure; but I wrote to Mr. Wickham, who left the place immediately, and Mrs. Younge was of course removed from her charge. Mr. Wickham’s chief object was unquestionably my sister’s fortune, which is thirty thousand pounds; but I cannot help supposing that the hope of revenging himself on me was a strong inducement.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
—With respect to that other, more weighty accusation, of having injured Mr. Wickham, I can only refute it by laying before you the whole of his connection with my family.

I must now proceed to give you a full account of Mr. Wickham's history with us, which will, I hope, enable you to judge more correctly of his character and of the justice of the accusations he has made against me.

Mr. Wickham is the son of the steward of Pemberley, a man who was highly esteemed by my father, and whom he supported and respected. My father was his godfather, and paid for his education at Cambridge, as his own father was unable to afford it. He was a favorite of my father's, and my father intended him for the church, planning to provide him with a valuable living.

However, I saw his true character long ago—his lack of principle and vicious propensities, which he concealed from my father but which I could not overlook. I am aware that this revelation will pain you, Elizabeth, as I know you have a regard for Mr. Wickham.

Upon my father's death five years ago, his will requested that I promote Wickham's career in the church, and that I should give him a living when one should become vacant, as well as a legacy of £1,000. Soon after, Wickham declared he would not join the church and asked for £3,000 instead of the future living, claiming he needed it to study law. I agreed, knowing he was unsuited for the clergy, paid the sum, and considered our connection dissolved, viewing his law studies as a sham.

He then lived a life of idleness and dissipation in town. When the church living became vacant three years later, he applied for it again, claiming financial distress, despite having formally relinquished his claim. I refused him.

His reaction was bitter, and I have no doubt he has slandered me since. I also wish to forget a recent, painful incident involving my sister Georgiana, whom I trust you will keep this secret. Georgiana, who is over ten years younger than myself, was under my and Colonel Fitzwilliam's guardianship. Last summer, at age fifteen, she stayed in Ramsgate with a companion, Mrs. Younge.

Wickham appeared there, having known Mrs. Younge before, and she connived with him. He used his charm and Georgiana's childhood affection to persuade her she was in love with him and to elope. I arrived unexpectedly just before the elopement, and Georgiana confessed everything, unwilling to deceive or hurt me.

I acted privately to protect her reputation, confronting Wickham, who left Ramsgate, and dismissing Mrs. Younge. I believe Wickham's main aim was Georgiana's inheritance of £30,000, but I also suspect revenge against me was a strong motive.

Mr. Wickham is the son of the steward of Pemberley, a man who was highly esteemed by my father, and whom he supported and respected. My father was his godfather, and paid for his education at Cambridge, as his own father was unable to afford it. He was a favorite of my father's, and my father intended him for the church, planning to provide him with a valuable living.

However, I saw his true character long ago—his lack of principle and vicious propensities, which he concealed from my father but which I could not overlook. I am aware that this revelation will pain you, Elizabeth, as I know you have a regard for Mr. Wickham.

Upon my father's death five years ago, his will requested that I promote Wickham's career in the church, and that I should give him a living when one should become vacant, as well as a legacy of £1,000. Soon after, Wickham declared he would not join the church and asked for £3,000 instead of the future living, claiming he needed it to study law. I agreed, knowing he was unsuited for the clergy, paid the sum, and considered our connection dissolved, viewing his law studies as a sham.

He then lived a life of idleness and dissipation in town. When the church living became vacant three years later, he applied for it again, claiming financial distress, despite having formally relinquished his claim. I refused him.

His reaction was bitter, and I have no doubt he has slandered me since. I also wish to forget a recent, painful incident involving my sister Georgiana, whom I trust you will keep this secret. Georgiana, who is over ten years younger than myself, was under my and Colonel Fitzwilliam's guardianship. Last summer, at age fifteen, she stayed in Ramsgate with a companion, Mrs. Younge.

Wickham appeared there, having known Mrs. Younge before, and she connived with him. He used his charm and Georgiana's childhood affection to persuade her she was in love with him and to elope. I arrived unexpectedly just before the elopement, and Georgiana confessed everything, unwilling to deceive or hurt me.

I acted privately to protect her reputation, confronting Wickham, who left Ramsgate, and dismissing Mrs. Younge. I believe Wickham's main aim was Georgiana's inheritance of £30,000, but I also suspect revenge against me was a strong motive.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Mr. Wickham's history with my family is indeed a complex one, and it is necessary to set the record straight to understand the true nature of his character. From the very beginning, he was a young man of promising appearance and engaging manners, which initially drew the attention and favor of many, including myself. However, as I have come to learn through more intimate acquaintance and reflection, appearances can be deceiving.

His relationship with my family was marked by a series of unfortunate events and misunderstandings, often manipulated or exaggerated by himself to serve his own interests. It is true that he was once employed by Mr. Darcy, and that their association was not without its difficulties. Yet, the circumstances surrounding his departure from that employment were far from the villainous portrayal he later attempted to project.

Wickham's dealings with my family, particularly with my sister Lydia, have been the subject of much speculation and misrepresentation. It is important to note that his involvement with Lydia was not merely a matter of youthful flirtation, but a calculated attempt to secure his own future at the expense of others. His elopement with Lydia Bennet was a reckless act, driven by his own greed and lack of moral restraint, rather than any genuine affection or regard.

Furthermore, his claims of injury and injustice are, in my opinion, a means to garner sympathy and to deflect from his own culpability. He has a talent for storytelling, often embellishing his narratives to evoke pity or admiration. Yet, when examined closely, his stories tend to fall apart under scrutiny, revealing inconsistencies and self-serving motives.

It is also worth mentioning that Mr. Wickham's financial situation has been precarious for some time, and his attempts to improve his circumstances have often led him into questionable associations and actions. His pursuit of personal gain has frequently overridden any sense of integrity or honor.

In conclusion, I believe that the accusations against Mr. Wickham are not only unfounded but also reflective of his own character flaws. His history with my family, when fully disclosed, presents a picture of a man who has often acted out of self-interest, with little regard for truth or morality. It is my hope that this explanation will provide a clearer understanding of the situation and dispel any unjust accusations.

events.title: Darcy's Conclusion: Appeal for Belief and Corroboration
detailed_summary: Darcy reflects that Wickham's revenge, had the elopement succeeded, would have been total.
He declares his narrative a faithful account of his involvement with Wickham.
He hopes that if Elizabeth doesn't dismiss it as lies, she will absolve him of the charge of cruelty towards Wickham.
He acknowledges Wickham has successfully deceived her but attributes this to her lack of prior knowledge about the situation.
He explains his own emotional turmoil prevented him from revealing these truths the previous night.
He vouches for the accuracy of his account and names Colonel Fitzwilliam as a key witness who is familiar with all the details due to family ties and his role as executor of the will.
He suggests Elizabeth consult Fitzwilliam if her dislike of Darcy makes her doubt his word.
He states he intends to find an opportunity to give her the letter that morning, facilitating potential consultation with Fitzwilliam.
He closes the letter with a simple 'God bless you' and his signature.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: His revenge would have been complete indeed.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Fitzwilliam Darcy.”

events.text_segment:
His revenge would have been complete indeed. This, madam, is a faithful narrative of every event in which we have been concerned together; and if you do not absolutely reject it as false, you will, I hope, acquit me henceforth of cruelty towards Mr. Wickham. I know not in what manner, under what form of falsehood, he has imposed on you; but his success is not perhaps to be wondered at, ignorant as you previously were of everything concerning either. Detection could not be in your power, and suspicion certainly not in your inclination. You may possibly wonder why all this was not told you last night. But I was not then master enough of myself to know what could or ought to be revealed. For the truth of everything here related, I can appeal more particularly to the testimony of Colonel Fitzwilliam, who, from our near relationship and constant intimacy, and still more as one of the executors of my father’s will, has been unavoidably acquainted with every particular of these transactions. If your abhorrence of me should make my assertions valueless, you cannot be prevented by the same cause from confiding in my cousin; and that there may be the possibility of consulting him, I shall endeavour to find some opportunity of putting this letter in your hands in the course of the morning. I will only add, God bless you.
“Fitzwilliam Darcy.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: His revenge would have been complete indeed. I have written to you at length, and I hope you will believe that my motives are honest, and that I have no other aim than to clear my own character and to set matters right. If you do not dismiss my narrative as a lie, I trust you will forgive me for the pain I have caused you, and that you will see that I have been deceived as much as you have been misled. Wickham has succeeded in deceiving you, but I do not blame you for that; I only blame myself for not having been able to explain everything sooner. The truth is, I was overwhelmed with emotion last night, and could not find the words to tell you what I now write. I can only say that I am sincere, and that Colonel Fitzwilliam, who is well acquainted with all the circumstances, can confirm my account. If you dislike me enough to doubt my word, I recommend you to ask Fitzwilliam, who is a witness to all that has passed. I shall look for an opportunity to give you the letter this morning, which will enable you to consult him if you wish. God bless you.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: His revenge would have been complete indeed, had he succeeded in his plans to humiliate her publicly. Elizabeth Bennet, with her keen wit and spirited independence, was a formidable opponent, and her refusal to be swayed by societal pressures only heightened his resolve. Mr. Darcy, once proud and reserved, found himself increasingly captivated by her intelligence and charm, qualities that he had previously dismissed as mere affectations. As the days passed, he began to see her in a new light, recognizing the depth of her character and the sincerity of her feelings. Elizabeth, meanwhile, remained unaware of his internal struggles, her mind preoccupied with the upcoming ball and the hopes of finding a suitable match. Yet, beneath her composed exterior, she harbored a cautious optimism, wary of the fickle nature of society and the possibility of disappointment. The tension between them was palpable, each aware of the other's regard but hesitant to bridge the gap of pride and prejudice that separated them. It was only through a series of unspoken exchanges and shared moments that they gradually began to understand one another's true intentions. In the end, Mr. Darcy's revenge was not to be fulfilled, for love and understanding proved stronger than any scheme of retribution, leading to a union founded on mutual respect and genuine affection.

events.title: Initial Reading and Angered Rejection of Darcy's Explanations
detailed_summary: Elizabeth receives Mr. Darcy's letter without any specific expectations about its contents.
Reading it prompts a whirlwind of conflicting emotions.
She is initially astonished that he believes he can offer any acceptable apology or explanation.
Her strong bias against him leads her to read his account of Netherfield events with an eagerness that hinders comprehension.
She instantly dismisses his assessment of Jane's lack of affection as false.
His justification for opposing the match angers her too much for impartial consideration.
She perceives his tone not as apologetic but as proud and insolent, lacking any satisfactory regret.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: ELIZABETH, when Mr. Darcy gave her the letter, did not expect it to contain a renewal of his offers, she had formed no expectation at all of its contents.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was all pride and insolence.

events.text_segment: ELIZABETH, when Mr. Darcy gave her the letter, did not expect it to contain a renewal of his offers, she had formed no expectation at all of its contents. But such as they were, it may be well supposed how eagerly she went through them, and what a contrariety of emotion they excited. Her feelings as she read were scarcely to be defined. With amazement did she first understand that he believed any apology to be in his power; and steadfastly was she persuaded, that he could have no explanation to give, which a just sense of shame would not conceal. With a strong prejudice against everything he might say, she began his account of what had happened at Netherfield. She read with an eagerness which hardly left her power of comprehension; and from impatience of knowing what the next sentence might bring, was incapable of attending to the sense of the one before her eyes. His belief of her sister’s insensibility she instantly resolved to be false; and his account of the real, the worst objections to the match, made her too angry to have any wish of doing him justice. He expressed no regret for what he had done which satisfied her; his style was not penitent, but haughty. It was all pride and insolence.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: ELIZABETH, when Mr. Darcy gave her the letter, did not expect it to contain a renewal of his offers, she had formed no expectation at all of its contents. As she opened it, her heart fluttered with curiosity and apprehension. She read the letter with a mixture of astonishment and indignation, her mind racing to reconcile his words with her previous judgments. The account of Netherfield's events, which she read with eager but biased eyes, seemed to her a distorted version of the truth, and she instantly dismissed his assertion that Jane Bennet's feelings were indifferent. His justification for opposing the match, far from softening her, inflamed her anger, and she perceived his tone not as remorseful but as proud and insolent, lacking any genuine regret.

events.title: Shock and Disbelief Reading Darcy's Account of Wickham
detailed_summary: Elizabeth's feelings become even more painfully acute and harder to define when she reads Darcy's account of Mr. Wickham.
This section details events that, if accurate, would completely destroy her high opinion of Wickham and align disturbingly with his own self-portrayal.
She is overwhelmed by astonishment, fear, and even horror.
She instinctively wishes to reject the entire account, exclaiming repeatedly that it must be untrue.
After finishing the letter, though barely processing the final pages, she quickly puts it away, vowing never to look at it or consider it again.
Disturbed and unable to focus, she walks on but finds herself compelled to unfold and reread the letter within moments.
She attempts to compose herself to meticulously examine the meaning of every sentence related to Wickham.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: But when this subject was succeeded by his account of Mr. Wickham—when she read, with somewhat clearer attention, a relation of events which, if true, must overthrow every cherished opinion of his worth, and which bore so alarming an affinity to his own history of himself—her feelings were yet more acutely painful and more difficult of definition.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: In this perturbed state of mind, with thoughts that could rest on nothing, she walked on; but it would not do: in half a minute the letter was unfolded again; and collecting herself as well as she could, she again began the mortifying perusal of all that related to Wickham, and commanded herself so far as to examine the meaning of every sentence.

events.text_segment:
But when this subject was succeeded by his account of Mr. Wickham—when she read, with somewhat clearer attention, a relation of events which, if true, must overthrow every cherished opinion of his worth, and which bore so alarming an affinity to his own history of himself—her feelings were yet more acutely painful and more difficult of definition. Astonishment, apprehension, and even horror, oppressed her. She wished to discredit it entirely, repeatedly exclaiming, “This must be false! This cannot be! This must be the grossest falsehood!”—and when she had gone through the whole letter, though scarcely knowing anything of the last page or two, put it hastily away, protesting that she would not regard it, that she would never look in it again.
In this perturbed state of mind, with thoughts that could rest on nothing, she walked on; but it would not do: in half a minute the letter was unfolded again; and collecting herself as well as she could, she again began the mortifying perusal of all that related to Wickham, and commanded herself so far as to examine the meaning of every sentence.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: But when this subject was succeeded by his account of Mr. Wickham—when she read, with somewhat clearer attention, a relation of events which, if true, must overthrow every cherished opinion of his worth, and which bore so alarming an affinity to his own history of himself—her feelings were yet more acutely painful and more difficult of definition. Elizabeth's heart fluttered with a tumult of emotions—astonishment, fear, and horror—each vying for dominance as she absorbed the details that painted Wickham in a new, disturbing light. Her mind struggled to reconcile the man she had admired with the revelations now laid bare, and she found herself instinctively rejecting the account, exclaiming repeatedly that it must be untrue. Yet, despite her vehement denials, she could not dismiss the words, nor the implications they carried. Hastily, she finished the letter, scarcely registering the final words, and in her agitation, she thrust it away, vowing never to look at it again. But her curiosity and distress soon compelled her to unfold the letter once more, to read and re-read the passages concerning Wickham, seeking to understand the truth behind the words that had so shaken her.

Elizabeth's mind raced to reconcile her perceptions with the new revelations, questioning her own discernment and the sincerity of her former admiration. Yet, amidst the tumult of her thoughts, a resolve began to form—to seek the truth, to understand the man behind the stories, and to guard her heart against the sway of superficial impressions. events.title: Careful Re-examination of Wickham's Story and Growing Doubt
detailed_summary: Elizabeth notes that Darcy's description of Wickham's connection to the Pemberley family and the late Mr. Darcy's kindness matches Wickham's own story.
However, a significant difference appears when she reads about the will.
Recalling Wickham's specific claims about the church living makes her recognize a stark contradiction, suggesting deceit on one side.
Briefly, she hopes her initial assessment favouring Wickham is correct.
Rereading closely the details about Wickham formally renouncing the living in exchange for £3,000 forces her to reconsider.
She pauses, attempting to weigh the circumstances impartially, but finds it difficult as both accounts are mere assertions.
Continuing to read, each line increasingly suggests Darcy's actions, previously deemed infamous by her, might be entirely blameless.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The account of his connection with the Pemberley family was exactly what he had related himself; and the kindness of the late Mr. Darcy, though she had not before known its extent, agreed equally well with his own words.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But every line proved more clearly that the affair, which she had believed it impossible that any contrivance could so represent as to render Mr. Darcy’s conduct in it less than infamous, was capable of a turn which must make him entirely blameless throughout the whole.

events.text_segment: The account of his connection with the Pemberley family was exactly what he had related himself; and the kindness of the late Mr. Darcy, though she had not before known its extent, agreed equally well with his own words. So far each recital confirmed the other; but when she came to the will, the difference was great. What Wickham had said of the living was fresh in her memory; and as she recalled his very words, it was impossible not to feel that there was gross duplicity on one side or the other, and, for a few moments, she flattered herself that her wishes did not err. But when she read and re-read, with the closest attention, the particulars immediately following of Wickham’s resigning all pretensions to the living, of his receiving in lieu so considerable a sum as three thousand pounds, again was she forced to hesitate. She put down the letter, weighed every circumstance with what she meant to be impartiality—deliberated on the probability of each statement—but with little success. On both sides it was only assertion. Again she read on. But every line proved more clearly that the affair, which she had believed it impossible that any contrivance could so represent as to render Mr. Darcy’s conduct in it less than infamous, was capable of a turn which must make him entirely blameless throughout the whole.

As she reread the details, she was struck by the stark contradiction—Darcy's actions, which she had once thought infamous, now appeared to be entirely blameless. events.title: Scrutinizing Wickham's Character and Darcy's Corroboration
detailed_summary: Elizabeth is deeply shocked by Darcy's accusations of extravagance and immorality against Wickham, particularly because she lacks evidence to refute them.
She realizes her knowledge of Wickham is limited to what he revealed since joining the militia, having never inquired further due to being charmed by his appearance and manners.
She searches her memory for any concrete examples of Wickham's virtue or integrity that could counter Darcy's claims but finds none beyond his general popularity and social charm.
She recalls Darcy's account of Wickham's designs on Miss Darcy, noting it aligns with information she received from Colonel Fitzwilliam just the previous day.
Darcy refers her to Colonel Fitzwilliam for verification, whose reliability she doesn't doubt and who she knows is close to Darcy's affairs.
She considers asking the Colonel but dismisses the idea as awkward and unnecessary, convinced Darcy wouldn't risk the suggestion without his cousin's support.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The extravagance and general profligacy which he scrupled not to lay to Mr. Wickham’s charge exceedingly shocked her; the more so, as she could bring no proof of its injustice.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: At one time she had almost resolved on applying to him, but the idea was checked by the awkwardness of the application, and at length wholly banished by the conviction that Mr. Darcy would never have hazarded such a proposal, if he had not been well assured of his cousin’s corroboration.

events.text_segment: The extravagance and general profligacy which he scrupled not to lay to Mr. Wickham’s charge exceedingly shocked her; the more so, as she could bring no proof of its injustice. She had never heard of him before his entrance into the ——shire militia, in which he had engaged at the persuasion of the young man, who, on meeting him accidentally in town, had there renewed a slight acquaintance. Of his former way of life, nothing had been known in Hertfordshire but what he told himself. As to his real character, had information been in her power, she had never felt a wish of inquiring. His countenance, voice, and manner, had established him at once in the possession of every virtue. She tried to recollect some instance of goodness, some distinguished trait of integrity or benevolence, that might rescue him from the attacks of Mr. Darcy; or at least, by the predominance of virtue, atone for those casual errors, under which she would endeavour to class what Mr. Darcy had described as the idleness and vice of many years’ continuance. But no such recollection befriended her. She could see him instantly before her, in every charm of air and address, but she could remember no more substantial good than the general approbation of the neighbourhood, and the regard which his social powers had gained him in the mess. After pausing on this point a considerable while, she once more continued to read. But, alas! the story which followed, of his designs on Miss Darcy, received some confirmation from what had passed between Colonel Fitzwilliam and herself only the morning before; and at last she was referred for the truth of every particular to Colonel Fitzwilliam himself—from whom she had previously received the information of his near concern in all his cousin’s affairs and whose character she had no reason to question. At one time she had almost resolved on applying to him, but the idea was checked by the awkwardness of the application, and at length wholly banished by the conviction that Mr. Darcy would never have hazarded such a proposal, if he had not been well assured of his cousin’s corroboration.

events.text_segment: She perfectly remembered everything that had passed in conversation between Wickham and herself in their first evening at Mr. Philips’s. Many of his expressions were still fresh in her memory. She was now struck with the impropriety of such communications to a stranger, and wondered it had escaped her before. She saw the indelicacy of putting himself forward as he had done, and the inconsistency of his professions with his conduct. She remembered that he had boasted of having no fear of seeing Mr. Darcy—that Mr. Darcy might leave the country, but that he should stand his ground; yet he had avoided the Netherfield ball the very next week. She remembered, also, that till the Netherfield family had quitted the country, he had told his story to no one but herself; but that after their removal, it had been everywhere discussed; that he had then no reserves, no scruples in sinking Mr. Darcy’s character, though he had assured her that respect for the father would always prevent his exposing the son.

events.title: Reinterpreting Wickham's Motives and Reassessing Darcy's Character
detailed_summary: Everything concerning Wickham now appears drastically different to Elizabeth.
His pursuit of Miss King now seems purely mercenary, her moderate fortune indicating his desperation rather than modest desires.
His attention to Elizabeth herself now lacks any acceptable motive; he was either mistaken about her wealth or simply feeding his vanity.
Her inclination to defend Wickham weakens considerably.
She recalls evidence supporting Darcy: Mr. Bingley had previously affirmed Darcy's innocence regarding Wickham when Jane inquired.
Despite Darcy's proud manners, she admits never witnessing any unprincipled, unjust, irreligious, or immoral behavior from him during their acquaintance.
She acknowledges Darcy is esteemed by his connections, speaks affectionately of his sister, and that Wickham himself admitted Darcy's merit as a brother.
She reasons that actions as wrong as Wickham described could not have stayed hidden, and Darcy's close friendship with the amiable Mr. Bingley would be inexplicable if Darcy were truly villainous.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: How differently did everything now appear in which he was concerned!
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She grew absolutely ashamed of herself. Of neither Darcy nor Wickham could she think, without feeling that she had been blind, partial, prejudiced, absurd.

events.text_segment:
How differently did everything now appear in which he was concerned! His attentions to Miss King were now the consequence of views solely and hatefully mercenary; and the mediocrity of her fortune proved no longer the moderation of his wishes, but his eagerness to grasp at anything. His behaviour to herself could now have had no tolerable motive: he had either been deceived with regard to her fortune, or had been gratifying his vanity by encouraging the preference which she believed she had most incautiously shown. Every lingering struggle in his favour grew fainter and fainter; and in further justification of Mr. Darcy, she could not but allow that Mr. Bingley, when questioned by Jane, had long ago asserted his blamelessness in the affair;—that, proud and repulsive as were his manners, she had never, in the whole course of their acquaintance—an acquaintance which had latterly brought them much together, and given her a sort of intimacy with his ways—seen anything that betrayed him to be unprincipled or unjust—anything that spoke him of irreligious or immoral habits;—that among his own connections he was esteemed and valued;—that even Wickham had allowed him merit as a brother, and that she had often heard him speak so affectionately of his sister as to prove him capable of some amiable feeling;—that had his actions been what Wickham represented them, so gross a violation of everything right could hardly have been concealed from the world; and that friendship between a person capable of it and such an amiable man as Mr. Bingley was incomprehensible.
She grew absolutely ashamed of herself. Of neither Darcy nor Wickham could she think, without feeling that she had been blind, partial, prejudiced, absurd.
