As they proceeded through the garden, Elizabeth could not help but observe the neatness and order that pervaded every part of the estate. The gardener, a stout, cheerful man, pointed out various plants and trees, speaking with pride of the grounds' beauty and the care he and his staff bestowed upon them. Elizabeth listened attentively, her curiosity about the estate and its management piqued.

Mr. Darcy, walking beside her, seemed equally engaged, occasionally adding a comment or asking a question about the flora. His manner was more relaxed than usual, and Elizabeth noted a softness in his expression that she had not seen before. As they strolled, they came upon a small pond, where ducks were swimming lazily. Elizabeth paused to watch them, and Mr. Darcy, noticing her interest, suggested they sit on a nearby bench.

While seated, Elizabeth took the opportunity to inquire about the estate's history. The gardener, eager to share, recounted stories of the land's past owners and the improvements made over the years. Elizabeth was captivated by his tales, which painted a vivid picture of the estate's heritage.

After some time, they continued their walk, passing through a series of flowerbeds bursting with color. The scent of roses and jasmine filled the air, creating a delightful atmosphere. Elizabeth felt a sense of tranquility and happiness, appreciating the beauty surrounding her.

As they approached the house once more, Mr. Darcy expressed his hope that she had enjoyed the tour. Elizabeth responded warmly, acknowledging the pleasure she had derived from seeing the estate and learning about its history. They re-entered the house, where the housekeeper awaited to guide them to the next part of their visit.

Throughout the afternoon, Elizabeth's impressions of Mr. Darcy grew more favorable. His genuine interest in the estate and his considerate manner had begun to dispel some of her previous reservations. As they prepared to leave, she reflected on the unexpected pleasure of the day, feeling a newfound respect and curiosity about the man who had shown her such kindness and attentiveness.

events.title: Elizabeth's Mortification and Confusion
detailed_summary: The Gardiners comment on Darcy's fine appearance, but Elizabeth, lost in her feelings, doesn't register their words.
She walks silently, consumed by shame and vexation over the encounter.
She mentally criticizes her decision to visit Pemberley as ill-judged and unfortunate, imagining Darcy's negative interpretation of her presence.
She fears he might believe she intentionally placed herself in his path.
She laments the timing of her visit coinciding with his unexpected early return.
The memory of the awkward meeting causes her to blush repeatedly.
She is profoundly perplexed by the dramatic change in his demeanor – his civility and gentle inquiries contrast sharply with their last meeting at Rosings.
Elizabeth cannot fathom the reason behind this transformation.
As they walk through scenic grounds beside the water, she remains oblivious to the beauty around her.
She responds absently to her aunt and uncle, her thoughts fixed on Darcy and his current state of mind.
She wonders intensely about his thoughts regarding her and whether he might still harbor feelings for her.
She questions the sincerity of his civility, though noting an undertone in his voice that didn't suggest mere ease.
She recognizes his lack of composure but cannot discern whether seeing her caused him more pain or pleasure.
Eventually, her companions' remarks about her distraction prompt her to make an effort to appear more composed.

events.text_segment:
The others then joined her, and expressed their admiration of his figure; but Elizabeth heard not a word, and, wholly engrossed by her own feelings, followed them in silence. She was overpowered by shame and vexation. Her coming there was the most unfortunate, the most ill-judged thing in the world! How strange must it appear to him! In what a disgraceful light might it not strike so vain a man! It might seem as if she had purposely thrown herself in his way again! Oh! why did she come? or, why did he thus come a day before he was expected? Had they been only ten minutes sooner, they should have been beyond the reach of his discrimination; for it was plain that he was that moment arrived, that moment alighted from his horse or his carriage. She blushed again and again over the perverseness of the meeting. And his behaviour, so strikingly altered,—what could it mean? That he should even speak to her was amazing!—but to speak with such civility, to inquire after her family! Never in her life had she seen his manners so little dignified, never had he spoken with such gentleness as on this unexpected meeting. What a contrast did it offer to his last address in Rosings Park, when he put his letter into her hand! She knew not what to think, or how to account for it.
They had now entered a beautiful walk by the side of the water, and every step was bringing forward a nobler fall of ground, or a finer reach of the woods to which they were approaching: but it was some time before Elizabeth was sensible of any of it; and, though she answered mechanically to the repeated appeals of her uncle and aunt, and seemed to direct her eyes to such objects as they pointed out, she distinguished no part of the scene. Her thoughts were all fixed on that one spot of Pemberley House, whichever it might be, where Mr. Darcy then was. She longed to know what at that moment was passing in his mind; in what manner he thought of her, and whether, in defiance of everything, she was still dear to him. Perhaps he had been civil only because he felt himself at ease; yet there had been that in his voice, which was not like ease. Whether he had felt more of pain or of pleasure in seeing her, she could not tell, but he certainly had not seen her with composure.
At length, however, the remarks of her companions on her absence of mind roused her, and she felt the necessity of appearing more like herself.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
The others then joined her, and expressed their admiration of his figure; but Elizabeth heard not a word, and, wholly engrossed by her own feelings, followed them in silence.

She walked on, her mind a tumult of shame and vexation. The image of Mr. Darcy's altered demeanor haunted her—his civility, his gentle inquiries, so different from their last encounter at Rosings. She wondered what had caused this change, whether her presence had softened his heart or merely masked his disdain. Her cheeks flushed repeatedly as she recalled the awkwardness of their meeting, and she could not help but question whether he saw her as a woman to be pitied or despised.

As they strolled through the scenic grounds beside the water, Elizabeth remained lost in thought, oblivious to the beauty surrounding her. Her aunt and uncle's remarks about her distraction only drew her further into her musings. She pondered whether Darcy still harbored feelings for her, or if his civility was merely a social veneer. The undertone in his voice, the slight hesitation in his manner—did it reveal pain or pleasure at seeing her? She could not tell.

Her reflections were interrupted only when her companions' comments about her absent-mindedness prompted her to make an effort to appear more composed, though her heart was still tumultuous with unanswered questions.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
As they moved on, Elizabeth's mind was a tumult of thoughts and emotions. She observed Mr. Darcy with a mixture of admiration and confusion. His presence was commanding, yet there was an air of restraint about him that she found intriguing. She wondered at her own reactions—how her heart fluttered whenever he drew near, and how her cheeks warmed at his slightest glance. Despite her initial prejudice, she could not deny the impression he had begun to make.

The conversation around her continued, but Elizabeth's attention was elsewhere. She reflected on the earlier moments when she had overheard Mr. Darcy's remarks about her family and her own feelings of indignation. Yet, beneath that, there was a flicker of curiosity—an acknowledgment that perhaps her judgments had been hasty. She considered the possibility that beneath his proud exterior, there might be a man of integrity and depth.

As they reached the edge of the lawn, Elizabeth took a moment to compose herself. The sun was beginning to set, casting a golden glow over the landscape, and the air was filled with the scent of blooming flowers. She looked around, observing the others engaged in lively conversation, their laughter ringing out. But her thoughts remained fixed on Mr. Darcy, pondering whether her initial impressions would be forever altered.

Suddenly, Mr. Darcy approached her, his expression more open than before. "Miss Bennet," he began, with a tone that was both respectful and earnest, "I hope I have not offended you with my earlier remarks. It was not my intention to be rude, but I find myself often at a loss for words in the presence of someone I respect so highly."

Elizabeth was taken aback by his sincerity. She responded with a gentle smile, "There is no need to apologize, Mr. Darcy. I believe we all have our moments of awkwardness. I must admit, I have been surprised by your behavior today, and I am beginning to see a different side of you."

He looked pleased, and for a moment, the tension between them eased. They continued to walk together, exchanging thoughts and opinions, each discovering new facets of the other's character. Elizabeth felt a cautious hope stirring within her—that perhaps, beneath the pride and prejudice, there was a genuine man worth knowing.

As the evening drew to a close, they rejoined the group, their conversation flowing more freely. Elizabeth's heart was lighter, her mind more open. She realized that her feelings were evolving, and that her perceptions of Mr. Darcy might be changing for the better. The day had begun with misunderstanding, but it was ending with a glimmer of possibility—a promise of future understanding and perhaps, affection.

events.title: Renewed Encounter and Darcy's Surprising Hospitality
detailed_summary: The group explores the wooded areas of the park, enjoying various views.
Mr. Gardiner learns the park's circuit is ten miles, deciding against attempting the full walk.
They follow a standard path back towards the river, crossing a bridge into a narrower, less adorned glen.

events.text_segment:
They entered the woods, and, bidding adieu to the river for a while, ascended some of the higher grounds; whence, in spots where the opening of the trees gave the eye power to wander, were many charming views of the valley, the opposite hills, with the long range of woods overspreading many, and occasionally part of the stream. Mr. Gardiner expressed a wish of going round the whole park, but feared it might be beyond a walk. With a triumphant smile, they were told, that it was ten miles round. It settled the matter; and they pursued the accustomed circuit; which brought them again, after some time, in a descent among hanging woods, to the edge of the water, and one of its narrowest parts. They crossed it by a simple bridge, in character with the general air of the scene: it was a spot less adorned than any they had yet visited; and the valley, here contracted into a glen, allowed room only for the stream, and a narrow walk amidst the rough coppice-wood which bordered it. Elizabeth longed to explore its windings; but when they had crossed the bridge, and perceived their distance from the house, Mrs. Gardiner, who was not a great walker, could go no farther, and thought only of returning to the carriage as quickly as possible. Her niece was, therefore, obliged to submit, and they took their way towards the house on the opposite side of the river, in the nearest direction; but their progress was slow, for Mr. Gardiner, though seldom able to indulge the taste, was very fond of fishing, and was so much engaged in watching the occasional appearance of some trout in the water, and talking to the man about them, that he advanced but little. Whilst wandering on in this slow manner, they were again surprised, and Elizabeth’s astonishment was quite equal to what it had been at first, by the sight of Mr. Darcy approaching them, and at no great distance. The walk being here less sheltered than on the other side, allowed them to see him before they met. Elizabeth, however astonished, was at least more prepared for an interview than before, and resolved to appear and to speak with calmness, if he really intended to meet them. For a few moments, indeed, she felt that he would probably strike into some other path. The idea lasted while a turning in the walk concealed him from their view; the turning past, he was immediately before them. With a glance she saw that he had lost none of his recent civility; and, to imitate his politeness, she began as they met to admire the beauty of the place; but she had not got beyond the words “delightful,” and “charming,” when some unlucky recollections obtruded, and she fancied that praise of Pemberley from her might be mischievously construed. Her colour changed, and she said no more.
Mrs. Gardiner was standing a little behind; and on her pausing, he asked her if she would do him the honour of introducing him to her friends. This was a stroke of civility for which she was quite unprepared; and she could hardly suppress a smile at his being now seeking the acquaintance of some of those very people, against whom his pride had revolted, in his offer to herself. “What will be his surprise,” thought she, “when he knows who they are! He takes them now for people of fashion.”
The introduction, however, was immediately made; and as she named their relationship to herself, she stole a sly look at him, to see how he bore it; and was not without the expectation of his decamping as fast as he could from such disgraceful companions. That he was surprised by the connection was evident: he sustained it, however, with fortitude: and, so far from going away, turned back with them, and entered into conversation with Mr. Gardiner. Elizabeth could not but be pleased, could not but triumph. It was consoling that he should know she had some relations for whom there was no need to blush. She listened most attentively to all that passed between them, and gloried in every expression, every sentence of her uncle, which marked his intelligence, his taste, or his good manners.
The conversation soon turned upon fishing; and she heard Mr. Darcy invite him, with the greatest civility, to fish there as often as he chose, while he continued in the neighbourhood, offering at the same time to supply him with fishing tackle, and pointing out those parts of the stream where there was usually most sport. Mrs. Gardiner, who was walking arm in arm with Elizabeth, gave her a look expressive of her wonder. Elizabeth said nothing, but it gratified her exceedingly; the compliment must be all for herself. Her astonishment, however, was extreme; and continually was she repeating, “Why is he so altered? From what can it proceed? It cannot be for me, it cannot be for my sake that his manners are thus softened. My reproofs at Hunsford could not work such a change as this. It is impossible that he should still love me.”

Elizabeth looked around with a sense of calm and pleasure, her thoughts wandering as freely as the landscape before her. The serenity of the scene was a balm to her spirits, which had been somewhat ruffled by the recent conversations and the complex feelings they had stirred. As they moved further into the woods, the sounds of the outside world faded, replaced by the gentle rustling of leaves and the distant call of a bird. Elizabeth's mind was occupied with reflections on her recent encounters, her own feelings, and the characters of those around her.

She thought of Mr. Darcy, whose proud exterior often concealed a more tender and generous heart. His words and actions had puzzled her at times, yet she could not deny the impression he had made on her. She wondered if he was truly as reserved and aloof as he appeared, or if there was a warmth beneath that exterior waiting to be discovered.

Her thoughts then turned to her sister Jane, whose gentle nature and sincere kindness had always been a source of comfort. Jane's happiness was Elizabeth's greatest concern, and she hoped that her sister's feelings for Mr. Bingley would soon be realized and reciprocated. Elizabeth admired Jane's patience and goodness, qualities that made her beloved by all who knew her.

As they reached a particularly open spot, Elizabeth paused to take in the view. The valley stretched out before her, a tapestry of green fields, winding streams, and distant cottages. The hills in the distance were bathed in the soft glow of the afternoon sun, creating a picture of idyllic beauty. Elizabeth felt a deep sense of gratitude for these moments of peace and the opportunity to reflect amidst such natural splendor.

The group continued their walk, the conversation light and cheerful, yet Elizabeth's mind remained partly absorbed in her own thoughts. She considered the nature of pride and prejudice, themes that had been so central to her reflections throughout her acquaintance with Mr. Darcy. She recognized her own prejudices and the importance of overcoming them to see people more clearly.

As they descended from the higher ground, the landscape changed once more, the trees growing closer together and the path becoming more shaded. Elizabeth felt a renewed sense of clarity and resolve. She was determined to approach her feelings and her judgments with honesty and humility, understanding that true happiness depended on such self-awareness.

The woods gradually gave way to a more cultivated area, and soon they found themselves back in the familiar surroundings of Longbourn. Elizabeth's heart was lighter, her mind more at ease. She looked forward to the days ahead, hopeful that her understanding of herself and others would deepen, leading her to a future filled with genuine affection and mutual respect.

detailed_summary: During the walk back, Mrs. Gardiner, feeling fatigued, shifts her support from Elizabeth's arm to her husband's.

Elizabeth breaks the ensuing silence, explaining she had verified his absence before visiting Pemberley.

events.text_segment:
After walking some time in this way, the two ladies in front, the two gentlemen behind, on resuming their places, after descending to the brink of the river for the better inspection of some curious water-plant, there chanced to be a little alteration. It originated in Mrs. Gardiner, who, fatigued by the exercise of the morning, found Elizabeth’s arm inadequate to her support, and consequently preferred her husband’s. Mr. Darcy took her place by her niece, and they walked on together. After a short silence the lady first spoke. She wished him to know that she had been assured of his absence before she came to the place, and accordingly began by observing, that his arrival had been very unexpected—“for your housekeeper,” she added, “informed us that you would certainly not be here till to-morrow; and, indeed, before we left Bakewell, we understood that you were not immediately expected in the country.” He acknowledged the truth of it all; and said that business with his steward had occasioned his coming forward a few hours before the rest of the party with whom he had been travelling. “They will join me early to-morrow,” he continued, “and among them are some who will claim an acquaintance with you,—Mr. Bingley and his sisters.”
Elizabeth answered only by a slight bow. Her thoughts were instantly driven back to the time when Mr. Bingley’s name had been last mentioned between them; and if she might judge from his complexion, his mind was not very differently engaged.
“There is also one other person in the party,” he continued after a pause, “who more particularly wishes to be known to you. Will you allow me, or do I ask too much, to introduce my sister to your acquaintance during your stay at Lambton?”
The surprise of such an application was great indeed; it was too great for her to know in what manner she acceded to it. She immediately felt that whatever desire Miss Darcy might have of being acquainted with her, must be the work of her brother, and without looking farther, it was satisfactory; it was gratifying to know that his resentment had not made him think really ill of her.
They now walked on in silence; each of them deep in thought. Elizabeth was not comfortable; that was impossible; but she was flattered and pleased. His wish of introducing his sister to her was a compliment of the highest kind. They soon outstripped the others; and when they had reached the carriage, Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner were half a quarter of a mile behind.

Elizabeth was utterly astonished and struggled to respond, instantly deducing that Georgiana's wish must originate from Darcy himself. This realization pleased her immensely, indicating his past resentment had not caused him to think ill of her.

They then walked onward in silence, both preoccupied with their thoughts. Walking faster than the others, they arrived at the carriage considerably ahead of Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner.

events.text_segment:
He then asked her to walk into the house—but she declared herself not tired, and they stood together on the lawn. At such a time much might have been said, and silence was very awkward. She wanted to talk, but there seemed an embargo on every subject. At last she recollected that she had been travelling, and they talked of Matlock and Dovedale with great perseverance. Yet time and her aunt moved slowly—and her patience and her ideas were nearly worn out before the tête-à-tête was over.
On Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner’s coming up they were all pressed to go into the house and take some refreshment; but this was declined, and they parted on each side with the utmost politeness. Mr. Darcy handed the ladies into the carriage; and when it drove off, Elizabeth saw him walking slowly towards the house.
The observations of her uncle and aunt now began; and each of them pronounced him to be infinitely superior to anything they had expected.
“He is perfectly well-behaved, polite, and unassuming,” said her uncle.
“There is something a little stately in him, to be sure,” replied her aunt; “but it is confined to his air, and is not unbecoming. I can now say with the housekeeper, that though some people may call him proud, I have seen nothing of it.”
“I was never more surprised than by his behaviour to us. It was more than civil; it was really attentive; and there was no necessity for such attention. His acquaintance with Elizabeth was very trifling.”
“To be sure, Lizzy,” said her aunt, “he is not so handsome as Wickham; or rather he has not Wickham’s countenance, for his features are perfectly good. But how came you to tell us that he was so disagreeable?”
Elizabeth excused herself as well as she could: said that she had liked him better when they met in Kent than before, and that she had never seen him so pleasant as this morning.
“But perhaps he may be a little whimsical in his civilities,” replied her uncle. “Your great men often are; and therefore I shall not take him at his word about fishing, as he might change his mind another day, and warn me off his grounds.”
Elizabeth felt that they had entirely mistaken his character, but said nothing.
“From what we have seen of him,” continued Mrs. Gardiner, “I really should not have thought that he could have behaved in so cruel a way by anybody as he has done by poor Wickham. He has not an ill-natured look. On the contrary, there is something pleasing about his mouth when he speaks. And there is something of dignity in his countenance, that would not give one an unfavourable idea of his heart. But, to be sure, the good lady who showed us the house did give him a most flaming character! I could hardly help laughing aloud sometimes. But he is a liberal master, I suppose, and that, in the eye of a servant, comprehends every virtue.”
Elizabeth here felt herself called on to say something in vindication of his behaviour to Wickham; and, therefore, gave them to understand, in as guarded a manner as she could, that by what she had heard from his relations in Kent, his actions were capable of a very different construction; and that his character was by no means so faulty, nor Wickham’s so amiable, as they had been considered in Hertfordshire. In confirmation of this, she related the particulars of all the pecuniary transactions in which they had been connected, without actually naming her authority, but stating it to be such as might be relied on.
Mrs. Gardiner was surprised and concerned: but as they were now approaching the scene of her former pleasures, every idea gave way to the charm of recollection; and she was too much engaged in pointing out to her husband all the interesting spots in its environs, to think of anything else. Fatigued as she had been by the morning’s walk, they had no sooner dined than she set off again in quest of her former acquaintance, and the evening was spent in the satisfactions of an intercourse renewed after many years’ discontinuance.
The occurrences of the day were too full of interest to leave Elizabeth much attention for any of these new friends; and she could do nothing but think, and think with wonder, of Mr. Darcy’s civility, and, above all, of his wishing her to be acquainted with his sister.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Mr. Darcy, observing her reluctance to move, felt a mixture of admiration and concern. He was struck once again by her spirited independence, which contrasted sharply with the usual submissiveness expected of women in their society. Elizabeth, noticing his gaze, smiled slightly, her cheeks tinged with a faint blush. The summer air was warm, and the gentle rustling of the leaves seemed to echo the unspoken tension between them.

"Are you not weary, Miss Bennet?" Mr. Darcy inquired softly, his voice tinged with genuine interest.

"Not at all," she replied, her eyes bright. "I find the open air quite invigorating."

He hesitated, then extended his hand towards her. "May I have the pleasure of walking with you?"

Elizabeth looked at him, surprised but pleased. "With pleasure," she said, taking his hand.

They strolled along the winding path, the conversation flowing more easily than either had anticipated. Mr. Darcy spoke of the countryside, its beauty, and the tranquility it offered. Elizabeth responded with observations of her own, her lively spirit shining through.

As they walked, Mr. Darcy found himself increasingly captivated by her wit and vivacity. He was aware of the subtle glances she cast his way, and he felt a burgeoning hope that perhaps, beneath her initial prejudice, there was a mutual affection waiting to be discovered.

"Miss Bennet," he began cautiously, "I must confess that I have been much mistaken in my judgments of you."

Elizabeth looked at him, her eyes curious. "Indeed?"

"Yes. I have come to see that your character is far more admirable than I had previously believed."

She smiled, a hint of mischief in her expression. "And I suppose I should thank you for your change of heart."

"It is I who should thank you," he replied sincerely. "For your honesty and your spirited nature."

They continued their walk, the sun casting a golden glow over the landscape. The moment felt suspended in time, a delicate balance of newfound understanding and tentative hope.

As they approached the house, Elizabeth hesitated. "I suppose I should return now. My sister will be wondering where I am."

Mr. Darcy nodded, a hint of disappointment in his eyes. "May I call upon you tomorrow?"

"I should like that very much," she replied, her heart fluttering.

He bowed slightly. "Until tomorrow, then."

Elizabeth turned to go, but then paused and looked back. "Mr. Darcy, I must admit, I had formed certain opinions about you, but I see now that they were unfair."

He smiled warmly. "And I, too, have learned to look beyond my initial impressions."

With that, they parted, each feeling a sense of anticipation for what the future might hold.

events.title: Unexpected Arrival and Rising Suspicions
detailed_summary: Elizabeth anticipates Mr. Darcy and his sister visiting the day after she arrives at Pemberley and decides to stay near the inn.
Her expectation is incorrect; Darcy and his sister arrive the morning after Elizabeth and the Gardiners reach Lambton, just as they return from a walk.
Elizabeth recognizes the Darcy livery on an approaching curricle, surprising her aunt and uncle by announcing the expected visitors.

The Gardiners are astonished, and Elizabeth's noticeable embarrassment, combined with the events of the previous day (presumably the Pemberley tour), leads them to suspect Darcy has a romantic interest in their niece.
While the Gardiners contemplate this new idea, Elizabeth's own anxiety increases.
She is surprised by her own nervousness, fearing Darcy might have praised her excessively to his sister and worrying she will fail to please.
Elizabeth moves away from the window to avoid being seen and paces the room, but her uncle and aunt's curious glances worsen her discomfort.

events.text_segment:
Elizabeth had settled it that Mr. Darcy would bring his sister to visit her the very day after her reaching Pemberley; and was, consequently, resolved not to be out of sight of the inn the whole of that morning. But her conclusion was false; for on the very morning after their own arrival at Lambton these visitors came. They had been walking about the place with some of their new friends, and were just returned to the inn to dress themselves for dining with the same family, when the sound of a carriage drew them to a window, and they saw a gentleman and lady in a curricle driving up the street. Elizabeth, immediately recognizing the livery, guessed what it meant, and imparted no small degree of surprise to her relations, by acquainting them with the honour which she expected. Her uncle and aunt were all amazement; and the embarrassment of her manner as she spoke, joined to the circumstance itself, and many of the circumstances of the preceding day, opened to them a new idea on the business. Nothing had ever suggested it before, but they now felt that there was no other way of accounting for such attentions from such a quarter than by supposing a partiality for their niece. While these newly-born notions were passing in their heads, the perturbation of Elizabeth’s feelings was every moment increasing. She was quite amazed at her own discomposure; but, amongst other causes of disquiet, she dreaded lest the partiality of the brother should have said too much in her favour; and, more than commonly anxious to please, she naturally suspected that every power of pleasing would fail her.
She retreated from the window, fearful of being seen; and as she walked up and down the room, endeavouring to compose herself, saw such looks of inquiring surprise in her uncle and aunt as made everything worse.

It was not until the next day that she saw them, and then she was surprised to find how much she had been looking forward to it, and how much she had been hoping for some particular expression of regard from Mr. Darcy.

Miss Darcy and her brother appeared, and this formidable introduction took place. With astonishment did Elizabeth see that her new acquaintance was at least as much embarrassed as herself. Since her being at Lambton, she had heard that Miss Darcy was exceedingly proud; but the observation of a very few minutes convinced her that she was only exceedingly shy. She found it difficult to obtain even a word from her beyond a monosyllable.
Miss Darcy was tall, and on a larger scale than Elizabeth; and, though little more than sixteen, her figure was formed, and her appearance womanly and graceful. She was less handsome than her brother, but there was sense and good-humour in her face, and her manners were perfectly unassuming and gentle. Elizabeth, who had expected to find in her as acute and unembarrassed an observer as ever Mr. Darcy had been, was much relieved by discerning such different feelings.

events.text_segment:
They had not been long together before Darcy told her that Bingley was also coming to wait on her; and she had barely time to express her satisfaction, and prepare for such a visitor, when Bingley’s quick step was heard on the stairs, and in a moment he entered the room. All Elizabeth’s anger against him had been long done away; but had she still felt any, it could hardly have stood its ground against the unaffected cordiality with which he expressed himself on seeing her again. He inquired in a friendly, though general, way, after her family, and looked and spoke with the same good-humoured ease that he had ever done.
To Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner he was scarcely a less interesting personage than to herself. They had long wished to see him. The whole party before them, indeed, excited a lively attention. The suspicions which had just arisen of Mr. Darcy and their niece, directed their observation towards each with an earnest, though guarded, inquiry; and they soon drew from those inquiries the full conviction that one of them at least knew what it was to love. Of the lady’s sensations they remained a little in doubt; but that the gentleman was overflowing with admiration was evident enough.
Elizabeth, on her side, had much to do. She wanted to ascertain the feelings of each of her visitors, she wanted to compose her own, and to make herself agreeable to all; and in the latter object, where she feared most to fail, she was most sure of success, for those to whom she endeavoured to give pleasure were pre-possessed in her favour. Bingley was ready, Georgiana was eager, and Darcy determined, to be pleased.

events.title: Searching for Signs of Bingley's Affection for Jane
detailed_summary: Seeing Bingley naturally makes Elizabeth think of her sister, Jane, and she desperately wishes to know if Bingley thinks of Jane too.
She speculates that he might be speaking less than usual and imagines he might be looking for a resemblance to Jane in her features.
While acknowledging this might be wishful thinking, she observes his interactions with Miss Darcy (once considered Jane's rival) closely.
Elizabeth sees no indication of special affection between Bingley and Miss Darcy, satisfying herself that his sister's hopes for a match are unfounded.
Before they part, a few small incidents reinforce Elizabeth's hope about Bingley's feelings for Jane.
In a moment when others are occupied, Bingley remarks to Elizabeth with seeming regret how long it has been since they last met.
He specifies it has been over eight months, pinpointing the date to the Netherfield ball on November 26th.
Elizabeth is pleased by his precise memory.
Later, when others are not listening, Bingley asks if *all* of Elizabeth's sisters are currently at Longbourn.
Elizabeth finds significance not just in the words but in Bingley's look and manner.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: In seeing Bingley, her thoughts naturally flew to her sister; and oh! how ardently did she long to know whether any of his were directed in a like manner.

events.text_segment:
In seeing Bingley, her thoughts naturally flew to her sister; and oh! how ardently did she long to know whether any of his were directed in a like manner. Sometimes she could fancy that he talked less than on former occasions, and once or twice pleased herself with the notion that, as he looked at her, he was trying to trace a resemblance. But, though this might be imaginary, she could not be deceived as to his behaviour to Miss Darcy, who had been set up as a rival to Jane. No look appeared on either side that spoke particular regard. Nothing occurred between them that could justify the hopes of his sister. On this point she was soon satisfied; and two or three little circumstances occurred ere they parted, which, in her anxious interpretation, denoted a recollection of Jane, not untinctured by tenderness, and a wish of saying more that might lead to the mention of her, had he dared. He observed to her, at a moment when the others were talking together, and in a tone which had something of real regret, that it “was a very long time since he had had the pleasure of seeing her;” and, before she could reply, he added, “It is above eight months. We have not met since the 26th of November, when we were all dancing together at Netherfield.”
Elizabeth was pleased to find his memory so exact; and he afterwards took occasion to ask her, when unattended to by any of the rest, whether all her sisters were at Longbourn. There was not much in the question, nor in the preceding remark; but there was a look and a manner which gave them meaning.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: In seeing Bingley, her thoughts naturally flew to her sister; and oh! how ardently did she long to know whether any of his were directed in a like manner. She was quite unable to conceal her feelings, and, in spite of her efforts to appear indifferent, her face betrayed her. Bingley, meanwhile, was observing her with a look of gentle curiosity, and she wondered if he could guess the thoughts that occupied her mind. As they parted, Bingley made a remark that seemed to carry a weight of meaning: 'It has been more than eight months since we last met, I believe—since the Netherfield ball on the 26th of November.' Elizabeth was pleased to find that he remembered the date so precisely. Later, when others were not listening, Bingley asked her if all her sisters were at Longbourn, and his manner and look conveyed a significance that she could not mistake.

events.title: Darcy's Astonishing Transformation
detailed_summary: Elizabeth occasionally glances at Mr. Darcy and observes his generally pleasant expression.
His tone lacks the haughtiness or disdain she previously associated with him, confirming the improved manners she noted the day before have persisted.
She is struck by his efforts to engage with and seek the good opinion of the Gardiners, people whose acquaintance he would have scorned months earlier.
Witnessing his civility not only to her but specifically to relations he once openly slighted astounds her.
Recalling their heated argument at Hunsford Parsonage highlights the dramatic change in his behavior.
The transformation is so profound that Elizabeth struggles to hide her astonishment.
She reflects that she has never seen him so eager to please or so free from pride and reserve, even among his close friends or esteemed family.
His current efforts seem particularly significant as they offer no social advantage and might even invite ridicule from circles like Netherfield or Rosings.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was not often that she could turn her eyes on Mr. Darcy himself; but whenever she did catch a glimpse she saw an expression of general complaisance, and in all that he said, she heard an accent so far removed from hauteur or disdain of his companions, as convinced her that the improvement of manners which she had yesterday witnessed, however temporary its existence might prove, had at least outlived one day.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Never, even in the company of his dear friends at Netherfield, or his dignified relations at Rosings, had she seen him so desirous to please, so free from self-consequence or unbending reserve, as now, when no importance could result from the success of his endeavours, and when even the acquaintance of those to whom his attentions were addressed, would draw down the ridicule and censure of the ladies both of Netherfield and Rosings.

events.text_segment: It was not often that she could turn her eyes on Mr. Darcy himself; but whenever she did catch a glimpse she saw an expression of general complaisance, and in all that he said, she heard an accent so far removed from hauteur or disdain of his companions, as convinced her that the improvement of manners which she had yesterday witnessed, however temporary its existence might prove, had at least outlived one day. When she saw him thus seeking the acquaintance, and courting the good opinion of people with whom any intercourse a few months ago would have been a disgrace; when she saw him thus civil, not only to herself, but to the very relations whom he had openly disdained, and recollected their last lively scene in Hunsford Parsonage, the difference, the change was so great, and struck so forcibly on her mind, that she could hardly restrain her astonishment from being visible. Never, even in the company of his dear friends at Netherfield, or his dignified relations at Rosings, had she seen him so desirous to please, so free from self-consequence or unbending reserve, as now, when no importance could result from the success of his endeavours, and when even the acquaintance of those to whom his attentions were addressed, would draw down the ridicule and censure of the ladies both of Netherfield and Rosings.

Elizabeth was surprised to observe that his manners, which had been so haughty and reserved, now appeared more open and engaging. She noticed that he was making an effort to be agreeable, not only to herself but also to her relatives, the Gardiners, whose acquaintance he would have once scorned. Witnessing his civility, especially towards those he once looked down upon, was astonishing.

Recalling their heated argument at Hunsford Parsonage, she was struck by the dramatic change in his demeanor. The transformation was so complete that she found it difficult to conceal her astonishment. She reflected that she had never seen him so eager to please, so free from pride and reserve, even among his closest friends or esteemed family.

His current efforts seemed particularly significant, given that they offered no social advantage and might even invite ridicule from circles like Netherfield or Rosings. Yet, he persisted, demonstrating a genuine desire to be better, to be different from the proud man she once knew.

events.title: An Invitation to Dine at Pemberley
detailed_summary: The visitors remain for over half an hour before preparing to leave.
Mr. Darcy prompts his sister to join him in inviting Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner and Elizabeth to dine at Pemberley before they depart the area.
Miss Darcy complies readily, though her shyness indicates she is unaccustomed to issuing invitations.
Mrs. Gardiner glances at Elizabeth, wanting to gauge her reaction as the invitation primarily concerns her, but Elizabeth deliberately looks away.
Interpreting Elizabeth's avoidance as momentary embarrassment rather than refusal, and noting her husband's eagerness for social engagement, Mrs. Gardiner accepts the invitation.
The dinner is scheduled for the day after next.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Their visitors stayed with them above half an hour; and when they arose to depart, Mr. Darcy called on his sister to join him in expressing their wish of seeing Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner, and Miss Bennet, to dinner at Pemberley, before they left the country.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Presuming, however, that this studied avoidance spoke rather a momentary embarrassment than any dislike of the proposal, and seeing in her husband, who was fond of society, a perfect willingness to accept it, she ventured to engage for her attendance, and the day after the next was fixed on.

events.text_segment: Their visitors stayed with them above half an hour; and when they arose to depart, Mr. Darcy called on his sister to join him in expressing their wish of seeing Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner, and Miss Bennet, to dinner at Pemberley, before they left the country. Miss Darcy, though with a diffidence which marked her little in the habit of giving invitations, readily obeyed. Mrs. Gardiner looked at her niece, desirous of knowing how she, whom the invitation most concerned, felt disposed as to its acceptance, but Elizabeth had turned away her head. Presuming, however, that this studied avoidance spoke rather a momentary embarrassment than any dislike of the proposal, and seeing in her husband, who was fond of society, a perfect willingness to accept it, she ventured to engage for her attendance, and the day after the next was fixed on.

events.title: Post-Visit Reflections: Bingley, Darcy, and Wickham
detailed_summary: Bingley expresses enthusiasm about seeing Elizabeth again soon, mentioning he has much more to discuss and inquiries about Hertfordshire friends.
Elizabeth interprets this as a desire to hear about Jane, which pleases her.
Partly due to this, and other factors, Elizabeth feels some satisfaction reflecting on the visit after her guests leave, though she enjoyed it little while it occurred.
Anxious to be alone and avoid questions from her aunt and uncle, she stays only long enough to hear their positive assessment of Bingley before excusing herself to dress.

events.text_segment:
Bingley expressed great pleasure in the certainty of seeing Elizabeth again, having still a great deal to say to her, and many inquiries to make after all their Hertfordshire friends. Elizabeth, construing all this into a wish of hearing her speak of her sister, was pleased; and on this account, as well as some others, found herself, when their visitors left them, capable of considering the last half hour with some satisfaction, though while it was passing the enjoyment of it had been little. Eager to be alone, and fearful of inquiries or hints from her uncle and aunt, she stayed with them only long enough to hear their favourable opinion of Bingley, and then hurried away to dress.
But she had no reason to fear Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner’s curiosity; it was not their wish to force her communication. It was evident that she was much better acquainted with Mr. Darcy than they had before any idea of; it was evident that he was very much in love with her. They saw much to interest, but nothing to justify inquiry.
Of Mr. Darcy it was now a matter of anxiety to think well; and, as far as their acquaintance reached, there was no fault to find. They could not be untouched by his politeness; and had they drawn his character from their own feelings and his servant’s report, without any reference to any other account, the circle in Hertfordshire to which he was known would not have recognized it for Mr. Darcy. There was now an interest, however, in believing the housekeeper; and they soon became sensible that the authority of a servant, who had known him since he was four years old, and whose own manners indicated respectability, was not to be hastily rejected. Neither had anything occurred in the intelligence of their Lambton friends that could materially lessen its weight. They had nothing to accuse him of but pride; pride he probably had, and if not, it would certainly be imputed by the inhabitants of a small market town where the family did not visit. It was acknowledged, however, that he was a liberal man, and did much good among the poor.
With respect to Wickham, the travellers soon found that he was not held there in much estimation; for though the chief of his concerns with the son of his patron were imperfectly understood, it was yet a well-known fact that, on his quitting Derbyshire, he had left many debts behind him, which Mr. Darcy afterwards discharged.

As they walked together, Bingley expressed his hope that they might meet again soon, perhaps at the next ball or gathering. Elizabeth, with a smile, agreed that she looked forward to seeing him again, and she was pleased to find that their acquaintance was growing more agreeable with each encounter.

Meanwhile, Jane was engaged in a similar manner with Mr. Bingley's sister, Caroline, who was eager to learn about her family and her prospects. The two young women quickly found common ground, and Jane was pleased to discover that Caroline was not at all as haughty as she had initially appeared.

Mr. Darcy, observing the scene from a distance, felt a mixture of satisfaction and unease. He was glad to see Elizabeth looking so well and so happy, but he was also conscious of the feelings that still troubled him. He had been reflecting on his own conduct and the misunderstandings that had kept him from expressing his true regard for Elizabeth.

As the evening progressed, the company moved to the drawing-room, where music and conversation filled the air. Elizabeth found herself enjoying the company of her friends and the lively entertainment, yet her thoughts often returned to Mr. Darcy and the complex emotions that his presence stirred within her.

The evening ended with a sense of anticipation for future meetings, and Elizabeth felt a renewed hope that her feelings might someday be understood and reciprocated. She was aware that much remained to be said and done, but she was also hopeful that time and sincerity would bring clarity and happiness to all involved.

events.title: Elizabeth's Gratitude and Emotional Reckoning
detailed_summary: Elizabeth's thoughts are consumed by Pemberley and its master more intensely this evening than the last.
She spends two hours awake trying to decipher her feelings towards Darcy.
She definitively concludes she no longer hates him; hatred disappeared long ago, replaced by shame for her previous dislike.
Respect for his good qualities, initially resisted, is no longer unwelcome and has grown due to the favourable accounts of his character and disposition from the previous day.
Beyond respect and esteem, she feels a powerful sense of goodwill: gratitude.
This gratitude stems not just from his past love for her, but from his enduring affection, strong enough to overlook her harsh rejection and unfair accusations.
She is moved that the man she expected to avoid her now seems eager to maintain their acquaintance after their chance meeting.
He solicits her friends' good opinion and introduces her to his sister, all without inappropriate displays of affection.
This significant change in such a proud man evokes both astonishment and gratitude, which she attributes solely to ardent love.
This realization feels positive and encouraging, though she cannot precisely define its impact.
She acknowledges her respect, esteem, gratitude, and genuine interest in his well-being.

Her uncertainty lies in determining how much she wants his happiness linked to hers and whether pursuing the potential renewal of his affections (which she senses is possible) would benefit them both.

events.text_segment: As for Elizabeth, her thoughts were at Pemberley this evening more than the last; and the evening, though as it passed it seemed long, was not long enough to determine her feelings towards one in that mansion; and she lay awake two whole hours, endeavouring to make them out. She certainly did not hate him. No; hatred had vanished long ago, and she had almost as long been ashamed of ever feeling a dislike against him, that could be so called. The respect created by the conviction of his valuable qualities, though at first unwillingly admitted, had for some time ceased to be repugnant to her feelings; and it was now heightened into somewhat of a friendlier nature by the testimony so highly in his favour, and bringing forward his disposition in so amiable a light, which yesterday had produced. But above all, above respect and esteem, there was a motive within her of good-will which could not be overlooked. It was gratitude;—gratitude, not merely for having once loved her, but for loving her still well enough to forgive all the petulance and acrimony of her manner in rejecting him, and all the unjust accusations accompanying her rejection. He who, she had been persuaded, would avoid her as his greatest enemy, seemed, on this accidental meeting, most eager to preserve the acquaintance; and without any indelicate display of regard, or any peculiarity of manner, where their two selves only were concerned, was soliciting the good opinion of her friends, and bent on making her known to his sister. Such a change in a man of so much pride excited not only astonishment but gratitude—for to love, ardent love, it must be attributed; and, as such, its impression on her was of a sort to be encouraged, as by no means unpleasing, though it could not be exactly defined. She respected, she esteemed, she was grateful to him, she felt a real interest in his welfare; and she only wanted to know how far she wished that welfare to depend upon herself, and how far it would be for the happiness of both that she should employ the power, which her fancy told her she still possessed, of bringing on the renewal of his addresses.

Respect for his good qualities, which she had at first resisted, was now no longer unwelcome, and had grown upon her from the favourable accounts she had received of his character and disposition. But beyond respect and esteem, she felt a strong sense of gratitude—gratitude not only for his past love, but for his continued affection, which had endured her harsh rejection and unjust accusations. She was touched that the man she had expected to avoid now seemed eager to maintain their acquaintance, soliciting her friends' good opinion and introducing her to his sister without any improper display of affection. This change in such a proud man surprised her, and she felt grateful, which she attributed solely to his ardent love. This realization was encouraging, though she could not precisely define its effect. She knew she respected, esteemed, and was grateful to him, and that she genuinely wished him well. events.title: Arranging the Return Visit to Pemberley
detailed_summary: During the evening, Elizabeth and Mrs. Gardiner agree that Miss Darcy's prompt visit—arriving the very morning she reached Pemberley—was a remarkable act of civility.
They decide this courtesy should be reciprocated, though perhaps not matched, by a polite visit from their side.
Consequently, they resolve to call on Miss Darcy at Pemberley the following morning.
Elizabeth feels pleased about the plan, although she cannot articulate a clear reason for her satisfaction when she questions herself.
Shortly after breakfast, Mr. Gardiner departs.
His fishing plans with gentlemen at Pemberley, arranged the previous day, are confirmed for noon.

events.text_segment:
It had been settled in the evening, between the aunt and niece, that such a striking civility as Miss Darcy’s, in coming to them on the very day of her arrival at Pemberley—for she had reached it only to a late breakfast—ought to be imitated, though it could not be equalled, by some exertion of politeness on their side; and, consequently, that it would be highly expedient to wait on her at Pemberley the following morning. They were, therefore, to go. Elizabeth was pleased; though when she asked herself the reason, she had very little to say in reply.
Mr. Gardiner left them soon after breakfast. The fishing scheme had been renewed the day before, and a positive engagement made of his meeting some of the gentlemen at Pemberley by noon.

events.title: Awkward Reception at Pemberley
detailed_summary: Elizabeth anticipated an unwelcome reception from Miss Bingley, suspecting jealousy as the root of her dislike.
Upon arrival, Elizabeth and Mrs. Gardiner were shown into a pleasant summer saloon with views of the grounds.
They were received by Miss Darcy, Mrs. Hurst, Miss Bingley, and Miss Darcy's companion, Mrs. Annesley.
Georgiana Darcy's reception was polite but marked by significant embarrassment stemming from shyness, which could be mistaken for pride.
Mrs. Gardiner and Elizabeth perceived Georgiana's shyness accurately and felt sympathy for her.
Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley offered only minimal courtesy (a curtsy).
An uncomfortable silence followed their seating.

events.text_segment:
Convinced as Elizabeth now was that Miss Bingley’s dislike of her had originated in jealousy, she could not help feeling how very unwelcome her appearance at Pemberley must be to her, and was curious to know with how much civility on that lady’s side the acquaintance would now be renewed.
On reaching the house, they were shown through the hall into the saloon, whose northern aspect rendered it delightful for summer. Its windows, opening to the ground, admitted a most refreshing view of the high woody hills behind the house, and of the beautiful oaks and Spanish chestnuts which were scattered over the intermediate lawn.
In this room they were received by Miss Darcy, who was sitting there with Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley, and the lady with whom she lived in London. Georgiana’s reception of them was very civil, but attended with all that embarrassment which, though proceeding from shyness and the fear of doing wrong, would easily give to those who felt themselves inferior the belief of her being proud and reserved. Mrs. Gardiner and her niece, however, did her justice, and pitied her.
By Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley they were noticed only by a courtesy; and on their being seated, a pause, awkward as such pauses must always be, succeeded for a few moments. It was first broken by Mrs. Annesley, a genteel, agreeable-looking woman, whose endeavour to introduce some kind of discourse proved her to be more truly well-bred than either of the others; and between her and Mrs. Gardiner, with occasional help from Elizabeth, the conversation was carried on. Miss Darcy looked as if she wished for courage enough to join in it; and sometimes did venture a short sentence, when there was least danger of its being heard.

events.title: Tense Observation and Anticipation
detailed_summary: Elizabeth became aware that Miss Bingley was watching her intently, particularly whenever she addressed Miss Darcy.
This scrutiny, combined with the seating arrangement, discouraged Elizabeth from engaging more with Miss Darcy.
Elizabeth found herself preoccupied with her own thoughts, anticipating the arrival of the gentlemen from the estate.
She was conflicted, simultaneously wishing for and fearing Mr. Darcy's appearance.
After about fifteen minutes of silence from Miss Bingley, the latter made a cold inquiry about the Bennet family's health, which Elizabeth answered with equal coolness.

The serving of food provided a welcome activity for the entire party, drawing them together around the table.

events.text_segment:
Elizabeth soon saw that she was herself closely watched by Miss Bingley, and that she could not speak a word, especially to Miss Darcy, without calling her attention. This observation would not have prevented her from trying to talk to the latter, had they not been seated at an inconvenient distance; but she was not sorry to be spared the necessity of saying much: her own thoughts were employing her. She expected every moment that some of the gentlemen would enter the room: she wished, she feared, that the master of the house might be amongst them; and whether she wished or feared it most, she could scarcely determine. After sitting in this manner a quarter of an hour, without hearing Miss Bingley’s voice, Elizabeth was roused by receiving from her a cold inquiry after the health of her family. She answered with equal indifference and brevity, and the other said no more.
The next variation which their visit afforded was produced by the entrance of servants with cold meat, cake, and a variety of all the finest fruits in season; but this did not take place till after many a significant look and smile from Mrs. Annesley to Miss Darcy had been given, to remind her of her post. There was now employment for the whole party; for though they could not all talk, they could all eat; and the beautiful pyramids of grapes, nectarines, and peaches, soon collected them round the table.

She felt a mixture of anticipation and apprehension about Mr. Darcy's appearance, unsure whether she wished to see him or preferred to avoid it. After about fifteen minutes of silence, Miss Bingley broke the stillness with a cold inquiry about the Bennet family's health, which Elizabeth answered with equal coolness, maintaining her composure. Servants then entered with refreshments—cold meat, cake, and fruit—prompted by subtle signals from Mrs. Annesley to Miss Darcy, indicating her role as hostess. The serving of food provided a welcome activity for all present, drawing them together around the table and momentarily easing the tension in the room.

events.text_segment:
While thus engaged, Elizabeth had a fair opportunity of deciding whether she most feared or wished for the appearance of Mr. Darcy, by the feelings which prevailed on his entering the room; and then, though but a moment before she had believed her wishes to predominate, she began to regret that he came.
He had been some time with Mr. Gardiner, who, with two or three other gentlemen from the house, was engaged by the river; and had left him only on learning that the ladies of the family intended a visit to Georgiana that morning. No sooner did he appear, than Elizabeth wisely resolved to be perfectly easy and unembarrassed;—a resolution the more necessary to be made, but perhaps not the more easily kept, because she saw that the suspicions of the whole party were awakened against them, and that there was scarcely an eye which did not watch his behaviour when he first came into the room. In no countenance was attentive curiosity so strongly marked as in Miss Bingley’s, in spite of the smiles which overspread her face whenever she spoke to one of its objects; for jealousy had not yet made her desperate, and her attentions to Mr. Darcy were by no means over. Miss Darcy, on her brother’s entrance, exerted herself much more to talk; and Elizabeth saw that he was anxious for his sister and herself to get acquainted, and forwarded, as much as possible, every attempt at conversation on either side.

events.title: Miss Bingley's Failed Attack
detailed_summary: Observing Darcy's encouragement of interaction between Elizabeth and Georgiana, Miss Bingley acted on her anger.
She addressed Elizabeth with pointed civility, inquiring about the removal of the militia from Meryton, adding that their departure must be a great loss to Elizabeth's family.
Miss Bingley avoided mentioning Wickham directly in Darcy's presence, but Elizabeth immediately understood the implication.
The reference caused Elizabeth momentary distress due to associated memories, but she quickly composed herself and answered neutrally.
During Elizabeth's response, she glanced at Darcy and saw his heightened color and intense gaze upon her.
She also saw Georgiana overcome with confusion, unable to look up.

The narrator notes Miss Bingley was unaware of the pain her remark caused Darcy (by distressing Georgiana), her only goal being to unsettle Elizabeth by mentioning a man (Wickham) she thought Elizabeth favored.
Miss Bingley hoped to make Elizabeth reveal sensibility that might lower her in Darcy's esteem and perhaps remind Darcy of the Bennet family's 'low' connections.

Miss Bingley was completely ignorant of Georgiana's near-elopement with Wickham, a secret Darcy had guarded closely, especially from Bingley's connections, partly due to his hopes (as Elizabeth suspected) of Bingley marrying Georgiana.
Elizabeth's calm demeanor quickly eased Darcy's agitation.
Miss Bingley, frustrated, did not pursue the topic of Wickham further.
Georgiana gradually recovered, though she remained silent.
Darcy, whose focus Miss Bingley intended to divert from Elizabeth, seemed instead to regard Elizabeth with increased cheerfulness.

events.text_segment:
Miss Bingley saw all this likewise; and, in the imprudence of anger, took the first opportunity of saying, with sneering civility,—
“Pray, Miss Eliza, are not the ——shire militia removed from Meryton? They must be a great loss to your family.”
In Darcy’s presence she dared not mention Wickham’s name: but Elizabeth instantly comprehended that he was uppermost in her thoughts; and the various recollections connected with him gave her a moment’s distress; but, exerting herself vigorously to repel the ill-natured attack, she presently answered the question in a tolerably disengaged tone. While she spoke, an involuntary glance showed her Darcy with a heightened complexion, earnestly looking at her, and his sister overcome with confusion, and unable to lift up her eyes. Had Miss Bingley known what pain she was then giving her beloved friend, she undoubtedly would have refrained from the hint; but she had merely intended to discompose Elizabeth, by bringing forward the idea of a man to whom she believed her partial, to make her betray a sensibility which might injure her in Darcy’s opinion, and, perhaps, to remind the latter of all the follies and absurdities by which some part of her family were connected with that corps. Not a syllable had ever reached her of Miss Darcy’s meditated elopement. To no creature had it been revealed, where secrecy was possible, except to Elizabeth; and from all Bingley’s connections her brother was particularly anxious to conceal it, from that very wish which Elizabeth had long ago attributed to him, of their becoming hereafter her own. He had certainly formed such a plan; and without meaning that it should affect his endeavour to separate him from Miss Bennet, it is probable that it might add something to his lively concern for the welfare of his friend.
Elizabeth’s collected behaviour, however, soon quieted his emotion; and as Miss Bingley, vexed and disappointed, dared not approach nearer to Wickham, Georgiana also recovered in time, though not enough to be able to speak any more. Her brother, whose eye she feared to meet, scarcely recollected her interest in the affair; and the very circumstance which had been designed to turn his thoughts from Elizabeth, seemed to have fixed them on her more and more cheerfully.

Miss Bingley saw all this likewise; and, in the imprudence of anger, took the first opportunity of saying, with sneering civility,—"Pray, Miss Elizabeth, are not the militia removed from Meryton? Have they disbanded?" Elizabeth replied that they had.

"I imagine you will be glad to have the peace preserved."

"Certainly," replied Elizabeth, who could think only of Mr. Wickham. 

Miss Bingley, observing her agitation, continued, with a slight sneer, "It must be a great loss to your family, Miss Elizabeth, to have the militia removed."

Elizabeth, feeling the sting, answered with a calmness that concealed her distress, "It is, indeed, a loss to Meryton, but I hope it will be only a temporary one."

Miss Bingley, aiming to unsettle her further, added, "I suppose you have heard of Mr. Wickham's departure from Meryton?"

Elizabeth's face betrayed a moment of pain, but she quickly recovered, replying, "Yes, I have heard."

She glanced at Darcy, who was watching her with a heightened color and an intense gaze. Georgiana, nearby, looked down, overwhelmed.

events.title: Post-Visit Criticisms and Darcy's Defense
detailed_summary: The visit concluded soon after Miss Bingley's provocative question.
While Darcy escorted Elizabeth and Mrs. Gardiner to their carriage, Miss Bingley criticized Elizabeth's person, behaviour, and dress to Georgiana.
Georgiana refused to join the criticism, influenced by her brother's positive recommendation of Elizabeth.
Upon Darcy's return to the saloon, Miss Bingley repeated some of her criticisms to him directly.
She exclaimed how ill Elizabeth looked, claiming she was greatly altered, appearing brown and coarse, and that she and Louisa (Mrs. Hurst) barely recognized her.
Darcy, though likely displeased, replied coolly that he only noticed a slight tan, a normal effect of summer travel.
Miss Bingley persisted, stating she never saw any beauty in Elizabeth, criticizing her thin face, lack of complexion brilliance, plain features, unremarkable nose, and tolerable-but-ordinary teeth.
She dismissed Elizabeth's often-praised eyes as having a sharp, shrewish look and condemned her overall air as displaying self-sufficiency without fashionable elegance.
Knowing Darcy admired Elizabeth, Miss Bingley's attack was unwise, but anger clouded her judgment; seeing Darcy finally look annoyed gave her the only success she achieved.
Darcy remained resolutely silent.

Determined to make him speak, Miss Bingley recalled their early acquaintance in Hertfordshire, reminding him he had once called Elizabeth's mother witty sooner than call Elizabeth herself a beauty, though acknowledging he later seemed to find her 'rather pretty'.
Unable to restrain himself, Darcy retorted that his initial low opinion was long past, stating he had considered Elizabeth one of the handsomest women of his acquaintance for many months.
He then left the room, leaving Miss Bingley with the hollow victory of having forced a statement that only caused her own pain.

events.text_segment:
Their visit did not continue long after the question and answer above mentioned; and while Mr. Darcy was attending them to their carriage, Miss Bingley was venting her feelings in criticisms on Elizabeth’s person, behaviour, and dress. But Georgiana would not join her. Her brother’s recommendation was enough to insure her favour: his judgment could not err; and he had spoken in such terms of Elizabeth, as to leave Georgiana without the power of finding her otherwise than lovely and amiable. When Darcy returned to the saloon, Miss Bingley could not help repeating to him some part of what she had been saying to his sister.
“How very ill Eliza Bennet looks this morning, Mr. Darcy,” she cried: “I never in my life saw anyone so much altered as she is since the winter. She is grown so brown and coarse! Louisa and I were agreeing that we should not have known her again.”
However little Mr. Darcy might have liked such an address, he contented himself with coolly replying, that he perceived no other alteration than her being rather tanned,—no miraculous consequence of travelling in the summer.
“For my own part,” she rejoined, “I must confess that I never could see any beauty in her. Her face is too thin; her complexion has no brilliancy; and her features are not at all handsome. Her nose wants character; there is nothing marked in its lines. Her teeth are tolerable, but not out of the common way; and as for her eyes, which have sometimes been called so fine, I never could perceive anything extraordinary in them. They have a sharp, shrewish look, which I do not like at all; and in her air altogether, there is a self-sufficiency without fashion, which is intolerable.”
Persuaded as Miss Bingley was that Darcy admired Elizabeth, this was not the best method of recommending herself; but angry people are not always wise; and in seeing him at last look somewhat nettled, she had all the success she expected. He was resolutely silent, however; and, from a determination of making him speak, she continued,—
“I remember, when we first knew her in Hertfordshire, how amazed we all were to find that she was a reputed beauty; and I particularly recollect your saying one night, after they had been dining at Netherfield, ‘She a beauty! I should as soon call her mother a wit.’ But afterwards she seemed to improve on you, and I believe you thought her rather pretty at one time.”
“Yes,” replied Darcy, who could contain himself no longer, “but that was only when I first knew her; for it is many months since I have considered her as one of the handsomest women of my acquaintance.”
He then went away, and Miss Bingley was left to all the satisfaction of having forced him to say what gave no one any pain but herself.

It is quite astonishing.' Elizabeth, unruffled, replied with gentle civility, 'I am sure I am very little deserving of such a compliment, but I thank you all the same.' Mr. Darcy, observing the scene, felt a mixture of embarrassment and concern. He was aware of Miss Bingley's envy and her attempts to undermine Elizabeth's reputation. As they reached the carriage, Mr. Darcy offered his arm to Elizabeth, and she accepted it with a gracious nod. The carriage door was opened, and they stepped in, leaving behind the uncomfortable scene. Elizabeth, reflecting on the encounter, thought it a pity that Miss Bingley should be so ill-natured, but she was accustomed to such behaviour and did not let it disturb her peace. Mr. Darcy, meanwhile, was quietly contemplating the situation, feeling a growing admiration for Elizabeth's composure and dignity. The carriage moved on, and the conversation turned to more pleasant topics, as they discussed the upcoming ball and the prospects of meeting their acquaintances there. Elizabeth was pleased to find Mr. Darcy in good spirits, and she appreciated his efforts to change the subject from the unpleasantness they had just left. As they approached their destination, Elizabeth resolved to maintain her usual calm and politeness, regardless of the petty criticisms of others. She knew that true worth was not to be judged by superficial qualities or the opinions of those who envied her. Mr. Darcy, observing her serene countenance, felt a renewed respect for her character. He was increasingly convinced that her virtues far surpassed her modest exterior. The rest of the journey was marked by a comfortable silence, broken only by Mr. Darcy's gentle remarks about the weather and the beauty of the countryside. When they arrived at their destination, Elizabeth stepped out of the carriage with a light heart, determined not to let Miss Bingley's words affect her. She was aware that such petty jealousies were often the result of envy and insecurity. As she entered the house, she was greeted by her sister Jane, whose cheerful smile instantly lifted her spirits. The evening promised to be a lively one, with music, dancing, and the company of friends. Elizabeth looked forward to the evening with a sense of hope and anticipation, eager to enjoy the pleasures of good company and lively conversation. She resolved to remain true to herself, unaffected by the criticisms of others, and to continue to cultivate her own happiness and virtue. Mr. Darcy, observing her from a distance, felt a deepening admiration and a desire to know her better. He was beginning to see her not just as a charming young woman, but as a person of true worth and integrity. As the night drew on, the ball commenced, and Elizabeth found herself enjoying the dance and the company of Mr. Bingley and his sisters. Despite the earlier discomfort, she was determined to make the most of the evening, confident that her true character would shine through any superficial criticisms.

events.title: Arrival of Delayed Letters from Jane
detailed_summary: Elizabeth's initial disappointment at not hearing from Jane during their stay in Lambton turns to relief on the third morning.
She receives two letters from Jane simultaneously.
One letter is marked as having been misdirected, which Elizabeth understands given Jane's poor handwriting on the address.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: They had just been preparing to walk as the letters came in; and her uncle and aunt, leaving her to enjoy them in quiet, set off by themselves.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I am afraid you will not be able to make it out, but I hardly know what I have written.”

events.text_segment:
They had just been preparing to walk as the letters came in; and her uncle and aunt, leaving her to enjoy them in quiet, set off by themselves. The one mis-sent must be first attended to; it had been written five days ago. The beginning contained an account of all their little parties and engagements, with such news as the country afforded; but the latter half, which was dated a day later, and written in evident agitation, gave more important intelligence. It was to this effect:—
“Since writing the above, dearest Lizzy, something has occurred of a most unexpected and serious nature; but I am afraid of alarming you—be assured that we are all well. What I have to say relates to poor Lydia. An express came at twelve last night, just as we were all gone to bed, from Colonel Forster, to inform us that she was gone off to Scotland with one of his officers; to own the truth, with Wickham! Imagine our surprise. To Kitty, however, it does not seem so wholly unexpected. I am very, very sorry. So imprudent a match on both sides! But I am willing to hope the best, and that his character has been misunderstood. Thoughtless and indiscreet I can easily believe him, but this step (and let us rejoice over it) marks nothing bad at heart. His choice is disinterested at least, for he must know my father can give her nothing. Our poor mother is sadly grieved. My father bears it better. How thankful am I, that we never let them know what has been said against him; we must forget it ourselves. They were off Saturday night about twelve, as is conjectured, but were not missed till yesterday morning at eight. The express was sent off directly. My dear Lizzy, they must have passed within ten miles of us. Colonel Forster gives us reason to expect him here soon. Lydia left a few lines for his wife, informing her of their intention. I must conclude, for I cannot be long from my poor mother. I am afraid you will not be able to make it out, but I hardly know what I have written.”
