events.title: Elizabeth's Painful Recognition of Darcy's Suitability and Lost Possibility
detailed_summary: Elizabeth believed any affection Darcy may have developed for her could not possibly endure the impact of Lydia's scandalous marriage.
She felt humbled and sorrowful, experiencing a vague sense of repentance.
Paradoxically, she began to value Darcy's good opinion more deeply now that she could no longer realistically hope to gain from it.
She longed for news of him precisely when communication seemed impossible and became convinced of their potential happiness together only when reunion seemed out of reach.
She reflected on the irony that she would now welcome the proposal she had once rejected so forcefully, acknowledging Darcy's generosity but imagining his justifiable sense of triumph.
Elizabeth came to a profound realization: Darcy possessed the exact combination of character and intellect that would perfectly complement her own.
She envisioned their marriage as mutually enriching—her liveliness improving his reserve, his wisdom benefiting her.
She lamented that this potentially ideal union, capable of demonstrating true marital happiness, was now prevented by circumstance.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The wish of procuring her regard, which she had assured herself of his feeling in Derbyshire, could not in rational expectation survive such a blow as this.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But no such happy marriage could now teach the admiring multitude what connubial felicity really was.

events.text_segment:
The wish of procuring her regard, which she had assured herself of his feeling in Derbyshire, could not in rational expectation survive such a blow as this. She was humbled, she was grieved; she repented, though she hardly knew of what. She became jealous of his esteem, when she could no longer hope to be benefited by it. She wanted to hear of him, when there seemed the least chance of gaining intelligence. She was convinced that she could have been happy with him, when it was no longer likely they should meet.
What a triumph for him, as she often thought, could he know that the proposals which she had proudly spurned only four months ago would now have been gladly and gratefully received! He was as generous, she doubted not, as the most generous of his sex. But while he was mortal, there must be a triumph.
She began now to comprehend that he was exactly the man who, in disposition and talents, would most suit her. His understanding and temper, though unlike her own, would have answered all her wishes. It was an union that must have been to the advantage of both: by her ease and liveliness, his mind might have been softened, his manners improved; and from his judgment, information, and knowledge of the world, she must have received benefit of greater importance.
But no such happy marriage could now teach the admiring multitude what connubial felicity really was.

She realized that her previous judgments had been clouded by pride and prejudice, and now, humbled and sorrowful, she saw Darcy in a new light. Her thoughts wandered to the possibility of their union, not as a matter of hope, but as a distant, almost impossible dream, given the circumstances. Yet, paradoxically, she began to cherish Darcy's good opinion more than ever, understanding that her own happiness might be intertwined with his, should fate allow it. She longed for news of him, feeling a strange sense of longing when communication was impossible, and found herself imagining their future together—an alliance that would be mutually enriching, where her vivacity could soften his reserve, and his wisdom could guide her. She lamented that such a union, capable of demonstrating true marital happiness, was now hindered by circumstances beyond their control, leaving her to ponder the ironies of love and fortune.

Her mind raced with confusion and disappointment, questioning whether her feelings had been misplaced all along. Yet, amidst her turmoil, she recognized the importance of maintaining her composure, for she knew that her future happiness depended on her ability to navigate this delicate situation with dignity. As she looked away, her eyes caught Mr. Darcy's, and in that silent exchange, a flicker of understanding passed between them. Perhaps, she thought, this was a test of her own character, a challenge to see if she could forgive and move forward. She resolved to reflect on her feelings and to consider whether her pride or her prejudice was more deserving of her attention. Though her heart was heavy, she knew that time and reflection would be necessary to heal the wounds inflicted by this unexpected blow. With a deep breath, she prepared herself to face whatever came next, determined to preserve her integrity and to seek the truth beneath the surface of her emotions.

events.title: Practical Arrangements for Wickham and Lydia, and the Decision for a Visit
detailed_summary: Elizabeth contemplated Lydia and Wickham's impending marriage, foreseeing little chance of financial security or true happiness for a couple united by passion rather than virtue.
A letter arrived from Mr. Gardiner, briefly acknowledging Mr. Bennet's gratitude while firmly requesting the financial assistance never be mentioned again.
Mr. Gardiner reported that Wickham had agreed to leave the militia for a position in the regular army, a move Gardiner strongly advocated for both their sakes.
Wickham was promised an ensigncy in a regiment stationed far away in the north.
Gardiner hoped the new environment would encourage more prudent behavior from the couple.
He confirmed he had contacted Colonel Forster regarding Wickham's Brighton debts, pledged himself for their payment, and asked Mr. Bennet to handle the Meryton creditors based on an enclosed list.
He relayed that Lydia was well and wished to visit Longbourn before departing for the north.
Mr. Bennet, Jane, and Elizabeth saw the wisdom in Wickham's distant posting, but Mrs. Bennet was displeased, mourning the loss of proximity to Lydia and her connections in the militia.
Mr. Bennet initially refused to allow Lydia and Wickham to visit Longbourn.
Jane and Elizabeth intervened, persuading their father with calm, rational arguments focused on Lydia's feelings and social standing, to permit the visit after the wedding.
Mrs. Bennet was gratified by the opportunity to display her married daughter locally.
Mr. Bennet communicated his permission to Mr. Gardiner.
Elizabeth, despite the arrangement, was personally displeased at the prospect of seeing Wickham again and puzzled that he would agree to visit Longbourn.

events.text_segment:
An union of a different tendency, and precluding the possibility of the other, was soon to be formed in their family.
How Wickham and Lydia were to be supported in tolerable independence she could not imagine. But how little of permanent happiness could belong to a couple who were only brought together because their passions were stronger than their virtue, she could easily conjecture.
Mr. Gardiner soon wrote again to his brother. To Mr. Bennet’s acknowledgments he briefly replied, with assurances of his eagerness to promote the welfare of any of his family; and concluded with entreaties that the subject might never be mentioned to him again. The principal purport of his letter was to inform them, that Mr. Wickham had resolved on quitting the militia.
“It was greatly my wish that he should do so,” he added, “as soon as his marriage was fixed on. And I think you will agree with me, in considering a removal from that corps as highly advisable, both on his account and my niece’s. It is Mr. Wickham’s intention to go into the Regulars; and, among his former friends, there are still some who are able and willing to assist him in the army. He has the promise of an ensigncy in General——’s regiment, now quartered in the north. It is an advantage to have it so far from this part of the kingdom. He promises fairly; and I hope among different people, where they may each have a character to preserve, they will both be more prudent. I have written to Colonel Forster, to inform him of our present arrangements, and to request that he will satisfy the various creditors of Mr. Wickham in and near Brighton with assurances of speedy payment, for which I have pledged myself. And will you give yourself the trouble of carrying similar assurances to his creditors in Meryton, of whom I shall subjoin a list, according to his information? He has given in all his debts; I hope at least he has not deceived us. Haggerston has our directions, and all will be completed in a week. They will then join his regiment, unless they are first invited to Longbourn; and I understand from Mrs. Gardiner that my niece is very desirous of seeing you all before she leaves the south. She is well, and begs to be dutifully remembered to you and her mother.—Yours, etc.
“E. Gardiner.”
Mr. Bennet and his daughters saw all the advantages of Wickham’s removal from the ——shire, as clearly as Mr. Gardiner could do. But Mrs. Bennet was not so well pleased with it. Lydia’s being settled in the north, just when she had expected most pleasure and pride in her company, for she had by no means given up her plan of their residing in Hertfordshire, was a severe disappointment; and, besides, it was such a pity that Lydia should be taken from a regiment where she was acquainted with everybody, and had so many favourites.
“She is so fond of Mrs. Forster,” said she, “it will be quite shocking to send her away! And there are several of the young men, too, that she likes very much. The officers may not be so pleasant in General——’s regiment.”
His daughter’s request, for such it might be considered, of being admitted into her family again, before she set off for the north, received at first an absolute negative. But Jane and Elizabeth, who agreed in wishing, for the sake of their sister’s feelings and consequence, that she should be noticed on her marriage by her parents, urged him so earnestly, yet so rationally and so mildly, to receive her and her husband at Longbourn, as soon as they were married, that he was prevailed on to think as they thought, and act as they wished. And their mother had the satisfaction of knowing, that she should be able to show her married daughter in the neighbourhood, before she was banished to the north. When Mr. Bennet wrote again to his brother, therefore, he sent his permission for them to come; and it was settled, that, as soon as the ceremony was over, they should proceed to Longbourn. Elizabeth was surprised, however, that Wickham should consent to such a scheme; and, had she consulted only her own inclination, any meeting with him would have been the last object of her wishes.

She wondered how this union would influence her family dynamics and whether it would indeed be for the best.

As the news spread through Longbourn, the household buzzed with speculation. Jane, ever gentle and kind, hoped that this new development would bring happiness and stability. Lydia, on the other hand, was more interested in the social implications and the possibility of new acquaintances. The Bennet sisters, each with their own perspectives, contemplated the potential changes that this union might bring.

In the days that followed, the family prepared to receive the prospective bridegroom and his family. Mrs. Bennet was particularly eager to make a good impression, ensuring that the house was spotless and that her daughters were dressed to perfection. Elizabeth observed her mother's enthusiasm with a mixture of amusement and concern, pondering how such alliances could influence her own prospects and the future of her family.

When the day arrived, the Bennets received their visitors with a mixture of politeness and curiosity. The gentleman was introduced as Mr. Collins, a clergyman of some standing, who was to be the future husband of one of the Bennet daughters. The family was somewhat surprised, as this was not the match they had anticipated, but they welcomed him graciously.

Elizabeth, however, was not convinced that this was the right match for her sister, and she voiced her concerns subtly.

The engagement was announced, and the family celebrated in their own way. Elizabeth, though pleased for her sister, felt a sense of unease. She wondered whether this union was truly advantageous or merely a matter of convenience and social climbing. Her thoughts were interrupted by her father's gentle teasing and her mother's exuberant plans for the wedding.

In the midst of these events, Elizabeth continued to observe her family and their new acquaintances. She reflected on the nature of marriage and the importance of genuine affection versus social convenience. Her own feelings about Mr. Darcy, whom she had met earlier and found intriguing yet somewhat aloof, lingered in her mind.

As the days went by, Elizabeth's understanding of her family and their choices deepened. She recognized the complexities of social expectations and the importance of personal happiness. Her own heart, meanwhile, was drawn to Mr. Darcy, whose pride and prejudice challenged her perceptions and stirred her curiosity.

The union in their family, therefore, was not merely a matter of social arrangement but a reflection of the intricate web of relationships, expectations, and personal desires that defined their world. Elizabeth resolved to remain true to her own feelings and to seek happiness based on mutual respect and understanding, rather than mere social advantage.

detailed_summary: On Lydia's wedding day, Jane and Elizabeth feel more apprehension for her than she seems to feel for herself.
The elder Bennet sisters dread the couple's arrival, particularly Jane, who feels vicariously ashamed for Lydia.
The family gathers to receive them; Mrs. Bennet beams, Mr. Bennet appears severely grave, and the daughters are anxious.

events.text_segment:
Their sister’s wedding-day arrived; and Jane and Elizabeth felt for her probably more than she felt for herself. The carriage was sent to meet them at——, and they were to return in it by dinnertime. Their arrival was dreaded by the elder Miss Bennets—and Jane more especially, who gave Lydia the feelings which would have attended herself, had she been the culprit, and was wretched in the thought of what her sister must endure.
They came. The family were assembled in the breakfast-room to receive them. Smiles decked the face of Mrs. Bennet, as the carriage drove up to the door; her husband looked impenetrably grave; her daughters, alarmed, anxious, uneasy.
Lydia’s voice was heard in the vestibule; the door was thrown open, and she ran into the room. Her mother stepped forwards, embraced her, and welcomed her with rapture; gave her hand with an affectionate smile to Wickham, who followed his lady; and wished them both joy, with an alacrity which showed no doubt of their happiness.
Their reception from Mr. Bennet, to whom they then turned, was not quite so cordial. His countenance rather gained in austerity; and he scarcely opened his lips. The easy assurance of the young couple, indeed, was enough to provoke him.
Elizabeth was disgusted, and even Miss Bennet was shocked. Lydia was Lydia still; untamed, unabashed, wild, noisy, and fearless. She turned from sister to sister, demanding their congratulations; and when at length they all sat down, looked eagerly round the room, took notice of some little alteration in it, and observed, with a laugh, that it was a great while since she had been there.
Wickham was not at all more distressed than herself; but his manners were always so pleasing, that, had his character and his marriage been exactly what they ought, his smiles and his easy address, while he claimed their relationship, would have delighted them all. Elizabeth had not before believed him quite equal to such assurance; but she sat down, resolving within herself to draw no limits in future to the impudence of an impudent man. She blushed, and Jane blushed; but the cheeks of the two who caused their confusion suffered no variation of colour.

detailed_summary: Conversation flows freely, dominated by Lydia and her mother.
Wickham engages Elizabeth with cheerful ease about local acquaintances, which she struggles to reciprocate.
Both Lydia and Wickham seem untroubled by past events.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There was no want of discourse.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Ah, Jane, I take your place now, and you must go lower, because I am a married woman.”

events.text_segment:
There was no want of discourse. The bride and her mother could neither of them talk fast enough; and Wickham, who happened to sit near Elizabeth, began inquiring after his acquaintance in that neighbourhood, with a good-humoured ease, which she felt very unable to equal in her replies. They seemed each of them to have the happiest memories in the world. Nothing of the past was recollected with pain; and Lydia led voluntarily to subjects which her sisters would not have alluded to for the world.
“Only think of its being three months,” she cried, “since I went away: it seems but a fortnight, I declare; and yet there have been things enough happened in the time. Good gracious! when I went away, I am sure I had no more idea of being married till I came back again! though I thought it would be very good fun if I was.”
Her father lifted up his eyes, Jane was distressed, Elizabeth looked expressively at Lydia; but she, who never heard nor saw anything of which she chose to be insensible, gaily continued,—
“Oh, mamma, do the people hereabouts know I am married to-day? I was afraid they might not; and we overtook William Goulding in his curricle, so I was determined he should know it, and so I let down the side glass next to him, and took off my glove and let my hand just rest upon the window frame, so that he might see the ring, and then I bowed and smiled like anything.”
Elizabeth could bear it no longer. She got up and ran out of the room; and returned no more, till she heard them passing through the hall to the dining-parlour. She then joined them soon enough to see Lydia, with anxious parade, walk up to her mother’s right hand, and hear her say to her eldest sister,—
“Ah, Jane, I take your place now, and you must go lower, because I am a married woman.”

Elizabeth, with her usual wit, responded with a gentle rebuke, which drew a smile from her sister and a slight blush from Mr. Collins.

The conversation then turned to the subject of marriage, a topic that always stirred a variety of opinions among the company. Elizabeth listened with interest as her mother extolled the virtues of a good match, while her father made light of the importance of wealth and status. Jane, ever modest, expressed her hope that she might find someone who would love her for herself, rather than for her connections.

Throughout the evening, Elizabeth's mind was busy with thoughts of Mr. Darcy, whose reserved exterior concealed a depth of feeling that she was only beginning to understand. She wondered whether his apparent aloofness was a barrier or merely a mask, and whether she might have the opportunity to discover the truth behind his demeanor. As the night drew to a close, she felt a mixture of anticipation and uncertainty, aware that her life was about to change in ways she could not yet imagine.

events.text_segment:
It was not to be supposed that time would give Lydia that embarrassment from which she had been so wholly free at first. Her ease and good spirits increased. She longed to see Mrs. Philips, the Lucases, and all their other neighbours, and to hear herself called “Mrs. Wickham” by each of them; and in the meantime she went after dinner to show her ring and boast of being married to Mrs. Hill and the two housemaids.
“Well, mamma,” said she, when they were all returned to the breakfast-room, “and what do you think of my husband? Is not he a charming man? I am sure my sisters must all envy me. I only hope they may have half my good luck. They must all go to Brighton. That is the place to get husbands. What a pity it is, mamma, we did not all go!”
“Very true; and if I had my will we should. But, my dear Lydia, I don’t at all like your going such a way off. Must it be so?”
“Oh, Lord! yes; there is nothing in that. I shall like it of all things. You and papa, and my sisters, must come down and see us. We shall be at Newcastle all the winter, and I dare say there will be some balls, and I will take care to get good partners for them all.”
“I should like it beyond anything!” said her mother.
“And then when you go away, you may leave one or two of my sisters behind you; and I dare say I shall get husbands for them before the winter is over.”
“I thank you for my share of the favour,” said Elizabeth; “but I do not particularly like your way of getting husbands.”
Their visitors were not to remain above ten days with them. Mr. Wickham had received his commission before he left London, and he was to join his regiment at the end of a fortnight.
No one but Mrs. Bennet regretted that their stay would be so short; and she made the most of the time by visiting about with her daughter, and having very frequent parties at home. These parties were acceptable to all; to avoid a family circle was even more desirable to such as did think than such as did not.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Lydia Bennet, with her usual light-heartedness and lack of foresight, had been quite confident that her flirtations and flirtatious conduct would not lead to any serious consequences. She had, after all, been the life of every gathering, the centre of attention, and she believed herself to be quite the accomplished flirt. However, her reckless behavior and the hasty elopement with Mr. Wickham had cast a shadow over her once carefree spirit.

As the days passed, Lydia began to realize the gravity of her actions. The shame and disgrace that her family now faced weighed heavily on her conscience. Her mother, Mrs. Bennet, was frantic, her nerves frayed by the scandal, and her father, Mr. Bennet, was quietly disappointed, though he tried to maintain his usual calm demeanor.

Lydia, in her youthful innocence, had not fully understood the implications of her actions. She had been swept away by the thrill of adventure and the attention she received from Mr. Wickham. But now, confronted with the reality of her situation, she felt a mixture of regret and embarrassment. She was aware that her family’s reputation was tarnished, and she feared the judgment of society.

Elizabeth Bennet, her sister, felt a mixture of concern and disappointment. She knew Lydia’s impulsiveness and lack of prudence had led to this predicament. Elizabeth hoped that Lydia would learn from her mistake and understand the importance of virtue and proper conduct.

The Bennet family’s prospects had been severely affected by Lydia’s elopement. Their social standing was at risk, and the possibility of Lydia’s marriage to Mr. Wickham being recognized and accepted was uncertain. Lydia’s carefree attitude was now replaced with a sense of shame, and she was beginning to grasp the seriousness of her situation.

Despite her embarrassment, Lydia was not entirely without hope. She was young and had time to reflect and perhaps change her ways. Her family’s love and support, though strained at the moment, remained a source of comfort. Lydia’s experience served as a harsh lesson, one that she would not soon forget, and she hoped that in time, she could regain her family’s respect and her own dignity.

events.text_segment:
Wickham’s affection for Lydia was just what Elizabeth had expected to find it; not equal to Lydia’s for him. She had scarcely needed her present observation to be satisfied, from the reason of things, that their elopement had been brought on by the strength of her love rather than by his; and she would have wondered why, without violently caring for her, he chose to elope with her at all, had she not felt certain that his flight was rendered necessary by distress of circumstances; and if that were the case, he was not the young man to resist an opportunity of having a companion.
Lydia was exceedingly fond of him. He was her dear Wickham on every occasion; no one was to be put in competition with him. He did everything best in the world; and she was sure he would kill more birds on the first of September than anybody else in the country.
One morning, soon after their arrival, as she was sitting with her two elder sisters, she said to Elizabeth,—
“Lizzy, I never gave you an account of my wedding, I believe. You were not by, when I told mamma, and the others, all about it. Are not you curious to hear how it was managed?”
“No, really,” replied Elizabeth; “I think there cannot be too little said on the subject.”
“La! You are so strange! But I must tell you how it went off. We were married, you know, at St. Clement’s, because Wickham’s lodgings were in that parish. And it was settled that we should all be there by eleven o’clock. My uncle and aunt and I were to go together; and the others were to meet us at the church.
“Well, Monday morning came, and I was in such a fuss! I was so afraid, you know, that something would happen to put it off, and then I should have gone quite distracted. And there was my aunt, all the time I was dressing, preaching and talking away just as if she was reading a sermon. However, I did not hear above one word in ten, for I was thinking, you may suppose, of my dear Wickham. I longed to know whether he would be married in his blue coat.
“Well, and so we breakfasted at ten as usual: I thought it would never be over; for, by the bye, you are to understand that my uncle and aunt were horrid unpleasant all the time I was with them. If you’ll believe me, I did not once put my foot out of doors, though I was there a fortnight. Not one party, or scheme, or anything! To be sure, London was rather thin, but, however, the Little Theatre was open.
“Well, and so, just as the carriage came to the door, my uncle was called away upon business to that horrid man Mr. Stone. And then, you know, when once they get together, there is no end of it. Well, I was so frightened I did not know what to do, for my uncle was to give me away; and if we were beyond the hour we could not be married all day. But, luckily, he came back again in ten minutes’ time, and then we all set out. However, I recollected afterwards, that if he had been prevented going, the wedding need not be put off, for Mr. Darcy might have done as well.”
“Mr. Darcy!” repeated Elizabeth, in utter amazement.
“Oh, yes! he was to come there with Wickham, you know. But, gracious me! I quite forgot! I ought not to have said a word about it. I promised them so faithfully! What will Wickham say? It was to be such a secret!”

She knew that his attachment was more about convenience and opportunity than genuine love or respect.

Lydia, on the other hand, was utterly captivated by Wickham’s attentions. She adored the flirtation, the excitement of being pursued, and the promise of adventure that he seemed to offer. Her youthful innocence and desire for romance blinded her to the potential consequences of her infatuation. She believed herself to be the object of his affection, unaware of his true intentions and the ease with which he could cast her aside once he found someone more advantageous.

Elizabeth’s concern grew as she observed Lydia’s flirtations and the way she eagerly sought Wickham’s company. She knew that Lydia’s reckless pursuit of happiness could lead to ruin, especially given Wickham’s reputation and the lack of stability in his circumstances. Elizabeth’s mind was troubled by the thought that Lydia’s innocence might be sacrificed for a fleeting moment of pleasure, and she felt a deep sense of responsibility to intervene if she could.

Mr. Darcy, observing Elizabeth’s distress, was moved by her concern. He admired her compassion and her ability to see beyond surface appearances. His own feelings for Elizabeth had begun to deepen, and he found himself wishing he could shield her from the pain she anticipated. Yet, he also recognized that Lydia’s situation was a reflection of the broader issues of morality and social standing that they all faced.

As the days passed, Elizabeth’s fears were confirmed when she learned of Lydia’s elopement with Wickham. The news struck her like a blow, and she felt a mixture of shame, anger, and helplessness. She knew that Lydia’s reputation was now compromised, and that her family’s prospects could be severely damaged. The thought of Lydia’s future, uncertain and precarious, filled her with sorrow.

Despite her distress, Elizabeth refused to despair. She understood that her family’s honor depended on swift and discreet action. She resolved to do everything in her power to rectify the situation, even if it meant risking her own happiness. Her love for her family and her sense of duty propelled her forward.

Meanwhile, Mr. Darcy’s feelings for Elizabeth continued to grow. He was increasingly aware of her virtues and her strength of character. Her concern for Lydia and her willingness to act for her family’s good touched him deeply. He saw in her a kindred spirit, someone who valued integrity and moral rectitude.

In the end, it was through the efforts of Mr. Darcy, who used his influence and resources to secure Wickham’s marriage to Lydia, that the crisis was averted. Lydia’s reputation was salvaged, and her marriage to Wickham was arranged under circumstances that minimized the damage to her family’s standing. Elizabeth was grateful for Darcy’s intervention, and her feelings for him grew stronger.

This episode served as a turning point for Elizabeth, revealing the importance of discernment and the true nature of love and virtue. She learned that appearances could be deceiving and that genuine affection was rooted in integrity and moral strength. Her understanding of Wickham’s character was confirmed, and her appreciation for Darcy’s nobility deepened.

As the story progressed, Elizabeth’s perceptions of herself and others evolved. She recognized the value of humility, the importance of moral judgment, and the power of genuine love founded on mutual respect and understanding. The trials they faced ultimately brought her closer to the man she was destined to marry, and she found happiness in the knowledge that true virtue and love could prevail over superficial charm and reckless pursuits.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “If it was to be a secret,” said Jane, “say not another word on the subject.

events.text_segment:
“If it was to be a secret,” said Jane, “say not another word on the subject. You may depend upon my seeking no further.”
“Oh, certainly,” said Elizabeth, though burning with curiosity; “we will ask you no questions.”
“Thank you,” said Lydia; “for if you did, I should certainly tell you all, and then Wickham would be so angry.”
On such encouragement to ask, Elizabeth was forced to put it out of her power, by running away.
But to live in ignorance on such a point was impossible; or at least it was impossible not to try for information. Mr. Darcy had been at her sister’s wedding. It was exactly a scene, and exactly among people, where he had apparently least to do, and least temptation to go. Conjectures as to the meaning of it, rapid and wild, hurried into her brain; but she was satisfied with none. Those that best pleased her, as placing his conduct in the noblest light, seemed most improbable. She could not bear such suspense; and hastily seizing a sheet of paper, wrote a short letter to her aunt, to request an explanation of what Lydia had dropped, if it were compatible with the secrecy which had been intended.
“You may readily comprehend,” she added, “what my curiosity must be to know how a person unconnected with any of us, and, comparatively speaking, a stranger to our family, should have been amongst you at such a time. Pray write instantly, and let me understand it—unless it is, for very cogent reasons, to remain in the secrecy which Lydia seems to think necessary; and then I must endeavour to be satisfied with ignorance.”
“Not that I shall, though,” she added to herself, and she finished the letter; “and, my dear aunt, if you do not tell me in an honourable manner, I shall certainly be reduced to tricks and stratagems to find it out.”
Jane’s delicate sense of honour would not allow her to speak to Elizabeth privately of what Lydia had let fall; Elizabeth was glad of it:—till it appeared whether her inquiries would receive any satisfaction, she had rather be without a confidante.

She understood well the importance of discretion, especially among their circle of acquaintances. The Bennet family, though lively and often careless, valued their reputation highly. Elizabeth thought it prudent to change the subject, and she quickly steered the conversation towards the upcoming ball at Netherfield. Jane, always gentle and considerate, smiled softly, grateful for her sister's understanding. As they continued their walk, Elizabeth reflected on the delicate nature of social secrets and the importance of trust among friends. She knew that some things were better left unspoken, to preserve harmony and avoid unnecessary gossip. The evening passed quietly, with the sisters sharing their thoughts and hopes for the future, each aware of the subtle nuances that governed their social interactions. Elizabeth felt a renewed sense of respect for Jane's prudence and for the unspoken bonds that held their family together. In the days that followed, they remained discreet about their private matters, focusing instead on the joys of their daily lives and the anticipation of the ball, where new acquaintances and opportunities awaited. Elizabeth was particularly eager to see how the evening would unfold, hoping to meet new friends and perhaps even find a moment of happiness amidst the usual social obligations. As the sun set and the Bennet household prepared for the event, Elizabeth resolved to enjoy the evening with an open heart and a cautious mind, knowing that some secrets, when kept well, could serve to strengthen the bonds of friendship and family.

events.text_segment:
“Gracechurch Street, Sept. 6.
“My dear Niece,
“I have just received your letter, and shall devote this whole morning to answering it, as I foresee that a little writing will not comprise what I have to tell you. I must confess myself surprised by your application; I did not expect it from you. Don’t think me angry, however, for I only mean to let you know, that I had not imagined such inquiries to be necessary on your side. If you do not choose to understand me, forgive my impertinence. Your uncle is as much surprised as I am; and nothing but the belief of your being a party concerned would have allowed him to act as he has done. But if you are really innocent and ignorant, I must be more explicit. On the very day of my coming home from Longbourn, your uncle had a most unexpected visitor. Mr. Darcy called, and was shut up with him several hours. It was all over before I arrived; so my curiosity was not so dreadfully racked as yours seems to have been. He came to tell Mr. Gardiner that he had found out where your sister and Mr. Wickham were, and that he had seen and talked with them both—Wickham repeatedly, Lydia once. From what I can collect, he left Derbyshire only one day after ourselves, and came to town with the resolution of hunting for them. The motive professed was his conviction of its being owing to himself that Wickham’s worthlessness had not been so well known as to make it impossible for any young woman of character to love or confide in him. He generously imputed the whole to his mistaken pride, and confessed that he had before thought it beneath him to lay his private actions open to the world. His character was to speak for itself. He called it, therefore, his duty to step forward, and endeavour to remedy an evil which had been brought on by himself. If he had another motive, I am sure it would never disgrace him. He had been some days in town before he was able to discover them; but he had something to direct his search, which was more than we had; and the consciousness of this was another reason for his resolving to follow us. There is a lady, it seems, a Mrs. Younge, who was some time ago governess to Miss Darcy, and was dismissed from her charge on some cause of disapprobation, though he did not say what. She then took a large house in Edward Street, and has since maintained herself by letting lodgings. This Mrs. Younge was, he knew, intimately acquainted with Wickham; and he went to her for intelligence of him, as soon as he got to town. But it was two or three days before he could get from her what he wanted. She would not betray her trust, I suppose, without bribery and corruption, for she really did know where her friend was to be found. Wickham, indeed, had gone to her on their first arrival in London; and had she been able to receive them into her house, they would have taken up their abode with her.

My dear Elizabeth,

I was surprised to hear from you, but I am not angry. Mr. Gardiner was also quite taken aback, and he only acted because he believed you were involved in the matter. I must tell you that Mr. Darcy came to see us unexpectedly the day I returned from Longbourn. He spent several hours explaining that he had found Lydia and Wickham.

He had spoken with Wickham multiple times and with Lydia once. Darcy left Derbyshire shortly after we did, determined to find the couple in London. 1. MAJOR STRUCTURAL ISSUES:

- The completion condenses or skips over the explanation of the writer's initial surprise and the reasoning behind the uncle's actions, reducing the depth of the original narrative.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Gracechurch Street, Sept. 6.

It was a fine morning, and the city was stirring with its usual bustle. Elizabeth Bennet, having just arrived in London, found herself walking along the busy thoroughfare, observing the myriad of faces and the hurried steps of passersby. She thought of her family at home, of the quiet countryside of Hertfordshire, and of the many changes that awaited her in this bustling metropolis.

As she strolled, her thoughts were interrupted by the sight of a familiar figure approaching. It was Mr. Darcy, looking as composed and reserved as ever, yet with a hint of warmth in his eyes. Elizabeth felt her cheeks flush, recalling their recent conversations and the slow unraveling of her own prejudices.

"Miss Bennet," he said, bowing slightly, "I hope I am not intruding."

"Not at all, Mr. Darcy," she replied, curtsying politely. "It is a pleasure to see you here."

They exchanged a few words about the weather and the city, the conversation flowing more easily than either had anticipated. Elizabeth noticed the change in Darcy, the subtle softness in his manner, and wondered if her own feelings were beginning to shift as well.

As they continued their walk, they passed by the shops and the crowds, each observing the other with a mixture of curiosity and newfound respect. Elizabeth thought of her sister Jane and her own hopes for happiness, while Darcy pondered the possibility of a future that might include her.

The morning wore on, and they parted with a promise to meet again soon. Elizabeth watched him disappear into the crowd, feeling a flutter of anticipation. She reflected on how her perceptions had changed, how her prejudices had been challenged, and how her heart was opening to the possibilities of love and understanding.

Later that day, she penned a letter to her sister Jane, sharing her impressions of London and her encounter with Mr. Darcy. She wrote of the city’s grandeur, the lively streets, and the unexpected pleasure of reconnecting with someone she had once misunderstood.

As evening fell, Elizabeth found herself in a cozy tavern, contemplating the events of the day. She felt a sense of hope and excitement, knowing that her journey of self-discovery was only just beginning. The bustling city of London, with all its noise and activity, seemed to mirror her own awakening to new feelings and possibilities.

In the quiet moments before sleep, she thought of her family and the life she left behind, grateful for the experiences that had brought her to this point. She looked forward to what tomorrow might bring, eager to see where her heart and her newfound understanding would lead her next.

events.text_segment: At length, however, our kind friend procured the wished-for direction. They were in —— Street. He saw Wickham, and afterwards insisted on seeing Lydia. His first object with her, he acknowledged, had been to persuade her to quit her present disgraceful situation, and return to her friends as soon as they could be prevailed on to receive her, offering his assistance as far as it would go. But he found Lydia absolutely resolved on remaining where she was. She cared for none of her friends; she wanted no help of his; she would not hear of leaving Wickham. She was sure they should be married some time or other, and it did not much signify when. Since such were her feelings, it only remained, he thought, to secure and expedite a marriage, which, in his very first conversation with Wickham, he easily learnt had never been his design. He confessed himself obliged to leave the regiment on account of some debts of honour which were very pressing; and scrupled not to lay all the ill consequences of Lydia’s flight on her own folly alone. He meant to resign his commission immediately; and as to his future situation, he could conjecture very little about it. He must go somewhere, but he did not know where, and he knew he should have nothing to live on. Mr. Darcy asked why he did not marry your sister at once. Though Mr. Bennet was not imagined to be very rich, he would have been able to do something for him, and his situation must have been benefited by marriage. But he found, in reply to this question, that Wickham still cherished the hope of more effectually making his fortune by marriage, in some other country. Under such circumstances, however, he was not likely to be proof against the temptation of immediate relief. They met several times, for there was much to be discussed. Wickham, of course, wanted more than he could get; but at length was reduced to be reasonable. Everything being settled between them, Mr. Darcy’s next step was to make your uncle acquainted with it, and he first called in Gracechurch Street the evening before I came home.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: But Mr. Gardiner could not be seen; and Mr. Darcy found, on further inquiry, that your father was still with him, but would quit town the next morning.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “M. Gardiner.”

events.text_segment:
But Mr. Gardiner could not be seen; and Mr. Darcy found, on further inquiry, that your father was still with him, but would quit town the next morning. He did not judge your father to be a person whom he could so properly consult as your uncle, and therefore readily postponed seeing him till after the departure of the former. He did not leave his name, and till the next day it was only known that a gentleman had called on business. On Saturday he came again. Your father was gone, your uncle at home, and, as I said before, they had a great deal of talk together. They met again on Sunday, and then I saw him too. It was not all settled before Monday: as soon as it was, the express was sent off to Longbourn. But our visitor was very obstinate. I fancy, Lizzy, that obstinacy is the real defect of his character, after all. He has been accused of many faults at different times; but this is the true one. Nothing was to be done that he did not do himself; though I am sure (and I do not speak it to be thanked, therefore say nothing about it) your uncle would most readily have settled the whole. They battled it together for a long time, which was more than either the gentleman or lady concerned in it deserved. But at last your uncle was forced to yield, and instead of being allowed to be of use to his niece, was forced to put up with only having the probable credit of it, which went sorely against the grain; and I really believe your letter this morning gave him great pleasure, because it required an explanation that would rob him of his borrowed feathers, and give the praise where it was due. But, Lizzy, this must go no further than yourself, or Jane at most. You know pretty well, I suppose, what has been done for the young people. His debts are to be paid, amounting, I believe, to considerably more than a thousand pounds, another thousand in addition to her own settled upon her, and his commission purchased. The reason why all this was to be done by him alone, was such as I have given above. It was owing to him, to his reserve and want of proper consideration, that Wickham’s character had been so misunderstood, and consequently that he had been received and noticed as he was. Perhaps there was some truth in this; though I doubt whether his reserve, or anybody’s reserve can be answerable for the event. But in spite of all this fine talking, my dear Lizzy, you may rest perfectly assured that your uncle would never have yielded, if we had not given him credit for another interest in the affair. When all this was resolved on, he returned again to his friends, who were still staying at Pemberley; but it was agreed that he should be in London once more when the wedding took place, and all money matters were then to receive the last finish. I believe I have now told you everything. It is a relation which you tell me is to give you great surprise; I hope at least it will not afford you any displeasure. Lydia came to us, and Wickham had constant admission to the house. He was exactly what he had been when I knew him in Hertfordshire; but I would not tell you how little I was satisfied with her behaviour while she stayed with us, if I had not perceived, by Jane’s letter last Wednesday, that her conduct on coming home was exactly of a piece with it, and therefore what I now tell you can give you no fresh pain. I talked to her repeatedly in the most serious manner, representing to her the wickedness of what she had done, and all the unhappiness she had brought on her family. If she heard me, it was by good luck, for I am sure she did not listen. I was sometimes quite provoked; but then I recollected my dear Elizabeth and Jane, and for their sakes had patience with her. Mr. Darcy was punctual in his return, and, as Lydia imformed you, attended the wedding. He dined with us the next day, and was to leave town again on Wednesday or Thursday. Will you be very angry with me, my dear Lizzy, if I take this opportunity of saying (what I was never bold enough to say before) how much I like him? His behaviour to us has, in every respect, been as pleasing as when we were in Derbyshire. His understanding and opinions all please me; he wants nothing but a little more liveliness, and that, if he marry prudently, his wife may teach him. I thought him very sly; he hardly ever mentioned your name. But slyness seems the fashion. Pray forgive me, if I have been very presuming, or at least do not punish me so far as to exclude me from P. I shall never be quite happy till I have been all round the park. A low phaeton with a nice little pair of ponies would be the very thing. But I must write no more. The children have been wanting me this half hour.
“Yours, very sincerely,
“M. Gardiner.”

She said Mr. Gardiner reluctantly yielded, allowing Darcy both the effort and the credit, though he was pleased that Elizabeth’s letter had prompted an explanation that revealed the truth. Mrs. Gardiner emphasized that this information must remain confidential between Elizabeth and possibly Jane.

She confirmed the settlement details: Wickham’s debts, amounting to over £1000, were paid; an additional £1000 was settled on Lydia; and Wickham’s commission was purchased. Darcy justified his earlier silence about Wickham’s character by feeling responsible for not revealing the truth sooner. Mrs. Gardiner doubted that Darcy’s reserve alone caused the situation but added that Mr. Gardiner only yielded because they suspected Darcy had 'another interest'—implying affection for Elizabeth—in the matter.

After resolving everything, Darcy returned to Pemberley but planned to be in London for the wedding and final financial settlements. Mrs. Gardiner concluded this part of her narrative, hoping it would not displease Elizabeth. She briefly mentioned Lydia’s stay with them, noting her behavior was unchanged and unsatisfactory, as confirmed by Jane’s letter. She described her unsuccessful attempts to reason with Lydia about her actions.

Darcy returned as planned for the wedding and dined with the Gardiners before leaving town. Mrs. Gardiner expressed her strong liking for Darcy, praising his behavior, sense, and opinions, suggesting only a need for more liveliness, which a wife could teach him. She noted Darcy rarely mentioned Elizabeth’s name, calling him 'sly'. She apologized for her presumptuousness and playfully expressed her desire to visit Pemberley again, ending her letter abruptly as her children needed her.

Elizabeth was quite pleased to hear this, for it meant that her father would have the opportunity to speak with Mr. Darcy again before leaving. She had been anxious about the impression her father might have made, and hoped that their conversation had been agreeable. As she reflected on the events of the day, she felt a renewed sense of hope that perhaps, despite their earlier misunderstandings, there might be a chance for reconciliation and mutual respect between the two men.

Meanwhile, Mr. Darcy, who had been observing Elizabeth from a distance, felt a mixture of admiration and concern. He was aware of her feelings and the delicate situation they were in. He resolved to find an appropriate moment to speak with her, to clarify his own intentions and to express his regard. The prospect of her departure saddened him, but he was determined to make the most of the remaining time.

Elizabeth, meanwhile, was engaged in a lively conversation with her sister Jane, who was eager to hear all the details of the recent visits and conversations. Jane, ever gentle and kind, was pleased to see Elizabeth in good spirits, and she hoped that the upcoming days would bring clarity and happiness for her sister.

As evening approached, the family gathered in the drawing-room, where the atmosphere was filled with a mixture of anticipation and quiet reflection. Elizabeth's thoughts kept returning to Mr. Darcy, pondering the possibility of their future meeting and the potential for understanding between them.

The next morning, as the carriage was prepared for her father's departure, Elizabeth took a moment to speak with her mother. She expressed her hope that her father would have a successful and pleasant visit, and that he would carry with him a good impression of Mr. Darcy.

When the time came for her father to leave, Elizabeth felt a pang of sadness. She watched as he bade farewell to her mother and sisters, and then turned to Mr. Darcy, who was waiting nearby. Their eyes met, and in that silent exchange, there was a promise of future conversations and perhaps, a deeper understanding.

As the carriage drove away, Elizabeth stood at the window, her heart full of mixed emotions. She was hopeful yet uncertain, eager yet cautious. The days ahead would be crucial in shaping the course of her feelings and her prospects.

In the days that followed, Elizabeth found herself reflecting on the events at Netherfield and the conversations she had shared. She considered the qualities of Mr. Darcy—their differences and similarities—and wondered whether her initial prejudices might give way to a more nuanced understanding.

Meanwhile, Mr. Darcy, back at his estate, was also contemplating the interactions he had with Elizabeth. He recognized her intelligence, her vivacity, and her integrity. He was determined to find a way to express his feelings and to seek her favor, despite the obstacles that might lie ahead.

As the seasons changed, so did the nature of their acquaintance. Letters were exchanged, each revealing more of their thoughts and feelings. Elizabeth learned of Mr. Darcy's true character, his kindness, and his sense of honor. Mr. Darcy, in turn, gained a deeper appreciation for Elizabeth's wit and her moral strength.

Their mutual understanding grew, and with it, the hope of a future together. The prejudices and misunderstandings that had once separated them began to fade, replaced by a genuine respect and affection.

In the end, it was not only love that brought them together, but also the recognition of each other's true worth. Their union was a testament to the power of patience, humility, and the willingness to see beyond first impressions.

And so, as the story of Elizabeth Bennet and Mr. Darcy unfolded, it became a timeless tale of growth, forgiveness, and the transformative power of love.

events.title: Elizabeth's Tumultuous Reaction to the Revelation
detailed_summary: Reading the letter left Elizabeth in emotional turmoil, struggling between pleasure and pain.
Her vague hopes and fears about Darcy's possible involvement in Lydia's marriage were confirmed far beyond what she had dared to imagine.
She comprehended the full extent of his efforts: purposefully pursuing them to London, undertaking the entire difficult and humiliating search.
Elizabeth dwelled on the unpleasantness Darcy endured: dealing with Mrs. Younge whom he must despise, and repeatedly meeting, reasoning with, and bribing Wickham, a man he loathed.
She recognized he did all this for Lydia, someone he held in low regard.
A fleeting thought suggested he did it for her, Elizabeth, but she quickly suppressed this hope.
She felt even her own vanity couldn't sustain the belief that his affection for her, a woman who had refused him, would overcome his natural disgust at being connected to Wickham.
The idea of Darcy becoming Wickham's brother-in-law seemed appalling to his pride.
While acknowledging the magnitude of his actions, she considered his stated reason – guilt over his past silence about Wickham – plausible, given his sense of fairness and resources.
However, she allowed for the possibility that a lingering partiality towards her might have influenced his actions, especially since her peace of mind was involved.
The knowledge of their immense obligation to Darcy, which could never be repaid, was deeply painful.
They owed Lydia's rescue entirely to him.
Elizabeth felt intense regret and shame over every past negative feeling and sarcastic remark she had directed at him.
She felt humbled personally but immensely proud of him for overcoming his own feelings out of compassion and honor.
She reread her aunt's praise of Darcy repeatedly, finding it gratifying though insufficient.
She also felt a mix of pleasure and regret realizing how convinced her aunt and uncle were of a mutual affection between herself and Darcy.

events.text_segment: The contents of this letter threw Elizabeth into a flutter of spirits, in which it was difficult to determine whether pleasure or pain bore the greatest share. The vague and unsettled suspicions which uncertainty had produced, of what Mr. Darcy might have been doing to forward her sister’s match—which she had feared to encourage, as an exertion of goodness too great to be probable, and at the same time dreaded to be just, from the pain of obligation—were proved beyond their greatest extent to be true! He had followed them purposely to town, he had taken on himself all the trouble and mortification attendant on such a research; in which supplication had been necessary to a woman whom he must abominate and despise, and where he was reduced to meet, frequently meet, reason with, persuade, and finally bribe the man whom he always most wished to avoid, and whose very name it was punishment to him to pronounce. He had done all this for a girl whom he could neither regard nor esteem. Her heart did whisper that he had done it for her. But it was a hope shortly checked by other considerations; and she soon felt that even her vanity was insufficient, when required to depend on his affection for her, for a woman who had already refused him, as able to overcome a sentiment so natural as abhorrence against relationship with Wickham. Brother-in-law of Wickham! Every kind of pride must revolt from the connection. He had, to be sure, done much. She was ashamed to think how much. But he had given a reason for his interference, which asked no extraordinary stretch of belief. It was reasonable that he should feel he had been wrong; he had liberality, and he had the means of exercising it; and though she would not place herself as his principal inducement, she could perhaps believe, that remaining partiality for her might assist his endeavours in a cause where her peace of mind must be materially concerned. It was painful, exceedingly painful, to know that they were under obligations to a person who could never receive a return. They owed the restoration of Lydia, her character, everything to him. Oh, how heartily did she grieve over every ungracious sensation she had ever encouraged, every saucy speech she had ever directed towards him! For herself she was humbled; but she was proud of him,—proud that in a cause of compassion and honour he had been able to get the better of himself. She read over her aunt’s commendation of him again and again. It was hardly enough; but it pleased her. She was even sensible of some pleasure, though mixed with regret, on finding how steadfastly both she and her uncle had been persuaded that affection and confidence subsisted between Mr. Darcy and herself.

She wondered how her family and friends would react to this new information, and whether her own feelings would be strong enough to overcome the prejudices that had so long influenced her judgments. Elizabeth knew that her decision would not be easy, and that it would require a great deal of courage and introspection. Yet, beneath her initial confusion, there was a spark of hope—a belief that love, once misunderstood, could be redeemed through honesty and humility. She resolved to reflect further before responding, understanding that her reply must be sincere and thoughtful. The letter had opened a new chapter in her life, one filled with uncertainty but also with the promise of genuine happiness. Elizabeth was aware that her feelings were evolving, and that her future depended on her ability to see beyond her previous prejudices and to embrace the possibility of true affection. As she looked out the window, the world outside seemed transformed—less rigid, more forgiving. She felt a gentle warmth in her heart, a sign that her own prejudices might be giving way to understanding and compassion. With a deep breath, Elizabeth prepared herself to face whatever came next, knowing that her happiness depended on her willingness to accept the truth and to act with kindness and integrity. The letter had indeed thrown her into a flutter of spirits, but now she saw it as an opportunity—a chance to grow, to forgive, and to find happiness in the most unexpected of circumstances.

events.title: An Unwelcome Interruption by Wickham
detailed_summary: Elizabeth's reflections were broken by someone approaching.
Before she could change paths, Wickham caught up with her.
He inquired, somewhat disingenuously, if he was interrupting her solitary walk.
Elizabeth replied with a smile that he was, but that the interruption wasn't necessarily unwelcome.
Wickham expressed pleasure, remarking on their past friendship and present connection as siblings-in-law.
Elizabeth tersely confirmed their new relationship and asked if the others were coming outside.
Wickham mentioned Mrs. Bennet and Lydia were taking the carriage to Meryton.
He then shifted the topic, stating he heard from the Gardiners that Elizabeth had visited Pemberley.
Elizabeth confirmed this.
Wickham expressed mock envy, suggesting the sight would be too emotional for him, and asked if she saw the housekeeper, Mrs. Reynolds, mentioning her supposed fondness for him.
He assumed Mrs. Reynolds wouldn't have mentioned his name.
Elizabeth corrected him, stating the housekeeper did mention him.

When Wickham asked what she said, Elizabeth relayed that Mrs. Reynolds reported he joined the army and feared he hadn't 'turned out well', adding a pointed remark about how things get misrepresented from afar.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: She was roused from her seat and her reflections, by someone’s approach; and, before she could strike into another path, she was overtaken by Wickham.

that, you know, things are strangely misrepresented.”

events.text_segment:
She was roused from her seat and her reflections, by someone’s approach; and, before she could strike into another path, she was overtaken by Wickham.
“I am afraid I interrupt your solitary ramble, my dear sister?” said he, as he joined her.
“You certainly do,” she replied with a smile; “but it does not follow that the interruption must be unwelcome.”
“I should be sorry, indeed, if it were. We were always good friends, and now we are better.”
“True. Are the others coming out?”
“I do not know. Mrs. Bennet and Lydia are going in the carriage to Meryton. And so, my dear sister, I find, from our uncle and aunt, that you have actually seen Pemberley.”
She replied in the affirmative.
“I almost envy you the pleasure, and yet I believe it would be too much for me, or else I could take it in my way to Newcastle. And you saw the old housekeeper, I suppose? Poor Reynolds, she was always very fond of me. But of course she did not mention my name to you.”
“Yes, she did.”
“And what did she say?”
“That you were gone into the army, and she was afraid had—not turned out well. At such a distance as that, you know, things are strangely misrepresented.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: She was roused from her seat and her reflections, by someone’s approach; and, before she could strike into another path, she was overtaken by Wickham. "Miss Bennet," said he, "I am glad I have found you. I thought I might, as I saw you walking alone. I hope I am not interrupting you?" Elizabeth smiled and replied, "Not at all. It is a pleasure to be interrupted by you, Mr. Wickham." He looked pleased and added, "I am glad to hear it. We have been friends once, and I hope we shall be so again, as brothers-in-law." Elizabeth, a little coldly, said, "Yes, we are now." She then asked, "Are the others coming out?" Wickham answered, "Mrs. Bennet and Lydia are gone to Meryton in the carriage." He then changed the subject, "I hear from the Gardiners that you have been to Pemberley." Elizabeth confirmed it. Wickham expressed a sort of envy, "I wish I could have seen it. I suppose it was very beautiful. I hear the housekeeper, Mrs. Reynolds, is very fond of you." Elizabeth looked surprised. "Mrs. Reynolds did mention you," she said. Wickham, with a slight smile, asked, "What did she say?" Elizabeth replied, "She said you had joined the army and that she feared you had not turned out well. She also said she thought you might have been misrepresented from afar."

events.title: Elizabeth Counters Wickham's Probing and Falsehoods
detailed_summary: Wickham, biting his lips after Elizabeth's previous remark, seemed momentarily silenced.
He soon commented on being surprised to see Darcy in London recently, wondering about his purpose there.
Elizabeth coolly suggested Darcy might be arranging his marriage to Miss de Bourgh.
Wickham pressed further, asking if Elizabeth saw Darcy while near Pemberley, claiming the Gardiners had implied she did.
Elizabeth confirmed this, adding that Darcy introduced them to his sister.
Wickham inquired if Elizabeth liked Miss Darcy.
Elizabeth replied positively.
Wickham remarked he'd heard Miss Darcy had improved, recalling her as unpromising when he last saw her, and expressed hope she'd turn out well.
Elizabeth curtly agreed, suggesting Miss Darcy was past the difficult age.
Wickham then asked if Elizabeth's party had passed through Kympton village.
When Elizabeth didn't recall it, Wickham lamented that Kympton was the church living he felt he deserved, describing it idyllically.
Elizabeth questioned his suitability for sermon-making.
Wickham insisted he would have performed the duty diligently and found happiness in such a quiet life, reiterating his grievance.
He asked if Darcy had ever mentioned the matter to Elizabeth in Kent.
Elizabeth stated she heard from a reliable source ('as good' as Darcy) that the living was only conditionally promised and dependent on the patron's will.
Wickham acknowledged there was 'something in that'.

Elizabeth pushed further, stating she also heard there was a time Wickham found sermon-making unappealing, had declared he'd never take religious orders, and that a financial settlement had been reached instead.
Wickham admitted this wasn't entirely untrue, referring back to their first conversation on the topic.
As they neared the house, Elizabeth, wanting to end the conversation quickly and avoid provoking him for Lydia's sake, suggested they cease quarreling about the past.
Appealing to their new familial tie, she expressed hope for future harmony.
She offered her hand; Wickham kissed it with outward gallantry but appeared uncomfortable, and they went inside.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Certainly,” he replied, biting his lips.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She held out her hand: he kissed it with affectionate gallantry, though he hardly knew how to look, and they entered the house.

events.text_segment:
“Certainly,” he replied, biting his lips. Elizabeth hoped she had silenced him; but he soon afterwards said,—
“I was surprised to see Darcy in town last month. We passed each other several times. I wonder what he can be doing there.”
“Perhaps preparing for his marriage with Miss de Bourgh,” said Elizabeth. “It must be something particular to take him there at this time of year.”
“Undoubtedly. Did you see him while you were at Lambton? I thought I understood from the Gardiners that you had.”
“Yes; he introduced us to his sister.”
“And do you like her?”
“Very much.”
“I have heard, indeed, that she is uncommonly improved within this year or two. When I last saw her, she was not very promising. I am very glad you liked her. I hope she will turn out well.”
“I dare say she will; she has got over the most trying age.”
“Did you go by the village of Kympton?”
“I do not recollect that we did.”
“I mention it because it is the living which I ought to have had. A most delightful place! Excellent parsonage-house! It would have suited me in every respect.”
“How should you have liked making sermons?”
“Exceedingly well. I should have considered it as part of my duty, and the exertion would soon have been nothing. One ought not to repine; but, to be sure, it would have been such a thing for me! The quiet, the retirement of such a life, would have answered all my ideas of happiness! But it was not to be. Did you ever hear Darcy mention the circumstance when you were in Kent?”
“I have heard from authority, which I thought as good, that it was left you conditionally only, and at the will of the present patron.”
“You have! Yes, there was something in that; I told you so from the first, you may remember.”
“I did hear, too, that there was a time when sermon-making was not so palatable to you as it seems to be at present; that you actually declared your resolution of never taking orders, and that the business had been compromised accordingly.”
“You did! and it was not wholly without foundation. You may remember what I told you on that point, when first we talked of it.”
They were now almost at the door of the house, for she had walked fast to get rid of him; and unwilling, for her sister’s sake, to provoke him, she only said in reply, with a good-humoured smile,—
“Come, Mr. Wickham, we are brother and sister, you know. Do not let us quarrel about the past. In future, I hope we shall be always of one mind.”
She held out her hand: he kissed it with affectionate gallantry, though he hardly knew how to look, and they entered the house.

He then asked if Darcy had ever mentioned the matter to Elizabeth in Kent. Elizabeth replied that she had heard from a source as reliable as Darcy himself that the living was only conditionally promised, depending on the patron's will. Wickham acknowledged, "There is something in that." Elizabeth pressed further, "I also heard that you once found sermon-making unappealing, declared you'd never take religious orders, and that a financial settlement was reached instead." Wickham admitted this was not entirely untrue, recalling their first conversation on the topic. As they approached the house, Elizabeth, eager to end the conversation and avoid provoking him for Lydia's sake, suggested they cease quarreling about the past. She expressed hope for future harmony, appealing to their new familial tie. She offered her hand; Wickham kissed it with outward gallantry but appeared uncomfortable, and they went inside.

events.title: Wickham and Lydia Depart; Mr. Bennet's Sarcasm
detailed_summary: Mr. Wickham ceased discussing his past grievances with Elizabeth after their prior conversation, bringing her relief.
The day arrived for Wickham and Lydia to leave for Newcastle.
Mrs. Bennet lamented the separation, which was expected to last at least a year as Mr. Bennet refused to move the family.
Lydia's farewell to her mother was casual, suggesting they might not see each other for years and delegating letter-writing to her sisters.
Wickham's departure was marked by charm and affectionate words.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mr. Wickham was so perfectly satisfied with this conversation, that he never again distressed himself, or provoked his dear sister Elizabeth, by introducing the subject of it; and she was pleased to find that she had said enough to keep him quiet.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I defy even Sir William Lucas himself to produce a more valuable son-in-law.”

events.text_segment:
Mr. Wickham was so perfectly satisfied with this conversation, that he never again distressed himself, or provoked his dear sister Elizabeth, by introducing the subject of it; and she was pleased to find that she had said enough to keep him quiet.
The day of his and Lydia’s departure soon came; and Mrs. Bennet was forced to submit to a separation, which, as her husband by no means entered into her scheme of their all going to Newcastle, was likely to continue at least a twelvemonth.
“Oh, my dear Lydia,” she cried, “when shall we meet again?”
“Oh, Lord! I don’t know. Not these two or three years, perhaps.”
“Write to me very often, my dear.”
“As often as I can. But you know married women have never much time for writing. My sisters may write to me. They will have nothing else to do.”
Mr. Wickham’s adieus were much more affectionate than his wife’s. He smiled, looked handsome, and said many pretty things.
“He is as fine a fellow,” said Mr. Bennet, as soon as they were out of the house, “as ever I saw. He simpers, and smirks, and makes love to us all. I am prodigiously proud of him. I defy even Sir William Lucas himself to produce a more valuable son-in-law.”

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
Mr. Wickham was so perfectly satisfied with this conversation, that he never again distressed himself, or provoked his dear sister Elizabeth, by introducing the subject of it; and she was pleased to find that she had said enough to keep him quiet.

The next day was to be the day of their departure. Mrs. Bennet, with tears in her eyes, exclaimed, "Oh! Lydia, my dear, I am so sorry to part with you! I wish you could stay a little longer."

Lydia, with a light laugh, replied, "Oh! mother, I shall be quite happy. I shall write to you often, and I am sure I shall be very happy with Wickham."

"But, my dear Lydia," said Mrs. Bennet, "you will be quite a different creature when you are married."

"Oh! I am sure I shall be just the same," said Lydia. "I shall always be Lydia Bennet, only with a husband to take care of me."

"Well, my love, I hope you will be very happy," said her mother, wiping her eyes.

Lydia, turning to her sisters, said, "Well, I suppose I shall not see you for a long time. I shall write to you, and I hope you will write to me."

"And I hope you will be very happy," said Elizabeth.

Lydia then bade her mother farewell, and, with Wickham, set off for Newcastle. Wickham's departure was marked by his usual charm and affectionate words.

Once they had gone, Mr. Bennet, with a sarcastic smile, said, "Well, I am glad to see you all so well pleased with your new son-in-law. I am sure I never saw a more promising young man."

Mrs. Bennet, wiping her eyes, replied, "Oh! Mr. Bennet, I am so sorry to part with Lydia!"

"Part with Lydia!" said he. "I thought she was going to be married for ever."

"Well, I am sure I hope she will be very happy," said Mrs. Bennet.

"I am sure I hope so too," said Mr. Bennet, with a smile.

events.title: News of Mr. Bingley's Return to Netherfield
detailed_summary: Mrs. Bennet felt dejected for several days following Lydia's departure, complaining about the sadness of parting with friends.
Elizabeth remarked that this feeling is a natural result of marrying off a daughter and should make Mrs. Bennet happier about her other single daughters.
Mrs. Bennet disagreed, stating Lydia left only because Wickham's regiment was stationed far away.
Her low spirits were soon lifted by news circulating that Mr. Bingley was returning to Netherfield for several weeks of shooting.
Mrs. Bennet became visibly agitated and excited by the news, sharing it with her sister, Mrs. Philips, while pretending indifference.
She declared Bingley meant nothing to them but welcomed his return and speculated about possibilities, despite having previously sworn off the topic.
Mrs. Philips confirmed the news, having heard it directly from the Netherfield housekeeper, Mrs. Nichols, who was making preparations for Bingley's arrival.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The loss of her daughter made Mrs. Bennet very dull for several days.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She was going to the butcher’s, she told me, on purpose to order in some meat on Wednesday, and she has got three couple of ducks just fit to be killed.”

events.text_segment:
The loss of her daughter made Mrs. Bennet very dull for several days.
“I often think,” said she, “that there is nothing so bad as parting with one’s friends. One seems so forlorn without them.”
“This is the consequence, you see, madam, of marrying a daughter,” said Elizabeth. “It must make you better satisfied that your other four are single.”
“It is no such thing. Lydia does not leave me because she is married; but only because her husband’s regiment happens to be so far off. If that had been nearer, she would not have gone so soon.”
But the spiritless condition which this event threw her into was shortly relieved, and her mind opened again to the agitation of hope, by an article of news which then began to be in circulation. The housekeeper at Netherfield had received orders to prepare for the arrival of her master, who was coming down in a day or two, to shoot there for several weeks. Mrs. Bennet was quite in the fidgets. She looked at Jane, and smiled, and shook her head, by turns.
“Well, well, and so Mr. Bingley is coming down, sister,” (for Mrs. Philips first brought her the news). “Well, so much the better. Not that I care about it, though. He is nothing to us, you know, and I am sure I never want to see him again. But, however, he is very welcome to come to Netherfield, if he likes it. And who knows what may happen? But that is nothing to us. You know, sister, we agreed long ago never to mention a word about it. And so, it is quite certain he is coming?”
“You may depend on it,” replied the other, “for Mrs. Nichols was in Meryton last night: I saw her passing by, and went out myself on purpose to know the truth of it; and she told me that it was certainly true. He comes down on Thursday, at the latest, very likely on Wednesday. She was going to the butcher’s, she told me, on purpose to order in some meat on Wednesday, and she has got three couple of ducks just fit to be killed.”

detailed_summary: Jane visibly reacted to the news of Bingley's return, changing color.
Later, alone with Elizabeth, Jane admitted she looked distressed but insisted it was only due to feeling observed, not from any lingering affection for Bingley.
Jane expressed relief that Bingley was coming alone, as it would mean seeing less of him and avoiding others' remarks.
Elizabeth was unsure how to interpret Jane's statement or Bingley's motives, recalling his apparent partiality in Derbyshire and wondering if Darcy approved of the visit.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: They were more disturbed, more unequal, than she had often seen them.

events.text_segment:
Miss Bennet had not been able to hear of his coming without changing colour. It was many months since she had mentioned his name to Elizabeth; but now, as soon as they were alone together, she said,—
“I saw you look at me to-day, Lizzy, when my aunt told us of the present report; and I know I appeared distressed; but don’t imagine it was from any silly cause. I was only confused for the moment, because I felt that I should be looked at. I do assure you that the news does not affect me either with pleasure or pain. I am glad of one thing, that he comes alone; because we shall see the less of him. Not that I am afraid of myself, but I dread other people’s remarks.”
Elizabeth did not know what to make of it. Had she not seen him in Derbyshire, she might have supposed him capable of coming there with no other view than what was acknowledged; but she still thought him partial to Jane, and she wavered as to the greater probability of his coming there with his friend’s permission, or being bold enough to come without it.
“Yet it is hard,” she sometimes thought, “that this poor man cannot come to a house, which he has legally hired, without raising all this speculation! I will leave him to himself.”
In spite of what her sister declared, and really believed to be her feelings, in the expectation of his arrival, Elizabeth could easily perceive that her spirits were affected by it. They were more disturbed, more unequal, than she had often seen them.
