events.title: Mr. and Mrs. Bennet Debate Visiting Bingley
detailed_summary: The topic of visiting Mr. Bingley, debated a year prior, was raised again between Mr. and Mrs. Bennet.
Mrs. Bennet insisted Mr. Bennet must call on Bingley upon his arrival.
Mr. Bennet flatly refused, recalling how his previous visit yielded no marriage for his daughters and deeming it a 'fool's errand'.
Mrs. Bennet argued that social propriety required gentlemen neighbours to pay such a call.
Mr. Bennet expressed disdain for the etiquette, stating Bingley should seek their company if he desired it.
Mrs. Bennet lamented his rudeness but resolved to invite Bingley to dine at Longbourn anyway, planning the guest list to accommodate him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The subject which had been so warmly canvassed between their parents, about a twelvemonth ago, was now brought forward again.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Consoled by this resolution, she was the better able to bear her husband’s incivility; though it was very mortifying to know that her neighbours might all see Mr. Bingley, in consequence of it, before they did.

events.text_segment:
The subject which had been so warmly canvassed between their parents, about a twelvemonth ago, was now brought forward again.
“As soon as ever Mr. Bingley comes, my dear,” said Mrs. Bennet, “you will wait on him, of course.”
“No, no. You forced me into visiting him last year, and promised, if I went to see him, he should marry one of my daughters. But it ended in nothing, and I will not be sent on a fool’s errand again.”
His wife represented to him how absolutely necessary such an attention would be from all the neighbouring gentlemen, on his returning to Netherfield.
“’Tis an etiquette I despise,” said he. “If he wants our society, let him seek it. He knows where we live. I will not spend my hours in running after my neighbours every time they go away and come back again.”
“Well, all I know is, that it will be abominably rude if you do not wait on him. But, however, that shan’t prevent my asking him to dine here, I am determined. We must have Mrs. Long and the Gouldings soon. That will make thirteen with ourselves, so there will be just room at table for him.”
Consoled by this resolution, she was the better able to bear her husband’s incivility; though it was very mortifying to know that her neighbours might all see Mr. Bingley, in consequence of it, before they did.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The subject which had been so warmly canvassed between their parents, about a twelvemonth ago, was now brought forward again. Mrs. Bennet was particularly eager on the subject, and she was determined that Mr. Bennet should call on Mr. Bingley as soon as he arrived in the neighborhood. Mr. Bennet, however, was not so easily persuaded. He remembered well enough how his previous visit to Bingley had resulted in no advantageous match for his daughters, and he was inclined to think it a fool's errand to make such a call. "You are over scrupulous surely," said Mrs. Bennet. "I dare say Bingley will be very glad to see you. I do not see why he should not. It is what a man of sense would do." Mr. Bennet, with a slight smile, replied, "If Bingley will not come to us, we ought not to go to him. If he is so fond of his own manners as to neglect his neighbours, he will be rather a less desirable acquaintance." Mrs. Bennet was not pleased with this answer, but she was determined to have her way. She declared that it was the duty of every gentleman to pay his respects to his neighbours, and that Mr. Bingley was no exception. Mr. Bennet, with a tone of disdain, observed that Bingley should seek their company if he wished it, and that they would not be the first to make advances. Mrs. Bennet, in a tone of disappointment, lamented his rudeness, but she was resolved to invite Bingley to dine at Longbourn, and she began to plan the guest list accordingly.

detailed_summary: As Bingley's arrival date approached, Jane confessed to Elizabeth her growing discomfort with the constant discussion surrounding him.

events.text_segment:
As the day of his arrival drew near,—
“I begin to be sorry that he comes at all,” said Jane to her sister. “It would be nothing; I could see him with perfect indifference; but I can hardly bear to hear it thus perpetually talked of. My mother means well; but she does not know, no one can know, how much I suffer from what she says. Happy shall I be when his stay at Netherfield is over!”
“I wish I could say anything to comfort you,” replied Elizabeth; “but it is wholly out of my power. You must feel it; and the usual satisfaction of preaching patience to a sufferer is denied me, because you have always so much.”
Mr. Bingley arrived. Mrs. Bennet, through the assistance of servants, contrived to have the earliest tidings of it, that the period of anxiety and fretfulness on her side be as long as it could. She counted the days that must intervene before their invitation could be sent—hopeless of seeing him before. But on the third morning after his arrival in Hertfordshire, she saw him from her dressing-room window enter the paddock, and ride towards the house.
Her daughters were eagerly called to partake of her joy.

Elizabeth, understanding her sister's feelings, sympathized but knew she could do little to ease Jane's distress, recognizing Jane's innate patience. When Mr. Bingley finally arrived at Netherfield, Mrs. Bennet was eager to learn the news and made sure to be the first to hear. On the third morning after his arrival, she looked out her window and saw him riding towards Longbourn. Excited, she called her daughters to come and witness the event.

She wondered how their first meeting would unfold and whether her initial impressions would be confirmed or challenged. The Bennet family prepared eagerly, with Mrs. Bennet bustling about, eager to make a favorable impression. When Mr. Darcy finally stepped out of the carriage, Elizabeth observed him carefully, ready to meet him with the grace and civility that her upbringing had instilled. Little did she know, this encounter would be the beginning of a story that would change her life forever.

events.title: Bingley Visits Longbourn Accompanied by Darcy
detailed_summary: While Jane remained seated, Elizabeth went to the window at her mother's urging.
Elizabeth was surprised to see Mr. Darcy accompanying Mr. Bingley and quickly sat back down.
Kitty pointed out the second gentleman, identifying him as the tall, proud man from before.
Mrs. Bennet expressed shock and distaste upon recognizing Darcy, though conceding any friend of Bingley's must be welcomed.
Jane looked at Elizabeth with concern, aware of the potential awkwardness given their history and Darcy's letter, of which Jane knew little.
Both sisters felt uncomfortable, each worrying for the other and themselves, while their mother continued voicing her dislike for Darcy.
Elizabeth experienced deeper turmoil, knowing Darcy's role in Lydia's salvation (a fact unknown to Jane) and harbouring changed feelings for him.
His unexpected appearance filled her with astonishment and a fleeting hope that his affections remained, quickly tempered by caution.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Jane resolutely kept her place at the table; but Elizabeth, to satisfy her mother, went to the window—she looked—she saw Mr. Darcy with him, and sat down again by her sister.

events.text_segment:
Jane resolutely kept her place at the table; but Elizabeth, to satisfy her mother, went to the window—she looked—she saw Mr. Darcy with him, and sat down again by her sister.
“There is a gentleman with him, mamma,” said Kitty; “who can it be?”
“Some acquaintance or other, my dear, I suppose; I am sure I do not know.”
“La!” replied Kitty, “it looks just like that man that used to be with him before. Mr. what’s his name—that tall, proud man.”
“Good gracious! Mr. Darcy!—and so it does, I vow. Well, any friend of Mr. Bingley’s will always be welcome here, to be sure; but else I must say that I hate the very sight of him.”
Jane looked at Elizabeth with surprise and concern. She knew but little of their meeting in Derbyshire, and therefore felt for the awkwardness which must attend her sister, in seeing him almost for the first time after receiving his explanatory letter. Both sisters were uncomfortable enough. Each felt for the other, and of course for themselves; and their mother talked on of her dislike of Mr. Darcy, and her resolution to be civil to him only as Mr. Bingley’s friend, without being heard by either of them. But Elizabeth had sources of uneasiness which could not yet be suspected by Jane, to whom she had never yet had courage to show Mrs. Gardiner’s letter, or to relate her own change of sentiment towards him. To Jane, he could be only a man whose proposals she had refused, and whose merits she had undervalued; but to her own more extensive information, he was the person to whom the whole family were indebted for the first of benefits, and whom she regarded herself with an interest, if not quite so tender, at least as reasonable and just, as what Jane felt for Bingley. Her astonishment at his coming—at his coming to Netherfield, to Longbourn, and voluntarily seeking her again, was almost equal to what she had known on first witnessing his altered behaviour in Derbyshire.
The colour which had been driven from her face returned for half a minute with an additional glow, and a smile of delight added lustre to her eyes, as she thought for that space of time that his affection and wishes must still be unshaken; but she would not be secure.
“Let me first see how he behaves,” said she; “it will then be early enough for expectation.”

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
Jane resolutely kept her place at the table; but Elizabeth, to satisfy her mother, went to the window—she looked—she saw Mr. Darcy with him, and sat down again by her sister.

Mrs. Bennet, observing her daughter’s movement, exclaimed, “Good gracious! Mr. Bingley is just coming into the room. I declare he looks as if he would never come to see us again!”

Elizabeth’s eyes followed the direction of her mother’s gaze, and she saw Mr. Bingley entering, accompanied by Mr. Darcy. She felt her cheeks flush and quickly turned away, trying to compose herself.

Kitty, noticing the strangers, pointed out, “That’s the tall gentleman, the proud one, I think. I saw him before.”

Mrs. Bennet, recognizing Darcy, exclaimed, “Good gracious! Mr. Darcy! I am surprised. I had not expected to see him here. Well, he is a very fine man, but I do not like his manners.”

Jane looked at Elizabeth with concern, sensing her sister’s discomfort. Elizabeth, meanwhile, was inwardly struggling with her feelings—remembering Darcy’s role in Lydia’s rescue, which Jane knew nothing of, and feeling a strange mixture of hope and apprehension.

Elizabeth’s mind was in turmoil. She knew Darcy’s presence could be awkward, yet she also felt a flicker of hope that he might still harbor some regard for her. She resolved to observe his behavior carefully, determined not to let her expectations get the better of her.

As Darcy approached, Elizabeth’s heart fluttered unexpectedly. She wondered if her feelings had truly changed, or if her past prejudices still lingered. She decided to wait and see, to judge his character by his actions rather than her assumptions.

- The passage does not include the description of Elizabeth's physical reaction and her decision to observe Mr. Darcy's behavior before forming expectations.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Elizabeth's heart fluttered with a mixture of surprise and apprehension. She had not expected to see Mr. Darcy so soon, nor in such a casual setting. Her mind raced with the implications of his presence, wondering whether it was merely a coincidence or a sign of something more. As she watched him from her vantage point, she observed the ease with which he conversed with her sister Jane, whose face was lit with a gentle smile. Elizabeth felt a pang of envy and curiosity, wishing she could understand the nature of their interaction.

Meanwhile, Jane, unaware of Elizabeth's observations, was engaged in a lively conversation with Mr. Darcy. Her cheeks flushed slightly as she responded to his remarks, her eyes shining with genuine warmth. Elizabeth noted the change in her sister's demeanor and felt a pang of concern mixed with hope. Could this be the beginning of something more meaningful between them?

Elizabeth's mother, noticing her daughter's distraction, leaned in and whispered, "Elizabeth, my dear, do you not think Mr. Bingley looks very well today? I dare say he is quite taken with Jane."

Elizabeth nodded politely, though her thoughts were elsewhere. She wondered what Mr. Darcy's intentions might be, and whether her own feelings towards him were as complicated as they seemed. She remembered their previous encounters—his haughty manner, his proud demeanor—and wondered if he was capable of change.

As the afternoon wore on, Mr. Darcy and Jane continued their conversation, occasionally glancing towards Elizabeth, who felt her cheeks grow warm under his gaze. The scene was a delicate dance of glances and words, each trying to gauge the other's feelings. Elizabeth's mind was filled with questions, her heart pounding with anticipation.

Finally, Mr. Darcy excused himself, and Elizabeth watched him walk away, a strange mixture of disappointment and hope swelling within her. She turned to her sister, who looked equally thoughtful. "Jane," Elizabeth whispered, "do you think he might be interested in you?"

Jane smiled softly, her eyes shining with a quiet happiness. "I cannot say, Elizabeth, but I do believe he is a man of great character."

Elizabeth nodded, her thoughts swirling with possibilities. The day had brought unexpected revelations, and she knew that her own feelings were beginning to change as well. The future was uncertain, but one thing was clear: her life was about to become more complicated—and more exciting—than she had ever imagined.

events.text_segment:
She sat intently at work, striving to be composed, and without daring to lift up her eyes, till anxious curiosity carried them to the face of her sister as the servant was approaching the door. Jane looked a little paler than usual, but more sedate than Elizabeth had expected. On the gentlemen’s appearing, her colour increased; yet she received them with tolerable ease, and with a propriety of behaviour equally free from any symptom of resentment, or any unnecessary complaisance.
Elizabeth said as little to either as civility would allow, and sat down again to her work, with an eagerness which it did not often command. She had ventured only one glance at Darcy. He looked serious as usual; and, she thought, more as he had been used to look in Hertfordshire, than as she had seen him at Pemberley. But, perhaps, he could not in her mother’s presence be what he was before her uncle and aunt. It was a painful, but not an improbable, conjecture.
Bingley she had likewise seen for an instant, and in that short period saw him looking both pleased and embarrassed. He was received by Mrs. Bennet with a degree of civility which made her two daughters ashamed, especially when contrasted with the cold and ceremonious politeness of her courtesy and address of his friend.
Elizabeth particularly, who knew that her mother owed to the latter the preservation of her favourite daughter from irremediable infamy, was hurt and distressed to a most painful degree by a distinction so ill applied.
Darcy, after inquiring of her how Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner did—a question which she could not answer without confusion—said scarcely anything. He was not seated by her: perhaps that was the reason of his silence; but it had not been so in Derbyshire. There he had talked to her friends when he could not to herself. But now several minutes elapsed, without bringing the sound of his voice; and when occasionally, unable to resist the impulse of curiosity, she raised her eyes to his face, she as often found him looking at Jane as at herself, and frequently on no object but the ground. More thoughtfulness and less anxiety to please, than when they last met, were plainly expressed. She was disappointed, and angry with herself for being so.
“Could I expect it to be otherwise?” said she. “Yet why did he come?”
She was in no humour for conversation with anyone but himself; and to him she had hardly courage to speak.
She inquired after his sister, but could do no more.
“It is a long time, Mr. Bingley, since you went away,” said Mrs. Bennet.
He readily agreed to it.
“I began to be afraid you would never come back again. People did say, you meant to quit the place entirely at Michaelmas; but, however, I hope it is not true. A great many changes have happened in the neighbourhood since you went away. Miss Lucas is married and settled: and one of my own daughters. I suppose you have heard of it; indeed, you must have seen it in the papers. It was in the ‘Times’ and the ‘Courier,’ I know; though it was not put in as it ought to be. It was only said, ‘Lately, George Wickham, Esq., to Miss Lydia Bennet,’ without there being a syllable said of her father, or the place where she lived, or anything. It was my brother Gardiner’s drawing up, too, and I wonder how he came to make such an awkward business of it. Did you see it?”
Bingley replied that he did, and made his congratulations. Elizabeth dared not lift up her eyes. How Mr. Darcy looked, therefore, she could not tell.
“It is a delightful thing, to be sure, to have a daughter well married,” continued her mother; “but at the same time, Mr. Bingley, it is very hard to have her taken away from me. They are gone down to Newcastle, a place quite northward it seems, and there they are to stay, I do not know how long. His regiment is there; for I suppose you have heard of his leaving the ——shire, and of his being gone into the Regulars. Thank heaven! he has some friends, though, perhaps, not so many as he deserves.”
Elizabeth, who knew this to be levelled at Mr. Darcy, was in such misery of shame that she could hardly keep her seat. It drew from her, however, the exertion of speaking, which nothing else had so effectually done before; and she asked Bingley whether he meant to make any stay in the country at present. A few weeks, he believed.
“When you have killed all your own birds, Mr. Bingley,” said her mother, “I beg you will come here and shoot as many as you please on Mr. Bennet’s manor. I am sure he will be vastly happy to oblige you, and will save all the best of the coveys for you.”
Elizabeth’s misery increased at such unnecessary, such officious attention! Were the same fair prospect to arise at present, as had flattered them a year ago, everything, she was persuaded, would be hastening to the same vexatious conclusion. At that instant she felt, that years of happiness could not make Jane or herself amends for moments of such painful confusion.
“The first wish of my heart,” said she to herself, “is never more to be in company with either of them.

Elizabeth looked up quickly, her heart pounding with a mixture of hope and apprehension. As the servant entered, she could see the faintest smile on her sister Jane's face, a smile that seemed to carry a thousand unspoken words. Elizabeth's eyes searched Jane's for reassurance, for confirmation of what she suspected but dared not believe. The servant announced that Mr. Bingley was coming to call, and Elizabeth felt her cheeks flush with excitement. She had long hoped for this moment, and now that it was upon her, she could hardly contain her anticipation.

Jane, ever gentle and composed, nodded softly, her eyes shining with happiness. Elizabeth's mind raced with thoughts of the possible reasons for Mr. Bingley's visit. Was it merely a social call, or was there something more? She remembered the conversations they had shared about his kind nature and the way he had shown a particular interest in her sister. Elizabeth's heart fluttered at the thought that perhaps her sister's feelings were reciprocated.

As the door opened and Mr. Bingley entered, Elizabeth felt her pulse quicken. He was as charming and amiable as she had heard, with a warm smile that seemed to light up the room. His eyes immediately sought Jane's, and Elizabeth saw the tenderness there that she had hoped for. The conversation flowed easily, filled with polite exchanges and gentle laughter. Elizabeth observed her sister with a mixture of pride and affection, grateful that her dear Jane was finally receiving the attention she deserved.

Throughout the visit, Elizabeth kept a watchful eye on her sister, noticing the subtle glances and the shy smiles that passed between them. She felt a surge of happiness, knowing that her sister's happiness was within reach. Yet, she also felt a twinge of concern, aware of the social intricacies and the potential obstacles that might stand in their way. Still, she resolved to support her sister in any way she could, believing that true affection and sincerity would ultimately prevail.

As Mr. Bingley prepared to leave, he expressed his desire to see Jane again soon, and Jane responded with a modest but hopeful smile. Elizabeth watched as they exchanged promises to meet again, her heart swelling with joy. She knew that this was only the beginning of a promising relationship, one that could bring happiness to her sister and perhaps even to herself.

After the visit, Elizabeth and Jane sat together in the quiet of the drawing room, their minds filled with the events of the day. Jane's cheeks were still tinged with a rosy glow, and her eyes sparkled with delight. Elizabeth reached out and took her sister's hand, offering her a reassuring squeeze.

"Jane, I am so glad for you," Elizabeth said softly. "Mr. Bingley seems to be very fond of you."

Jane blushed and looked down, a shy smile playing on her lips. "I am grateful for his kindness, Elizabeth. I had not expected such attention, and I must admit, I feel quite overwhelmed."

Elizabeth chuckled gently. "You deserve all the happiness in the world, Jane. You are the sweetest girl I know."

They sat in comfortable silence for a moment, each lost in her own thoughts. Elizabeth's mind wandered to the future, imagining the possibilities that lay ahead. She hoped that her sister's happiness would be long-lasting and that love would find its way into their lives.

Meanwhile, Elizabeth's own feelings were a mixture of hope and uncertainty. She had heard of Mr. Darcy's arrival in the neighborhood, and her curiosity about him grew stronger with each passing day. She wondered what kind of man he was, and whether he would be a suitable match for her. Her thoughts were interrupted by the arrival of her mother, who burst into the room with her usual enthusiasm.

"Elizabeth! Jane! I have the most wonderful news! Mr. Bingley has just left after a delightful visit, and he has expressed a strong desire to see Jane again soon."

Elizabeth smiled at her mother's excitement. "That is indeed good news. I am glad to hear it."

Mrs. Bennet beamed with pride. "Oh, Elizabeth, I do believe this is the beginning of something very special."

Elizabeth nodded, her heart full of hope. She knew that life was unpredictable, but she also believed in the power of love and sincerity. As she looked at her sister, she felt a deep sense of contentment, knowing that happiness was within their reach.

The days that followed were filled with anticipation and joy. Jane and Mr. Bingley continued to see each other, their affection growing stronger with each encounter. Elizabeth found herself increasingly drawn to Mr. Darcy, whose reserved demeanor concealed a depth of character that intrigued her. She wondered if their paths would cross in a meaningful way, and she resolved to remain open to whatever the future might hold.

In the midst of these developments, Elizabeth reflected on the importance of patience, virtue, and understanding. She knew that love was a delicate matter, requiring kindness and sincerity. She also understood that societal expectations and personal feelings often clashed, creating obstacles that needed to be navigated with wisdom.

As the seasons changed and the days grew warmer, the Bennet family found themselves caught up in the joys and challenges of courtship and social engagement. Elizabeth continued to observe and learn, her mind expanding with new insights and her heart opening to the possibilities of happiness.

In the end, she believed that true love would find its way, guided by honesty and virtue. And as she looked forward to the days ahead, she felt a quiet confidence that, no matter what obstacles might arise, love and goodness would prevail.

events.title: Bingley's Rekindled Interest and Dinner Invitation
detailed_summary: Elizabeth's distress was somewhat alleviated when she observed Bingley's renewed admiration for Jane's beauty.
Although initially reserved towards Jane, Bingley seemed to pay her increasing attention throughout the visit.
He perceived Jane as still beautiful, good-natured, and unaffected, though perhaps less talkative than before.
Jane, trying hard to appear unchanged, was often lost in thought and unaware of her own silences.
When Bingley and Darcy prepared to leave, Mrs. Bennet formally invited them to dine at Longbourn soon.
She pointedly reminded Bingley of his previous promise to dine with them, which he had broken.
Bingley appeared slightly foolish at the reminder and mumbled an excuse about business preventing his return.
The gentlemen then departed.

Mrs. Bennet confessed she had considered asking them to stay for dinner that day but decided against it, wanting a more elaborate meal (two courses) for Bingley, given her ambitions for him and his wealth.

events.text_segment:
Their society can afford no pleasure that will atone for such wretchedness as this! Let me never see either one or the other again!”
Yet the misery, for which years of happiness were to offer no compensation, received soon afterwards material relief, from observing how much the beauty of her sister rekindled the admiration of her former lover. When first he came in, he had spoken to her but little, but every five minutes seemed to be giving her more of his attention. He found her as handsome as she had been last year; as good-natured, and as unaffected, though not quite so chatty. Jane was anxious that no difference should be perceived in her at all, and was really persuaded that she talked as much as ever; but her mind was so busily engaged, that she did not always know when she was silent.
When the gentlemen rose to go away, Mrs. Bennet was mindful of her intended civility, and they were invited and engaged to dine at Longbourn in a few days’ time.
“You are quite a visit in my debt, Mr. Bingley,” she added; “for when you went to town last winter, you promised to take a family dinner with us as soon as you returned. I have not forgot, you see; and I assure you I was very much disappointed that you did not come back and keep your engagement.”
Bingley looked a little silly at this reflection, and said something of his concern at having been prevented by business. They then went away.
Mrs. Bennet had been strongly inclined to ask them to stay and dine there that day; but, though she always kept a very good table, she did not think anything less than two courses could be good enough for a man on whom she had such anxious designs, or satisfy the appetite and pride of one who had ten thousand a year.

Elizabeth knew that true happiness could not be bought with wealth or social rank, yet the world around her seemed blind to this truth. She longed for a time when people would value sincerity over superficial appearances, and kindness over social advantage. As she walked through the bustling assembly rooms, she observed the shallow flirtations and empty compliments exchanged among the attendees. It was a stark contrast to the genuine connections she yearned for. Her thoughts drifted to her own family, to her father’s good humor and her mother’s lively spirit, which often clashed with the rigid expectations of their society. Elizabeth resolved to remain true to her principles, even if it meant standing apart from the crowd. She believed that integrity and virtue were the only true riches, and that the pursuit of superficial pleasures was a hollow endeavor. Her resolve was strengthened by her love for her sister and her hope for a future where genuine affection and moral worth would be valued above all else. As she looked around at the glittering scene, she felt a quiet determination to seek happiness in authenticity, rather than in the empty pursuits that society so often celebrated. She knew that true contentment could only be found in living according to one’s conscience, and she was determined to do just that, regardless of the societal cost.

events.title: Elizabeth's Vexation and Jane's Professed Indifference
detailed_summary: Following the departure of Bingley and Darcy, Elizabeth seeks solitude outdoors to process her feelings.
She is deeply perplexed and irritated by Mr. Darcy's reserved and seemingly indifferent demeanor during the visit.
Elizabeth questions his motives for visiting if he only intended to be silent and serious.
She contrasts his current behavior with his previous amiability towards her aunt and uncle in London.
She internally debates whether his silence stems from fear or lack of interest, finding his behavior utterly perplexing.
Elizabeth resolves to stop thinking about him, but her sister Jane interrupts this resolution.
Jane appears cheerful, expressing satisfaction with how the visit went and feeling confident she can maintain composure around Bingley.
Jane states her relief that the initial encounter is complete and anticipates the upcoming dinner on Tuesday as a public display of their mutual indifference.
Elizabeth responds with playful skepticism, warning Jane to be cautious.
Jane asserts her emotional strength, believing she is no longer vulnerable to Bingley.
Elizabeth counters, suggesting Jane is actually close to making Bingley fall deeply in love with her again.

events.text_segment:
As soon as they were gone, Elizabeth walked out to recover her spirits; or, in other words, to dwell without interruption on those subjects which must deaden them more. Mr. Darcy’s behaviour astonished and vexed her.
“Why, if he came only to be silent, grave, and indifferent,” said she, “did he come at all?”
She could settle it in no way that gave her pleasure.
“He could be still amiable, still pleasing to my uncle and aunt, when he was in town; and why not to me? If he fears me, why come hither? If he no longer cares for me, why silent? Teasing, teasing man! I will think no more about him.”
Her resolution was for a short time involuntarily kept by the approach of her sister, who joined her with a cheerful look which showed her better satisfied with their visitors than Elizabeth.
“Now,” said she, “that this first meeting is over, I feel perfectly easy. I know my own strength, and I shall never be embarrassed again by his coming. I am glad he dines here on Tuesday. It will then be publicly seen, that on both sides we meet only as common and indifferent acquaintance.”
“Yes, very indifferent, indeed,” said Elizabeth, laughingly. “Oh, Jane! take care.”
“My dear Lizzy, you cannot think me so weak as to be in danger now.”
“I think you are in very great danger of making him as much in love with you as ever.”

events.text_segment:
They did not see the gentlemen again till Tuesday; and Mrs. Bennet, in the meanwhile, was giving way to all the happy schemes which the good-humour and common politeness of Bingley, in half an hour’s visit, had revived.
On Tuesday there was a large party assembled at Longbourn; and the two who were most anxiously expected, to the credit of their punctuality as sportsmen, were in very good time. When they repaired to the dining-room, Elizabeth eagerly watched to see whether Bingley would take the place which, in all their former parties, had belonged to him, by her sister. Her prudent mother, occupied by the same ideas, forbore to invite him to sit by herself. On entering the room, he seemed to hesitate; but Jane happened to look round, and happened to smile: it was decided. He placed himself by her.
Elizabeth, with a triumphant sensation, looked towards his friend. He bore it with noble indifference; and she would have imagined that Bingley had received his sanction to be happy, had she not seen his eyes likewise turned towards Mr. Darcy, with an expression of half-laughing alarm.
His behaviour to her sister was such during dinnertime as showed an admiration of her, which, though more guarded than formerly, persuaded Elizabeth, that, if left wholly to himself, Jane’s happiness, and his own, would be speedily secured. Though she dared not depend upon the consequence, she yet received pleasure from observing his behaviour. It gave her all the animation that her spirits could boast; for she was in no cheerful humour. Mr. Darcy was almost as far from her as the table could divide them. He was on one side of her mother. She knew how little such a situation would give pleasure to either, or make either appear to advantage. She was not near enough to hear any of their discourse; but she could see how seldom they spoke to each other, and how formal and cold was their manner whenever they did. Her mother’s ungraciousness made the sense of what they owed him more painful to Elizabeth’s mind; and she would, at times, have given anything to be privileged to tell him, that his kindness was neither unknown nor unfelt by the whole of the family.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
They did not see the gentlemen again till Tuesday; and Mrs. Bennet, in the meanwhile, was giving way to all the happy schemes which the good-humour and common politeness of Bingley, in half an hour’s visit, had revived.

A large party was assembled at Longbourn on the Tuesday; and Bingley and Darcy arrived at the appointed hour. As they entered the room, Elizabeth looked eagerly to see whether Bingley would sit beside Jane, as he used to do, and was pleased to observe that he hesitated only a moment, and then, at Jane’s look and smile, made his way across the room and took his seat by her.

Mrs. Bennet, who had been watching for the opportunity, did not lose her chance of bringing Bingley to her side; but Elizabeth, who had her eye on Mr. Darcy, was too much engaged to notice her mother’s manoeuvre. Bingley’s behaviour towards Jane was exactly what Elizabeth had expected; and she could now only observe that he was very much in love with her, though he was too shy to show it.

Elizabeth felt a secret triumph, and, casting her eyes towards Darcy, saw him looking at her with a calm, steady gaze, which she could not interpret. But she observed Bingley looking towards Darcy with a smile of amusement and a slight degree of apprehension, as if he was conscious of Darcy’s awareness or approval.

Throughout dinner, Bingley’s conduct towards Jane was marked by evident admiration, though more restrained than before; and Elizabeth, in her heart, was convinced that their happiness might be secured if external circumstances did not interfere. She derived some pleasure from observing Bingley’s behavior, though her spirits were low.

Mr. Darcy was seated far from Elizabeth, next to her mother. Elizabeth could not help feeling that this arrangement was unlikely to please either Darcy or Mrs. Bennet, or to allow them to display themselves well. Though she could not hear their conversation, she noticed that they seldom spoke to each other, and that their manner was stiff and reserved.

Elizabeth was distressed by her mother’s lack of graciousness towards Darcy, and her own awareness of the family’s debt to him increased. She wished she could find a way to express their gratitude, but the circumstances did not permit.

detailed_summary: Elizabeth anticipates the post-dinner period, hoping for a chance to converse properly with Darcy.

events.text_segment:
She was in hopes that the evening would afford some opportunity of bringing them together; that the whole of the visit would not pass away without enabling them to enter into something more of conversation, than the mere ceremonious salutation attending his entrance. Anxious and uneasy, the period which passed in the drawing-room before the gentlemen came, was wearisome and dull to a degree that almost made her uncivil. She looked forward to their entrance as the point on which all her chance of pleasure for the evening must depend.
“If he does not come to me, then,” said she, “I shall give him up for ever.”
The gentlemen came; and she thought he looked as if he would have answered her hopes; but, alas! the ladies had crowded round the table, where Miss Bennet was making tea, and Elizabeth pouring out the coffee, in so close a confederacy, that there was not a single vacancy near her which would admit of a chair. And on the gentlemen’s approaching, one of the girls moved closer to her than ever, and said, in a whisper,—
“The men shan’t come and part us, I am determined. We want none of them; do we?”
Darcy had walked away to another part of the room. She followed him with her eyes, envied everyone to whom he spoke, had scarcely patience enough to help anybody to coffee, and then was enraged against herself for being so silly!
“A man who has once been refused! How could I ever be foolish enough to expect a renewal of his love? Is there one among the sex who would not protest against such a weakness as a second proposal to the same woman? There is no indignity so abhorrent to their feelings.”

events.text_segment:
She was a little revived, however, by his bringing back his coffee-cup himself; and she seized the opportunity of saying,—
“Is your sister at Pemberley still?”
“Yes; she will remain there till Christmas.”
“And quite alone? Have all her friends left her?”
“Mrs. Annesley is with her. The others have been gone on to Scarborough these three weeks.”
She could think of nothing more to say; but if he wished to converse with her, he might have better success. He stood by her, however, for some minutes, in silence; and, at last, on the young lady’s whispering to Elizabeth again, he walked away.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
She was a little revived, however, by his bringing back his coffee-cup himself; and she seized the opportunity of saying,—“Is your sister at Pemberley still?”

“Yes,” he replied; “Georgiana is to remain there till Christmas.”

“And Mrs. Annesley is with her, I suppose?”

“Yes; she is. The other friends left for Scarborough some weeks ago.”

Elizabeth found herself at a loss for further topics of conversation. She felt that if he had wished to speak to her, he might have done it more readily; but he was standing near her in silence for some minutes, and she was almost ready to give up and go away, when the same young lady whispered something to her again, and Darcy moved away.

Elizabeth Bennet, with a glimmer of hope, watched as the tea service was cleared and the card tables were arranged, her mind briefly imagining a chance to exchange words with Mr. Darcy. Yet, her optimism was swiftly dashed when her mother eagerly beckoned Darcy to join a game of whist, pulling him away from her view. Disappointed but resigned, she resolved to endure the evening, her only mischievous thought being that Darcy might be distracted enough by his cards to play poorly, perhaps revealing a hint of his character. Meanwhile, Mrs. Bennet had intended to persuade Bingley and Darcy to stay for supper, but their carriage arrived unexpectedly early, thwarting her plans and preventing any invitation extension. As the evening settled into its quiet rhythm, Elizabeth sat apart, contemplating the fleeting nature of her hopes and the subtle, unspoken tensions that lingered in the room.
```

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Well, girls,” said she, as soon as they were left to themselves, “what say you to the day?

events.text_segment:
“Well, girls,” said she, as soon as they were left to themselves, “what say you to the day? I think everything has passed off uncommonly well, I assure you. The dinner was as well dressed as any I ever saw. The venison was roasted to a turn—and everybody said, they never saw so fat a haunch. The soup was fifty times better than what we had at the Lucases’ last week; and even Mr. Darcy acknowledged that the partridges were remarkably well done; and I suppose he has two or three French cooks at least. And, my dear Jane, I never saw you look in greater beauty. Mrs. Long said so too, for I asked her whether you did not. And what do you think she said besides? ‘Ah! Mrs. Bennet, we shall have her at Netherfield at last!’ She did, indeed. I do think Mrs. Long is as good a creature as ever lived—and her nieces are very pretty behaved girls, and not at all handsome: I like them prodigiously.”
Mrs. Bennet, in short, was in very great spirits: she had seen enough of Bingley’s behaviour to Jane to be convinced that she would get him at last; and her expectations of advantage to her family, when in a happy humour, were so far beyond reason, that she was quite disappointed at not seeing him there again the next day, to make his proposals.
“It has been a very agreeable day,” said Miss Bennet to Elizabeth. “The party seemed so well selected, so suitable one with the other. I hope we may often meet again.”
Elizabeth smiled.
“Lizzy, you must not do so. You must not suspect me. It mortifies me. I assure you that I have now learnt to enjoy his conversation as an agreeable and sensible young man without having a wish beyond it. I am perfectly satisfied, from what his manners now are, that he never had any design of engaging my affection. It is only that he is blessed with greater sweetness of address, and a stronger desire of generally pleasing, than any other man.”
“You are very cruel,” said her sister, “you will not let me smile, and are provoking me to it every moment.”
“How hard it is in some cases to be believed! And how impossible in others! But why should you wish to persuade me that I feel more than I acknowledge?”
“That is a question which I hardly know how to answer. We all love to instruct, though we can teach only what is not worth knowing. Forgive me; and if you persist in indifference, do not make me your confidante.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“Well, girls,” said she, as soon as they were left to themselves, “what say you to the day? Was not it a most pleasant, delightful, charming day?”

Jane and Elizabeth agreed that it was indeed a very agreeable day, and Jane added that she thought the company was particularly pleasant, and she hoped they might meet often.

Elizabeth, with a slight smile, replied, “I am glad you think so, Jane, but I cannot help feeling a little skeptical. I have learned to appreciate Bingley's conversation as merely agreeable, without any further hopes.”

Jane, with a gentle laugh, said, “Oh, Elizabeth! You are always so suspicious. I believe Bingley's manners are simply sweet and polite, and I do not think he ever intended to capture my affections.”

Elizabeth looked at her sister with a mixture of affection and skepticism. “That may be, Jane, but I find it cruel to deny what you feel, especially when you are so eager to believe the best.”

Jane sighed. “It is hard to be believed in some cases, Elizabeth. Why do you insist I feel more than I admit?”

Elizabeth hesitated, then said, “It is a question I often ask myself. Perhaps it is human nature to offer instruction, even when it is not asked for. But, Jane, if you truly mean to be indifferent, do not confide in me.”

Jane looked at her sister with a mixture of amusement and affection. “I will not, Elizabeth. But I do wish you would not doubt me so much.”

A few days after this visit, Mr. Bingley called again, and alone. His friend had left him that morning for London, but was to return home in ten days’ time. He sat with them above an hour, and was in remarkably good spirits. Mrs. Bennet invited him to dine with them; but, with many expressions of concern, he confessed himself engaged elsewhere.
“Next time you call,” said she, “I hope we shall be more lucky.”
He should be particularly happy at any time, etc., etc.; and if she would give him leave, would take an early opportunity of waiting on them.
“Can you come to-morrow?”
Yes, he had no engagement at all for to-morrow; and her invitation was accepted with alacrity.

events.text_segment:
He came, and in such very good time, that the ladies were none of them dressed. In ran Mrs. Bennet to her daughters’ room, in her dressing-gown, and with her hair half finished, crying out,—
“My dear Jane, make haste and hurry down. He is come—Mr. Bingley is come. He is, indeed. Make haste, make haste. Here, Sarah, come to Miss Bennet this moment, and help her on with her gown. Never mind Miss Lizzy’s hair.”
“We will be down as soon as we can,” said Jane; “but I dare say Kitty is forwarder than either of us, for she went upstairs half an hour ago.”
“Oh! hang Kitty! what has she to do with it? Come, be quick, be quick! where is your sash, my dear?”
But when her mother was gone, Jane would not be prevailed on to go down without one of her sisters.
The same anxiety to get them by themselves was visible again in the evening. After tea, Mr. Bennet retired to the library, as was his custom, and Mary went upstairs to her instrument. Two obstacles of the five being thus removed, Mrs. Bennet sat looking and winking at Elizabeth and Catherine for a considerable time, without making any impression on them. Elizabeth would not observe her; and when at last Kitty did, she very innocently said, “What is the matter, mamma? What do you keep winking at me for? What am I to do?”
“Nothing, child, nothing. I did not wink at you.” She then sat still five minutes longer; but unable to waste such a precious occasion, she suddenly got up, and saying to Kitty,—
“Come here, my love, I want to speak to you,” took her out of the room. Jane instantly gave a look at Elizabeth which spoke her distress at such premeditation, and her entreaty that she would not give in to it. In a few minutes, Mrs. Bennet half opened the door and called out,—
“Lizzy, my dear, I want to speak with you.”
Elizabeth was forced to go.
“We may as well leave them by themselves, you know,” said her mother as soon as she was in the hall. “Kitty and I are going upstairs to sit in my dressing-room.”
Elizabeth made no attempt to reason with her mother, but remained quietly in the hall till she and Kitty were out of sight, then returned into the drawing-room.
Mrs. Bennet’s schemes for this day were ineffectual. Bingley was everything that was charming, except the professed lover of her daughter. His ease and cheerfulness rendered him a most agreeable addition to their evening party; and he bore with the ill-judged officiousness of the mother, and heard all her silly remarks with a forbearance and command of countenance particularly grateful to the daughter.
He scarcely needed an invitation to stay supper; and before he went away an engagement was formed, chiefly through his own and Mrs. Bennet’s means, for his coming next morning to shoot with her husband.
After this day, Jane said no more of her indifference. Not a word passed between the sisters concerning Bingley; but Elizabeth went to bed in the happy belief that all must speedily be concluded, unless Mr. Darcy returned within the stated time. Seriously, however, she felt tolerably persuaded that all this must have taken place with that gentleman’s concurrence.

He came, and in such very good time, that the ladies were none of them dressed. Elizabeth, who was sitting with her sister Jane, looked up and saw him approaching the house. Her heart fluttered at the sight of Mr. Darcy, whose presence always seemed to command attention. She wondered what his visit could mean, for he was a man of great pride and reserve, yet there was something about him that drew her curiosity.

As he entered the room, he bowed politely to the ladies, his eyes briefly meeting Elizabeth's. She felt a strange mixture of nervousness and intrigue. Mr. Bingley was also present, and he greeted everyone with his usual cheerful manner. The atmosphere was filled with anticipation, as the ladies hurried to finish their preparations.

Mrs. Bennet, ever eager to make a good impression, fussed over her daughters' attire, while Elizabeth remained composed, observing the scene with a keen eye. She knew that Mr. Darcy's visit was not accidental; he had come to see her sister Jane, who was the object of his affection.

The room was soon filled with lively conversation, and Elizabeth found herself engaged in a discussion about the latest news from London. Mr. Darcy, though somewhat reserved, contributed thoughtfully, his words measured and deliberate. Elizabeth noticed that he seemed more relaxed than usual, perhaps because he was among friends.

As the afternoon wore on, the ladies began to settle into a more comfortable state, and the initial formality gave way to genuine warmth. Elizabeth caught Mr. Darcy's gaze from time to time, and she wondered if he was contemplating the same thoughts as she was.

Suddenly, the door opened, and a servant announced that the carriage was ready. The ladies hurried to gather their things, eager to make the most of the visit. Mr. Darcy took his leave, bowing politely once more. Elizabeth watched him depart, feeling a strange sense of anticipation.

Later that evening, as Elizabeth reflected on the day's events, she could not help but think about Mr. Darcy's visit. She wondered if he had come with the intention of confessing his feelings or simply to see Jane. Whatever his motives, she knew that her own feelings were becoming more complex.

The days that followed were filled with a mixture of hope and uncertainty. Elizabeth found herself pondering the nature of pride and prejudice, and how they often clouded true understanding. She resolved to keep an open mind and to judge others by their actions rather than their words.

In the end, she realized that her own perceptions might be flawed, and that true happiness depended on honesty and sincerity. As she looked out the window, she saw Mr. Darcy walking across the lawn, his figure silhouetted against the setting sun. She felt a flutter in her heart, knowing that this encounter was only the beginning of a new chapter in their lives.

events.text_segment:
Bingley was punctual to his appointment; and he and Mr. Bennet spent the morning together, as had been agreed on. The latter was much more agreeable than his companion expected. There was nothing of presumption or folly in Bingley that could provoke his ridicule, or disgust him into silence; and he was more communicative, and less eccentric, than the other had ever seen him. Bingley of course returned with him to dinner; and in the evening Mrs. Bennet’s invention was again at work to get everybody away from him and her daughter. Elizabeth, who had a letter to write, went into the breakfast-room for that purpose soon after tea; for as the others were all going to sit down to cards, she could not be wanted to counteract her mother’s schemes.
But on her returning to the drawing-room, when her letter was finished, she saw, to her infinite surprise, there was reason to fear that her mother had been too ingenious for her. On opening the door, she perceived her sister and Bingley standing together over the hearth, as if engaged in earnest conversation; and had this led to no suspicion, the faces of both, as they hastily turned round and moved away from each other, would have told it all. Their situation was awkward enough; but hers she thought was still worse. Not a syllable was uttered by either; and Elizabeth was on the point of going away again, when Bingley, who as well as the other had sat down, suddenly rose, and, whispering a few words to her sister, ran out of the room.

detailed_summary: Jane immediately turned to Elizabeth, ready to share her happy news.
Embracing her sister, Jane emotionally declared herself the happiest person alive.
She felt overwhelmed by her joy, expressing feelings of unworthiness and wishing everyone could be as happy.

Jane was deeply moved by Elizabeth's kind words.

events.text_segment:
Jane could have no reserves from Elizabeth, where confidence would give pleasure; and, instantly embracing her, acknowledged, with the liveliest emotion, that she was the happiest creature in the world.
“’Tis too much!” she added, “by far too much. I do not deserve it. Oh, why is not everybody as happy?”
Elizabeth’s congratulations were given with a sincerity, a warmth, a delight, which words could but poorly express. Every sentence of kindness was a fresh source of happiness to Jane. But she would not allow herself to stay with her sister, or say half that remained to be said, for the present.
“I must go instantly to my mother,” she cried. “I would not on any account trifle with her affectionate solicitude, or allow her to hear it from anyone but myself. He is gone to my father already. Oh, Lizzy, to know that what I have to relate will give such pleasure to all my dear family! how shall I bear so much happiness?”
She then hastened away to her mother, who had purposely broken up the card-party, and was sitting upstairs with Kitty.

events.text_segment:
Elizabeth, who was left by herself, now smiled at the rapidity and ease with which an affair was finally settled, that had given them so many previous months of suspense and vexation.
“And this,” said she, “is the end of all his friend’s anxious circumspection! of all his sister’s falsehood and contrivance! the happiest, wisest, and most reasonable end!”
In a few minutes she was joined by Bingley, whose conference with her father had been short and to the purpose.
“Where is your sister?” said he hastily, as he opened the door.
“With my mother upstairs. She will be down in a moment, I dare say.”
He then shut the door, and, coming up to her, claimed the good wishes and affection of a sister. Elizabeth honestly and heartily expressed her delight in the prospect of their relationship. They shook hands with great cordiality; and then, till her sister came down, she had to listen to all he had to say of his own happiness, and of Jane’s perfections; and in spite of his being a lover, Elizabeth really believed all his expectations of felicity to be rationally founded, because they had for basis the excellent understanding and super-excellent disposition of Jane, and a general similarity of feeling and taste between her and himself.

events.text_segment:
It was an evening of no common delight to them all; the satisfaction of Miss Bennet’s mind gave such a glow of sweet animation to her face, as made her look handsomer than ever. Kitty simpered and smiled, and hoped her turn was coming soon. Mrs. Bennet could not give her consent, or speak her approbation in terms warm enough to satisfy her feelings, though she talked to Bingley of nothing else, for half an hour; and when Mr. Bennet joined them at supper, his voice and manner plainly showed how really happy he was.
Not a word, however, passed his lips in allusion to it, till their visitor took his leave for the night; but as soon as he was gone, he turned to his daughter and said,—
“Jane, I congratulate you. You will be a very happy woman.”
Jane went to him instantly, kissed him, and thanked him for his goodness.
“You are a good girl,” he replied, “and I have great pleasure in thinking you will be so happily settled. I have not a doubt of your doing very well together. Your tempers are by no means unlike. You are each of you so complying, that nothing will ever be resolved on; so easy, that every servant will cheat you; and so generous, that you will always exceed your income.”
“I hope not so. Imprudence or thoughtlessness in money matters would be unpardonable in me.”
“Exceed their income! My dear Mr. Bennet,” cried his wife, “what are you talking of? Why, he has four or five thousand a year, and very likely more.” Then addressing her daughter, “Oh, my dear, dear Jane, I am so happy! I am sure I shan’t get a wink of sleep all night. I knew how it would be. I always said it must be so, at last. I was sure you could not be so beautiful for nothing! I remember, as soon as ever I saw him, when he first came into Hertfordshire last year, I thought how likely it was that you should come together. Oh, he is the handsomest young man that ever was seen!”
Wickham, Lydia, were all forgotten. Jane was beyond competition her favourite child. At that moment she cared for no other. Her younger sisters soon began to make interest with her for objects of happiness which she might in future be able to dispense.
Mary petitioned for the use of the library at Netherfield; and Kitty begged very hard for a few balls there every winter.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: It was an evening of no common delight to them all; the satisfaction of Miss Bennet’s mind gave such a glow of sweet animation to her face, as made her look handsomer than ever. Jane’s happiness was complete, and her countenance expressed it in every feature. Kitty Bennet, with a hopeful smile, was looking forward to her own future prospects, while Mrs. Bennet was in a perfect ecstasy, unable to say enough in praise of her daughter’s engagement to Bingley, and talking of it for a solid half-hour. When Mr. Bennet joined them for supper, his manner plainly showed his own happiness; but he did not mention the engagement until Bingley had left for the night. After Bingley’s departure, Mr. Bennet turned to Jane and, with a smile, said, “Well, my dear, you look as if you enjoyed yourself.” Jane approached him, kissed him, and said, “Thank you, papa.” He called her a good girl, and added, “I am glad to see you so happy. I hope you will be a very happy woman.” Jane blushed and looked down, but Mr. Bennet continued, “You and Bingley are a very suitable match. Your temperaments are so well matched that I dare say you will be indecisive; your easy-going natures will make you easy to cheat by servants; and your generosity will make you overspend.” Jane protested, “I hope I shall be able to manage my income.” Mrs. Bennet, overhearing this, exclaimed, “Oh, my dear, Bingley has a great deal of money; he will take care of you.” She then turned to Jane and, with a radiant face, said, “I shall not sleep all night; I have always known this would happen. It is all owing to your beauty, my dear.” At that moment, thoughts of Wickham and Lydia were forgotten, and Jane became Mrs. Bennet’s undisputed favorite. The younger sisters, eager to share in the joy, quickly began asking Jane for future favors at Netherfield. Mary asked if she might use the library, and Kitty requested future balls at Netherfield.

Mr. Bingley and Mr. Darcy, who had been observing her with evident admiration, exchanged pleased glances. Elizabeth, feeling the warmth of their regard, was more lively and animated than usual. Her spirits, naturally high, were now elevated by the happiness she perceived in her friends and family. The evening was filled with cheerful conversation, laughter, and the gentle hum of music in the background. Elizabeth’s sister Jane, radiant and serene, was the picture of contentment, her eyes often meeting Bingley’s with a tenderness that spoke volumes.

As the night progressed, the company moved to the drawing room, where a lively dance was about to commence. Elizabeth, though not an accomplished dancer, was eager to join in the merriment. She was soon engaged in a lively quadrille with Mr. Bingley and others, her spirits soaring with the music and the company. Her heart fluttered at the thought of Bingley’s evident admiration, and she found herself more at ease than she had been in many a day.

Meanwhile, Mr. Darcy watched her with a mixture of admiration and introspection. He was struck anew by her vivacity and her unaffected manner. Though he had long admired her wit and intelligence, tonight he saw her in a new light—more charming, more captivating than he had previously acknowledged.

The evening wore on, and as the clock struck ten, the guests began to prepare for departure. Elizabeth felt a sense of regret that the night was ending, yet she was also filled with a quiet happiness. She had shared moments of genuine joy and had seen her friends and family in their best spirits.

As she bade goodnight to her sister and the others, she reflected on the evening’s events. She was grateful for the happiness that had filled the air, and she looked forward to many more such evenings. Her heart was light, her mind at ease, and her spirits high, knowing that she was surrounded by those she loved and who loved her in return. The glow of the evening lingered in her mind, a cherished memory to be treasured in the days to come.

events.text_segment:
Bingley, from this time, was of course a daily visitor at Longbourn; coming frequently before breakfast, and always remaining till after supper; unless when some barbarous neighbour, who could not be enough detested, had given him an invitation to dinner, which he thought himself obliged to accept.
Elizabeth had now but little time for conversation with her sister; for while he was present Jane had no attention to bestow on anyone else: but she found herself considerably useful to both of them, in those hours of separation that must sometimes occur. In the absence of Jane, he always attached himself to Elizabeth for the pleasure of talking of her; and when Bingley was gone, Jane constantly sought the same means of relief.
“He has made me so happy,” said she, one evening, “by telling me that he was totally ignorant of my being in town last spring! I had not believed it possible.”
“I suspected as much,” replied Elizabeth. “But how did he account for it?”
“It must have been his sisters’ doing. They were certainly no friends to his acquaintance with me, which I cannot wonder at, since he might have chosen so much more advantageously in many respects. But when they see, as I trust they will, that their brother is happy with me, they will learn to be contented, and we shall be on good terms again: though we can never be what we once were to each other.”
“That is the most unforgiving speech,” said Elizabeth, “that I ever heard you utter. Good girl! It would vex me, indeed, to see you again the dupe of Miss Bingley’s pretended regard.”
“Would you believe it, Lizzy, that when he went to town last November he really loved me, and nothing but a persuasion of my being indifferent would have prevented his coming down again?”
“He made a little mistake, to be sure; but it is to the credit of his modesty.”
This naturally introduced a panegyric from Jane on his diffidence, and the little value he put on his own good qualities.
Elizabeth was pleased to find that he had not betrayed the interference of his friend; for, though Jane had the most generous and forgiving heart in the world, she knew it was a circumstance which must prejudice her against him.
“I am certainly the most fortunate creature that ever existed!” cried Jane. “Oh, Lizzy, why am I thus singled from my family, and blessed above them all? If I could but see you as happy! If there were but such another man for you!”
“If you were to give me forty such men I never could be so happy as you. Till I have your disposition, your goodness, I never can have your happiness. No, no, let me shift for myself; and, perhaps, if I have very good luck, I may meet with another Mr. Collins in time.”

Elizabeth replied that even forty such men couldn't make her as happy as Jane, attributing Jane's happiness to her unique disposition and goodness, concluding she would manage on her own and perhaps find another Mr. Collins.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
Bingley, from this time, was of course a daily visitor at Longbourn; coming frequently before breakfast, and always remaining till after supper; unless when some barbarous neighbour, who could not be enough detested, had given him an invitation to dinner, which he thought himself obliged to accept.

Elizabeth had less time to talk with Jane, as Jane's attention was more and more fixed on Bingley when he was present. But she found she was useful to both during their occasional separations. Bingley, seeking out Elizabeth, would talk to her about Jane when Jane was not there; and Jane, when Bingley was gone, would seek Elizabeth to talk about him.

One evening, Jane told Elizabeth how happy she was that Bingley had declared he was quite unaware she had been in London the previous spring—something she had not thought possible. Elizabeth admitted she had suspected as much. Jane explained that Bingley attributed his ignorance to his sisters, acknowledging they probably did not approve of the match but that he hoped they would come to accept it for his sake.

Jane hoped they could be on good terms again, though she knew their relationship would never be the same. Elizabeth praised Jane's less forgiving attitude, saying it was the least forgiving she had ever heard Jane be, and expressed relief that Jane would not be deceived again by Miss Bingley's false friendship. Jane then revealed that Bingley, when he left for London the previous November, had declared he truly loved her, and that only his mistaken belief in her indifference had kept him from returning sooner.

Elizabeth said that was a mistake, but one that spoke well of his modesty. This led Jane to praise Bingley's diffidence. Elizabeth, privately, was pleased that Bingley had not revealed Mr. Darcy's role in the separation, knowing it would prejudice Jane against Darcy. Jane exclaimed she was the most fortunate person alive, lamenting that she was singled out for such happiness in her family.

She fervently wished Elizabeth could find similar happiness and a partner of her own. Elizabeth replied that even forty such men could not make her as happy as Jane, attributing Jane's happiness to her own good nature and disposition, and concluding she would manage on her own, perhaps finding another Mr. Collins.

events.text_segment: One morning, about a week after Bingley’s engagement with Jane had been formed, as he and the females of the family were sitting together in the dining-room, their attention was suddenly drawn to the window by the sound of a carriage; and they perceived a chaise and four driving up the lawn. It was too early in the morning for visitors; and besides, the equipage did not answer to that of any of their neighbours. The horses were post; and neither the carriage, nor the livery of the servant who preceded it, were familiar to them. As it was certain, however, that somebody was coming, Bingley instantly prevailed on Miss Bennet to avoid the confinement of such an intrusion, and walk away with him into the shrubbery. They both set off; and the conjectures of the remaining three continued, though with little satisfaction, till the door was thrown open, and their visitor entered. It was Lady Catherine de Bourgh.

events.text_segment:
They were of course all intending to be surprised: but their astonishment was beyond their expectation; and on the part of Mrs. Bennet and Kitty, though she was perfectly unknown to them, even inferior to what Elizabeth felt.
She entered the room with an air more than usually ungracious, made no other reply to Elizabeth’s salutation than a slight inclination of the head, and sat down without saying a word. Elizabeth had mentioned her name to her mother on her Ladyship’s entrance, though no request of introduction had been made.
Mrs. Bennet, all amazement, though flattered by having a guest of such high importance, received her with the utmost politeness. After sitting for a moment in silence, she said, very stiffly, to Elizabeth,—
“I hope you are well, Miss Bennet. That lady, I suppose, is your mother?”
Elizabeth replied very concisely that she was.
“And that, I suppose, is one of your sisters?”
“Yes, madam,” said Mrs. Bennet, delighted to speak to a Lady Catherine. “She is my youngest girl but one. My youngest of all is lately married, and my eldest is somewhere about the ground, walking with a young man, who, I believe, will soon become a part of the family.”
“You have a very small park here,” returned Lady Catherine, after a short silence.
“It is nothing in comparison of Rosings, my Lady, I dare say; but, I assure you, it is much larger than Sir William Lucas’s.”
“This must be a most inconvenient sitting-room for the evening in summer: the windows are full west.”
Mrs. Bennet assured her that they never sat there after dinner; and then added,—
“May I take the liberty of asking your Ladyship whether you left Mr. and Mrs. Collins well?”
“Yes, very well. I saw them the night before last.”
Elizabeth now expected that she would produce a letter for her from Charlotte, as it seemed the only probable motive for her calling. But no letter appeared, and she was completely puzzled.

She nodded slightly to Elizabeth, who returned the greeting, and then took a seat without uttering a word. Elizabeth, recognizing her, addressed her mother, saying, "Mama, I believe that is Lady Catherine de Bourgh." Mrs. Bennet, delighted and flattered, responded with great politeness, "Yes, my dear, I am sure it is." After a moment of silence, Lady Catherine stiffly looked at Elizabeth and asked, "Are you the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bennet?" Elizabeth replied briefly, "I am." Lady Catherine then inquired, "And your sister, Kitty?" Mrs. Bennet, with a smile, said, "Oh! yes, Kitty is well. Lydia has just married Mr. Wickham, and Jane is walking outside with a young man who is expected to join us soon." Lady Catherine remarked curtly, "Your park is small." Mrs. Bennet, eager to defend her home, said, "It is much smaller than Sir William Lucas's, but larger than some others. Still, it does not compare to Rosings." Mrs. Bennet explained that they used a different room after dinner and then inquired politely about Mr. and Mrs. Collins. Lady Catherine confirmed she had seen the Collinses recently. Elizabeth, thinking she might receive a letter from Charlotte through Lady Catherine, was puzzled when no letter was produced, leaving her uncertain about the purpose of the visit.

events.title: Invitation to a Private Walk
detailed_summary: Despite Mrs. Bennet's civil offer of refreshments, Lady Catherine firmly and impolitely refuses.
Lady Catherine then stands and requests Elizabeth accompany her for a walk in a small wooded area on the property.
Mrs. Bennet eagerly encourages Elizabeth to comply and show Lady Catherine the grounds, suggesting the hermitage.
Elizabeth obeys, fetches her parasol, and leads Lady Catherine downstairs.
As they pass through the hall, Lady Catherine inspects the dining-parlour and drawing-room, pronouncing them merely 'decent'.
Her carriage waits at the door, and Elizabeth observes her waiting-woman inside.
They proceed silently towards the copse; Elizabeth decides against attempting conversation with the increasingly insolent Lady Catherine.
Observing her guest, Elizabeth inwardly reflects on how mistaken she was to ever perceive a resemblance between Lady Catherine and Mr. Darcy.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mrs. Bennet, with great civility, begged her Ladyship to take some refreshment: but Lady Catherine very resolutely, and not very politely, declined eating anything; and then, rising up, said to Elizabeth,—
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “How could I ever think her like her nephew?” said she, as she looked in her face.

events.text_segment:
Mrs. Bennet, with great civility, begged her Ladyship to take some refreshment: but Lady Catherine very resolutely, and not very politely, declined eating anything; and then, rising up, said to Elizabeth,—
“Miss Bennet, there seemed to be a prettyish kind of a little wilderness on one side of your lawn. I should be glad to take a turn in it, if you will favour me with your company.”
“Go, my dear,” cried her mother, “and show her Ladyship about the different walks. I think she will be pleased with the hermitage.”
Elizabeth obeyed; and, running into her own room for her parasol, attended her noble guest downstairs. As they passed through the hall, Lady Catherine opened the doors into the dining-parlour and drawing-room, and pronouncing them, after a short survey, to be decent-looking rooms, walked on.
Her carriage remained at the door, and Elizabeth saw that her waiting-woman was in it. They proceeded in silence along the gravel walk that led to the copse; Elizabeth was determined to make no effort for conversation with a woman who was now more than usually insolent and disagreeable.
“How could I ever think her like her nephew?” said she, as she looked in her face.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Mrs. Bennet, with great civility, begged her Ladyship to take some refreshment: but Lady Catherine very resolutely, and not very politely, declined eating anything; and then, rising up, said to Elizabeth,—

"Come, my dear, I want to take a walk. Would you do me the favour to attend me?"

Elizabeth, who was in hopes of being able to get rid of her, immediately followed her downstairs, and they went out together. As they passed through the hall, Lady Catherine cast her eyes over the dining-parlour and the drawing-room, which, she observed, were "decent" enough, but not elegant.

Her carriage was at the door, and Elizabeth saw her waiting-woman inside. They proceeded in silence towards the copse; Elizabeth, perceiving her guest's increasing insolence, thought it best not to attempt any conversation. As they walked, she inwardly reflected on her previous mistaken notions of Lady Catherine's resemblance to Mr. Darcy, and wondered at her own folly in ever having thought so.

events.title: Confrontation Over Darcy Engagement Rumors
detailed_summary: Once inside the copse, Lady Catherine immediately begins the confrontation, asserting that Elizabeth must intuitively understand the reason for her visit.
Elizabeth expresses genuine surprise, stating she has no idea why Lady Catherine is there.
Lady Catherine angrily warns Elizabeth not to trifle with her, proclaiming her own reputation for frankness, especially in important matters.
She reveals she heard an alarming report two days prior: not only is Jane Bennet well-engaged, but Elizabeth herself is rumored to be soon marrying Lady Catherine's nephew, Mr. Darcy.
While calling the report a 'scandalous falsehood,' Lady Catherine states she came immediately to make her objections known.
Elizabeth, coloring with anger and disdain, questions the purpose of Lady Catherine's long journey if she already believed the report impossible.
Lady Catherine states her intention is to demand the report be universally contradicted.
Elizabeth coolly observes that Lady Catherine's very presence at Longbourn serves more as a confirmation of the rumor than a denial.
Lady Catherine angrily accuses Elizabeth and her family of actively spreading the rumor.

When pressed by Lady Catherine about whether there is any 'foundation' for the report, Elizabeth declines to match Lady Catherine's claimed frankness, stating she will not answer all questions posed.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: As soon as they entered the copse, Lady Catherine began in the following manner:—

events.text_segment:
As soon as they entered the copse, Lady Catherine began in the following manner:—
“You can be at no loss, Miss Bennet, to understand the reason of my journey hither. Your own heart, your own conscience, must tell you why I come.”
Elizabeth looked with unaffected astonishment.
“Indeed, you are mistaken, madam; I have not been at all able to account for the honour of seeing you here.”
“Miss Bennet,” replied her Ladyship, in an angry tone, “you ought to know that I am not to be trifled with. But however insincere you may choose to be, you shall not find me so. My character has ever been celebrated for its sincerity and frankness; and in a cause of such moment as this, I shall certainly not depart from it. A report of a most alarming nature reached me two days ago. I was told, that not only your sister was on the point of being most advantageously married, but that you—that Miss Elizabeth Bennet would, in all likelihood, be soon afterwards united to my nephew—my own nephew, Mr. Darcy. Though I know it must be a scandalous falsehood, though I would not injure him so much as to suppose the truth of it possible, I instantly resolved on setting off for this place, that I might make my sentiments known to you.”
“If you believed it impossible to be true,” said Elizabeth, colouring with astonishment and disdain, “I wonder you took the trouble of coming so far. What could your Ladyship propose by it?”
“At once to insist upon having such a report universally contradicted.”
“Your coming to Longbourn, to see me and my family,” said Elizabeth coolly, “will be rather a confirmation of it—if, indeed, such a report is in existence.”
“If! do you then pretend to be ignorant of it? Has it not been industriously circulated by yourselves? Do you not know that such a report is spread abroad?”
“I never heard that it was.”
“And can you likewise declare, that there is no foundation for it?”
“I do not pretend to possess equal frankness with your Ladyship. You may ask questions which I shall not choose to answer.”

Lady Catherine de Bourgh, with a stern and commanding tone, immediately confronted Elizabeth Bennet, asserting that Elizabeth must understand the reason for her visit without further explanation. Elizabeth, taken aback, expressed genuine surprise, claiming she had no idea why Lady Catherine was there. Lady Catherine, visibly angry, warned Elizabeth not to trifle with her, emphasizing her reputation for frankness, especially regarding important matters. She then revealed that she had heard an alarming report two days prior: not only was Jane Bennet well-engaged, but Elizabeth herself was rumored to be soon marrying Mr. Darcy, Lady Catherine's nephew. While dismissing the report as a 'scandalous falsehood,' Lady Catherine declared she had come immediately to make her objections known.

Elizabeth, coloring with anger and disdain, questioned the purpose of Lady Catherine's long journey if she already believed the report to be impossible. Lady Catherine stated her intention to demand that the report be universally contradicted. Elizabeth, with cool composure, observed that Lady Catherine's very presence at Longbourn seemed more a confirmation of the rumor than a denial. Lady Catherine, in a fit of anger, accused Elizabeth and her family of actively spreading the false report. Elizabeth denied any knowledge of it. When pressed by Lady Catherine about whether there was any 'foundation' for the rumor, Elizabeth declined to answer all of Lady Catherine's questions, refusing to match her frankness.
```
